review_body: The room, staff and restaurant food were fine. The executive lounge however looked like it was from the 50's. The food was poor. Unimaginative, repetitive and low quality. This is not what I expect from a Marriott property. I am a staunch Marriott supporter, but this one should be rebranded. It is a disservice to Marriott frequent travelers. BTW, it is really an out of the way location unless you need to be in Shinagawa.

Great service, great food, helpful staff. Concierge had great knowledge of local events and even small details. Breakfast was so good, it became a trip highlight. Great environment for reading and studying while eating.This was the first time I have done a review and by mistake I put 1 instead of 5 which I have no corrected. My apology for inconvenience. I look forward to staying with you again.

Stayed here four four nights before returning home. I have stayed in a few hotels in the Shinagawa area and this hotel in my view is up there with the best of them! Excellent service from all that work at the hotel.The executive room is one of the best I have been in, well laid out and friendly service.The station is a small walk away, but hardly worth taking the free shuttle bus or even getting a taxi. Okay I may have dropped lucky with no rain but it’s a pleasant 10 minute walk away.Excellent grounds to walk around with waterfalls for relaxation.Overall I recommend this hotel when staying in Tokyo.

HiThis Marriott is about an hour and a half drive from the Narita airport. If you hire a private car through the hotel, it’s going to cost you about $300 USD after converted from Yen. Additionally the gym is not in the hotel, it is directly next to the hotel. Cheers, K

I liked this hotel in my past stays as I reviewed previously but it has clearly gone in the wrong direction. Overall I believe it is still a good deal. Unfortunately out of their control is the location. It is 15 minute walk to the hotel from Shinagawa station and while there is a shuttle bus it is not always convenient. Obtaining a taxi especially during rush hour or during inclement weather can take up to 30 minutes (I was late for a meeting and had luggage so no alternative (could have used Japan Taxi App).But within control of the hotel is their service. During my 3 day stay my desk table had sticky remnants of food and what I am guessing is soda that was never cleaned. The bathroom floor was also not cleaned. The service while polite and staff trying hard, was not up to standards of a 4 or 5 star hotel in Tokyo - I am guessing because the staff seemed young and inexperienced comparatively. I called for room service but my call to Service Express button went unanswered for 5 minutes.On a positive note, the breakfast is very good with a nice juice station and fresh egg and waffle station. Quality of the breakfast food is better than many local hotels.Overall for the price of the hotel for what you get is a bargain. I would recommend if you are patient, have extra time - basically on vacation but probably not for business.

Here for business so i would say this is not a place to stay for vacation. Not alot here unless you like to walk alot. Rooms are good and service is excellent. Food is pricey in the restaurant but is good. Cabs are easy to come by if you need one.

If you need to be by the Station then this might be an Ok choice bit if you don't then I would give it a miss .There is nothing around this hotel and the restaurant in the hotel has a restricted choice, is expensive for what it is and not great quality food. Drinks are very expensive and a Merlot which is retail £9.95 in the UK was £28 for a regular glass .There is an executive lounge you can use if you have an exec room which we did but this is a tad bizarre . They serve some food up until 7:30 but even if there is loads left they just take it away and presumably throw it away. They would not let us have the volume up on the TV in place of the piped music despite every person (8) wanting it. The reason was it will disturb people !The following night a family with 2 small children ran riot in the lounge shouting and screaming and not told to quieten down so we left.Breakfast was good but beware the buffet closes early and then it is a la carte with not a huge choice , service at breakfast was very good.On leaving we brought our own cases down and checked out and said we were having breakfast before we left and could they sort our cases and we were told by reception to take our cases to the porters at the front of the hotel some distance away. Not what you would expect from a quality hotel.

The hotel served as our base for our small group twice during our trip to Japan. It's a modern, well maintained hotel that is a short 15 minute walk from the train station that made it super convenient to get around the city. The rooms are smallish but clean and satisfied our needs. Staff was friendly and helpful and would return to hotel if back in Tokyo.

Booked a non-smoking room. Assigned room smelled of smoke and air freshener. Asked for a change. Same issue. Decided to stay through it as probably this is the case for most rooms. The corridors are dark and also smells.

We had a perfect 5 nights stay thanks to the people who work there. They made us feel like home. As platinum member we received a royal treatment and a very spacious room. The breakfast is excellent. The only thing we didn't like was the executive lounge. You won't regret your choice if you pick this hotel as you will receive a 5 stars experience. Special thank you to Tan and the beautiful blonde lady at the Egg station for being so perfect with us so far from home. We will come back for sure.

I stayed 2 nights on a business trip. My room was spacious and nicely appointed unlike my colleague who’s room was the size of a postage stamp. The room overlooks the train tracks of one of the busiest stations in Tokyo so if you are a light sleeper this will be a major issue. The executive lounge is nice and the staff throughout the hotel is lovely. Breakfast which was included was good. If you are expecting to get a workout in plan on bringing your Yoga mat and download an app. The “gym” is probably one of the worst I have seen in a long time. The cardio equipment is old and there is very little of it. Weight portion seems ok. If I were to return I would not stay here if I had other options. I would much prefer a more central location. This is a bit of a ways from where I would prefer to be.
user_name:
keschpo
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed over a week at the Tokyo Marriott and loved it. The location is great, a 10 minute walk from Shinagawa station (easy to connect to just about anywhere it seems, with the Yamanote line and multiple Shinkasen trains) but far enough away to be removed from the hustle and bustle of the area immediately around the station. Note there is a shuttle bus running between Shinagawa and the hotel, check their schedule and find the waiting spot just to the left of the station West Exit (if you don't see the WING store, you're at the wrong exit). The hotel is a top tier Marriott property, and provides exactly what you'd expect in such a property. Excellent service, good food, quiet rooms and a peaceful location. The breakfast restaurant is frequently busy, so if you're in a hurry, you need to time your breakfast time to insure you can get in and out in a timely fashion. They do open an extra room when necessary. The shuttle bus also serves a large adjacent business complex so if you're planning on using the shuttle during rush hours (to the hotel in the morning hours, from the hotel at 5PM) expect a long queue.

Stayed here during the Rugby World Cup with 150 enthusiastic Irish fans. The hotel coped amazingly well and dealt with the culture clash with calm aplomb. The room we stayed in was large and comfortable. The breakfast was superb. We had a great stay.

I assumed being a full service Marriott in Tokyo it would be phenomenal. It was not, this met US average Marriott standards but was not up to international Marriott levels. It is an acceptable business hotel if your flying into or out of Haneda or your business is in Shibuya. Otherwise there are equal to better options in key business regions of Tokyo.

I’ve stayed here the past four Mays. It’s very good, not great. The 10 minute walk from Shinagawa station is refreshing, weather permitting. And the restaurant selection around Shinagawa is tremendous. The hotel itself is a quality business hotel. The lounge is pretty high quality. The staff excellent.

The hotel was mainly a business hotel with hardly any lounge features which meant no where to sit downstairs.Annoying especially as a typhoon was about to hit us and everyone was confined to the hotel.Staff very helpful especially the Concierge. Food good with a nice variety. Rooms fairly average ..our TV was at the side of the bed so making it difficult to watch.Better hotels to stay in with nicer locations.

Handy location near Shinagwa (10 minutes walk or Bus Shuttle) high rise tower with top floor concierge lounge).Rooms are quiet and the lobby restaurant serves an excellent breakfast both Japanese & Western. Loads of Rugby Heads due to the RWC so plenty of rugby apparel but no singing.Front Office upgraded our rooms and allowed our boys lounge access and complete breakfasts so that was very welcome and appreciated.

Stayed here during the RWC and generally found it to be pretty good.The front of house staff were great - the concierge in particular.Also, the breakfast was excellent, as were the Restaurant staff, especially the lovely, friendly “egg lady”.A couple of downsides - there could have been a wider choice of menu options for dinner - got a bit boring after a few nights - my wife and I had booked a twin-room but were allocated a room with a king-size bed. Although this sounds great, it turned out to be a corner room, which was somewhat smaller than a twin-bedded room and had less wardrobe space, and which was a little cramped for a nine night stay

The hotel itself is perfectly ok. The rooms are large by Japanese standards and the executive lounge is above average. Service was a little slow, especially on checkout, and I had the impression some staff didn’t really know what they were doing. The location is excellent. Shinagawa station is close by, either a 10 min walk, via a free shuttle bus, or a short taxi ride. It is extremely well connected to both Haneda and Narita as well as the city. This makes it an excellent choice of hotel.

This hotel is a short 500¥ Taxi from Shinagawa Station and there are free shuttle as well. Staff speak English. Very nice staff. Good food in both the Executive Lounge for those who qualify and a view 26th floor. Very good restaurant in first floor too. Room was comfortable and clean. Horrible moveable showerhead...horrible. would not stay in position. Great water pressure. Elevators were quiet and efficient.

I’ve stayed here many times. It’s clean, the food is usually good, and the Executive Lounge is comfortable. The frustration I have is the level of helpfulness from the staff. I often ask where to go eat or help finding a tourist show, like geisha or sumo wrestling. The employees often haven’t any idea or cannot find what I’ve found online. I expect to find someone that has great ideas for entertainment!Also, the staff at this Marriott are not as friendly towards Americans. When I stay in the city (which is great and is easy to walk the city) the staff at that Marriott go out of their way to offer suggestions or help find local attractions. Hopefully I will be able to book the other hotel in the future for all my trips!

We began our 4 week Asia tour in Japan and selected the Marriott properties because of my travel and status with the hotel chain. I used points for this stay and never felt like anything but a special guest. We were there during the typhoon and had to remain in the property for about 36 hours. Staff were great and given that they were working with little sleep I applaud their commitment to service. Very close to rail station with shuttle service easily and frequently available. Nice buffet breakfast and concierge lounge. Great choice.

We stayed in this hotel when visiting for tbe rugby world cup. The hotel is close to shinagawa station so is great for tokyo in 10 mins and the bullet train runs through here Sonia easy for access.The staff were 1st class and very helpful and tbe rooms were a food size (plus a great breakfast buffet and lounge access). Overall a great hotel

This was the first of three Hotels we have experienced during our two week stay in Tokyo (for the Rugby!) I think it’s predominantly a Business Hotel but they coped well with our groups, and were so pleasant and helpful. The twin room was good - spacious with everything we needed, although if you are located at the back of the Hotel there is some noise from the trains (not too bad though!)Special thanks go to the Concierge (from Nepal, so sorry I forgot your name!) and Kōji Kuwano, their Events Manager who accompanied me to the Post Office situated in the Tower building next door to post a gift off to my Godson. A great start to our visit to Japan.

A very good hotel close to Shinagawa railway station. Friendly and helpful staff. Rooms good. Breakfasts quite good too. Food quite expensive so apart from breakfast would suggest using the many restaurants close to the station. Overall a good place to stay in Tokyo.

Disappointing smell of smoking in the room, even the bathroom! Just what I don’t need after a serious chest infection! Non-smoking rooms should be exactly that - not interchangeable. Even replacing or washing the smoking stained curtains might help. Little chance of being move with over 200 rugby fans having just checked in.
user_name:
Rainie2014
Henley in Arden, United Kingdom

review_body: Nice breakfast and convenient shuttle bus to 品川 train station(every 20 minutes). although need cross the bridge. it will be hard to bring large luggage. Lounge self service is also nice and just need the room key card till 23：00

Was there for a second time and nothing has changed. Staff is dedicated, just to bad I couldn't get a late check-out. Rooms and bathrooms are big, breakfast buffet is really nice. And on the top of that the situation near Shinagawa station is convenient. Price is high but what can you do, it seems they are fully booked.

We got the most fantastic welcome when we arrived from a large group of staff members. My room was incredible, the breakfasts were to die for. There were plenty of good places to eat near the railway station which was only 10 minutes walk. The purchase of the meal vouchers outside the restaurants was tricky and the beer was very reasonably priced by Irish standards and tasty. I brought my own cutlery and cloth napkin to avoid destroying my tee shirt as I am well capable of doing. The people were so polite and helpful every where I went.The downside the hotel food and drink in the evening was very expensive and best avoided.

We had a very enjoyable family stay in this hotel. Access to Shinagawa station is excellent which opens up options on travel around Tōkyō. The staff are excellent and Check-in and out was very good. The rooms were particularly good for a Tokyo hotel. The only issue was the bar and restaurant were not able to cater for large groups very well - we had to dine away from the hotel. Breakfast was very good however.

This hotel is great in so many ways. The staff is incredibly friendly. Given our status, they upgraded us to an amazing room. We also received access to the executive lounge with free snacks and wine/beer every evening. The breakfast was awesome with so many choices (both eastern and western). There is a convenience store downstairs with anything you might need. There is a local gym connected to the hotel which was big and has a swimming pool. The only thing keeping this from a 5 star review is the location. It’s about 12-14 minutes to Shinagawa station. It doesn’t sound that far but when you are doing it 3 to 4 times a day, it adds up. The hotel does offer shuttle service but the time is almost the same given traffic. Overall, this is a really solid option and I would recommend it if you want to be near Shinagawa and are willing to walk/shuttle to the station.

2nd stay and most likely not the last.  Check in is swift and given a room at level 21, facing the subway tracks but not affected. Room noise insulation is fantastic.  Got an upgrade as a Marriott member but given two beds which is not necessary as preferred a king size bed.  All the necessary stuff provided within the room.  Executive lounge at level 26 and view is cool. Only serve cocktail at 530pm, selection is limited and not much changes to the menu for 8 nights.  Lounge can be extremely crowded during cocktail. Children are allowed so if you intend to have a private and quiet environment anytime within the lounge, it may not be possible.  Please take note,  breakfast must be at the main restaurant at ground floor and not the lounge.  Gym is neat as compared to some negative feedback that were observed. Maybe hotel has made changes since receiving those feedback.   There are various workout equipment and weights for all.  There is a swimming pool which I did not check out.  Gym staff are friendly and keeping watchful eyes for any assistance required. Area for improvement1. Wi-Fi is unstable and not suitable for having video call.  The worst so far in all Marriott chain I have stayed in. 2. Lounge needs to be more spacious with more food variety.3. Smell within room.  Unable to figure out but there is a strange smell since the day in check into the room. 4. Please have more English channels as maybe 3.5 channels are in English.  Due to the breakfast which is better than intercontinental,  the distance to the subways and distance to my workplace, I will still be staying with Tokyo Marriott coming Nov.

Stayed there with my son after a week travelling across Japan. The availability of a free shuttle service from nearby Shinagawa station was nice. We were looking forward to a swim and were told that this entailed an extra charge of 2100 yen per person... due to my membership status.. As this a relatively high end hotel I would have expected fitness and pool access for all guests. Room was very nice and big but smelled of smoke. Last but not least the hypocrisy of caring for the planet when almost every little thing in the bathroom was wrapped individually in plastic!! Having stayed in several other hotels in Jpn it seems standard to provide all these things but at least the other did not pretend to care for the environment. It’s time these luxury chains think hard about their single-use plastic waste.

We stayed at this hotel 2 years ago. We liked it then.Things have changed, not for the right reason.My wife and I are non-smokers, so we always ask for a non-smoking room.After entering the room, we immediately can tell that someone smoked in the room.Hotel sprayed freshener heavily, so we also smelled the freshener.We notified the front desk and the front desk manager was trying to find another room.However, five rooms later, we still didn't find any of the room without smoke smell.All the rooms were on non-smoking floor. The front desk manager didn't get how the room has smoke smell.That's disappointing. No wonder they have so many non-smoking rooms with smoke smell.We ended in a one bed room since no more 2-bed rooms that were smoke free.Since we traveled with 2 little kids, that was not pleasant.And that one-bed room still had smoke smell, but not as heavy as the others.Breakfast was still good, but was handled poorly.We came down around 9am, and by that time, there was a long line.We're given a number and waited for about half an hour.The wait staff called the numbers in Japanese. Since most of us were foreigners, no one responded to her calling.She then tried to look at our numbers one guest at a time which make the wait even longer.And still she did the same the next time she called.The restaurant manager should have seen this issue and corrected it.Also, no swimming pool for under-16 kids. So that's a minus.Concierge was great. Always willing and trying to help.Executive lounge was disappointing. We only went in there for water, as there's no good snacks.We complained in the Marriott survey, and we got very standard response from the front desk manager. Sounds like copy paste response.

The Marriott is located in a good business area if you are working nearby, but there isn’t much to do or eat in the area. The closest place is back at Shinagawa Station, which is about a ten minute walk away. The hotel itself is very nice. The room was lovely, although I found the bed to be not as comfortable. The space has a small desk, couch, and dressers with slipper and pajamas. There is also an iron and ironing board in the room. Check in was decent, although I didn’t interact with many hotel staff during my two day stay. Overall the hotel is good, but I wouldn’t stay here again since I like to walk around at night and explore the city.

Upscale business hotel in Shingawa area. A short walk from Shinagawa station (Yamanote line). Large rooms for Japan, very comfortable. They run a shuttle between the hotel and the station if you prefer not to walk. There is a Family Mart (convenience store) in the building next door, for any sundries you might need.

Excellent place to stay, not far from what we were here for...we arrived early and the staff were very accommodating with our day...they offered some local restaurants the things to do in the local area, including the nearby forest....

I booked late for a 3 of us, but enjoyed our stay at the Marriott Tokyo hotel. Great service, hospitality and enjoyed the amenities.Pros: * Concierge and reception were very helpful with all of our asks. Our reception even asked about removing an extra bed that cost about 70 USD per night since we were a small group. * Concierge was very helpful with directions, recommendations and even Disney tickets* This was the biggest room I've stayed at ever in Japan with a living room and a very large bath * Since I am a Marriott elite member I had access to the lounge which had lovely views of the city* Free shuttle to Shinagawa station that left 2-3 times every hour* Family mart next to the hotel for small incidentalsCons: * The twin beds were small, but where in Japan are the beds large?* Gym was run by an independent operator and was not open 24 hours* The extra charge for an extra bed seemed very expensive and value for the price was still an issue overallThe hotel was great for family and business if you're looking for western standards. This was was an easy base to go several areas of interest and I'd highly recommend.Thank you

Delicious food and nice executive lounge. Attentive professional staff with good English skills. This hotel is quiet and elegant yet close to Shinagawa station. Located next to a park. Post office, convenience store and gym located in the same building. My go-to hotel for Tokyo

This is a decent property about a 5 minute taxi ride from Shinagawa Station. We stayed in this property. Let me first of all say that this is pretty much an average Marriott property. The rooms are a bit dated, and not much English programming on TV, but then again you are in Japan where this is the norm. The Executive Lounge is also nice. The buffet breakfast is not on par with other international Marriott properties; the hotel should step up a bit here. This hotel is set within an excellent garden area and office park with frequent free shuttles to Shinagawa station. What really makes this property outstanding is the concierge staff who gave us numerous suggestions for restaurants and places to go.One warning I have is that I found that there are rooms here that are sold as "non smoking" that smell heavily of smoke. The first night we checked in, both of the two rooms we reserved had strong cigarette smells. Thankfully the staff found two rooms on another floor that did not have this smell. Not sure if this is just the Marriott or Tokyo hotels in general, so be warned when booking a room to make sure it has not been smoked in. We came off a long international flight only to come to our room and realize it had this strong smell and had to wait 30 mins for the front desk to find 2 alternate rooms.
user_name:
MillionMilr
New York City, New York

review_body: Only one restaurant with poor selection of food.Bad location, not in walking distance of anything.Noisy plumbing in the room.Smoking room closes at night, and there is only one, and you can't smoke outside, so if you wake up at night and want to smoke, tough luck.

Rooms were clean. The higher rooms seemed to have been renovated more recently though as some of the other lower level rooms seemed a bit dated. Recommend staying on the higher floors and away from the train station to limit the noise. The beds are firm and very comfortable. The staff, especially at breakfast, are very nice and make it so you never want to leave. The service in Japan is consistently good no matter the service being provided. Stayed at the Westin too, and even though it was much more expensive, it didn’t compare.

Marriot standard “hardware” and prices but .... understaffed and lacking the typical superior Japanese customer attention: only three people at check in (long waiting time),and in the evening, when seated for drink and dinner at the restaurant, our group of 8 had to wait over 15 minutes before being attended. (After asking for attention)This being said, the food and the suggested Japanese red wine were both excellent.Despite being on 27th floor, the noise of trains quite audible.So next time I will try another hotel in the neighbourhood.

Less than 30min taxi ride from Haneda airport, easy walking distance to train station. What was noteworthy on the hotel is the room size which is really large for Tokyo, I have stayed much smaller before. I also very much enjoyed the breakfast that has International but also local options, one cannot go wrong with noodles for breakfast. Very friendly staff, nothing to complain at all, would stay at the Marriott again for sure.

We stayed on night at this hotel in June post cruise. We easily took the train from Yokohama into Tokyo and then it was about a 7-8 minute walk up hill from that station to the Tokyo Marriott Hotel. We checked in early and left our luggage at the front desk to go out sightseeing. When we came back later our room was ready and they had already taken our luggage to our room. The room was of average size, modernly decorated, and had a large window. One complaint with this room was that the bed faced one direction and the TV was on the side wall making it nearly impossible to watch TV in bed. There were quite a few stations, but nothing in English, so we didn’t keep the TV on long anyway. My other complaint is the step in the bathroom. There is a small step from the sink area to where the toilet and tub/shower are located. It seems like a very odd place to put a step, it is unexpected and I’m sure people fall. Just keep and eye out for the step if you get up to go to the bathroom in the middle of the night or after you step out of the shower. If you have access to the concierge lounge, it is very nice. They have a nice selection of snacks and candy out all of the time and then several choices for appetizers in the evening along with free alcohol.

It’s our first time to stay at Tokyo Marriott. Thanks to my status and the hotel I was upgraded to a very nice suite. The room was well-appointed, clean, and spacious. The bed was very comfortable. Abundant amenities and precise housekeeping. I like the small touches like small card indicating the weather next day, and yet another letting you know who was in charge of housekeeping on that day.The breakfast was nice enough. There were selection of Western, Japanese, Chinese dishes. Not the biggest buffet but there were plenty of things to choose from. One thing I was amazed is the chef still served new food near the closing time of the breakfast. Late comers for breakfast sometimes get fewer choices because the buffet station would be left empty. Not here. I saw a few times the chef still bring out (mostly Japanese) food just to make it look complete at 10:00, when the breakfast was supposed to finish.The front desk staff was nice and capable to handle all of my requests too. Have a few packages for me. They handled them perfectly and seamlessly. Had to change another credit card to pay. They did it perfectly. Thank you Natsumi and your colleagues! The staff at the concierge and restaurant is always smiling and welcoming too, which is nice.The lounge was nice with beautiful view of the city. Just attend the evening happy hour once but the food they served was nice. Love the homemade tofu! The location of the hotel is indeed not in the center of the action. But we find the proximity to Haneda Airport was excellent. Keikyu connects perfectly Haneda Airport and Shinagawa Station. Just one simple ride. And from Shinagawa, one takes the shuttle to the hotel. Timetable is on the website. Note the shuttle is not just for the hotel so it looks exactly like regular bus. If one misses the shuttle, walking is not so crazy. Just make sure you cross the street from Shinagawa Station first, and the rest is quite an easy and flat 5-10 mins walk.Overall it was a nice stay. We would like to thank the hotel for the stay!

The Staff are friendly, professional and genuinely polite and go beyond the normal level for service.Breakfast in the lobby restaurant is world class. Rooms are generous in size and good value for a property in Tokyo.

This is the second time I stayed there and on both occasions I experienced that they are stingy in giving upgrades to the loyal members. It is unfortunate because the loyal guests will try out different properties.

Okay, I realize that Marriott hotels are independently owned and they can offer whatever benefits they want but this is the first Marriott hotel I have been to that did not extend my elite benefits (Titanium Elite) to my teenage children. In Japan you usually have to get two rooms if you have four people. In the past the Prince Sakura and the Courtyard Tokyo station have extended my Club Lounge benefits to our family of four but at this hotel my benefits were only extended to myself and one "guest". I could pay about $78 a day for my 14 and 16 year old children to use the lounge but we passed.The other issue I had with the hotel was the location. You have to take a free bus from Shinagawa station. Both the Prince Sakura and the Courtyard Tokyo station are within walking distance of their stations and have fantastic amenities for elite members. If you do stay, here is the information for the bus. Take the West exit from Shinagawa station and walk towards your left. You will see Bus stop number 6. Wait for the bus that says "Gotenyama Trust building" and enter at the back. There are other buses at that stop and those people will be waiting at the front to enter their bus so you just stand at the back. It runs every 20 to 30 minutes depending on the time of day but if you have a particularly early or late train you might have to get a taxi. It doesn't go anywhere else but the Marriott but there are a lot of locals and wedding guests that ride the bus.

We chose this hotel because we are American and I am a high Marriott Bonvoy member who got additional perks such as the buffet breakfast and access to the executive lounge.The service at the hotel was exceptional in every area: the front desk, concierge, bell desk, door greeting staff, as well as all of the staff in the restaurant. Once we picked this hotel I started my communication with the concierge desk a couple of months prior to our arrival. This was our first trip to Asia and we wanted to stay in a place that had familiar surroundings and food and also a concierge who would be able to help us navigate Tokyo. The chief concierge, Ymke Simonis, provided exceptional service prior to our arrival to help me plan a private day trip to Mount Fuji, a private day trip to the Nikko area as well as a day tour of Tokyo our first day so that we could get a little acquainted with the giant city. We were only here for seven nights so we used guides to try and see as much as possible. Throughout our stay she and her staff were extremely friendly and helpful in every way.The bell desk and door greeting staff were all very pleasant and very helpful with any directions you may want to include traveling by taxi, bus or train. Every time we left the hotel we were greeted with “have a nice day“. Every time we came back to the hotel whether it was at the end of the day or sometime in the middle of the day we were always greeted with a wide smile and a “welcome back” greeting. I particularly liked the door greeter Thi Anh Thu Pham who always had a very large gracious smile and was very eager to help in anyway.After the staff got to know us in a couple days we were always greeted by name whether it was at the breakfast buffet or coming and going from the hotel. The hotel is in a great location and provides a free shuttle to the Shinagawa train station which leaves every few minutes. The hotel is immediately next to a very large business building so there are a lot of commuters.This Marriott is also an easy 15 minute taxi ride from the Haneda airport. With 2 suitcases and 2 carry-ons we did not want to tackle the train station with luggage. If you have one small to medium bag then it might be OK however we chose this airport because of its close location to the hotel.Because of my Marriott status we were able to have the breakfast buffet each morning. The staff was exceptional and the manager, Masashi Ono, is great. Again after a couple of mornings we were always greeted by Marical with a large grin and smile as she was saying good morning and our name.For Marriott members there is an executive lounge on the top floor with great views and snacks however there is no true breakfast upstairs. The breakfast is the breakfast buffet downstairs which had a huge selection of both American and Japanese food. The room itself was a standard Marriott room although in keeping with Japanese style was admittedly a little bit smaller than an American hotel. But it provided plenty of space and we had a corner room with nice views of Tokyo Tower. There were robes, a mini bar, a safe, and lots of plugs for your electronics. There were times when we wanted to get ice or additional towels and the service was almost immediate. It was unlike any other Marriott or any other hotel for that matter that we’ve ever stayed at. When we asked for additional towels they would often be at our door in less than 10 minutes.I would highly recommend this hotel and will definitely stay here again when I go back to Tokyo.

A reasonable business hotel about 12 minute walk from JR Shinagawa Station. We stayed in a corner quad room with couch, large bathroom with shower stall and tub and foyer area to hold our luggage. Our room was 512 facing the train station - we did hear the train noise but its so faint that it's not a problem at all. If you are a high-level Marriott Bonvoy members, the hotel throws in some great perks (free breakfast buffet, lounge access with snacks and drinks, and a restaurant discount). The gym is a bit dated but they have all the usual equipment where you can get a good sweat and pump. The pool is only for 16 y.o. and older - sorry no kids allowed. The wifi is strong and consistent. And the service feels like a 4.5 star western hotel - staff is fast, friendly and genuinely warm.

It is a comfortable hotel with all the necessary knick knacks. But it is situated at a quiet residential area, far from food and shopping. There is only one restaurant. So you either eat at the restaurant or use the hotel shuttle bus. And it is the Marriot, an American chain hotel. I know it is Japan. But I am a bit paranoid about terrorism. And like I say, the surprise element is essential to the success of a terrorist attack.

Large rooms and very quiet upto the 3rd floor from what I can tell - shielded by a wall and greenery. Some rooms can face the noisy train line at the back. Fantastic garden and pond at the back to walk around in. Good breakfast, although I found myself always waiting a few minutes whenever I went to the ground floor restaurant, even for a coffee. I’d stay again and take a room upto the 3rd floor - as a business traveler, I look for proximity to client locations downtown,easy access to taxis, comfortable beds, quiet rooms, sound sleep and fast service at breakfast rather than a view or the quality of the lounge. Liked the touch of the doorman asking my name and alerting reception to pull up my details before I got there. I’d stay again.

A nice hotel a 10-minute walk from Shinagawa Station. The rooms are quite large, with comfortable beds and a large bathroom. Our room was looking at the railway line, but the noise was not very strong. There is also a nice Japanese garden next to the hotel.I'm the Marriott Titanium - executive lounge is superb, with a great selection of evening hors d'oeuvres (you can easily skip dinner in another place) and a great variety of hard liquor. Although we were here during the golden week, there were always free seats. Breakfast was at the main restaurant and was very good with a wide variety of dishes.I'm not happy with the service and that's why I give ****.I had booked two rooms. Instead of the original two they gave me a normal and one extremely small room, and that was without warning from the reception. The small room was much cheaper than the original one, but money was not offered to me as compensation. This after a 12-hour flight from Europe. I tried to change the room after seeing it, but at the reception they strongly refused to change the room with the apology that they did not have the right room. The next day the hotel gave me the original room.

Two nights on points as members of Marriott, great room with large bathroom and terrific view. Breakfast included and was terrific, dinner in restaurant was very nice but expensive. Members lounge great value. Shuttle was terrific as was was the train to Tokyo.
user_name:
Georgia912
City of Greater Geelong, Australia

review_body: Very nice hotel in peaceful setting. Exceptionally helpful and friendly staff.Excellent food service. Shuttle bus to Shinigawa station is frequent. Location is outside central Tokyo so it is helpful to be able to take the train to the city.

I am being Marriott gold member for few years. This was one worst customer service Marriott I have came across. Front desk was not at all helpful to accommodate right room. I was given a room with continuous train sound . On asking to change a room they gave me a reason they are completely booked. My 17 month little baby was crying for the milk at middle of night . I asked room service provide a milk but they told me room service was closed in spite hotel says 24 hours room service. Avoid this hotel if you are staying with your family.

Don’t bother with the shuttle pick up from Shinagawa station.It is not a Hotel bus!! A crowd tries to board it. Easier to take a taxi, for 6 bucks or so.The breakfast downstairs is great and the hotel reception was really very pleasant with two fun girls checking us in. Outside the modern garden is very much worth a Walk especially during the Sakura. It was the tail end and petals were drifting down. Pretty scenic garden.

Stayed twice during the course of a week. Staff excellent overall - with Maricar in the breakfast area a total STAR! Ambassador suite upgrades appreciated - spacious and well appointed. Housekeeping wonderful.Evening lounge service very nice although it can get very crowded and hot in the relatively small space. They did have an overflow lounge space on the lobby level which was very thoughtful considering the high occupancy. The gym was poor, without a single elliptical machine or cross trainer. It looked more like an old YMCA workout room. The pool was also out of order. As the signature Marriott property in the world’s largest metropolitan city area, an excellent gym and pool are Must Have’s in order to be a truly top class hotel. Location was good in my opinion - a short 10 minute walk to Shinagawa station with loads of dining and shopping options. An overwhelming variety to choose from! The hotel also runs a complimentary scheduled shuttle to the station if you don’t want to walk.

On our arrival we were escorted to the lounge, which was small and substandard not only by look but also by service, which too was grotty. I never had such experience before where you were charged much more than your room rent and also without your permission. Further more I was told that the hotel has not charged or taken deposit and will charge only on check out. Surprisingly I was charged again on check out.It was only when I confronted with Mr Tomokazu the room manager and shown him I am charged twice as per Bank SMS. He apologized and assured me that they will instruct their bank to refund the money in few days time. Be care full if anybody stays in the hotel to ensure that your credit card is not misused. Though apart from above too the hotel is not worth staying. Evening snacks and drinks are also not match with the Marriott standard.The rooms are small and grotty too. Location also not very good quite far from subway or points of attractions. So in over all not good choice to stay in Tokyo.

Tokyo Marriott Shinagawa is located in Lake City Buildings, about 1 km from Shinagawa South Exit. There is a free shuttle bus service between the hotel and the station (ever 15-20 minutes, depending on time and day). The bus looks just like regular public bus, so commuters must aware. From Shinagawa station, the pick up point is bus station number 6 (just right after you get of the station building, a bit to the right). The drop off area is on the other side of the station. The hotel is big. The room is quite nice and large than regular tokyo hotels. The bathroom is also comparatively large. The service is A++. The staff are very caring and attentive. There speak very good English too. Free wifi, gym, and typical hotel facilities are all there. The hotel also arrange airport transfer service, both narita and haneda. Price and schedule can be checked at the lobby.

It was our first visit to Japan. We stayed here for 2 nights prior to going on a cruiseRoomThe room was nice, comfy beds, TV, hairdryer, iron and ironing board, towling gown and slippers provided.  Good size bathroom with a strong shower and a mod con toilet. A well stocked box of complimentary toiletries. The was a mini bar and complimentary still waterDiningWe didn't eat on the first night as we'd had plenty on the two flights to get there. We had a drink in the bar. For 2 x 180ml glasses of wine we paid approx £23.93.For the 2nd night we had a steak sandwich and fries plus 2 small glasses of wine and it cost approximately £69.73These prices might be ok for people on business trips but I thought were expensive for ordinary people on vacation.The staff were very niceThe hotel is set in nice grounds. We found out on return from a trip on the second day that there was a complimentary shuttle bus from the train station which didn't take long. We wouldn't have been aware of this if it wasn't for the fact I enquired at the train station

For us, the location wasn't bad, because our first two days included a conference in a technopark on a nearby metro line. It was also reasonably convenient to Haneda. The shuttle bus to Shinagawa station allowed you to get anywhere in the city with reasonable ease. The hotel looks new inside and out and is very clean and well equipped. They have hordes of staff to help with anything you need. The concierges were particularly good (and all we spoke to very fluent in English) Everything about the room was perfect-spacious,clean, great view, everything worked (including the fancy toilet typical of most upscale Japanese establishments). The lounge was nice, but the breakfast in the main dining room (free for platinum members) was probably the best hotel buffet breakfast we've ever had. We didn't try other meals, or the very large health club. The price was reasonable for the quality, much less than the top rated ***** hotels. Maybe they have more to offer for their cost, but I'm not sure what. Would definitely stay here again.

Connectivity is great from JR Shinagawa station, free shuttle multiple times a day, just plan your day accordingly. Great amenities in room. Nice outdoor walk in the hotel complex. Lavish breakfast and kids eat free ... highly recommended.

My friend and I stayed here for 4 nights at the start of our vacation in Japan. We are both Platinum members and split the stay via our points. Pro's: wonderful complimentary breakfast buffet for Platinum members. concierge lounge is well stocked with beverages and snacks and has a nice happy hour in the evenings. fast elevators, even on such a big property with so many rooms. Family Mart in basement of building next door, which is nice since train station or other stores and restaurants are not close. Con's: did not know about bus up from train station prior to arrival so pushed big suitcases up the hill in the dark on arrival. This should be listed on their website and highlighted in the confirmation email. Also, there is only 1 express train from the station that connects to other metro stops. Otherwise it's the JR rail, which means multiple changes to get to any of the tourist locations in town. Would recommend another Marriott property if you want to be close to the action. We did not use the pool or spa. This hotel seemed to be frequented mostly by business professionals with a few families on vacation. Staff were helpful throughout the stay and we did receive a welcome gift (our choice of beverage and snack) upon arrival.

位置勉強算近，還算新的飯店但是內裝已經有破敗的痕跡，服務到位英文都很好，早餐非常棒但是房價很高，而且沒有什麼好用的公設。這次再訪是因為前一次去年八月蜜月旅行時貼心的服務和安排，不過這次覺得跟其他Bonvoy系列相比沒有勝出的地方，之後應該就不會再選擇這裡了。The location is not close to the Shinagawa station but the hotel provides shuttle bus which compensates the inconvenience. The service is really good and considerate. All the staff speaks fluent English and has efficiently service. The breakfast is perfect. However, the hardware here doesn’t correlate to the room rate. The bath tub and the blanket wear in the room I stayed. The reason I chose here again is due to the wonderful experience of previous stay (August, 2018) . I may not comeback again for the other Bonvoy series offer better environment under relative room rate in Tokyo.

I’m a gold Marriott member, no upgrade/ lounge access/ or free breakfast at this property! Wished I’d had known. Lovely breakfast buffet tho’. Good fitness center. Convenient store with an ATM. Good WiFi. Lots of elevators so not much waiting! And an exceptional staff throughout the property.

Unpleasant check-in in spite of Marriott gold status. No upgrade, nothing in lieu of upgrade and no apology either. I was informed that I could use the pool without the usual 2700 yen charge, but my kids under 16 could not join (a rule not specified on hotel website). So a poor start to my stay.On the positive side, the rooms are clean, comfortable and comparatively spacious, and the breakfast is of high-standard even for Tokyo. However, the rumbling of the trains below early in the morning was a slight negative.Overall, don't recommend this hotel for families or Marriott Rewards members. There simply are better options in the wonderful city that is Tokyo!

I've stayed at this hotel several times in the past two years because it is located close to our company's office in Tokyo. The hotel itself is maintained, but the rooms and facilities are spartan, poorly lit, cheaply decorated and not at a Marriott standard. The hotel lacks a gym so you need to go to a work-out shop in an adjacent building which is very poorly equipped and has limited hours. Room service this stay was average quality and did not deliver what was requested. Staff is generally friendly. But for this overall mediocre, mixed-bag hotel you pay a very high rate, even for Tokyo. Apart from it's location, I would not stay at this hotel again.
user_name:
Tim K
Mahtomedi, Minnesota, United States

review_body: As a lifetime Platinum Marriott/Bonvoy member, I have never had occasion to recommend against staying at a Marriott property; until now. I will not stay here again. I left the hotel so disappointed in the service I received at the hotel that I sent a note to Marriott Corporate offices to complain. I will say my Platinum status was recognized, I was given access to the lounge (the only bright spot of my stay, the lounge is quite nice) and it was noted during check-in that I booked a non-smoking room. I was taken up to my room (as it turns out by Mr. Sakurai, the front desk manager) and when I arrived I noticed a bottle of deodorizer on the desk. I commented to him that I had never seen that before. Well it didn't take long to realize that the deodorizer was to try to cover the smell of cigarette smoke. Frankly, I felt deceived. I went back to the desk to complain and have my room changed. Due to high occupancy, the room choice was limited and I was placed in room 209 (despite my profile noting my preference for high floors). The room may have been in the same category as the rate I booked, but it seemed smaller. I don't feel the front desk staff showed any interest in my situation when I discussed it with them, nor any concern that neither room was consistent with what was in my profile. I do thank Mr. Sakurai for taking the time to discuss the situation with me. But I still felt disregarded as a customer and I will not return to the Tokyo Marriott Hotel.

I think the property is a bit old but I always have been treated really nicely here. All of the staff I have interacted with were friendly, helpful, and good English speakers. There are definitely better Marriott hotels around the world but this one will stay as one of my favorite.It would be perfect if they can have their own gym there though ...

This Marriott emulates the great hospitality of the Japanese people. Truly a very welcome spirit coupled with the conveniences if one is accustomed to a western hotel. Have had the good fortune of staying in Marriotts around the world this is one of the best.

This place is old and clearly in need of a facelift. The gym is very substandard for a chain like Marriott, as the executive lounge. The location is decent from an access perspective, but there is virtually nothing nearby in terms of restaurants or nightlife.

We stayed here for three nights in a family room. Overall the experience was pleasant. A special nod to the guest-services person who arranged for our luggage to be delivered, unaccompanied in a taxi from another hotel. Who knew this could be such a complex logistical operation? I regretfully lost her business card so am unable to mention her name.The rooms themselves were spacious with their own WiFi access point. There were a few interesting furniture choices I did not understand that may be cultural. The separate bedroom had twin beds, a queen/king would be more appropriate for a family couple. We had 2 adults and two children, this meant four suitcases. There were no dressers to unpack into and no luggage carts on which to open the suitcases leaving them cluttering the floor.As a titanium member, the executive lounge was top notch with a great view and plenty of nibbles. The breakfast exceeded all expectations with freshly cooked eggs, pancakes and waffles available.The hotel provides a free shuttle to Shinegawa station, although we never were able to find the bus stop #6 for the return to the hotel. The taxi was 740 jpy, an acceptable expense.We will stay here again.

As a platinum member, I was upgraded to executive floor upon check in. Didn’t get suite as I was told hotel was overbooked for the night. Room was basic type but quite spacious for Japan standard. There’s a tub in bathroom albeit it’s not separated from the shower area. Toiletries are from famous Thai brand Thann just like many Marriott hotels in Asia. Overall for the room I’d say it was okay and nothing to complain (also nothing to brag) about. However, be warned of short restaurant/room service hours if you plan to arrive in late. It was 11pm when I checked in and all restaurants were closed by then even room services stopped at 11pm, leaving me no choice but having to walk out for 5mins to get to nearest convenience store for food. Not a pleasant experience in terms of late night dining options. The concierge staff was kind and friendly on the other hand, he gave us directions to find food and lent an umbrella without us asking for use in the rainy night. 1 extra star for their hospitality.

This is a great hotel. There are several Marriotts to choose from, but you won't go wrong with this one. It's close to local transportation and it's got all the benefits of the Marriott brands. The views are 'ok', but it's mostly just cityscape. For a business location, it's great and I'd recommend it anytime.

The official check in time was 2pm. I arrived from a red- eye flight totally exhausted at 2.20pm and was told my room was NOT ready and that I could not check-in because another guest with " Diamond" status was given an hour complimentary late check-out. Come-on... Really? You have the gall to tell your paying guests this crab of an excuse? To rub salt to the wound, I was offered a smaller room than what I paid for should I insist on having a room right away. The reason I was offered this option, " oh, your booking was made through your company's website booking isn't it?" Translated into: corporate customers are not important? i don't get it. I visit Tokyo on business at least 3-4 times a year and twice on leisure. I have not returned and have no intention to ever do that.

We had a 36 hour stopover and stayed at the Tokyo Marriott. It’s a short walk from the train station and has a solid lounge. Good food and drink flowing along with a complimentary meeting room which can be reserved in 2 hour slots Views are from there Breakfast was taken downstairs in the restaurant and was a good selection of Full buffetRates are high in Tokyo so prepaid rate was used.Would stay again

I took my family to Tokyo during Lunar New Year holiday and stayed at Tokyo Marriot due to my Marriott/SPG/BONVOY membership and its reasonable rates.Tokyo Marriott is a business hotel so it’s not situated in a tourist area. It’s about 10-15 minutes walk from Shinagawa train station. Other than a ramen street, there’s not much to see or do during the walk. Its’s good that free shuttle bus service between the hotel and train station is available and its schedule is quite frequent. I checked in via mobile prior to my arrival so the process was pretty quick. The check in staff was very friendly and recognized my Platinum Premier status. He first apologized for not able to upgrade my room. Then he went to explain my benefits such as breakfast options and lounge access. The 2 rooms I booked were located on the same floor. Room size was big considering most hotel rooms in Japan are very small. Rooms were clean and well maintained. The bedside Ikea mini clock is interesting. Breakfast at the lobby was delicious. I liked the fresh smoothies as they have many varieties. Japanese options were also my recommendation. My plat status allows 2 person free for breakfast, so we paid additional for 3 more persons. The cost is expensive but food quality is very high.Lounge is on the 26th floor with a nice view. I only went once and found it very cozy.Overall, a decent hotel with quality food and professional staff. Location wise is average if you are a tourist. Nevertheless, the rates speak for itself. Will stay again in May.

Stayed a night as a transit to Kawaguchiko and found it excellent. Though is a bit far from JR Shnagawa Station (10 mins walk), they provide free shuttle between the station and the hotel. The front desk personnel were very welcoming. A special thanks to Rachel who took the effort to prepare a box of mini beautifully crafted desserts for my friend's birthday that happened to fall on the day we checked in. I was also surprised with the size of the standard room, very spacious and you can hardly get such size in Tokyo. If there is any shortfall, I would say that it is not linked with the Tokyo metro but JR Yamanote Line (circle line) is available.

No limousine bus from haneda airport to hotel after 2 pm daily and took a taxi instead. staff was friendly and able to converse well in english at the lobby and reception. given a 18 floor room. noise insulation is not too bad although facing the rail tracks. room is spacious for tokyo standard and the toiletries are more impressive than String Intercontinental. Breakfast is fantastic having many option. Room is well maintained and clean, although building is quite old.There are regular buses to Shinagawa station and back to hotel. walking to the station is around 8 to 9 mins. Down side, the internet is extremely unstable and video call is terrible. Beside restaurants within the hotel, nearest place will be at shinagawa station. Overall if you do not mind waiting for the bus or walking, it is still a neat hotel.

The hotel room is very small, not worth the value of HKD$2000/night. We need to back hotel on foot after 9:30pm. The distance is around 10-15mins. I wont recommend this hotel as the price is not cheap but the room is too small and far away from JR station.

A business trip that during the spare time was transformed to a pleasure trip.Services, personnel from any department, restaurant, atmosphere were incredible. I have never experienced something like this. Clean and tidy, well connected to the train station as well with Tokyo Haneda airport.

It started with a horrible check in experience. Unfriendly, arrogant with zero customer focus or customer appreciation. Although I mentioned I needed a quiet room as I'm a light sleeper and that I needed good internet as I had multiple calls scheduled throughout the week, the lady assigned me with a room with a very poor internet and facing the train tracks all topped with Windows which weren't properly closing. The noise was so loud that I couldn't sleep all night.After mentioning this the next morning they didn't bother giving me another room but wanted to fix the windows. I even believed they did until later that week when the howling noise of the wind was back an I realized they didn't. Internet as mentioned was awful and it was embarrassing when getting disconnected multiple times throughout a call. Even calls organized from the Executive Lounge were constantly interrupted because of the bad connection. Management doesn't care about customers or guests well being.Only exception was the restaurant staff. Everybody was nice and truly cared about us. They even apologized for the room - which wasn't their fault at all - but it showed they care about their customers. I will definitely not going back there as there are plenty of choices in Tokyo. Based on my experience I wouldn't recommend it at all.

I stayed here for 3 nights as part of a business trip. The room was relatively small, but clean and the decor appeared fresh and up to date with a clean en suite bathroom with a shower over the bath. There was a huge breakfast buffet with many options (even for my colleague on the Keto diet). The staff both in the restaurant and at reception were very friendly and helpful. The M Club was nice with good selection of snacks and drinks, but the food offerings in the evening were limited and they stopped serving food at 19:30 hr.i would gladly stay here again.

Hotel is a bit old already - mainly the rooms are worn and the bathrooms are a bit ugly... The gym is also super old and you don't really want to touch the equipment. Food is ok, but not great and service is good (though language an issue as usual in JP). Overall Hotel is ok, but try to find a better one on this price range.

On the upside, the hotel is clean and the rooms are generously sized. The hotel staff is friendly. The breakfast buffet while expensive offers many choices. The downside of this hotel is that there is a train station located below the window and we could hear the train in our room. It is noisy. I tried to like the noise but after three days it interfered with rest and sleep. We stayed in room 1912. The location is okay but consider where you want to be in the city and what you want to do.

Stayed in a quad room. Rooms are large and bathroom is spacious, especially in Japan.Location is ok with a free shuttle bus to and from Shinagawa station which was very helpful.Hotel is clean and beds are very comfortable.

My wife, 7 year old and I stayed here in October 2018 for 7 nights. We were in Tokyo for a family vacation. The hotel location is great, the rooms were big by Japanese standards and the staff was very friendly. The breakfast (included because of my Marriott status) was very good with a large selection of Western and Japanese foods. We will definitely book here again when coming back to Tokyo.

Desk agent didn’t ask how my brief stay was when checking out, so I didn’t bother to tell her how disappointed I was. I work in Executive Lounge, so seek hotels that have decent lounge. Unfortunately I didn’t get to experience this one as there were no seats and a queue out into the hallway. I guess this is how it is now with the merged program with way too many elites.

Ideally located in the quarter of Shinagawa, the hotel is at walking distance of the trai station. A little park brings a quiet atmosphere in the middle of the city. Rooms are very comfortable, and functional.Breakfast is of very good quality, with many options.The reception is a at the end of a corridor, which is unusual.Overall, the hotel has not much of a character, but delivers a solid service and is a good place to take a rest.

No disappointment except lack of platinum upgrade, excellent service, I had a large standard room for Tokyo, decent lounge with the great views I did not get with my room. The breakfast buffet was great and had the most impact on the rating.

This hotel is very convenient to move other place in Tokyo. The hotel provide free-shuttle bus, so you can very easily move to Shinagawa station to take JR line. And, you can also take a limousine bus from Haneda or Narita airport. The limousine will take you directly from the airport to the hotel lobby. Guest room is not small and the room was very clean. Every morning, you can have breakfast at 1st floor. There're lots of kind of foods and very nice juice bar. Most of all hotel staffs are very kind and they also have very supportive manner always. I'd like to strongly recommend to you, if you have a plan to visit Tokyo.

Good position in Shinagawa, best place to visit Tokyo with Jr line that arrivee everywhere in Tokyo. Free Shuttle bus u til 10pm. Wonderful staff and hotel. For New Year Evening perfect party. Thanks all the staff.

The Negative:The hotel is a shuttle bus away from Shinagawa station, with the immediate surrounding area having little by way of amenities, walking to the *main station would take approx 15 minsPoor SPG/ Marriott Recognition - Declined late checkout @ Premier Platinum levelSmall Rooms - was "upgraded" to a city-view room, which was 90% covered by another building immediately in front of the windowThe Positive Excellent Lounge, Excellent Breakfast, Staff were mostly incredibly kind and helpful

LocationHotel is located about 15 mins walk from the Shinagawa station next to a large office building. There is a shuttle that runs between the hotel and Shinagawa station every day at different frequency and the airport limosine bus from Haneda airport (and I believe Narita) does stop at the hotel too. Midway between the hotel and Shinagawa station, they have this "Ramen street" which has some good ramen shops and wel worth a try (or two). Besides that, there are not much other interesting attractions. Check InI arrived very early and was at the hotel before 7am. As expected there was no one and I was helped immediately. I was lucky (or maybe based on my status) managed to get a room that early. No upgrade was provided (unless I waited until early afternoon for the room - but that was only to a higher floor) so I just accepted what I was available since it was just a 1 night stay. I was also asked to choose my arrival gift which I requested to be delivered later that evening. I was given a rundown of my Elite benefits at the hotel. RoomI was assigned a room on the 8th floor (out of the close to 20+ floor of the hotel) facing the railway tracks. If the TV was no on, you could hear the trains passing by, but this was not a big bother to me - however it could be for those who are sensitive to noise. It seems that after 10 pm and before 7am, the disturbance from the trains are close to zero.The size of the room was OK, though still smaller compared to other Marriotts outside of Japan but much bigger than the average hotel rooms at other type of Japanese based brand hotels.They had the usual coffee/tea making facilities available and a well stocked minibar. Internet speed was good -stable and sufficiently fast for normal browsing.Bathroom size was ok with a bathtub. Water pressure and temperature was good. The bed was I suspect a queen size bed, but it was comfortable and there was well positioned lighting and other controls by the bedside. One item to note is that all plugs are Japanese plugs standard and there did not see to have be any USB charger available. Room temperature control was good and easy to use. Executive LoungeThe hotel seems to have recently moved the Executive lounge from the 1st floor (same floor as the lobby) to the 24th floor which is a big improvement. The previous lounge area was windowless and much smaller. The new lounge area has much more seating and there is a nice view (~180deg) of the Shinagawa area down to Tokyo Bay ( you can see to the distance planes taking off from HND).During the day, the lounge has small bites available (mainly M&M's, Kitkat, Shortbread cookies, etc. In the evening, during the evening hors d'oeuvres hour, it is mainly small individual appetizers and desserts.There was quite a number of staff in the lounge that did effectively clear the tables. Lounge access is by the key card - therefore they don't really request for your room number since it is limited access to the key card.BreakfastBreakfast is served in the main restaurant at the 1st floor. No breakfast option at the lounge. The breakfast area is not large, so there can be a possibility during certain hours the wait can be long.Breakfast spread is good, with lots of options and eggs to order. Service is ok, although maybe due to the pressure, they do sometimes tend to forget orders. For example after settling in, I ordered Green tea, but this never appeared during the whole time. I saw that this happened too at tables near me - the guests had to remind someone for their orders.Also tables are placed quite close to each other, so for some this could be a not so nice experience.ServiceIn general, service is OK especially for Japan. However for hotel of this standard and especially in Japan, I would have expected much better service. For example, in the morning after checking in and getting my request for my arrival gift for later delivery, this never arrived. After waiting 30 mins after the requested time, I had to call to ask about it - I could have just ignored and bring it up the next day during check out. When calling about it, I was informed that I had chosen the points instead of the choices and even after that, I had to wait about 20 mins before it arrived.The other example of small service failure is the forgetting about customer orders during breakfast.OverallAll in all, this hotel is OK. I've noticed compared to my previous stays some good changes and some improvement area. For the first time visitor to Tokyo, this hotel would not be the best property to use a the base due to the limited options from Shinagawa station (there is no Metro line, and with the JR lines, the stations might still be quite a walk to the attractions). The hotel is close to Haneda is a plus point even as an airport hotel. For me, I will only choose this property if the price is right and all my plans or destination is accessible within the JR or Keisei Line trains.

Recently spent a week in Tokyo and stayed at this wonderful hotel. The rooms are spacious, well appointed, and quiet. What makes this hotel special is the attention to detail each member of the hotel staff show its visitors. Overall, a wonderful venue. As I have stayed at Marriott properties around the World, this is no doubt the finest hotel within the chain. Kudos to the Tokyo Marriott staff for maintaining such a friendly, welcoming and accommodating place for visitors to rest while in Tokyo.

We spent 5 nights in this hotel, we have wonderful stay. Their email response and arrangement is wonderful. The staff can speak English pretty well. When we check-in, it was such a warm welcome to us (worse thing I did not get that person's name whom checked us in); he was so nice even he told us they could not upgrade our room. Then he suddenly went to a room and gave us 2 little gifts (chopsticks = good things come), which he really didn't need to do it since the room upgrade is really based on availability, so that we totally understood that we may not get any; anyway, we really appreciate his gesture.Location/Limousine Bus:Location for this hotel would be better choice for business, since it is located away from the busy area, it is a very quiet area. Since this time we went there as leisure; therefore, it maybe a bit far away from the JR or any sightseeing spot; however, we still love this hotel and say Thanks to the C/I person! However, one good thing is the limousine bus, you basically do not need to carry any of your luggage literally, from C/O to bus to Narita, you basically did not need to carry your luggage at all. That is very important to shoppers!!! Elevator:There are 3 elevators, and they are always fast and empty; sometimes it could be headache for lacking and slow elevators especially if you stay in high floor, but Tokyo Marriott did not have any problem for this

I like this hotel very much. The folks were awesome before I got out of the cab on arrival and all the way through check in and then to my room. Room is large and nice. The executive lounge was nice with a good view of the city. Food was good also especially the desserts.

We had some issues when arriving so I decided to notify management of the problem. Within minutes I had a call from the manager and started discussing his resolution to the issues with me. He was very prompt and made sure I was satisfied with my stay. Also breakfast at the lobby was very nice.

In a word, noisy! We have loyaly stayed here over the last 7 or so years and we have patiently dealt with the ongoing issues of poor internet connectivity, zero food options after 2300, and the overly packed lounge, but when we start putting Marriott Platinum Elite Plus Ambassadors in the lowest level corner rooms facing the railroad tracks (715) it’s cleary time to move on. Worst part, when a room of this “quality” is knowingly assigned at 14:30 in the afternoon, it becomes painfully obvious that the management team doesn’t care how loyal you are to the brand. It’s even more painful when the front desk staff plays stupid and try’s to convince you that no other rooms were available when we know for a fact that wasn’t true! We aren’t asking for an upgrade in anyway, we just want the room preferences to be recognized. Evidently, that’s asking too much. Well, I just spent my last two nights at this hotel and we shall look for a better option. I’ll save the 42,000 yen next time and just sleep on the tracks right outside my window(s) , it might be quieter. What a huge disappointment, but then again, what did I really expect from my 235 night a year commitment to the Marriott Corporation. And please do me a favor and save the canned “we are sorry we didn’t meet your expectations” response. I live in your hotels 8 months out of every year, and I am not really interested in hearing the same re hashed excuses.

Good location, luxurious room, delicious food and sound sleep, but we are asked to wait 20 minutes in line for breakfast.I wish they would have told it in advance.At the Executive Lounge on 26 level, a guest sitting next to me mentioned a hygiene problem (a waiter solved it).Although the hotel staffs are nice and the hotel is comfortable, I can’t recommend my business associates to stay at this hotel.駅から少し離れてるけど送迎バスあるし、値段からしたら他のところは相応だと思うけど、20分冷え冷えしたホールで事前予告も代替手段の提示もなしに朝食を待てと言われるのは、これから旅程のある人には結構問題だと思うし、エグゼクティブラウンジならそれなりのクオリティ求めたいので、この2点はかなり残念だった。

This time we decided to visit Japan, "The Land of the Rising Sun", during this month of November. It is always a great experience to meet new people and new cultures. The Japanese people stand out for their extreme education, friendliness and cordiality. We were impressed with its customs and history, from its ancient Jomon civilization to the people of today, being main protagonists emperors, shoguns and samurai. Their religious and philosophical traditions so different from the Western ones are a point of great importance that opened us other horizons and perspectives of life, expressed in several temples that we visited, mainly Shinto and Buddhist. Finally, the cult of the nature that these people have is worthy of being highlighted, being high points the "sakura" and the "momiji". Of these, we had the opportunity to enjoy the "momiji" of the autumnal season, fully impregnated of vegetation with reddish colours, which, in reality, is very beautiful and was for us greatly appreciated. We began our visit in Tokyo, the current capital of the country, formerly known as Edo. We chose the Tokyo Marriott Hotel for our 5-night stay in this city. This hotel is about 1 hour from Narita International Airport by train to Shinagawa (Narita Express) and features a complimentary and frequent shuttle between the hotel and this station, in a 5-minute drive. The hotel is away from all tourist attractions, but has multiple accesses available either by subway or train. The property is part of the "Trust Tower" building, sharing with it its infrastructures such as fitness centre and indoor swimming pool. The hotel has pleasant common areas and is now renovated. Upon arrival, we were welcomed and were assigned the room #2211. It seemed to us only a standard room, with a "small" King bed, which however was comfortable. The AC, while allowing the proper temperature, was a bit noisy. There was complimentary Nespresso coffee, tea and water, replenished daily. Note that the bathroom had an electronic toilet that allowed a perfect hygiene. All the necessary amenities were also available, replenished daily and generously. Also worthy of mention is the availability of an Android smartphone that could be used in the city. We had access to the buffet breakfast in the main restaurant, which we considered to be of excellent quality and variety, especially when compared to other Marriott properties we know of. As a Platinum Premier member, we had access to the Executive Lounge, which provided a regular variety of items, which quickly became repetitive throughout the stay. We must emphasize that the high point of the hotel is the excellent service offered by all staff, from the bellman to the restaurant staff. In conclusion, we made good choice in choosing this hotel for our stay in Tokyo and we recommend it.

Great location with walking distance of 12 minutes to Shinagawa station. This hotel provides great service to its guests. Having a panorama view lounge at 26th floor, guests could take scenic view of Tokyo city and Tokyo Tower from a distance. With a short to Shinagawa station, one could access to cities around Tokyo effortlessly. Best of all, we could take Keikyu Line from this station directly to Haneda Airport with just 460 Yen

The hotel is located on Shinagawa trains trackside. Thus if you do not ask to have a room on the rear side you have no chance to sleep. Even on rearside and at the 6th floor, you still have the trains as a background noise.The beds are perfect as well as the service. The breakfast buffet is very good, the usual Marriott one. But we dearly miss the view reserved for the silver members. The swimming pool is the most expensive of the Tokyo hotels -more than 20€

This Marriott hotel had great staff, good food, decent amenities and great service.The one thing lacking was its location. It’s relatively close to train station but it’s a distance away from some of the more popular tourist attractions.Couldn’t fault the hotel experience though. Very good

The deluxe room is spacious enough for 4 of us.( 2Adult 2 young teenagers)Love the buffet breakfast, and lounge service. Swimming pool and sauna room are great too but close too early (8pm)Food served in lounge are tasty but need to have more choices or menu change. We stayed for 5 nights and offer the exact same food and dessert everyday.

Very typical Marriott, clean & hospitably, enough room space which is very rare in Tokyo. Need to take a shuttle bus or taxi to Shinagawa station, which is little bit inconvenience.It will take around 15 mins to walk.

Decent hotel, while here on holiday, caters to business stays. Breakfast is mostly an a Western style buffet and individual items. Small Japanese breakfast area as well. Live music some nights by the bar. Nice view from the exec lounge. Has a free shuttle from Shinagawa station that runs frequently. If you want to be close to Shinagawa station in a Marriott property, this fits the bill.

Go after 10 for the a la carte breakfastThe location is about 20m walk from shinagawa which didn't bother us.Room was pretty good with a great view. Exec lounge had awesome view.Breakfast blew my mind Service goodGood good good

I've stayed at many Marriotts around the world and I'd rate this one as above average compared to US locations, but a little below average compared to other countries. It was definitely a nice hotel, just not "Wow" like some I've stayed at (Shanghai, Budapest, and Prague to name some). The room was good, but not amazing. Bathroom was big (very big for Japan standard). Executive lounge was small with less options than I'm used to (one reason I didn't give it a 5). I know the location comment will be somewhat controversial. Its about a 10+ minute walk from Shinagawa station. That's not bad for a casual stroll, but when you're pulling a larger suitcase and its warm out, and its uphill, its not great. There are a few other hotels closer to the station. I guess they have a free shuttle (would have been nice to know, especially when I asked the bellman which way to go to the station while pulling my suitcase), but that should give you an idea how far it actually is. The layout of the hotel is also a bit confusing. Took me a while to find the exercise room and when I did, the equipment was OK, but dated, and the room was quite warm (I think the thermometer said 24?). Staff was very friendly, but check in and out took a surprisingly long time considering I'd reserved with Marriott and checked in online.
