We are so pleased we choose the Tokyo Marriott for our short stay. The hotel is beautiful, conveniently located and has a wonderful staff.The fact my wife and I were celebrating our 25th anniversary did not get relaid but once the hotel became aware and most importantly the management we were well taken care of. Tokyo Marriott went well beyond my expectations and I appreciate it!!A very special thanks to Racel for being so very helpful and providing excellent suggestions. You personally made our stay and capped an end to a wonderful weeks celebration of our 25 years.

We stayed for 10 days, it was a very memorable stay.The staff are excellent, very professional, always have a nice smile and greeting.Whenever we had an inquiry, the staff assisted happily and promptly.Our room was serviced each day to perfection, everything clean, neat and tidy.The dinning staff were always prompt with service and did it with a smile,always willing to do that extra bit to make our stay memorable.The breakfast choices were extensive buffett style but omelettes, egg benedict etc were customed prepared to your request.It is obvious the hotel is well managed as the teams were cohesive, efficient and happy.Very easy to recommend this hotel.Very convenient to Shinagawa station via a free 5 minute bus ride.

I am a loyal Marriott Platinum Premier member who travels extensively and stay exclusively at Marriott properties when possible. In Tokyo, I am a regular at the Tokyo Marriott every time I come for business, several times a year. The hotel is located near to my company’s offices in Japan, which make it a bonus!The service and rooms at the Tokyo Marriott are excellent. The rooms are clean, modern and comfortable, as well as well appointed. They include a Nespresso machine in the room, which I very much appreciate, and the bathrooms are large for Japan. The service staff is very good and very kind to guests, always doing a good job and trying to respond quickly to customers needs. My biggest complaint, however, and opportunity for improvement, is the hotel’s fitness center. It seems to be run by an independent company and is grungy, dated and with old equipment, and worn and dirty carpets. The treadmills and equipment are old (even rusty and dirty in areas) and the floors are very badly maintained, especially the carpets leading down to the pool. I wanted to go the the pool, but you are required to take off your shoes and, given that the floors were so worn and bad, I decided to forego the experience. As well, all the signage around the hotel has stickers taping off information on the hotel maps. At the beginning I thought that it was because they were making changes or renovations. Now, after several years of coming here, I can’t understand why the hotel management simply doesn’t make new boards with the proper signage, as opposed to having a bunch of stickers covering information. It just looks bad and unprofessional, unbecoming of Marriott’s global standards. Lastly, the Executive Lounge is not very appealing. It lacks some of the essential elements that are usually present at full-service Marriotts. I would encourage the hotel to benchmark its lounge to other Marriott properties to see what they can do to improve, especially for the business traveler who does not want to deal with a crowded restaurant in the mornings.

This Marriott is an excellent hotel in the Marriott tradition, the rooms are a bit smaller than in America but similarly appointed, service is like everywhere in Japan fantastic, the restaurant is also very good.It is located close to the Shinagawa subway and train station (10 minute walk) and a free shuttle runs constantly between the hotel and the station.About a 7 minute walk from the hotel I found an excellent laundromat and there is a mini market next to the hotel.The only negative points are the mediocre wifi, the lack of a business Center and to some extent the smaller rooms although this last point is shared with most Japanese hotels, still an outstanding choice.

We stayed at the hotel for 2 nights and overall we enjoyed the place. I do agree with other comments that the lounge isn’t the best we have seen - further we have been actually more surprised about the fact that it looks like that Marriott does not everywhere apply the same access rules. I had places where as Platinum Elite Member I was allowed to access the lounge with the entire family (2 adults and 2 teenagers) and at that place access was limited just to myself and my wife.Breakfast at the restaurant was OK but as well not the best choice I have seen. So overall good but somehow I was missing the WOW effect.

This hotel was ideal for us on a 2-night stopover before a cruise, it had many advantages.It is one of very few places where we could get a 3-bed room, normally a twin, for myself, my wife and adult daughter. Despite the 3 beds the large room didn't feel overcrowded.All the room facilities were first class and everything was spotlessly clean.Although it is at Shinagawa, not in central Tokyo, there is a free shuttle bus to the station where you can quickly get into the city.And conveniently we were able to get a limo bus from Narita airport direct to the front door with no intermediate stops, just the ticket when we were tired and jet-lagged.We had a good sleep in the very comfortable beds.There are loads of interesting shops, cafes, etc at Shinagawa station itself.And across the road from the station there are a lot more restaurants.We ate breakfast at an American-style diner and dinner at an excellent Italian.There's nothing around the hotel itself.The second morning we took the hotel breakfast which was good but very expensive.

I stayed 5 nights at the Tokyo Marriott hotel for a work trip.I have visited Tokyo many times for work, but this is the first time staying at the Tokyo MarriottThe hotel room is large in comparison to many hotels in Tokyo. My room allows me access to the Executive Lounge - which I used almost everyday. The lounge serves some food at different times of the day, and has desserts (cakes) available at most times.The service was also great. When we checked in, a typhoon was about to arrive. The reception advised us that the trains were going to be shut down and it may be difficult to get a taxi - so we decided to eat in the hotel that evening.The hotel is about a 15 min to the JR Shinagawa Train station - so not very convenient. Fortunately they provide a complimentary bus to the station.

This was a clean centrally located hotel that is part of a major hotel chain for those looking for that. While this caters to a business market more than a tourist market, it’s still a great place to tour the city from. Rooms are large and clean, with a decent view of some nearby gardens. People are friendly with the front desk having several people who spoke excellent English. It was less than a 5 minute walk to shinagawa station that is easily navigable even without a strong understanding of the neighborhood or train system.

It’s rare that a Marriott disappoints and this one is no exception. From our reception at check in to the room and amenities. The restaurant breakfast was excellent especially the eggs Benedict. The executive lounge was spacious with the snack/dining offerings being quite good. Surprisingly the liquor/wine/beer is gratis - almost unheard of in most Marriott lounges. The concierges were very helpful (Thank you Saki) with guidance on getting around and tour suggestions. Should we get bs k to Tokyo this is where we’ll stay.

From the moment we arrived we were treated with the upmost warmth and welcome. The gentleman that checked us in was utterly charming along with his female colleagues. Our room was amazing, they have honestly thought of everything to ensure that their guests have a comfortable stay. We dined in the restaurant which was Devine and the array of culinary delights at breakfast were amazing. Don’t hesitate to come here, just come! You won’t regret it.

Nice rooms. Executive lounge is well-appointed. Excellent service. Train station is a bit of a walk in the heat, but taxis are convenient. Close to Haneda Airport- about 5 miles. If. coming from Narita, recommend limo bus - approximately a 2 hour ride.

The Marriott hotel is well situated hotel in Tokyo. If you can have access to the executive lounge, the view is fantastic.Customised services are outstanding and concierge is very efficient.Only concern is the choice of in situ restaurants for lunch or dinner which is not poor, but you have nice options nearby and again concierge will help to find what you are looking for.

Doing a distinctly occidental brand in a distinctly oriental culture is tricky. Still there is a standard of customer service that Marriott maintains very well. They care and it shows. Having said that, if you have expectations for great western food prepared like Marriott does elsewhere . . . well, it's okay but fell short. Even the classic Marriott hamburger, not a difficult option, fell short. Breakfast was an exception and a delight. The rooms are a nice size and meet expectations but strangely had limited drawer space. As we stayed for five days and wanted to unpack, we couldn’t. We basically had to live out of our luggage.

the location is really good, either for Business or Vacations. The hotel is really close to the central station and around the hotel, you can find a lot of options for shopping, drink and eat. The services of the hotel are excellent and the breakfast option is amazing. the cons? I think the room is small and the English level from some of the employees was not good.

While certainly more flashy and new than the Sheraton Miyako, the Marriott disappointed in many ways. The location is about a 15 minute walk to Shinagawa station, though they do run a bus service 3 times an hour. But step out of the hotel for a walk, and it’s a pretty dingy location. Nothing much around. As a Marriott Platinum member, I was offered an upgrade. So basically the same room type but on a higher floor. Why that’s an upgrade, I have no idea. Availability for better room types showed on their booking page, so I’m disappointed that the “space available upgrade” meant being a couple of floors higher. Other benefits were complimentary breakfast, lounge access and 20% off food & drink at the restaurant.In fairness the lounge was nice with a good number of options for the light evening meal service. It was very crowded even for a Sunday evening, so get there early. Breakfast had good variety compared to the Sheraton. The problem I had here was that none of the food items was labelled on a Monday morning. Guests were asking each other if they knew what the food items were. I complained about this twice and was told that for some reason they didn’t have labels for that morning (????). Overall it’s a pleasant hotel to stay in, nice rooms, modern an decent food. I wouldn’t really stay again and go for a place where I’d get a better upgrade. I would also say that I didn’t find the staff particularly welcoming or friendly. They’re not rude, but not as warm and smiley as at the Sheraton.

30th anniversary trip, staff so polite friendly and helpful, room spotlessly clean and comfortable. Booking agent had got bed configuration wrong for one of our two rooms, but no problem to sort on check in. Free mobile w-fi phone set for each room, so no need to but expensive wi-fi package. Restaurant and bar service attentive and knowledgeable. This is a great hotel, would definitely stay here again. Colin McQ Bridgend UK
user_name:
Colin M
Bridgend County, United Kingdom

review_body: Tokyo Marriott Hotel is conveniently located within a 5 minute walk near the Shinagawa Line and a 20 minute taxi from the Haneda International airport. A very clean Marriott with all the things that you have come to expect at Marriott. Good location to get around Tokyo by rail or taxi, but this location is not in the heart of the city.

After 16hr of travel, wanting to check in. Reception informed me I had to wait for 3,5 hrs because they first had to check out 140 guests. Ater sharing my unhappiness, they did manage to get me an available room. The room however smelled very much like stale smoke. They did find another room quite fast after I told them about it, though.Room has closet with hangers, but no drawers! So where do you keep your t-shirts and socks??There’s no hotel-bar, apart from members-lounge, and restaurant is quite small for the number of rooms; it does not serve typical Japanese food, which I think is a missed chance.Service is friendly, but facilities are below standard for a hotel with this rate.Fitness and massage desk clerks don’t speak English, which is not helpful when trying to get information or making a booking. No free entrance to fitness or swimming pool! For tourists, it’s too far from highlights, nothing to do in close proximity. For business, too little conveniences and service.Not a repeater.

Spent 3 nights at Marriott Shinagawa last April. And the experience was very good.The room was immacolate and extremely cleaned. It was very spacious compairing other Hotels in Tokyo of the same categories. Nespresso coffee mashine was Waiting for me Inside the room and I appreciated this so much.Breakfast was really very good and full of fresh fruits. Reception is small and not so confortable for this kind of hotel.This hotel in Tokyo will be my first choise also for the next time.

I just completed an 8-night stay for business. The staff was courteous and quite helpful throughout my stay, especially Racel, a member of the Front Dek team. Their command of English was excellent. (I called the Front Desk once, put the phone on speaker, and the Front Desk staff member spoke in Japanese to my taxi drive to direct him how to get me back to the hotel from Midtown Tokyo - very helpful to me!) The Platinum Member benfits were notable and appreciated, especially the courtesy full breakfast and evening Executive Lounge services. The Excecutive Lounge on Floor 26 offered excellent views and comfortable work areas, with coutesy snacks and drinks and convenient access. The courtesy bus shuttle to/from Shinagawa Train Station was helpful and timely (every 20 minutes). My room on the 23rd Floor was cleaned very well and promptly every day. And given the heat and humidity during the week, I appreciated the two courtesy bottles of water provided each day. There is no doubt in my mind about this - I will certainly stay here again during my next business trip to Tokyo.

Stayed here for a family trip, the staff were all very friendly and accommodating to our requests. The rooms were immaculate and very spacious. Can't recommend enough and will certainly be returning in the future.

The location: not too far away from the city and public transportationRoom: clean but a bit worn and old Lounge: well definitely could be better a bit small and food is okish... breakfast: great with a large selection of products.Staff: polite and offering a great service

I was advised to stay here since it’s next door to my company’s office and it was a great choice and suggestion. The hotel front desk were very nice and polite, the room was very very good. The whole experience at this hotel was amazing. Their breakfast was one of the best I had in japan. The staff working in the restaurant were great. I was served many times at lunch and breakfast by Alicia and she was amazing. The bell staff were great too. Overall, I highly recommend this Marriott hotel even though I’m a Hilton loyal. I think the Marriott hotels in the US need to learn how to be good like this one. I will for sure stay here again, and stay at Marriott property in Asia as they seem better managed than the USA counterparts.

A typical business like Hotel. Big room size, but too dark of the lighting. For leisure travel, it is not a convenience location to stations to go to city. Cool front desk service, not expect too much and just sleep. Fortunately, we met a senior concierge staff who took care of our earliest car booking and baggage which make our trip smoothly goes on.

Stayed 5 nights. Close to Shinagawa station. Very convenient for us to get around with our JR Rail pass. Free shuttle to station every 20 minutes. More often at peak times. As a platinum member we had a great free breakfast in the main restaurant. Had nice room 19th floor with nice view towards Tokyo bay.

But not very good:The location is convenient and clean.The premises are in good conditions, and the check in was very pleasant : thanks and congratulations to the lady ‘Saki’. Very professional attitude and efficient.The room was fine, comfortable bed, bathroom ok, maybe the towels need replacement by new ones, more fluffy and bigger in size.The proximity of the railway could be heard during the night, not good.In terms of food, we tried the restaurant by the lobby, I guess it was satisfactory but we were disappointed no Japanese food was available.The lounge on the 26th floor offers a nice view and is comfortable.No breakfast available but coffee, tea with some fruits and sweets.For the evening bites, there again a bit disappointed, no Japanese delicacies but ‘Mexican’ nachos with guacamole, peanuts and a wide choice of lollies and sweets (cheap stuff not healthy at all!)Decent variety of drinks, wines and beers available.Overall a good experience but not Great!

This is my second business trip in a row where I opted to stay at the Marriott Tokyo near Shinagawa station. Easy access from Narita via the NEX straight to Shinagawa, then a short 15 minute hike to the hotel on the hill. The breakfast is AMAZING, and I find I only need two meals per day after stocking up on a delicious breakfast. This trip I found a 24 hour coin operated laundry (Kojima Coin Laundry) that is 10 minute walk from the hotel and I leveraged my early morning jet lag to catch up on some laundry, explore the area near Gotanda metro stop, and watch the residents wake up!

Free shuttle bus every 20 minutes to and from Shinagawa station makes it convenient.Food choice in restaurant quite limited and when full (which is most nights as no other restaurants in the immediate vicinity) service can be quite slow. Food is excellent however, as is the service.Decent gym. Railway side rooms can be quite noisy.

This isn’t the worst Marriott but it’s definitely below average. We stayed here in 2 rooms for 3 nights in August as part of a 10 night stay in Japan at 3 Marriott hotels.As a Marriott Rewards member, next time I will stay again at Prince Sakura Tower in Shinagawa (amazing! But pricey) or perhaps Courtyard by Marriott in Ginza.If you aren’t a Marriott Rewards member, and want to stay in Shinagawa, check out the Prince Hotels. They are closer to the station, offer a more Japanese experience, and may have better service and room quality. Pros* great value / low cost* rooms were clean* very nice executive club with great food and views. The hotel wasn’t very busy when we were there but we didn’t have the problem with a busy exec lounge that others reported* amazing breakfast buffet that was included for Marriott rewards members. Very good service at the BuffettCons* the rooms! It was hot in August and for some reason the hotel room A/C has the rooms uncomfortably humid. The beds were sticky wet. Gross. Never in 550 Marriott hotel nights have we ever felt it. Very uncomfortable. One of our rooms got down to 70 degrees but the other couldn’t get below 75.* feels like any American Marriott. No Japanese restaurant. You won’t feel like you are in Japan, which to me on vacation was the point of going. This feels like a Sacramento or Kansas City Marriott. The plus side is everyone working there speaks English * 15 min walk from shinagawa station. Not terrible and part of the train it’s a bargain but it gets old. They do have a free shuttle but we liked to walk from Sakura Tower* few if any other restaurants within 10 minute walk. Many 10-20 min. How is this even possible in Tokyo?!!!* the front desk staff was Very Disapponting- concierge refused to reserve us a table at a restaurant- front desk refused to mail a stamped envelope with our WiFi router return for us* housekeeping - didn’t clean our used wine glasses but instead put a new paper lid on them and in general did a poor job cleaning up

At first the location of the hotel may not seem very nice. In fact the area around is a bit boring. But still the location in very comfortable! From Shinagawa station you can go anywhere you want. When you arrive at Haneda (which I recommend) it only takes about 15 minutes to reach Shinagawa station. From the station there is a free bus service to the hotel (look for Gotanyama trust city) But it's an easy walk which should take less then 10 minutes. Further the station is on the Yamanote line and the Shinkansen for Kyoto, Osaka and Hiroshima. The service is very friendly and reception really try to help you. they are very helpful if you need information about the area. The room is spacious and if you have a high floor you have a nice view over the railways. This can also give some noises of the trains passing by all the time. The bathroom is also spacious and complete, but it could use more light and a little update. I wasn't impressed with the breakfast. First of all, it's not cheap and mostly focussed on asian breakfast. For "Western" taste the choice was limited. Above that it was also so busy there was a huge line waiting to be seated. I prefer to go to Shinigawa and have a coffee and something to eat there. The WiFi in the hotel wasn't the best I ever seen. Streaming videos had difficulties sometimes loading, but for general browsing it's sufficient.The hotel is a nice place and the spacious rooms is something hard to find in a city like Tokyo!

We stayed in this hotel for 4 nights and enjoyed it very much. Location is good, the room was huge and very well maintained. The morning buffet is special and the quality of the food is superb. Overall I highly recommend this hotel.

I’m really picky. Always looking for a quality hotel at a fair price. I found one at the Tokyo Marriott in Shinagawa . I was traveling with my 17 year old son and wife. We loved the free shuttle bus to the train station. From here it was a 15 minute ride to anywhere in Tokyo . I am not sure why people complained about the location- as this hotel would be double the price in Ginza! Other items we loved:- The Lounge on the 23 floor- Beautiful Japanese garden- Great breakfast buffet with English and Japanese items free for platinum or gold members- Pool access - free bottle water in the room- Free Shuttle to shinagawa station- excellent concierge for booking restaurants and tours - family room booked with an extra bed.- friendly staff I can’t recommend this hotel enough.Ps there are excellent restaurants near the Shinagawa station .

Allows full families to enter executive lounge and take space when the typical policy for lounge is 1+1, they also do not prioritize those that have been loyal to the hotel chain, in my case for 25 years. Makes people wait for lounge space sending them to a holding area on the ground floor with no windows and no clean-up or plates and glasses. Sad that the Tokyo Marriott has done this and does not respect long time customers.

Most hotels in Japan have great service. This is no exception. The location is nice, near the Gotenyama gardens, with greenery around. The hotel has a frequent free bus shuttle to and from Shinagawa station that takes about 5 - 6 minutes. Gym and lounge access is available tor Gold Elite members (may change once the programs for SPG and Marriott merge). Food choices are limited to the restaurant in the lobby area - distinctly average with higher than usual prices (Westin in Meguro-ku is much better). Also, the rooms and facility is ok with increasing need of a refresh. Mattresses too are getting lumpy. Finally, be mindful of the location of the room, there's the train side facing Kita-Shinagawa station and the quieter side.

Stayed a week for business, was half hoping they could upgrade this long stay. Didn’t happen but I won’t fault them. Each staff member were respectful and friendly when approached. Room amenities were full and Housekeeping services were impeccable. After asking for 4 bottles of water for the first 2 days, I wished they could pick it up as a daily thing for a Long stay guest but they didn’t. Used the Nespresso machine, was a good amenity.Probably time to renovate the shower area, bathtub was stained. But still a great and comfortable stay, frequent shuttle bus was a lifesaver.

I must say Marriott Hotel Shinagawa in Tokyo is amazing.We all know that Japan is an outstanding country in terms of education,service,respect,politness:Japan os leading and the other Countries follows.So all this values you can find on Marriiott Hotel Shinagawa:staff is ultra-kind! Suepr polite!! Rooms are very clean,so clean!! Food is very good! Gym is so good too! I want to thank the staff for their very nice approach! I like this Hotel and hos servoce.Speciall mention to lobby restaurant! Sevice so good!! Thank you Mr.Ben!!I will be back again here:next time for holiday!

I selected this hotel as it's location is in Shinagawa and I had a return train from Kyoto that stopped at this station. While the hotel appears to be within walking distance of Shinagawa station, I'd highly recommend taking the free Marriott shuttle bus from/to the station or a taxi - as it is a good 10 minute ride by car. Also it's a bit confusing to find the bus stop at Shinagawa station so you may want to investigate the location beforehand.As to the hotel - the property seems to have been very recently renovated as all public areas and rooms are upgraded and modern. The lobby is enormous and reception is actually located quite a distance from the front door - the entire lobby is pretty much occupied by the lobby restaurant.The rooms are typical Tokyo size - as mentioned upgraded and modern - only no electrical outlets next to the bed (pet peeve). Bed and bedding were very comfortable and there is a Nespresso machine as well as a hot pot for tea in the room. The bathroom is a good size with a combined tub/shower - believe some rooms may have a separate shower stall set up.We had a breakfast included rate at the lobby restaurant and there was an enormous, good selection of Western and Asian choices, including an egg/waffle station. The breakfast gets very, very busy with the restaurant filling up. Recommend earlier the better to beat the crowd.I did not use the fitness center as it had an open time of 7am (too late for me) - it is located in the tower next to the hotel and I believe it is a private facility shared between the hotel and the public.I did use the Executive Lounge and found it to be one of the best lounges I've experienced in terms of food and drink choices available at Happy Hour as well as the fantastic view from the 28th floor.The location of the hotel is a bit "odd" for a tourist - probably great for business folks who work in the area. There are a couple of commercial areas - in either direction of the hotel, each about a 15 minute walk - and mainly comprised of restaurants, convenience stores and in 1 area lots of "night" life. These areas also each have a JR or subway line so with a short walk you can get to other more touristy areas of Tokyo (such as Shibuya which is a short train ride).The only minor issue occurred on my first morning where the Wifi suddenly stopped working - a call to Guest Services was fairly useless as I was told it is working when clearly it was not and there was no offer to at least investigate within my room or that part of the hotel But after about an hour it did start working again. Also we had a remote hotspot (picked up from the airport) which did not function in this corner of the hotel (9th floor) It may be a "dead spot" for coverage...Overall I'd recommend Tokyo Marriott - the service from the staff is top-notch - and once you figure out how to get around with some walking you can manage your way around both the local area and other parts of Tokyo.

We arrived at the Tokyo Marriott from an overnight flight, so looking to check in early. The reception were helpful and while we were waiting for our room to be prepared, gave us a complimentary entry to the exec lounge for a great view of Tokyo, drinks and snacks. The other notable benefit of this hotel, in common with many Marriott's is the free mobile phone for calls and loaded with maps, so making navigation easy around the streets and subways.The hotel is some way south of the centre, but with a free shuttle bus to the Shinagawa station.

Great staff, comfortable clean rooms, and nice bath amenities. Stayed here a few times and only issue is some train noise in the room if you are facing the tracks. Other than that, they need a place to sit by the front lobby as you wait for the buses and shuttles. Plenty of space for seating, just not there. Only a small bench outside, and in the high heat days...that sucks.

If you have lounge access, the lounge is great! Free alcohol, evening snacks which can substitute dinner, and great views. There is also a free smartphone to take out of the room and use if you don't have a cell plan for abroad.Only downside is that it's not really near any attractions. You'll need to walk about 10-15 minutes to get to the train station, which isn't a subway stop but rather a Japan Rail station (Shinagawa station).

The great:Awesome breakfast at the hotel restaurant for Gold and Platinum members. I've been to many hotel breakfasts, this one may be the best.The good: The hotel staff was overall very nice, and tried to be helpful. The mediocre: The regular concierge seemed to be on vacation or something, so other staff filled in, their helpfulness on a 1-10 scale ranked from 3 to 8. There is a hotel shuttle, but if you arrive in the Shinagawa station, there is no clue where to find it (bus stop 6 just south of the exit). It can be extremely crowded, as it is shared with an office building. Alternatively, a taxi to or from the station is about five dollars.The hotel gym and pool are also shared with the office building. The pool is nice, the gym mediocre. Oddly, hotel guests aren't allowed to use the lockers where locals put their shoes before entering the locker rooms. The gym doesn't open until 6, the pool until 7, which was annoying b/c given jet lag, there were nights I would have used the gym at 4 or 5 AM.The lounge was mediocre for us, because there was a very limited selection of soft drinks and snacks, and they didn't change. But if you drink alcohol, the free booze could save you a lot of money vs. going to a bar.The bad:We traveled as a family of 5, and requested connecting rooms well in advance. Oddly, the hotel apparently only has one connecting room (a suite), and that was booked, so we go rooms together. I'm not sure why, but even though one of us had paid an extra $20 a night for a room on a high floor (that was what was available at the time of booking), we were both put on a low floor (next to each other). No discount was offered for the "downgrade."The ugly:The rooms we were given directly overlooked a busy railroad track, with many trains coming to and fro. Considering how close the trains were, it wasn't very noisy, but compared to the noise levels one should expect at a good hotel, it was much, much noisier than it should have been. Fortunately, we were all exhausted from jet lag and touring so it didn't bother us too much, but under other circumstances I would have insisted on changing rooms and if nothing was available, changing hotels. There is no excuse in 2018 for not having proper noise abatement measures in the room. PS Our room with 2 double beds had a couch that could be slept on. We could have managed with 5 in a room if we needed to, if you have a family with 2 or 3 kids and 2 adults, you can consider whether you want to squeeze into one room or not.

It was beautiful but quite inconvenient location. In order to get there, only public transportation or taxi (or car) could access.The hotel was simply nice. You could view Shinkansen (bullet train) and local trains from your room yet relatively quiet.Only one restaurant was open when we stayed. The business building was attached to the hotel but over the weekend, it’s totally empty and no activities. Convenient store was in the same facility but limited items mainly bento boxes and snack.I doubt if I want to stay there again, however, if you have business around Shinagawa, it’s absolutely calm and relaxing place to stay. A bit boring for family stay.
user_name:
nyay
New York City, New York

review_body: We had 5 nights here anda very pleasant stay. Can't fault the service or room facilities. The staff were very friendly and helpful. We had a twin room for 3 of us, 30 square metres. We had enough space for luggage and didn't feel cramped. The beds were 2 semi doubles. I had to sleep with my 8y old as it would not be comfortable for 2 adults unless you're very small. The bathroom was fine and offered all the required toiletries. Breakfast offered all you would want with plenty of choice both western and Japanese. As club members we also had access to the lounge which offered plenty of snacks in the evening. There was no need to go out for dinner!The only downside of the hotel is the location. It's not a big deal as they have a frequent free bus which takes you down to shinigawa station and then easy to get anywhere. It's only about a 10 minute walk to the station but we were here in the heat of summer. Staying somewhere like Shinjuku you could just step outside and findings to do??The other downside for us was te pool which was not at all inviting. The room was hot, stuffy and was not the refreshing splash you need after a hot day out!

The hotel is located under a mile from the Shinagawa train station. There is a shuttle from the train station every 20 minutes or so. When we first arrived we could not figure out where the bus is. You need to exit the station towards Central Gate, look for the line of people waiting for taxis and turn left towards the Broadway store. Look for bus station number 6. Since we could not find the bus we took a taxi, it is 410 yen. We used the taxi several times and the price varied between 410 to 770 yen depending on traffic.We are a family and booked two rooms. We emailed the hotel prior to our arrival asking for connecting rooms and they said that they will try to accommodate us if rooms are available. When we arrived we learned that they only have suites that are connecting, no rooms. Since we are gold members we are eligible for an upgrade, but no connecting suites were available. We made a reservation for rooms on a high floor but we received rooms on a low floor because that's where the hotel had rooms on the same floor. So basically we got downgraded. If joining rooms are important to you, book suites or stay elsewhere.Staff was very nice. We liked Koichi who was helping in the concierge desk and the front desk. There was a young Japanese girl who was helping the concierge and we felt like she was doing a research project when we asked her a question. She had to look up everything, consult with others, and she was soft spoken. The last day we saw a Caucasian woman in the concierge desk but she was busy. I think that the hotel could use a native English speaker, who knows Tokyo well, in the concierge desk.As Marriott gold members we received lounge access. Breakfast is served in the dining room in the lobby. Breakfast was really nice with a lot of options. You can ask for omelette made to order, delicious French toast, waffle, there is an udon soup station, breads, cheese, meats, jams, smoked salmon, fish, rice, very nice fruit selection, juices, shakes, cereal. There is a Caucasian chef who makes very good omelettes. The breakfast is around 3200 yen otherwise.The lounge has appetizers from 5:30 to 7:30. They have guacamole, hummus, carrots, pretzels, cakes, kit Kat, gummy bears, hors d'oeuvres such as mini corn dogs, taco station, free alcohol, coffee machine and juices. It is a very nice spread and they are family friendly. My only suggestion for improvement is the hors d'oeuvres, they were not that great.We used the shuttle bus to the train once. It drops you off across from the station and you need to walk on a pedestrian bridge to cross the busy street. With a stroller it is not that pleasant. Also, since the bus arrives every 20 minutes starting at 7:30 am, if the bus was not there when we arrived we took a taxi to the station. If you are planning to walk a lot during the day I suggest not walking from the hotel to the station and back to conserve energy. The hotel is located south to central Tokyo. If I understood the geography better I would have stayed in the Shinjuku area. It would have been nice to have attractions within walking distance, which you don't have there.Make sure to pack ear plugs. Although the hotel is not next to the train station, our room was overlooking railroad tracks and you could hear the train late at night and early in the morning.

Stayed here twice in a week. First booked a family room for three and next booked two rooms, this time for me and my wife and a seperate room for adult daughter. Now that Marriott and SPG have combined, being a platinum SPG member for so many years, I thought I would experimented and try the category 8 Marriott in Tokyo rather than being safe and staying with SPG.I had read reviews about the location being near the Shinagawa Station. And shuttles available for guests. Positive. But that’s where the compliments stop.Let me start with the executive club which some poor guests pay extra for but I received complimentary as being a platinums member.Well if you like children under 10 running amok while seeking sanctuary look else where. It’s more a crèche than a executive lounge. How a professional hotel allows such poor standards I just don’t understand. Furthermore, the canapés, are average, the same almost night after night, we gave up and just didn’t bother and just went out for dinner without the noise, without children running around like it was a playground.One more observation, don’t stay here Saturday night and expect to get a seat in the club lounge. We couldn’t, gave up and left but watched as some leaned against walls, having a drink and canapé as extends families enjoyed the facilities.Upgrade was non existent, breakfast buffet in the morning is pedestrian, coffee is so abysmal, it was an insult to a coffee bean, and my senses.The one and only reason why this poor hotel doesn’t get one star is the staff. They are lovely, do their best to please. What a shame they are let down by management not having the processes and systems to recognise premium guests and then afford them the sanctuary of the executive lounge in the evening.Unfortunately I prepaid my second visit otherwise I would have canceled and stayed at the tried and true Westin in Ebisu.Tired and failed, this hotel doesn’t deserve to have the Marriott name until some fundamental changes are made to accommodate premium customers.

Very comfortable stay, the hotel staff were outstanding in thoughtfulness and consideration. Room was very comfortable with a great view of Shinagawa Station and Tokyo Tower. Delicious food in the restaurant, breakfast included on my plan. Outside, a beautiful garden not to be missed. Convenient if you are going to be traveling on Shinkansen (a 5 minute taxi ride to the Shinkansen platform). Well worth it!
user_name:
lizf2014
Santa Rosa, CA, United States

review_body: It was great to see the exec. lounge is now moved to 26th floor which has a nice view. As there are many platinum members, the upgrade to Suite seems to be always impossible, but still the executive room at high floor is clean and nice with a view. I loved egg/waffle station and squeezed juice. Staff members were very kind and helpful. A Korean staff at the lounge - Sarah Sim - assisted my check out and she was professional and kind. Shuttle service to Shingawa was helpful for the trip. Swimming pool is clean and well maintained as well.

This is a luxury hotel in every sense.The staff are highly professional and extremely courteous (of course).The rooms are spacious and well appointed. Breakfast is a wide selection of western and Japanese food. Set up as a buffet, you can also request an omelette (other cooked foods) and provide the staff with a small wooden flag identifying your table. The meal is then delivered to your table.Business Lounge is very well managed with a variety of snacks. The location is nearby convenient the Shinagawa Train Station.

This hotel is a 10 minute walk from the Shinagawa Train Station but is tucked into a heavily wooded beautifully designed setting. There is a lovely garden area with several waterfalls, and it's so quiet you can hear lots of birds. The service is excellent, and if you are at least a gold Marriott Rewards person, you have access to the Executive Lounge which has wonderful snacks and drinks. The rooms are larger than other hotels in Japan. I will definitely come back here if I return to Japan. The hotel is good for everyone--families, business, singles, couples.

We loved the Tokyo Marriott in every regard. At first, we were afraid it would be inconvenient for our Tokyo exploration, because Shinagawa, while a major area, is not in the thick of things in Tokyo. However, it was very easy to explore Tokyo from this location. The hotel is a 10 minute walk to Shinagawa station, or there is a free city-bus shuttle that runs 3 or 4 times an hour to the station, which takes 1-2 minutes. Shinagawa Station is actually really nice - good food, nice shops - one of the nicer stations in Tokyo. Shinagawa is on the Yamanote line, the JR Line that goes in a circle around all the major large areas in Tokyo, which was perfect for us. As for the hotel (almost forgot!), it was fabulous - very friendly staff, excellent restaurant, great rooms and nice views. If you don't mind staying a bit outside the very center of the city, you will not be disappointed with a stay at the Tokyo Marriott.

Easy access to mass transportation. Nice rooms with the toilets Japan is known for. Good mix of breakfast options whether you are from the west or east. Not many extra amenities - but if there for business don’t always have extra time to enjoy these anyway. Staff were extremely attentive and helpful.

The hotel is very nice with clean rooms. It is about 5/8 minute walk from a large train station that can pretty music get you anywhere in the city. I used the train very day. The hotel has a nice restaurant and bar area.

My daughter and I are travel pros. We decided to do something different for our big summer vacation. We settled on Japan and stayed at the Tokyo Marriott Hotel. Great location, great staff, great everything!! If you arrive at Narita, you can take the Narita Express (part of the JR Line if you have a JR Pass), you get off at Shinagawa Station (one hour via train) and hop on a bus for a < 5 minute ride to the hotel. You can walk, but with my 10yo daughter and our luggage it was better to hop on the bus. I was originally put off by the bus aspect, but don't let this put you off. It drops you off in front of the hotel and if you are going the opposite way, it drops you off in front of Shinagawa Station. We used it each day then hopped on the JR Line to see the sights of Japan.We were given access to the Executive Lounge which is on the 26th floor. There is happy hour each night. My daughter liked to go to the lounge and look at the view of Tokyo and the planes landing at Haneda while relaxing after a long day in Tokyo on her iPad.The entire team was top notch. Always a warm smile, a "konichiwa," or "ohio gozaimasu" whenever we passed someone in the hallway or lobby.My daughter did not want to leave...neither did I. A truly remarkable trip to Tokyo and an even better stay at Tokyo Marriott Hotel.

Hotel delivered to my expectation of any Marriot hotel.Close to train station with free shuttle bus (schedule varies).Good breakfast spread.Good views from the lounge and good variety of drinks.Room is large (for Tokyo!) and comfortable.

I have stayed at this hotel annually since before it became a Marriott 3-4 years ago. It is an excellent hotel and certainly meets all expectations for an international 5-star property. The hotel is conveniently located near Shinagawa Station with free scheduled shuttle (mini-bus) service between the hotel and station (and return) throughout the day and into the evening. Inexpensive train service is available from this station on the JR line and several others to all over Tokyo, and this is also a Shinkansen station. The hotel is far enough from the station to be away from most of the noise and crowds, but close enough for a casual walk if you don't want to take the shuttle. The rooms are very nice, large, clean and up to date. The beds and linens are very comfortable and the rooms are attractive. The executive lounge, recently relocated to the 26th floor, is comfortable and has a good selection of drinks and food along with an excellent view. I recommend upgrading to an executive floor in order take advantage of the lounge if you don't already have status with Marriott. The restaurant serves an elaborate and excellent breakfast (free with Marriott status) as well as lunch and dinner. The staff are excellent - friendly, very helpful, cheerful, and knowledgeable. This is a wonderful hotel and I plan to return next year.

Loved the stay. The hotel is close to walking distance to Shinagawa station. I happen to get an end room that overlooked the station, the city and toTokyo tower. It was quite a view. The hotel also provides a cellphone free of cost for the customers for the duration of your stay. This came in very handy when I went into the city to look up maps and location. It was a great!!

The hotel, rooms, club room and breakfast are very nice. Rooms are large for Tokyo. Breakfast buffet was extensive an excellent. Good location for the Shibuya area, but a bit far for some other areas. Service was very high standard.

This property isn't too far from the airport - but you'll want to take a taxi or bus; the train station is too far if you are lugging bags. The rooms are clean and the hotel is priced well for business travelers. The lobby is slightly hidden - you walk around the lounge and breakfast area towards the elevators and it is off to one side.

We stayed 5 night and thought the hotel as a whole was 5 out of 5. The staff, room, and restaurant were outstanding. People were polite and helpful. The restaurant had a wide selection of food to satisfy anyone’s whim. Western or Asian. The executive lounge was great. It has a wonderful view of the city and much more. Good place to chat and relax with a cold drink or a snacks.

The location of that hotel just near the Shinagawa station is really convenient. You can take the shuttle bus to the station or just walk about 10 mn to be there. And from Shinagawa station everything is quiet near. For the rest, hotel to the Marriott standards with dedicated staff. Maybe a bit expensive but you are in Tokyo. I can recommend. Upper floor with nice view.

Dining is limited but the staff was very helpful and the breakfasts were excellent as very close to train station. The rooms were well designed and very clean. A good gym was next door to the hotel. Would stay again

We stayed here for ten consecutive nights. In terms of overall rating we would give it a 4.5 out of 5. We will stay here again when in Tokyo. Staff were excellent and so helpful. The Executive Lounge has an awesome view and lots of goodies/drinks all day long. The breakfast buffet on the main floor is superb with a fantastic variety of hot and cold foods, both North American and Japanese. The only caution is Sunday mornings they are quite busy and run out of food. We had good sleeps in our king-size bed and we were happy with our corner room. Nicely appointed and kept clean and tidy each day. It is about a ten minute walk downhill to the Shinagawa train station and you can take their shuttle bus if that works better. The Shinagawa station offers the Yamanote or Circle Line so that is an advantage when navigating around Tokyo. Noise can be a challenge as you are near the train tracks. Take ear plugs? Another prompt is the internet/wifi can be very slow or not working at some peak times.

Rooms in the upper part of the hotel are good. Lower part specially the ones where the railroad is are noisy. It is a hotel for business guests. Service in the dining section is slow specially when large groups are using the dining facilities .
user_name:
Tulipkingstonhill
Kingston upon Thames, United Kingdom

review_body: Our room on 11th floor was very bland in color, lacked walls decoration and 7 pieces of furniture, without common style, looked like leftover from furniture sale. The bathroom tiles were in need of mildew cleaner. The only pleasant surprise were 2 firm, comfortable beds. The hotel is located in close proximity of very busy Shinagawa train station, so ear plugs are “a must” for restful night. The hotel restaurant serve only western food. The hotel staff is very helpful.Recommended if you must stay only.Gina

I stayed at this hotel for four nights in May. The room on the fourth floor was extremely comfortable and had a nice view over the garden. The staff at the hotel were brilliant and the concierges in particular went above and beyond. The bar restaurant area has a nice atmosphere and is lovely and bright. The main drawback for me is the very limited menu in the restaurant which had almost no vegetarian options and too much western food. This didn’t matter because we went to some excellent traditional Japanese food. Conference and business facilities at the hotel are good, although there were not enough places to have meetings due to the restaurant being closed for non-guests before 11am

Three outstanding people are Natsumi Tatsuzawa, Rachel Cananan, and Galova Marketa.Thank you for a great stay. Our only drawback is my profile choice of rooms has the king size up, which is up against the wall, which is fine for the Traveler but not the Husband and Wife at our age. However, the staff was sympathetic.

nice hotel near to the main station and a free shuttle bus to get you there. The main reception is very open and not very welcoming, but the the rooms were very nice and the toilet was amazing!! Heated seat, spray wash and dry and numerous other buttons.

Tokyo Marriott never disappoints. This is always my favorite place to stay in the Tokyo area. In addition to great service, the hotel is near Handea Airport and Shinagawa Station. The Executive Lounge has much to offer with very attentive staff.

We stayed here for 3 nights whilst visiting Tokyo. The hotel is about 10 minutes walk or a ¥600 taxi ride from Shinagawa Station. There is also a free shuttle bus every 20 minutes.Check in was quick and friendly and we went to our room on the 8th floor. The room was small but managed to fit a desk and a separate chair in so that was good. Two things spoiled it for us - the bed was against the wall so if I got up in the night I had to crawl down the bed before I could walk on the floor. Also, there was no pelmet around the window so from about 5AM the room was too light for sleep.The amenities were great, the heated toilet a novelty and the bed was very comfy. There was some train noise but not too intrusive. The staff were excellent here, particularly the concierge and bell staff. They arranged my luggage forwarding faultlessly and were a very useful source of advice.

Very comfortable hotel amidst the expansiveness and busyness of Tokyo. We experienced a very seamless and tranquil guest experience which included a quiet and clean guest room along with some nice evenings spent in the executive lounge overlooking Tokyo Bay and the surrounding area. The gardens next to the hotel were a great place to walk and reflect and the surrounding neighborhood, which at first glance appears to be "just residential", proved to be very interesting to explore with some nice surprises in terms of food, shops, architecture, people and parks. Proximity to one of Tokyo's main train station was very convenient to either walk to or take the easy shuttle bus. We trained or took the subway all over Tokyo and enjoyed being welcomed back to the tranquility of the Marriott each day. Pleasant and friendly staff topped off a nice stay.

We’ve stayed at Marriotts all over the world and I would have to rate this one an ‘average ‘ at best. First of all, I’d written the concierge prior to our arrival and requested an upgrade to a room on a high floor, quiet, with one king sized bed (as a platinum elite benefit). The woman told me at checkin that nothing of the sort was available and gave us room on the 7th floor (709) that faced an office building and was so incredibly smelly of must and mold that an air freshener spray bottle was left in the room. The shower tiles were full of mold as well. We stayed here four nights. The redeeming factor of this hotel was the breakfast buffet in the lobby each morning. The executive lounge had the SAME stale tacos every night, which really got old. We will definitely seek out a different hotel the next time we are in Tokyo.

As a Gold member through SPG, this was my first stay to try out a Marriott before the programs merge in August. I wanted to see what it was like and as a result, I can say that I will not be staying at a Marriott ever again which includes SPG / Ritz Carlton hotels brought into the same program. I don’t believe I’m entitled to anything or expect a lot but my stay was just a huge disappointment. The cheapest room rate included lounge access which Gold members already have so there was no benefit in having the membership in this case for me, but then again, the lounge was nothing to write home about and was just a glorified waiting room.Maybe I’ve been spoiled by the Executive and Club Lounges at Hilton and Intercontinental respectively where there is proper food, but the Marriott lounge provided just snacks. Paying nearly $550 AUD (over 44,000 yen) for one night, I expected more than just chips, carrot sticks, Kit Kats, cookies and muesli bars. Unfortunately, that’s what they had and to make things worse, when the staff saw the chips bowl empty (which I didn’t even get to have because some guy took it all), it wasn’t refilled but the bowl was just taken away. Arriving straight from the airport, I was checked in and at the lounge before 9pm. As I entered, there was one cake and some ice cream in the fridge. Decided to have some ice cream and cake after whatever snacks were left but when I thought it was time to try the dessert, they were gone. I didn’t see it but it was taken away before I knew it. This was before 9.30pm and the lounge closes at 11.30pm. I understand cleaning time is required for the staff but this is just cake and ice cream rather than hot food so I don’t believe cleaning would be too difficult? Maybe it’s kept for the next night so no cleaning is even required? I think a more appropriate time would have been 10.30pm but even if that’s not possible, the staff should have notified the guests that it was being taken away. Even restaurants tell guests it’s time for last order.The room itself was also very tired, shower/bath tub was dirty and the amenities box was broken. This is definitely not a room worth paying over 44,000 yen for. I can accept that there was no room upgrade available because it was Golden Week holiday in Japan so no empty rooms, however, being told the 'Guaranteed 4 p.m. Late Checkout' was not available either started to make me agitated. This hotel is not a 'resort and convention hotels' according to the T&Cs where late checkout is ‘subject to availability’. There was no mention while booking that because it was Golden Week the benefit would be ‘subject to availability’. The site T&Cs do not mention 'subject to availability' but instead it is 'guaranteed'. I have read both the English and Japanese websites and both say 'guaranteed'. The only time it said 'subject to availability' was in Japanese when the staff handed the explanation of Gold member 'benefits' sheet. Is each hotel allowed to have their own separate T&Cs? After politely trying to speak with the staff to request late checkout, she went as far as to say that guests should have known that it was not available because there were no rooms due to the busy season. This was the final straw. Excuse me?? This is about room management because the hotel knows how many Gold and above members have this benefit when they booked the room and the hotel will also have statistics on how many members are likely to make use of it so it should have taken this into account when management availability rather than just saying it was not available. Do not put this obligation back onto the guests. It was just plain rude and absolutely appalling. I don’t even expect the cheap APA or Toyoko Inn business hotels in Japan to have this type of attitude at 10,000yen a night so paying this price for this ‘service’ was just unacceptable. As an IHG Ambassador, I have always had 4pm checkout because it is a 'guaranteed' benefit when I stay at Intercontinental and they don’t try to change the terms to suit them. The only thing decent was the breakfast but that was normal and nothing fancy, especially for the price paid.With such a poor lounge (pretty but that’s about it), dirty and old room, bad service and basically no benefits for being an elite member, I will not be staying at another Marriott chain hotel again and as SPG is becoming Marriott as well, I’ve given up on Sheraton / St Regis etc. I can accept all benefits not available if I’m notified in advance but being told I’m responsible I should know a benefit would not be available was just shocking to say the least. The name Marriott will bring back this horrible experience for me and I won’t be able to have a good relaxing time anymore. As a result I’ll be sticking to Hilton / Conrad and Intercontinental.
user_name:
Jim W
New South Wales, Australia

review_body: My wife and I stayed at the hotel for one night, got the deluxe room with amazing city view and enjoyed our stay. The room is spacious, especially when comparing to other hotels we stayed at in Japan. The wifi in the room is great, AC is amazing, the bathroom and shower are enormous, and overall it was a very positive experience for our last night in the city. You get a free wifi device that you can take and use while walking around the city (and also can be used as a phone). The water bottles in the mini-bar are complimentary.The staff was amazing and helpful. Few small annoyances (if to be picky)- It's about 15 min walk to the nearest train station - Which is not too far but uncomfortable when carrying suitcases. We had no idea (and I don't think it was communicated) that we can take a complimentary bus ride from the train station - We were told that there is a bus that can take us directly to the airport. When we boarded the said bus, it took us to the train station. I assume it's just a communication/language barrier. - The prices at the bar are outrages. Almost $20 for a glass of plum wine with soda. Save yourself the trouble; the cocktails are not that good and priced double if not more than in any bar in the city.With all that - It's most definitely a 5-star experience, and you will enjoy your stay

Spent 6 nights here for a family trip from the US. The hotel is located adjacent to a business center while also nestled within the Trust City neighborhood area. We absolutely loved the Japanese garden right outside the building, the walking route and the early morning neighborhood gathers at 6:30am for their morning stretch. The closest station is a 15 min walk, however, we never waited more than 5 minutes for the free shuttle bus to the station and never made the trek. The station is a major station with the JR line and Tokyo subway lines coming together. We could access every major city area within 4 stops. As platinum elite, we were treated with the upmost service. From an amazing breakfast buffet, to a small M lounge, things got crowded during the Golden week and the staff did their best to make more room, accommodate the overflow and lines, even allowing us a spot to sit and bumping a gold elite at the M lounge during its craziest moment.. Every single staff member was paying attention and well aware of all going on around them with every desire to serve the patrons of the hotel. The only down side was the gym, the weights were a little out dated but I took to more outdoor running around the super cute neighborhoods instead. We will absolutely return. We had a wonderful trip and an amazing opportunity for our 11 year to soak in the culture. Kudos staff.

It is a bit of a walk from the railway station or metro. there is indeed a scheduled shuttle, but not so frequent. Breakfast is quite big and reasonable even for a vegetarian like me. the lounge could do with bit more flair but that is ok. There is not much view from the hotel, and rooms are reasonable sized for Tokyo.

Excellent Room, Easy to Reach, Good Food. It was easy to reach hotel from Narita, Tokyo international airport. It is located in good place to reach to your desired destination. Rooms are very good and food is also very nice. I will recommend this to my friends.

We enjoyed 2 wonderful days at this beautiful hotel in Tokyo. It is conveniently located to the Shinagawa train station and we used the hotel shuttle several times to go to the Train station and nearby shopping and restaurant area. The hotel breakfast buffet in Japanese style was wonderful and we also enjoyed lunch in the restaurant. The hotel lobby is huge and the hotel staff ate very friendly and pleasant. The hotel concierge was very helpful in planning our daytime trips. If you are a Marriotts rewards member the 26th floor is great and accessible to rewards members. I definitely recommend this hotel

Except for the location I don't know what complains one could have. Yes, it is not 5 start rating because for that some superb services or other things are required but everything else is fine. Smaller things like the mobile check-in isn't provided which caused me to wait 30 minutes in the queue to check in. Lounge provided good choice of breakfast and service is also ok. Location is a bit far off from Metro therefore I used the shuttle which brought us to Shinagawa Station.

We stayed here with the family for a week. Upon arrival we discovered that our two room reservation didn’t have the note that they should be interconnecting. Yuta-san was helping us at the front desk. First, he was so warm and welcoming, even attempting his German with my German husband. Then he called housekeeping and arranged for connecting rooms, which turned out to be a suite. Truly above and beyond the call of duty. We also encountered this thoughtful service in the cafe. We ate there every morning and Marika (spelling ?) knew our drink order and as soon as she saw us would place our order even before we got seated. The rooms are clean and spacious, bigger than most rooms in Tokyo. The walk to and from the train station isn’t bad, and the shuttle is fast and frequent. We enjoyed our stay and would come back one day.

Beautiful hotel with great service but location is not that convenient unless taking taxi. Enjoy a good walk at the beautiful garden located behind the hotel. The room is beautiful and they have a great lounge for higher tier members access. There is a convenient store located below. The breakfast has a wide range food selection. Ambience : 5/5Bed       : 4/5Design  : 4/5Food     : 4/5Price.    : 4/5Service : 5/5

My 21 year old son and I stayed at the Moxy Tokyo for the last few days of our trip to Japan. We LOVED the hotel vibe, relaxed atmosphere, friendly staff and the funky aesthetic. The rooms are small (normal for Japan), but incredibly well designed and comfortable. The staff seriously go out of their way to make you feel welcome. The games are a great touch to use up time before a flight or just hanging out. General area isn't great, but we never felt unsafe and I would even travel and stay here as a single female. Can't rate this highly enough for good value in an incredibly expensive city.
user_name:
Sally J
Auckland Central, New Zealand

review_body: Very diverse nationalities yet standardized high quality hospitality services. Both English/Japanese skills are professional level. Staffs are very courtesy, polite, and willing to help.However, my experiences for stay was unpleasant, mainly poor WiFi.1. Poor signaling. Very hard to connect, and part of this reason, the initial authentication page was not even launched in my first night. 2. Poor speed. 2.6M attachment took me 25 min. to complete downloading.3. Poor connectivity. Always dropping my VoIP calls (every 3~5 min.), hard to hear/talk. Cleanliness issue:1. Few spots of Mold in shower2. Never got vacuumed during my 4 nights stayShuttle bus from Sinagawa-station:very conveniently located bus stops; however, other than peak hours, 20 min. intervals and the last from Station to Hotel is departing at 22:00. If we go for business dinner, it will def. miss the last bus.No food choices other than hotel restaurant in 10 min. range.No breakfast included for Y37,000/night stay and extra charge for swimming pool usage for above quality. To me, it's really low CP value

The shuttle bus from the hotel to Shinagawa station is very convenient. Getting to anywhere around Tokyo city is fast through taxis too, around 20-30 minutes. Rooms are good. The Breakfast is elaborate for a westerner.

Stayed 2 nights here while in Tokyo. I have been a long term SPG Platinum member concerned about the merger. No longer. The Executive Club on the 26th floor was exceptional. Far better than any SPG club lounges Ive experienced. The highllight of my stay was the Concierge member Shoko Hida. She was so great and arranged all of our city tours at the last minute. I’ve stayed at hotels all over the world and she is the new standard for me, the GOAT of Concierge service. When I go back to Japan, im staying here.

The Vibe: Newer Marriott in a Unique Building Environment – One of My Favs in Tokyo Location & Transit Options: Located 15min walk from North/West Shinagawa station exit. They also have a shuttle bus which picks up just outside the station and runs every 20min. Best way to get to hotel is either the Narita Express train to Shinagawa (then walk or hotel shuttle) or take a limo bus direct to the hotel. Some people say this hotel is not centrally located but nothing really is – Tokyo is very big and tourist and business locations are all over. What is important is a good transit connection and Shinagawa is one of the best – many lines, on the Yamanote loop line, and also contains one of the two Shinkesan bullet train stations to everywhere else across Japan.Room & Bath: Rooms are newly (last 5yrs) renovated and have all the normal Marriott amenities. There is a sitting couch and a round table as your business desk (this may actually be a negative as I’d prefer more of an official work desk setup). Higher floors have nice city view. Large (50”?) TV with good English channel selection. Kuerig coffee maker. Amenities (wifi, gym, pool, etc.): Wifi is very strong and consistent. You have free of charge access to local gym attached to the same building - and equipment and facilities are quite extensive (lots of free weights, indoor pool, tennis court). Food & Beverage: The hotel has a very nice lobby bar/restaurant also with an outside patio. There are also a couple nicer dining options on the upper floors. The breakfast buffet is wonderfully extensive and they have newly expanded their executive lounge and moved it to the top floor (it is now awesome compared to previous ground floor setup). There are also many external dining and drinking options if you want to take a short walk toward either Shinagawa or Gotenyama stations. Staff & Service Level: Staff if typical Japanese style with exceptional service and they are always willing to help. Misc.: One of the nicer Japanese gardens is directly behind the hotel. Would I Repeat?: Yes. A great choice at a reasonable price. One of my Tokyo favorites.

We stayed there for a wedding, a different story altogether. The room was brilliant, large and well appointed. Check in was not as easy as it should have been, with the receptionist rushing off periodically to finish up elsewhere. They also debited 20000 yen from my credit card, something that has not happened to me in years. I was told it would be used against any purchases I made in the hotel. Interestingly, my credit card company contacted me to verify my location as they feared fraudulent use and the amount was never charged. Meals there were excellent and it was only a 15 minute walk to the station which was fortunate as this hotel is not centrally located.

Arrived to Japan but had to stay in another hotel because this Marriot was full. For me, this hotel is wonderful because it is right beside the offices I came for meetings. The hotel personnel is great and very kind at all times!

This is not a hotel I recommend for business. It seems great for families. There are three train stations within walking distance (convenient) and their morning breakfasts are fantastic (hello to the Czech lady making the omelets, she's great). I discourage it for business because there is no adequate place to work. The room has a table (of a height with the accompany chair) that is not ergonomically friendly for typing. The lounge, same thing -- plush chairs you can sink into, which are good for cocktails, not good for work. They have a room called the Executive Lounge, which is 6000 yen, and whose name suggests its a business lounge. It is not. It is a daycare for three-generation families who revel in the free food and running space for children. There are no tables/desks set for working. Had they labled this room "Family room", then expectations would be set reasonably and I'd rate higher and I'd have gone in knowing to expect. But let's not kid anyone, don't call it an executive lounge when it's a space inappropriate for conducting work.

We have stayed at this hotel before. Good location near the Shinagwa train station. However, the room we have on the Executive level is a step down from previous visit and other Marriott hotels around the world we have stayed in. No light switch at the door so you can turn on lights before entering a dark room, no towel bars in bathroom to hang a towel, only one light switch panel for the whole room, only one small dresser drawer, no wall art or other cosmetic relief from bland grey walls, etc. None of the normal features of a room in the executive levels one would expect. We won’t be coming back. Big disappointment.
user_name:
Boyd W
Grand Forks, North Dakota

review_body: The location was great and the breakfast spread really good.The room was small but that was expected for Japanese standards. The service was excellent. We stayed there for 5 days and thoroughly enjoyed it.

Great hotel in Shinagawa close to the main JR station in Shinagawa. Great to have the 10 minute shuttle to the station but after hours you can walk 15-20 minutes or cab/Uber. Wish was closer to Shinagawa

This hotel share a building with an office complex close to the train station. Rooms are large and comfortable. Bathroom has the magical Japanese toilet with the heated seat.There is a bakery attached to the downstairs restaurant that opens at 10 AM, it is famous for the Curry Pan, which is feature on a local TV show.One minor detail about this location is the constant noise of the trains going in and out of the station nearby. Trains start running from early in the morning until after midnight.The staff is very courteous and friendly.

We stayed last week here, and all though the rooms are spacious, you can get a much better located hotel in Tokyo for the same price. The location is not cool at all must take the subway to get anywhere. The hotel knowing we were going for our honeymoon, gave us a small and outdated room. Luckily they agreed to change us to a better, bigger room ( Like the one we were expecting when we reserved). The room is big, decor outdated but with flowing amenities and Nespresso. We were charged 280 dollars, twice by the hotel, supposedly for “authorization” at check in. Not even told they were going to charge this amount, just asked for a credit card. I called to the hotel after checkout , and they had no idea what his charge was for, been waiting for a confirmation email from their behalf, that has not yet arrived. This was a huge imposition for us, since our credit card is now maxed out as a result of this charge. This hotel well deserves its mediocre rating, bad location, overpriced food, outdated rooms and hidden charges. Find somewhere cool in Shibuya or minato. HopeThis helps!

I’ve been living in Japan for a year and travelling around Japan with family for a little more than a week, we stayed at The Tokyo Marriott. I’ve always shared with my family how safe Japan is and how no one steals anything here.. except I guess if you stay here. The day before checking out I counted my money in my bag (which I leave in the room) and found out I was missing $300, my family knows that I keep my cash there and that I count it everyday or every other day. We’ve been staying in different hotels in Sapporo, Niseko, Tokyo and never had problems as I trust it will be safe in the room. On the last day I counted my cash again and found out someone stole cash.. the reception and concierge team were very helpful in doing an investigation but unfortunately no one can find an answer. I am still not happy as I work hard for my money and as I actually used to work with Starwood and Marriot group in the US and Australia. I would’ve given a 1 star rating as I was very furious, but Kenichi Asai from the Front Desk was very professional in handling my situation.

On August 23rd, I rated this Property 3 STARS and noted that this property would have received 5 STARS if it fixed two problems (1) An Executive lounge befitting a 5 Star Marriott and (2) Stop charging for Sauna, Steam and Pool which is the not in the same building as the Guest rooms. Well, the hotel has since fixed both of these major areas and it would be most appropriate to rate this property and the facility 5 STAR.The Executive lounge is now on a 26th floor and has a beautiful view and a great setting. The Hotel already has a great staff from the bell men to front desk and those in the Executive lounge so you can't go wrong when it comes to service and comfort. Also, as I mentioned in the earlier review, the hotel has a free shuttle to Shinagawa station and is extremely convenient to connect to rest of Tokyo and even Japan as all Shinkensen stop at Shinagawa station.Do book in advance as this hotel fills up quickly and is very pricey during holidays and peak season as it offers incredible service and a great location with free shuttle to the train station,.Thank you Tokyo Marriott for listening to guest feedback on Tripadvisor and making improvements.

On March 18, 2018, I arrived in Japan with my wife for vacation. We tried riding the limousine bus in Haneda Airport for less than 1000 yen. Since it was a Sunday, the bus ride only took us twenty minutes. From Tokyo station, you have to walk for around ten minutes to Marriott Hotel. In my case, it took me around fifteen to twenty minutes because I had to stop walking every once in a while due to backache. The weather on our second day there was really cold, reaching 2 degrees because it was raining. The people at Marriott Hotel were very courteous. They can speak English really well and assisted me when I asked where I can get a ride to Shibuya. Marriott Courtyard reception was located at the 4th Floor. If you are a member of the Marriott Courtyard, you will get a discount for breakfast at the LAVAROCK. Instead of paying 3,200 yen for breakfast, we only paid 2,000 yen. It was a pretty reasonable price for a complete breakfast. The hotel’s reception had a small lobby with a refrigerator that offered unlimited fruits, juices and candies for its members anytime they wanted. The Fitness Center was at the 3rd Floor where our room was also located. Our room was pretty small but it was fine with me.Fronting Marriott Hotel was a restaurant that offered subway sandwiches. At the back of the hotel was Starbucks and beside Starbucks was a convenience store. Located just one building after Marriott Hotel was a metro train station where you can ride for a minimum of 170 yen. From there to Shibuya, you will pay for almost 200 yen. Upon going home, we only had a walking distance from Marriott Hotel to the South side of Tokyo station. There was a bus named JR lines that could bring you to the airport for 1,000 yen however they only allowed passengers with one baggage to ride the bus. Since I had more than one baggage, I asked where I can ride another bus and I was told that just across the JR lines bus station, around 150 meters away, was Kainsai station where passengers with more than one baggage were allowed to ride the bus. It took us one hour from Tokyo Station going to Narita International Airport Terminal 2.

I have stayed at this hotel before and liked the Executive Lounge and its facilities. The lounge has now moved to a higher floor offering a better view but has dispensed with a key facility (computer access). So remember to bring your laptop or IPAD with you. I relied on the Executive Lounge providing this facility and was disappointed to find out that the computers were no longer provided. There was an added benefit this time round though. My room came with a free local/international call mobile and free internet access. I was very convenient to have on the go.It didn't bother me but those who are very light sleepers, this hotel is very close to the rail station so you may hear the sound of trains approaching/departing the station. It's very faint but if you are an extremely light sleeper, this may disrupt your sleep.

We enjoyed 4 nights at courtyard ginza and 3 nights at marriott shinagawaThe location is not the best unfortunately quite outside but the good thing is there is a free shuttle bus to shinagawa. We got a nice upgrade to premier executive room for being platinum and loved the room. Very spacious for tokyo. The executive on 26th floor is very nice with great drinks. I would however wish more variation in food and not all day the same at lounge. Breakfast at restaurant is nicely done! Not sure if would come back. Might try prince sakura next time which is better located and has more japanese style deccor. The marriott is just a big building and something was just missing. The park outside however is beautiful as well the sakuras :)

This is a good business quality hotel right near the Shinagawa station. The lobby is not readily apparent when you walk in. You are forced to walk around a large restaurant area until you get to check-in. The young lady who helped me and my associate was nice enough to see that the line to check in was long so she grabbed us and took us up to the club level to check-in. That was a nice touch and the lounge has a beautiful view. The rooms are well appointed with large spacious bathrooms and views of Shinagawa out the window.
