The beds were comfortable and there was an assortment of pillows to choose from. The room had an ironing board, Coffee/Tea service and a safe. The staff is attentive and helpful. I was particularly impressed with two young ladies at the bell desk that helped me search for some quick sight-seeing locations with only a two hour window. They were both incredibly helpful and friendly. The only suggestion I would have for this Marriott is to provide more variety in their room service offerings. The options were incredibly limited. Other than that a great hotel in a great location.

The Tokyo Marriott is a great hotel, but to be clear the location is best suited for business trips to Minato or surrounding. Vacationers will not find the Minato location convenient. That said, this property does a lot of things well. It’s quiet, clean, comfortable, and the restaurant/bar is really quite good. Staff was friendly and accommodating. I would absolutely recommend and personally return if business brings me back to Minato. I would not consider it, however, for a leisure/holiday trip.

Simply amazing! Believe everything that is said that is good about this hotel, the service and the overall experience at this Marriott in Tokyo! Wow! We loved it! The free shuttle bus from the train station was very convenient and seemed to run about every 1/2 hr. It is right outside the train station around the corner just a little walk near the street. Be sure to take note of the name on the front of the bus' lighted display which is actually the name of the business tower/building that the hotel is located inside of. I think it said City??.... Don't get on the wrong bus. Get the exact name of the bus from the hotel before you arrive to be sure you get on the right bus because they all look alike except for the display. It seemed that more business people were getting on the hotel bus who worked there or even lived in the adjoining building. The shuttle/bus ride was free and only about 5-10 minutes away.Once inside the hotel, it is huge and very nice! The lobby bathroom has very modern heated seats, as well! Everyone from the concierge desk to the front desk to the staff walking through the hallways were extremely pleasant with a smile and ready to help! We were very impressed! The hotel is extremely bright, modern, clean, and stylish! The executive lounge is nice and very well stocked! The food in the lounge was very nice and we were treated very well as Gold members. The staff in the lounge were very very helpful and friendly as was everyone else. The room is very very nice and very clean! I loved the purple accents and I especially loved the very modern, heated toilet! Simply amazing! The food in the restaurant was great, the price was not too high, and the service was great! The concierge desk was very helpful as well and very patient with giving us good info. and directions and suggestions. I loved loved the sheets which were the most crisp that I've ever had at a hotel and they were very very white! I can't say it enough, everything was amazing and I can't wait to return!

Stayed in this hotel for a week, front desk was warm and friendly, best part was view of sunrise from the loungeRooms are decent size, not big though, spread of breakfast is limited, I was surprised that even though they had few vegetarian food they mixed shrimp or meat in it, not a good dining for vegetarianIt’s walking distance from railway station only if there are no luggage

I'll start with the negative points:On a map this hotel looks really close to Shinagawa station, it turns out it's a good 10-15 minute walk (up hill) from the station. The road system and pathways are such that it's awkward to get to.That said, once your at the hotel then forget about the issues as it's a great environment. Hotel staff in lobby and around the ground level are only too happy to assist you and get you where you need to be, even carrying your bags. The concierge helped enormously in helping me find the best way to Haneda airport early the following morning.The hotel rooms are very well equipped and really pleasant to be in. The amenities are endless and so well arranged and well presented. The bed and the covers were all really cozy which resulted in a good nights sleep.If you get a lucky room, you can watch the Shinkansens out of the window as they pass through Shinagawa station. In the restaurant on ground level they were serving afternoon tea, which sadly I wasn't able to take, but it did look good.The price for the hotel was mid-high but honestly I don't think it was a bad price for the surroundings and the service.

We recently spent 4 nights at the Tokyo Marriot and found it to be a great place to stay. The rooms were large with comfy beds, fantastic bathroom with top quality toiletries and the staff were all very helpful and pleasant. There is a shuttle bus that takes you to Shinagawa station (which will get you to anywhere in Tokyo) or alternatively its a 10 minute walk. If we travel back to Tokyo we will strongly consider staying there again.

This hotel is pretty nice. I love the atmosphere, the ambience and warmth when you walk in the hotel. The staff is extremely extremely friendly...My 2nd time to stay here and love coming back here. Station (Kita-Shinagawa) is near by, so is main station Shinagawa to go around the city

They have a direct shuttle from narita airport costing 3100 per person. Straight drop to Tokyo Mariott. The place is lovely . They have a very regular free shuttle to Shinagawa station from where you can go anywhere in Japan. (Bullet trains also start from there). The rooms are spacious and wonderful. The lounge is amazing and breakfast plentiful. It was a brief stay but really enjoyed the hospitality of Tokyo Mariott . A special word of thanks for Ms Xueling Lee for her amazing help and lovely smile which made the day. She is what Mariott is all about.

I’ve been a Marriott customer for over 10 years now. Most of their hotels are similar in terms of amenities and service. Tokyo Marriott exceeded my expectations. While the room is fairly standard, customer service is excellent! My husband and I truly enjoyed their hospitality. Everyone - from bell desk to servers to concierge - are pleasant and helpful. Grace was our favorite server - always a smile on her face and very welcoming. My favorite perk is the Handy phone available for our use. It’s a local smart phone with free data plan so we didn’t have to incur roaming charges. It was extremely useful on-the-go. We used it for google maps, TripAdvisor, etc.

Ok- first the good. Bustling area with great shopping and restaurants. Very good jogging close to the hotel. WiFi worked well. The hotel is a meh overall. Small rooms. Ok breakfast buffet. Workout room opens too late for any business traveler. There are better choices in the area.
user_name:
Chuck S
Anna Maria Island, Florida

review_body: It is a typical Marriott, which gives you a set of expectations. In fact my room was very odd. The bed was hard against a wall, facing the window, which meant one of us had to crawl over the other to get in and out of bed. The TV was mounted on the wall at a right angle to the bed, so you could only watch TV sitting on your side. From the workspace table you could only see the TV from the far side, which meant you could not really watch the news while working. In any event, the CNN had Japanese language voice-over which meant I could not really enjoy it. The wifi works well, and the bathroom is spacious and well appointed. Breakfast was the usual mad-house buffet -- a queue to get a table, and when I went back for a second helping, I came back to find my table cleared and someone else sitting there. The hotel rooms overlook a large train track and you can hear -- albeit muffled -- the sound of the clickty clack of the trains on the tracks day and night. I am not a particularly light sleeper, but if I were, I suppose it would have kept me up in the night. All in all it was not a place I would come back to, least of all because of the odd configuration of the room.

great experience and service taking care of all details during our stay. great lounge and easy access to train and subway. Breakfast is first class and rooms are spacious, clean and comfortable with all detailed Japanese style amenities.

Functional, quiet, but lacking given the Marriott brand. Compared to other Marriott's in Japan, this one focuses on simplicity and cleanliness. Service is not as good as other locations, but adequate, hence the "average" rating.

Nice Marriott. Rooms comfortable. Staff all very friendly with superb Japanese service. Breakfast buffet had many choices. Just 15 minute walk to famous Shinagawa train station. Convenience store under hotel. Marriott rewards members will love this hotel.

This is a high quality hotel, a short 15min walk to Shinagawa station. Breakfast was excellent and otherwise up to the standard one would expect from a Marriott. There is a fitness centre connected to the hotel which is free to use, although annoyingly the pool in the same complex is chargeable.

Super hotel. Very nice club lounge. Nice cocktails and hors d'oeuvres in the evening. Great views on higher floors. Superb breakfast buffet with international specialties. Helpful staff. Walkable from Metro and train station, but shuttle available.
user_name:
NevskyNY
New York City, New York

review_body: The hotel is hip and modern. You walk-in to the hotel being greeted by the bellhops. The modern open style restaurant and bar is the second thing you see. You are escorted if preferred to the check in. The rooms are big for and spacious for Asia. The king bed is a California king bed. the room is perfect for two people, three very easy going friends. The bathroom is modern. Tub/shower combo is inviting. They even give you bath salts. The toilet seat is heated and has an electronic bidet. I could spend hours playing video games while spoiling my bum with the perfect amount of warmth. It’s definitely a royal flush with the many options for refreshing your bum. Why stand and pee when you can sit in welcoming warmth. Ok, ok I’ll move on but I do shed a tear saying goodbye to my favorite John. The concierge lounge is awesome. It has snacks all day. Sodas and juices. 5-7 is the evening appetizers. There was 8 choices of finger foods. Also dips and two types of chips. Guacamole, hummus, salsa (very spicy caution) 5 -9:30 there is adult beverages. There is a Japanese whisky with the best Smokey flavor. Absolute vodka and other fun spirits. The juices are fresh squeezed. So the grapefruit packs a punch. 2 canned beers and one white wine and one red blend wine but they are very good. They also have bubbly. They have candy and chocolates to spoil yourself with; M&ms and jelly belly beans are my favorite. The view is the best part. The concierge lounge is a reason not to leave the hotel. The fitness studio. Small but you can get a good workout in. The pool, hot tub and sauna are awesome. They also have a women’s and men’s only area to frolic naked in. I know Americans are prude and get squeamish around nudity please get over yourself. Anything sexual is offensive and completely in appropriate in this setting. Moving passed my rant . The breakfast buffet. They have fresh made to order eggs - omelets, eggs Benedict, fried eggs, waffles, French toast (fantastic). They have pho (savory soup for breakfast yes please and don’t knock it until you try it) they have Japanese cuisine, breads and spreads, Cheese, meats, pastries. Fresh squeezed juices and frozen juices. I made a pb&j to go and they brought me a to go bag. The hotel is awesome. Lots to do. Lots of reasons to not go out. But if you do. The concierge can hook you up with a private driver for about $40 bucks an hour. Pick upAnd drop off at the hotel. Very nice car too. I didn’t do my homework so I just told the driver to take me where I should see. Now for the main reason I write my review. The staff is exceptional. Friendly and genuine. If you have an issue with the staff. Then you should check yourself for the staff will go out of their way to make your stay happy. Language was a slight barrier but I was grateful for them to communicate with me and do their best. The hotel is a great choice. It is in a residential area but in a main area with a great view of the city.

I normally stay at the Strings Intercontinental as it's a little closer to the station and I have to admit is quite quirky and extremely luxurious.The Mariott is equally luxurious, and the staff were excellent from the moment I arrived. Bags were delivered promptly, and if you're a platinum/gold member which several of our party were, there is a lounge at the top-floor with drinks, nibbles, and a conference room that we used.Restaurant in the lobby/bar was very good, we had breakfast a few times and also lunch. Service was great and prices were as you would expect, perhaps slightly cheaper than I would have expected.Rooms were very good, extremely modern and recently renovated. I would have to say it's not perfect, there was some mould around the grout in the shower, only minor but enough to be noticeable and lower the quality of the finish overall.You won't go wrong staying here though, and excellent hotel at a premium price.

Very nice hotel. Staff was extremely courteous and everything was up to the Marriott standard. To help future travelers, it would be helpful to have detailed descriptions on the web site of how the hotel shuttle bus from the train station works. Also, the attached gym has a 25m lap pool, but this isn't mentioned in the description.

Checked in week of January 26th and was warmly welcomed by staff. The breakfast food is plentiful and there is a wide variety for different tastes. A server in the breakfast area, MaryGrace, is exceptionally friendly and gracious. There is a free shuttle to the Shinagawa train station that is very convenient. The concierge staff, Shoko Hida and Saki Takashima, gave us some terrific suggestions for local cuisine and things to do. I would highly recommend this beautiful (hotel is surrounded by a garden) and functional Marriott property (full disclosure: I am a Marriott Platinum member).

This hotel, located in Shinagawa, is very close to the JR station. They offer a free shuttle bus to and from the hotel. Rooms are clean and spacious with all the basic amenities offered by Marriott.Breakfast at the G restaurant is great, with local and international favorites. Try the pancake or the egg benedict.

Check-in was speedy and efficient even if the front desk staff wasn’t super fluent in English. We booked a quadruple room which was huge with almost 100sqm of space; for that price we would normally get less than half of that space in Tokyo. The kids bed were located in the living area and we had our own room. The kids were offered proper beds and not sofa beds. The bathroom was between our room and the living area so we could all access it conveniently and close off everything at bedtime and had enough privacy. However, the room and decor was a bit aged. The bathroom wasn’t super clean and I found some mould in the shower area and lot of accumulated dust under a bench that was used to store towels. I felt that the space wasn’t fully utilized either as there should have been more hooks for used towels and a hand towel rack was inexistent. The lighting in the bathroom was also a bit dark. The iron was cordless and low quality and couldn’t really iron properly with it. Humidifiers are available upon request and not de rigueur. The hotel is very close to Shinagawa JR station so we could hear trains and I don’t think that the windows were soundproof enough; I sleep with earplugs so it didn’t bother me that much. There is a convenient store located outside the hotel where we could stock up on fruits. We didn’t bother trying breakfast as they didn’t offer Japanese breakfast. A free shuttle bus is available between the hotel and Shinagawa station and it takes less than 15 minutes by foot. The main issue is that this place was a bit out of the city center and would take approx 25 minutes at least by taxi or by train to get to any places like Shinjuku or Marunouchi so if you’re just in Tokyo for just few days, somewhere more towards the city center would be more convenient.

Visited here for 2 days on business in January. Positives:Excellent breakfast. Lots of locals enjoying delicious looking drinks and dessert throughout dayImmaculate rooms, spacious for Japan. Comfy bedsQuietMost of staff speaks pretty good EnglishOpportunities for improvement:I like a flatter pillow. These were plush and fat. Nitpicking here.Laundry service is a bit pricey

The hotel is only a few minutes from the Shinagawa Station. There is a free shuttle bus that takes you to the hotel - it is not a hotel shuttle it is a city bus that goes to Gotenyama Trust City. There is a schedule for this bus at the bus stop or exit of the hotel. It is not a long walk but if you have luggage this bus is very helpful.The staff is friendly and very polite. The room is spacious and very clean. My room was on the side of the trem tracks but you cannot hear a single train passing by. The executive lounge is busy at night but offer a great view of the city. You can even see the planes taking off and landing at Haneda Airport.The rate had breakfast include and it was good because the restaurant that serves breakfast is excellent. Many choices of food and fresh fruits with egg and pancake stations to cooking it to order.

First trip to Tokyo with my husband who booked this hotel as close to his business contact. Hotel has free regular shuttle bus which takes you to Shinagawa station and from there you can get pretty much anywhere, so very convenient. Staff in hotel were all superb. The breakfasts were lovely as were the couple of lunches and dinners we had. Surprised there is only one restaurant though. Room was very clean and comfortable.

Hotel offers excellent service rooms and a restaurant. As in any Japanese hotel the staff are courteous and helpful. However the hotel is a bit remote it is ten minute walk to Shinagawa station. The hotel does provide shuttle service. Not many restaurants around. However my overall experience was very nice.

The axiom of “Buddha is in the details” is apparent from the geometrically designed glass doors that open to welcome you to the Western and traditional robes hanging in the closet. The architectural finishes and interior design details give this Marriott a well deserved 5 star rating.After navigating the Tokyo train system and weary from a 12 hour flight from San Diego we were greeted warmly by the staff who gave us a thorough and patient overview of the hotel’s amenities and layout. Heading up to our 20th floor suite we passed the bar and restaurant with comfy and inviting chairs as well the carefully placed lamp illuminating the floor number.The room was spacious with a skyline view, seating area and king size bed. The bidet with lots of options, Nespresso coffee maker, and oversized gym were details that made me happy with our choice of hotels.Renovated in 2013, the architects transformed this 30+ year old building to become one of Marriott’s flagship hotels. The building stands 26 stories tall and offers panoramic views of Tokyo Bay, Mt Fuiji, Rainbow Bridge and central Tokyo - all of which can be seen from the executive lounge reserved for platinum members. The breakfast buffet is worth lounging for an hour and taking several small plates. We enjoyed the fresh noodles, smoked fish, pickled vegetables and other delectables.When you need a great nights sleep and a scrumptious breakfast after a morning swim this is the place. Just would have liked to stay another day or two here.

Stayed here a number of times and finally a very good move by the hotel to upgrade the lounge from the ground floor to one with a great view. It's very comfortably sized with a beautiful long wooden table that can sit 10-12. Staff were exceptionally friendly and helpful. Shinagawa is nearby and there is a free shuttle bus available. If you are flying in from Haneda airport there is a direct train to Shinagawa. However did now that limousine bus services to/from Haneda isn't as frequent so do check on the latest schedule.

What a fantastic hotel to stay at in Tokyo. My husband and I were here during high season so we paid premium price here (as is everything in Japan.) But to us, it was worth every penny. There were of course a few flaws but they are minuscule compared to our overall experience. Pros: - 10 minute walk from Shinagawa Station (or you can take their free shuttle to and from the station that leaves about every 20 min.)- Free WIFI, although it was laggy at times- Spacious & clean rooms. Comfortable mattress and blankets - High-quality toiletries and a very good shower head - Nespresso in every room with complimentary capsules refilled daily (as well as TWG green and black tea) - Very clean & fully-equipped gym with everything you need; from barbells, gym mats, cardio/exercise machines, squat rack, to foam rollers - Family Mart and Post Office downstairs in the connecting building- First-class service by the housekeepers and concierge/bellmen Cons:- Food at their restaurant, Lounge & Dining G, is mediocre (unless you are having the breakfast buffet.) We had dinner here on our first night since we were tired from our 10-hour flight and didn't want to go out. Our food was very bland and disappointing, not to mention very expensive. We also ordered room service on another day and again, not good. I recommend only trying the breakfast buffet or going out to eat. Many local restaurant nearby. As you can see, the pros outweigh the cons by far for us. The only qualm we had with the hotel was the food. But otherwise, our stay was incredibly comfortable and convenient, as it is centrally located in Tokyo and many cities are just a train ride away. Definitely a hotel with a high price-tag but you are paying for a very comfortable stay with excellent service.

This hotel exceeded my expectations. This is of course primarily a business hotel and traveling as a family I was unsure if we would be welcome but we were and am quite happy with their amenities and their food! They also provide a shuttle service to Shinagawa station.

After a 12 hour flight the Marriott Tokyo was a welcome sight. Settle in and enjoy the rooms which have a great view of the city. marriott branding means a good staff and good food. Recommend a 2 day stay then move on.

When we called the desk to ask about the shuttle they didn’t explain that we needed to get on a city bus so we missed it and had to walk with our luggage to the hotel which was quite a far walk. The location is definitely inconvenient if you’re planning to use the trains in Tokyo since it would be a 15 min walk each time. The rooms are ok but boring and sterile, I also don’t like carpeted rooms. The front desk wasn’t very helpful but the lounge was good - except that the food is the same each night.

Was a bit concerned with the location but they have a shuttle bus that runs regularly to the jr station in shinagawa. Also a nice walk to osaki jr station if the weather is good which may be quicker if you are heading to the shibuya or shinjuku side of the jr. Good size rooms for Tokyo.Outstanding service by everyone encountered at this hotel. Concierge was extremely helpful with restaurant recommendations and reservations. Will definitely stay here again next time I am In tokyo.

Of course it is a Marriott so you come to expect the 'standard' things. They have all those covered. The breakfast is awesome. The staff make it even more so. The fresh fruits and smoothies and juice combinations are healthy and fantastic. The executive lounge is also very relaxing after a day's worth of sight seeing.It is convenient to Shinagawa so the rest of Tokyo is easily accessible. We loved our stay here.

Staying for a long weekend in Tokyo, we were recommended to stay at the Marriott. At first, we were a bit reticent given the location, but it was very very easy. The bus from Narita was very efficient and the shuttle service to the JR station made the location worries go away. The hotel it's self is very polished. The restaurant staff were very good and a special shout out to the concierges who were super helpful. When we go back, will stay again which, when given all the choices in Tokyo is testament to how well the hotel works.

Typically, hotels in Tokyo are very cramped by Western standards, but this Marriott is spacious. That, of course, comes at a trade-off. The hotel is located away from most of the major business and tourist districts and difficult to get to unless you are traveling by taxi or car. The closest major station is about a 15 minute walk away and there are limited bus options. For business people with work in the area, it is fine.There were three areas in which the property fell down. The first is the executive lounge. It is one fairly small room. On both nights we visited the lounge it was so over capacity that they were taking reservations and encouraging guests to take whatever food and drink they wanted to their rooms. The self-serve bar is excellent and the staff is attentive. The food is fairly average, but with the capacity issue, the food was usually gone within a few minutes of being brought out.There is only one restaurant on the property, which is more of an afternoon tea and pastry type of place, although they do provide a full breakfast buffet. Unfortunately, the wait for breakfast was about 30 minutes. The closest alternatives are Starbucks and Denny's which are both about a 15 minute walk away. On the plus side, there is a convenience store on the property that sells its products at normal market prices (not the typical insanely inflated Marriott prices where a can of Coke can cost US$5).The hotel was generally well-kept. But there were some areas in which the hotel was not as clean as it should have been. The first was the fact that many of the rooms have been heavily smoked in. This is perhaps a cultural issue and could be overlooked. But there were areas in which the hotel was surprisingly dirty. I have attached a photo of the bathroom mold as an example. Lastly, although not a full time issue, the internet on the property was spotty. I found myself at times switching to mobile date for a better connection.

Location: It's a bit far from Shinagawa Station, about 15 mins walk. If you want to walk to the hotel from Shinagawa Station, take the Tankanawa exit, and cross the road to the McDonald side first, as there will be no zebra crossing when you walk on the train track side when near the hotel. The shuttle bus is frequent, and it's a real bus, better than the prince hotel shuttle bus, can easily bring the luggage onto it. Service: A lady knock my door right after I step into the room and hand me a Tokyo Map and welcome cookies, very good service. But the Check-in counter isn't near the main door, it's very inside after the restaurant, a bit weird.Room: The room is facing the train track. You can hear the train pass by. However, it's acceptable. The bed isn't facing the TV, so cannot watch TV on the bed properly. The bed is comfortable and they provide famous TWG teabag. Only a few rooms per floor, therefore it's ok quiet.Breakfast: The breakfast is very good with a lot of variety. And the egg station can cook a lot of different style for you, and you can order waffle and pancake as well. It's very crowded in the morning. The waitress forgot to give me coffee after showing me the table 2 days in a row, which is a bit disappointed. However, it's good overall.

Functional hotel with all the amenities needed. Rooms are a good size and very quiet. The reception area is not located in the lobby which on a first visit is a bit confusing, but staff were on hand to help.
user_name:
Rachel T
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Hotel is accessible from Shinagawa Station with free shuttle. Staff is very friendly and helpful. Staff always willing to go out of their way to assist. Hotel is very clean with all areas. Will definitely stay again on next visit to Japan.

Stayed there for a week while I was in Tokyo last August on business trip. Pretty lavish and spacious rooms, clean and comfortable. The hotel staffs were friendly, an attribute very close to the Japanese people culture and tradition. Loved my stay in Tokyo, did a lot of walking. One can easily take the local buses from the station nearby the hotel. The Shinagawa station is also not very far from the hotel itself. In case you need help, you may ask the hotel staffs for guidance. The taxis are expensive, only take them if really need it. Otherwise, the world famous trains in Japan gets you to any point in no time. Thank you.

It was our first trip to Tokyo and we were blown away by the hospitality shown to us. The level of graciousness, patience and attention to detail we experienced at this hotel was amazing. Special mention of Masakazu Numakura, the Assistant Front Manager. He helped us move rooms when we had issues with the room we were assigned and as it was late, personally helped with our luggage without complaining. He also helped with arranging a small surpise for my wife as we were celebrating our 18th anniversary and our checkout. An unassuming man, he nevertheless anticipated our needs and did everything efficiently, without any hint of displeasure. Also the breakfast lounge staff is manned by some superstars of hospitality. The international staff are never short on smiles and always ready with a kind and happy word. If I have any complaints, it would be the gym. Understandably it is not managed by Marriott, at least that is not the impression I got. It was decent but poorly located. Also the equipment needs some attention. As for the rooms, nothing bad to say. Clean and comfortable, it is bigger than most Japanese hotels and the view is quite outstanding on the higher floors. The free shuttle is very helpful and nearby Shinagawa station is a transport hub. Only downside is that the bus service should operate until 11pm at least.

I stayed here on a recent business trip. The location was really great for where I was going, I wouldn’t stay here if I were a tourist because this hotel is in the business district and there are no restaurants nearby. The room was not large but super clean, bed was comfortable and internet worked flawlessly, staff was very friendly, breakfast was very good with both American and Japanese varieties. The executive lounge was a bit disappointing for an international Marriott, gym was below average, it had a few low end stair masters and three treadmills that could use a upgrade. Overall, good but expensive business hotel, if you are a tourist paying the room with your own money, there are better options elsewhere in the city.

It is a good hotel definitely !1- réception: people were nice and polite and did their best to accommodate you.2- room was fantastic ! I liked it very much ... clean and spacious3- breakfast was just fantastic as well ...Regarding the location it was too short to enjoy around ...

Outstanding staff, very attentive, helpful, very good service from lobby restaurant staff. Especially noteworthy was the help I got from two staff members in setting up a visit to a doctor nearby when I became ill with a bad cold. They deserve special thanks: Executive Lounge Assistant Nguyen Thi Nue and Concierge Saki Takashima. Both spoke good English, a big help for me. Recommend Executive Lounge be relocated to a large room with a view. The current location is drab room with no windows. Food and drink in Exec Lounge are adequate in variety and appropriate. Dave/Sherrie

It was our last night in Tokyo after about a 9 day trip in Japan. Being a Platinum with Marriott o thought I had booked (especially based on the points I had used) a very nice Marriott. Didn’t really turn out to be that way. We arrived there about 5/5:30. As Platinum my room should ha e been ready. It was not. The checkin process seemed very disorganized and not very warm as we had experienced at other hotels in Japan. It took us probably an hour to get our room (and we had also requested an early checkin which is supposed be guaranteed for Platinum). I was surprised that the associate checking me in couldn’t communicate in English. I would have expected that at the Tokyo Marriott this shouldn’t have been the case. Finally, the room was lack luster. Breakfast spread seemed great but the service wasn’t. Again quite a departure from what we had experienced around the rest of JapanQuite dissappointed and wished we had booked a better hotel.

Rooms are good + and staff service is very "Japanese" if you travel to Japan a lot you will understand my meaning. see "rigid"Pretty decent digs except for one massive issue. There is no place to eat around this hotel. Be prepared to pay some fairly inflated prices for some very average food at the restaurant in the lobby. The option is to take a taxi down to the train station or take a shuttle bus. (IE: Waiting and ...)Great news is there are some really good places to eat at the train station. Be adventurous and check out the food on the second floor. That would be the stairway to the left of the station if you are standing and looking at the front of the station. Kinda crowded, a little smokey, and whole lot of great sushi.

The location near the Shinagawa station, and the convenient free shuttle made touring the city so easy...we could get anywhere from there. The staff at the hotel were all so warm and welcoming, whether it was the restaurant, the front desk, the executive lounge, or housekeeping. And our room was exceptionally comfortable and welcoming with muted colors, good lighting, very modern and well equipped, and exceptionally clean. Loved the whole 3 night stay, and hope to be back again!

I have been on a business trip to Tokyo and stayed in Mariott. It has been very confinient and pleasant stay. The pluses are: coffee for free, bottlewater fresh every day, nice atmosphere, friendly + helpful staff, location in shinagawa In my opinion the breakfast is very good but to expensive and that the menue is mostly western style e.g. Sandwich, burger....I wanted to experience japanese food, of course I have to say that we have had a japanese business menue which has been very tasty - pls more of this in daily menue

Great hotel with rooms larger than normal in Tokyo.Yes it is a walk up the hill from Shinagawa station but the exercise is good for you and you can always catch the complimentary bus.Breakfast is a buffet style with a clever system for the items you order - eggs, omelettes, waffles - you have tooth picks with your table number on you place the order and hand over a tooth pick. A few minutes your order appears. Breakfast is very extensive.Free wi-fi was fast supporting Netflix Narita Airport Friendly bus drops off and picks up at this hotel I was ill (for the first time in Japan) whilst staying and the hotel staff were very attentive and caring in looking after my needs - THANKS

Tokyo Marriott is a hotel of Marriott's standards and is located in a quiet area less than 2 kilometers away from Shinagawa Station. This 23-storey, 242-room hotel is also serviced by a free shuttle bus plying between the hotel and Shinagawa station which runs every 10 to 30 minutes and takes only about 10 minutes per trip. Take note however that the shuttle service is not by the hotel but provided by JR Company for the benefit of the hotel guests as well as for people living or working around the hotel and the Gotenyama Trust Building vicinity, a commendable service which is hard to comprehend. As you exit the station , follow the west exit (Takanawa) and just wait for the bus at Bus stop no.6. For those leaving from the hotel, there's a waiting line just behind the door of the next building, the Gotenyama Trust. Hope that helps and please get a copy of the shuttle schedule from the Marriott reception.For Japanese standards, the hotel room is considered large. It was very clean and well-maintained with all amenities in fine working condition.and the bed was very comfortable. Even pyjamas were provided for those who need them. Water pressure of the shower was great, ensuring a good bath and even the toilet bowl was computerised/automated for the convenience of the guests. However, there was no microwave oven in the room.Overall it's a nice hotel and accessibility to the city centre and connecting areas is no issue and I hope the atached photos would be of help to visitors staying at Tokyo Marriott.

We were in a beautiful suite, room 412. It had 2 full beds. We would have preferred a king. It was very clean and comfortable. The room was very spacious and the bathroom was large. It had a separate shower, which was very nice. The service was excellent! One issue I had, there was a sharp metal plate on the chrome bar on the wall separating the tub from the sink. I didn't notice it, until the sharp corner cut my hand open, deep enough for stitches. The plate was attached crooked, which left the sharp corner sticking out on the bottom. The hotel was very quick to remedy the problem.The location was great! They had a free shuttle to the train station, but we easily walked back at the end of the evening.We booked the Executive rate, which included the breakfast buffet and the Executive lounge. The lounge had a delicious assortment of food choices. The breakfast buffet was incredible! A huge variety of Asian and Western style foods. The upgrade was definitely worth it!I highly recommend this hotel and I definitely would stay here again.

The hotel is located about a kilometer from Shinagawa Station so it is not in the 'center' of Tokyo but it is a short train ride on the Yamanote line to Tokyo station.The Limouse Bus calls in and the NEX stops at Shinagawa so there is good access to Narita and Haneda as does the local train to Haneda. The sa=taff are top class and all rooms haved been renovated and are good size for a Tokyo hotel. There is a delightful garden (Gotenyama) at the rear of the hotel. A free bus runs frequently from Shinagawa station to the hotel.They provide an excellent breakfast. Overall this has a little more class than the average Marriott.

Hotel has very large rooms for Tokyo and the restaurant and breakfast were very good. Only drawback is the 10-15 walk to Shinagawa station and most restaurants. Hotel is in a quiet neighborhood which has less noise from the street.

My Husband and I were holidaying with friends. We stayed at the Marriott Tokyo for three nights.We arrived extremely early and were of course unable to check in until 15.30, we were already aware of this. The Reception staff allowed us to leave our cases while we went out to explore.We returned just before 15:00 and myself and my husband were allocated our room at the said time. However the friends we had travelled with were not able to get into their room until much later and as we had already pre-booked the Robot restaurant our friends also had to use our room to get ready.The Reception staff were very apologetic but this wasn’t their fault more so the House Keeping staff.On check-in my Credit Card wasn’t accepted neither was my Husband’s. Our friend kindly used their card. The Receptionist very kindly allowed me to use the telephone and contact the credit card company in the UK and again the following day when the card still didn’t work .Our room was lovely, the bed was extremely comfortable , the shower and bathroom were great . We overlooked the railway line which didn’t matter to us as we were just excited about being in Japan and being able to see the Bullet train on what we then found to be regular as clockwork!The coffee machine, well I just couldn’t seem to get it to work.The breakfast is very expensive (over priced I’d say) and as such we only ate there once. We usually caught the shuttle bus and ate at on of the little cafes across the road from the Shinagwa train station.After staying at the Marriott we went onto a cruise, after the cruise we returned with our cases (I’d pre-arranged that we could leave our cases while we flew to Hiroshima for two days before returning to the Marriott for our finalday and night. I have read in previous reviews that the Receptionist staff’s English could be improved but their English was far better than my Japanese! It did take a little while for the Receptionist to understand that we were leaving our cases, flying to Hiroshima before returning – but we got there in the end!We have no hesitation on recommending the Marriott and its great location. If (hopefully when) we return to Tokyo we’d definiately stay here again.

We were upgraded to a suite because of my wife’s platinum status but were more than surprised at the size of the suite- may have been the bridal suite no complaints whatsoever. Shout out to Tomukazu the front office manager for his friendliness and expertise. Location to Shinagawa station with free bus service was a big plus. Executive lounge staff and food were excellent. Excellent food and beverage selection . Hotel was refurbished from an older hotel. Decor could have been brighter rather than subdued but strictly personal preference. Highly recommended hotel

The room we stayed in was beautiful. It was a family room, with two beds in main living area and a separate bedroom with two more beds. Bathroom was lovely with excellent toiletries. Heated toilet was a nice touch. We had breakfast downstairs, which was very good in a pleasant environment. We went for a walk around the hotel and found this to be lovely.

I stay at Marriott locations all over the world and this hotel never fails to please. I have stayed at this exact location on all my tokyo trips and have gotten to know the staff who always go above and beyond to make my stay as best as it could get. Just minutes away from the train station, this hotel is only 20 minute drive from Haneda international airport and about an hour from Narita. Everyone from the staff at the door to the waiters and cooks are constantly smiling and ready to make everything perfect! The breakfast buffet is very diverse and the freshly made smoothies are a must! There is more than enough seating to accommodate one if dining alone or a party of 6 or more without it feeling over crowded. There are always more than 2 reps at check in and I have noticed if the line is getting long they quickly bring in more hotel reps to aid in the checking to limit the wait time. There is a lounge conveniently located on the lobby level that offers food and drinks at happy hour. The gym is around the corner and has everything you need for a full body workout and is extremely clean and organized! Don’t forget to rerack your weights!!!!!! :)The rooms are in always the best of condition with a newspaper at the door every morning!If you are looking for a place to stay look no further as you will be pleased here at the tokyo marriott hotel!Enjoy!Platinum elite member with an avg of 90 night stays a year at all marriott locations

Magnificent, strong property and we stayed inside the room listening to the roaring sounds of the massive typhoon which swept Tokyo on Oct 22,23. Everything went well except for a girl who insulted us after check out!! Had a 5 nights stay with my wife and son. The moment we checked in we realised that even though it’s Marriott brand, English is spoken well by only a handful of staff. The tour desk girls were very communicative and guided us well. Three of us stayed together in three different rooms during the same journey. Went to Kyoto and returned the next day due to Typhoon. We expected some sort of a written notification on the mammoth typhoon in our room, since we are tourists and traveling on our own. But we had to depend on internet and English speaking hotel staff. The hotel is just 5 minutes by free shuttle to Shinagawa railway station connecting all destinations. Airport shuttle is far cheaper and much more comfortable than cabs and takes 11/2hours to Nerita airport. The reception staffs at Marriott were speaking slowly as if translating word by Word to English. When we checked out during the second stay for 3 nights and walked out a staff by name Nayo Koyoma came shouting and running after my wife to pay for her room!! It was a serious insult to us, being Marriott rewards member for quite some time!! Never happened with Marriott earlier! We tried our level best to convince her that we are a family and stay together in a single room!! The young girl is still scared and confused:)  Marriott in Japan badly needs very good English speaking reception staff round the clock. They need to follow global rules and not the Japanese stringent rules while dealing with tourists.

Stayed here with work for 4 nights towards the end of September. I had a room overlooking the train lines but was on the 9th floor so the noise didn’t disturb me. The room was well appointed with a good range of toiletries and a Nespresso coffee machine which I made full use of. The location was good, close to Shinagawa station. Breakfast was good too. There is also a shop just as you exit the hotel which was handy for snacks and drinks. I would definitely stay again.

Stayed 5 nights at the Marriott Hotel, Tokyo for business - everything was exactly as it needed to be. Very clean, spacious, close to public transport (and also airport bus to the door), good restaurant and even minimarket in the same building. Also the staff were very attentive and friendly.Lastly, at the base of the building there is a lovely garden, with large trees / foliage and flowing water (with small waterfalls) which I particularly enjoying going for a walk in, to clear my head.Overall, I can highly recommend this hotel to both business travellers and family alike.

We loved our stay at the Tokyo Marroitt.The rooms were spacious and clean, bathroom huge. As a family of 4 we were not expecting so much space. The staff are polite and helpful, the location was great, close to a major train station with a shuttle bus. The convenience store made life easier. We loved having the train line below us, kids got a kick out of watching the bullet trains.Our youngest left his favourite toy behind, after a quick email to the hotel, we have arranged for it to be shipped back to Australia. I would recommend this hotel, especially to families.

Good Hotel, nice room, good services, nice meal, have a free shuttle bus to shinagawa station and from the station. We really enjoy our stay. And also there is a family mart so everything is easy here unless late night.

Tokyo Marriott is located in a very convenient location. The free shuttle takes guests to the Shinagawa train station so that one can get around Tokyo using the trains for subway. We had a nice room which was clean and comfortable. The Executive Lounge had good food and in the morning for breakfast Gold and Platinum members could eat a very nice breakfast in the dining room.There is a nice garden right next to the hotel. My Marriott rewards points were slow in posting and I had to contact hotel more than once to get it posted. Don't expect an upgrade, even if you are Lifetime Platinum. In addition, we one day waited 45 minutes for the concierge and when she finally got finished telling the first couple everything she knew about Tokyo, she then wanted to take someone ahead of us. She apologized, but it was pretty much a waste of our vacation time.

We stayed at the Marriott Tokyo on October 13th for one night on our way to my step sons wedding in Kumamoto. Talk about culture shock but the hotel is beautiful and there were enough people who understood English to help us out. We were only there for one night. The hotel amazing, the food excellent and the service phenomenal!We left the hotel to go to Kumamoto a 6 hour bullet train ride when I remembered I left the dress for the wedding in the closet. I called the hotel in a panic. The concierge went to my room and got the dress. Within 30 minutes she had left the hotel dress in hand and took it to a courier. Saki emailed me once it was done. Saki and the manager both emailed again saying they received confirmation that the dress arrived at its destination.Saki the concierge went above and beyond. I am a Maeriott Platinum member and this hotel reminded me why.OUTSTANDING

I recently stayed here for 4 nights with my friends. Very good location, close to the metro station, easy to get around. Staff always keep smile and very attentive. Room was very clean. I would definitely come back next time.

I was pleasantly surprised by my 4 night stay at this property. I was a little disappointed that there wasn't an upgrade (or even a 1 king bed room available), but the room I got was very comfortable.The room was large by Tokyo standards and the A/C worked really well. There was a nice Nespresso machine in the room with a decent size refrigerator. The housekeeping was OUTSTANDING. Tokyo is generally a very clean city, but my room was spotless and there was a full housekeeping service in the AM and evening. The executive lounge was small, but had surprisingly good offerings with drinks from 530-930 and food 530-730 nightly - including GH Mumm Champage and a wide selection of hard and soft drinks. The breakfast provided a lot of options and the service was consistently excellent.Overall, this will be my new go to hotel in Shinagawa area.If you are arriving from Narita, I would highly recommend taking the Airport Limousine Bus. It's Y4500 roundtrip and they let you right off and pick you back up at the front door of the hotel. It's much easier than taking the Narita Express and then walking 10-15 minutes or taking the shuttle to the hotel.

Great location near the Shinagawa station. Hotel is a 10 minute walk or you can catch the free shuttle. The staff at the front desk is very friendly. Great customer service. The concierge lounge is awesome. The staff is very helpful. Very good appetizers. I would highly recommend this hotel for tour stay in Toyko.

Enjoyed my stay, little far away from the center of Tokyo, but very beautiful hotel. Big spacious room, huge king size bed, 2 double beds put together. Very clean. Staff very friendly. Breakfast buffet delicious. Close to the train station.

Great choice if you get the right room as sizes and quality of furniture, fittings etc seems to vary. Asked to move from the tiny room they initially allocated and was given one more than twice the size (35 sqm or so) of the original.Would put this property somewhere in between a standard Marriott and JW, definitely higher quality than 90% of the other Marriott's around the world. The only caveat is the Shinagawa location which is not ideal for first time visitors to Tokyo wanting seamless access to shopping, sightseeing and public transport.If you can get a decent rate and can live with being slightly out of central Tokyo, then the hotel won't disappoint. The only major aspect that needs improving is the gym, exceptionally dated equipment and generally run down feel to it that frankly has no place in a modern 4*+ business property.

Overall, my stay at the Tokyo Marriott was good but not great. It wouldn't have been my first choice simply due to the location, but it was already arranged by my husband's company since he was visiting on business. I tagged along and did some sight seeing, so the Shinagawa location meant long train rides to get to the main sites. I'm not including the location as a factor in my rating but I did want to mention. On the plus side, our hotel room was a good size, and well decorated and appointed. I definitely appreciated the Nespresso coffee in the room. Bed was comfortable and air conditioning worked well. Front desk service was always good. Where we encountered some problems were with dining and service in the restaurant. We had a slightly negative encounter our last morning with the hostess - on previous mornings, we simply showed our room key and gave our room number and that seemed to serve as notice that we should get the buffet for free. We had also received vouchers but since we weren't asked the first few days, we didn't think they were needed. So the last day, the hostess demanded the voucher, which was in the room. This was after we had been seated and already were eating. Trust me, we were not trying to steal breakfast, but that was the vibe we got from the hostess. Anyway, she finally left after we promised to bring the voucher down after we finished but it was an odd and embarrassing encounter. I mention this solely because there was a service breakdown somewhere that needs to be addressed and I hope hotel management reads this. Even if we were in the wrong, the hostess should have been friendlier and less accusatory. I will say that the breakfast buffet was really good with a great variety of items. Also, on several occasions, we didn't get coffee after asking for it. And on our final evening, we ate dinner at the restaurant, waited forever for our meals, and both were not great (and quite expensive). I probably wouldn't stay here again as a result of these factors.

Outstanding in EVERY way. The service, the executive lounge was always nicely arranged. The concierge staff was very helpful. Shuttle bus to nearby Shinagawa was convenient and we used it often. They also have very affordable transfers to airports

This was a very nice hotel, with pleasant views and a good location. Staff were polite and rooms clean. The members lounge was poor though, and in need of an expansion and update. The food in it was not of Marriott standard, and there was barely room to sit. Other than that, the hotel is excellent.

I stayed in this hotel twice. The 1st time i had a big beautiful room, the second time a much smaller one but still cute and with espresso maker! The reason i gave only average to this hotel is first the gym, very old equipment,closes early some days and no wifi working there! Second reason no express laundry service! All hotels charge more and you have the possibility to do it but not here. Many employees also do not speak good english so good luck! I had to speak to 3 different people to find out what i wanted.

We stayed at the Tokyo Marriott Hotel for a total of 8 nights during our vacation. The hotel was very clean, modern, and the rooms were very spacious for Tokyo (certainly not as large as you might see in some US cities where space is less expensive, just to set expectations). We were very comfortable here with 2 large suitcases, the bathroom especially was spacious, and the shower was tall enough for my 6'3" husband.This hotel is a 10-minute walk from Shinagawa Station; to find it, exit the station via the Takanawa Exit (follow the yellow signs) and then cross the street toward the giant white building, which looks like a casino (it's actually a pachinko parlor). Turn left after crossing the street, then walk up the hill about 3/4 of a mile. You'll probably see the Gotenyama Trust office building first, but the hotel is attached to it.There is also a free bus from the Gotenyama building lobby to the Shinagawa train station, when it's really hot or you have lots of luggage.Shinagawa is a good station because it's on the Keikyu Line (which has an express train to/from the Haneda airport), the Shinkansen bullet train (for day trips to Kyoto or other cities), and also several JR train lines, which gets you almost anywhere in metropolitan Tokyo. You can also easily transfer to the subways after a short train ride, but some locations (like Shibuya) are a direct route from Shinagawa. The location of this hotel near the large train station was immensely advantageous.There are a few neighborhood restaurants near this hotel, but we didn't eat in the neighborhood because we were always out somewhere in a different location where there were many more food choices.There is a convenience store in the lobby of the attached Gotenyama Trust building too, great for picking up beverages, snacks, and breakfast items on your way home each evening if you don't want to spring for the $35/person breakfast buffet each day.I did the buffet one morning during our trip and it was very impressive, with both American and Asian items, too many things to try all in one meal. But I did not want to pay that much for breakfast *every* day.You do get a Toto washlet in the hotel rooms here.Worth the money for the location and access to transportation.

We stayed here for 10 days recently. In general, I liked this hotel: polite staff with impeccable services, great breakfast (free as a gold elite member), a gorgeous garden nearby. However, the hotel itself is a bit old, which you can see in the room, e.g., its carpet, and the bath tub was a bit too small. They provide a shuttle bus between Shinagawa Station and the hotel. However, they don't operate after 10pm (the last bus from Shinagawa Station leaves at 9:55pm). Then, you need to either walk or get a taxi. Finally, their current executive lounge located on the first floor is subpar: too small and no view. I heard that this is a temporary one, and they would eventually finish its construction/renovation on the 26th floor by the end of this year, which would be great.

Pros: free shuttle to Shinagawa Train station, good breakfast spread, warm service with smiles at check-in, concierge, bell desk, lounge. Cons: no Japanese bath. Almost identical buffet breakfast daily and exec lounge as well.Verdict: will definitely go back!Instead of photos of hotel, I will post photos of employees that make all the difference for my stay!!

While this Marriott is laid out a bit differently, with no doorman and the registration away from the entrance a bit, it still delivers in quality. The rooms are clean and have all the typical toiletries. The restaurant has some great food and if you have lounge access it is ok for heavy evening snacks, although they seem to be the same every night. The staff is helpful and professional. Worth the stay if you are in the area.

This hotel was outstanding. I have seen some criticism on TA of this hotel before we went. Room was large and comfortable. Bathroom was very large. We had 0 problems with the shuttle to/from the Shinagawa Station. The one time that we did not want to wait for the shuttle, we took a waiting taxi. The price of the taxi was under $5.00. The breakfast buffet was fantastic, and the staff at the buffet was amazingly friendly and helpful. The concierge, Ms Simonis, was so accommodating and helpful to us. One of the best hotel experiences we have had anywhere. The only negative is that the hotel is a long ride from Narita Airport.

Hotel is simply awesome in true Japanese and Marriott style. A refreshing change back to how I remember the Marriott brand. While hotel is not situated in the heart of Shibuya and/or Shinjuku, it is nicely located in busy enough Shinagawa district and 15 minutes' walk from the train station. The rooms are immaculate and the breakfast spread touts a blend of cultural and international selections. Now, the staff!! COURTEOUS, and ever warming. While some parts of Tokyo have the language challenge, everybody at the hotel (with the exception of the concierge) spoke and understood English well enough to communicate with us. We struggled in our attempts to find tourist attractions- from the concierge, no less. After what should have been a 5 minute chat (and twenty minutes later) we were off on our inevitable to-be-lost adventure!Will I revisit this hotel? Even with an increased price (to the already pricey rooms) - ABSOLUTELY!Two big thumbs up, Tokyo Marriott!

My home away from home, the staff at the Tokyo Marriott know what it takes to make you feel at home. The Concierge, Ms. Simonis was VERY helpful assisting me with arranging a Tour Guide / Interpreter and with other details during my stay. Her recommendations for restaurants were superb. I cannot emphasize enough how this Marriott Hotel made the difference in my Tokyo visit. THANK YOU!

For a hotel of this standard, I would have expected: 1) a much quicker check-in and check-out (took 10 minutes!) 2) a much larger restaurant (had to wait for breakfasts and chose to take a taxi to go for dinner at the hotel the Prince, next to Shinagawa station, where they have 13 restaurants!!! Waiting time at the Marriott at 9 pm was 30 minutes!!!). 3) Have a bar/coffee lounge: we were 6 colleagues and were virtually kicked-out after 30 minutes, despite our coffees at 900 yens each. The design is also strange: front desk far away from entrance, and only one restroom for the ground floor... A lot of walking when you spend your day there because of work... Honestly, would never chose to stay there again.

I am writing this review a little late. My wife and I stayed here in April, 2017 for 3 nights. Overall it was a very good experience. The hotel is in a good location in shinagawa. There is a bus that goes regularly between the hotel and shinagawa station. We arrived early in the morning after taking a night flight from Bangkok. They didn't have a room ready for us but being a gold Marriott rewards member they gave us access to the lounge where we could have breakfast and hang out until the room was ready which was about noon. The lounge breakfast was awesome as it was the hotel buffet in the main restaurant. In the evening the drinks and apps in the loung were good The only issue we had was that the bathroom wasn't very clean. We brought it to their attention and they sent someone to the room when we were out but didn't seem to do much. Overall it was a good experience and would recommend to others.

The family room in Tokyo Marriott provides great value to the family of 4. The room is about 70 square meters. There are two beds in the bedroom and two other beds in the living room. The hotel itself is about 15 minutes walk from train station. There is a complimentary shuttle bus between this hotel and train station (every 20 minutes, not operated by hotel, so there is no hotel sign on the bus). The breakfast selection is very good, with multiple types of fresh fruit juices. One thing could be better is the Concierge Lounge, which is a relatively small window less room on the ground floor. It always full during the afternoon tea and early evening hours.
user_name:
ahu98
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We were lucky to arrive on time and catch the last Airport Limousine bus from Narita which drops you directly in front of the hotel. No sign of concierge, the hotel seems to be run on very limited staff.Disappointed that there is no room service or anything to eat after 11pm this is not the standard I've experienced in other Marriotts. Staff couldn't even warm food at this time and the Family Mart downstairs closes at 11pm.The room is very nice but quite plainly decorated. The bathroom however looked quite old. Wifi and aircon worked well and housekeeping did a lovely job each day. We upgraded to the Executive Lounge for our final night at the cost of 6,000 ¥ each. When we arrived we were told there wasn't any room in the lounge and we should go and wait in our room for whenever a seat might become available.This was poor and I had to argue how they can justify charging people for nothing. I noticed two empty tables and after some arguing we were seated. A very poor and negative experience.The food in the lounge however was excellent and the range of drinks for the Happy Hour experience was fantastic. I hadn't expected champagne and this made the price worth it despite the lounge not being big enough to accommodate all guests and attitude of staff.Breakfast for the lounge is taken in the main restaurant so this was really nice with lots of choice. We didn't have a lot of time but still enjoyed it before taking the airport limousine to Haneda airport to pick up a car rental. Overall, if it had a decent pool a bigger lounge and proper room service this could be a 5 star hotel but at the moment it has lessons to learn to improve.

I kinda like the Marriott group of hotels but was left disappointed. 2 incidents, there was a loud noises at 2300hrs for 30-40 mins coming from the room upstairs. I called the service desk and basically asking me what they should do and I told them the obvious to go to the room above me and tell them to stopping banging on the floor. Another incident was I checked in at 2330hrs and There was no food after 11 and told me to go to a family mart yo get some. There was an executive lounge which had biscuits which could be offered, i was not told till I discovered it the next day.The positive part was the chefs at breakfast were very welcoming - she is Czech and the Conceirge person, a Nepali was ever ready to help. So with this, that's why I give it a 3 from a normal 4. Will probably be back again. And one last thing, the tv channels are all in Japanese.

I am currently staying at the Marriott in Tokyo and can only say the service is not up to the standard i am used to either from Marriott or from Japan. it's a pity...I checked in, as one of a group of about 8 people. Upon check-in, at least 2 of us were given the twin queen bedroom we had reserved but upon entering the room we discovered they were smoking rooms. Nothing was mentioned on our reservation. i went straight down to the front desk to ask if it was possible to change to which i was told yes, if i was ok to switch to a king size. i said no problem and was given the key to my room. what wasn't mentioned was that i was given a smaller, lower quality (in particular the bathroom!) room. of course no change to the price. when i asked again the front desk whether there was a mistake, i was told that there were no other rooms available other than the larger smoking rooms or my current small lower standard room. when i said i preferred non smoking, but expected a reduced price if the only room available is of lower standard, i was told repeatedly that i had no choice and no effort would be made on the price. so there you go, i personally don't think it's the right approach and can assure you, it certainly doesn't encourage me to come back here again. fine if you don't have anything else, but the least you could do is make an effort on the price. fortunately the other person got a room of the same standard as his original booking, so at least one of us did ok..

Spent five nights at the Tokyo Marriott Hotel with my 10 year old son. The customer service at the hotel was simply outstanding. The room was large and the bathroom was very spacious too with a nice bath. The lounge was good with good quality dinners and drinks. The breakfast buffet was absolutely amazing with Japanese and Western food option, great coffee and very attentive staff. The shuttle bus to the Shinagawa station was convenient but the walk to the station was only around 10 minutes so sometimes we opted to walk rather than wait for the bus. Overall, highly recommend this hotel
user_name:
Alex D
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel is near Shinagawa station and you can walk there if you travel light. If you have luggage, it is recommended to take taxi (just 1 minute taxi.) They also have free shuttle bus from hotel to Shinagawa station.Room is large and clean, but a little bit boring with the views.Breakfast buffet is excellent, with many items you can enjoy.

This hotel is 12-20 minute walk from Shinagawa station.Public shuttle to and from to the hotel was a better option as Tokyo was a bit humid and it was summer.Provided free breakfast coupons for elite members, so that's good. We however got a smaller room than non-members' that booked standard rooms.Breakfast buffet was great. Fresh (non-concentrate) juice, udon, and others.Not much available in their M-Club. Only bottled water, milk, tea, coffee, and very few snacks. Spacious room (for Tokyo standard), clean and nice bath.Family Mart and small post office is on the lower floor of the hotel.Concierge was great. Helped us call Taxis to the airport and drop my pocket wifi package in the post office on the next day as it was closed then. Can't ask for more. A slight difference attitude at front desk. My bill was printed incorrectly and it took around 10 days after I requested to have it corrected, including few days without any response.

The hotel is about a 15-20 minute walk from Shinagawa station but easy to find. It's a typical Marriott property with the normal big rooms (unusual for Japan). Impressive entrance into the building with a slightly confusing reception location (not obvious from when you walk in but just turn right and walk past the bar/restaurant).Comfortable hotel rooms, quiet in a non-noisy location. All the elegance you would expect of a Marriott with a wonderful bar and restaurant out front. They even have mobile charging stations they can loan you at the bar to recharge you dying mobile phone.Good sized Executive Lounge with interesting food for breakfast and dinner. Wonderful staff in the lounge taking care of your needs too.Rooms had the usual you'd expect including iron, hairdryers, toiletries, safe, big television and comfortable beds. Pleasure to stay here - nice touch that they give Elite members two free drinks at the bar on arrival. Would definitely stay here again if I return to Tokyo for work!

My wife and 2 daughters age 14 and 17 stayed for 4 nights here in two separate rooms. The rooms were well appointed and very clean. The staff are very traditional Japanese polite, attentive, professional, but with a western familiarity. The hotel has a very good restaurant for breakfast, lunch or dinner. We had breakfast buffet each day, which was very delicious with fresh cooked omelettes and waffles to traditional udon noodle. Our dinner was as delicious very professional staff and attention to detail was outstanding. The hotel is a short walk 5 minutes to the Shinagawa train station and Taxi's are always available to get anywhere in Tokyo. TO THE STAFF YOU ARE ALL DOING AN AMAZING JOB

It was my third Tokyo trip in 14 months. We always stay at Shinjuku, would like to try some new location for us, and obviously it was a good idea. The room was clean and tidy, front desk officer were attentive and very friendly, helped us a lot during our 4 nights stay, we would definitely come back next time.

My wife secured a very favorable rate for the two of us in a very large room (unusual for Tokyo) A huge and varied Breakfast was included and its value was half the price of the room. The concierge was polite and helpful - there is a free bus to and from Shinagawa Station every 20 minutes. The other highlight of the visit was (being a lifetime Platinum member) access to the Executive Lounge with dinner-like snacks and a pletory of adult beverages. Good for business travelers too.

I had an enjoyable stay at the Tokyo Marriott. With its impressive light filled atrium and dining area, I thought wow this is going to be good. I was met by the Concierge/Supervisor and was promptly shown to the check in area. Everything there went ok and soon I was up in my room. Again pleasantly surprised. Lovely toiletries, terrific shower, good size room with plenty of light with a modern white twist. Not knowing exactly where it was in relation to the railway station (Tokyo main station for the shinkasen), we took a taxi and it was about a 10 minute ride. I wouldn't recommend walking if you don't like the heat/humidity and have suitcases to contend with as well (this is a personal thing though). Had dinner in the restaurant one night and it was lovely and service was very good. A big shout out to Maharjan Bishal who helped me courier a gift I had for a friend in Tokyo and also Maharjan Rajeshwor (Bellboy) for their assistance. Also their English was impeccable. Something I found lacking in the other hotels that I stayed in whilst in Japan.Whilst I liked the hotel and everything else about it, I'm not sure of the location. It is located in Shinagawa, a bit further south of Tokyo than I thought. You are away from the action and bright lights of Shinjuku/Shibuya/Ginza, however, if you are looking for some peace and quiet, then it's ok. There was a regular free shuttle that stopped outside the hotel to take you to the metro train station if you wanted to which was helpful if you didn't want to walk in the heat and humidity. Just one thing that I thought was odd was that where the shuttle bus dropped you off wasn't where you got it to go back to the hotel. It was on the opposite side of the road which was rather confusing.Also if you are coming from or going to Haneda Airport, the Airport Limousine bus stops right outside the door (will cost you about 720 Yen) and can be booked via the concierge (would suggest the day before you leave) when departing the hotel.Lastly and this was a bit off putting, I was also charged twice for my accommodation. After several emails to the Tokyo Marriott and a phone call to the Marriott Customer Service Centre all was rectified. Other than that, as a hotel for its cleanliness, appearance, staff and service, I would recommend staying there.

spent 2 nights at the Tokyo Marriott. Staff are very polite and courteous, they go the extra mile for you. Room was comfortable as was bed and pillows, spotless and clean.All staff greeted you with a warm smile made you feel most welcome.Had a lovely dinner at their restaurant, lobster tail, it was presented beautifully and delicious.Could not fault the Marriott.

Amazing hotel, great location ,good for business or pleasure. Nice rooms, elevators, beds, bathroom,transportation.Great customer service staff. Good price, valuable hotel. I love it. If can go again to Tokyo I will stay at the same Hotel.

The hotel is in Shinagawa area and is around 10 minutes walk from the station, however they also provide round trip free shuttle as well. Sadly, we do not know that so we inevitably walk up the hills with our heavy luggage when we first arrive Shinagawa station. There is no time schedule and pick up location from their website until we were told during check-in.We arrive at around 4pm and was greeted to the executive lounge for check in. Staff is friendly and efficient and offer us wet towels (Tokyo is hot!! We are sweating with our heavy luggages!) She also explained the neighbourhood briefly. The executive lounge is small and windowless. We immediately get the room key and back to the room. This time we are staying in the superior corner room. The room is spacious and comfortable, with two big windows overlooking the city and the train rail (somehow guest may find it noisy but we are fine). Those prefer breathtaking view should book a room on high floor, you may also see the Haneda airport if you are lucky enough. We then went to the executive lounge again for the evening cocktail. The lounge is busy and full of people. Luckily we arrived early, otherwise we have to wait for the table. Food and beverage selection is wide and taste is also good. I especially recommend the deep fried beef patty. Food refill is also quick. But the design of the lounge should be improved in some way, at least it should be enlarged to accommodate hotel guests. We then went out for site seeing and returned at mid night. The bed is fresh, smooth and silky. We had a very good sleep. On the following day, we had breakfast in the only restaurant of the hotel, offering buffet breakfast. Again, there is a long queue when it is 9am. But staff is efficient that we are able to get the table in 10 minutes. Food selection is good and I am very happy to have fresh fruit in the buffet (normally I only saw canned or sweetened fruits in hotel buffet). All fruit juices are freshly squeezed, tastes healthy and refreshing. We check out early at around 1100 and take the shuttle again to the station.Overall, the location of the hotel is not perfect, but they have free shuttle. I find it quite different from Osaka Marriott and Nagoya Marriott hotel, in which the other 2 hotels seems to be more large scale in terms of rooms, executive lounge and restaurants. It will be a perfect stay if better guest traffic control can be made.
user_name:
porkypugpug
New York City, New York

review_body: Staying here currently and decided to go to the gym and pool. Was shocked when I was asked to pay for the use of swimming pool! Pool is paid and I was asked to go to the reception and enrol to Marriott membership if I wanted to use gym without paying. I mentioned that I am already a member. It was further annoying when I was told to show my Marriott membership card or tell number if I wanted to use the gym despite having provided my membership details at the time of checking in. Do you expect guests to carry their membership card all the time? And if so, plz be kind enough in mentioning it at the time of booking so that we can go to other properties and not stay with you. Although the place is good, it ruined my entire experience. Have never stayed in any of your properties (or other hotels) across the world so far where a guest is asked to pay for gaining access to swimming pool or gym. If your policies are so strict, you should mention clearly on your website that the hotel doesn't have pool or gym unless you pay extra...that way at least you are not misleading all the guests who expect these basic services which all your other properties or competitive hotels seem to provide....I am really thankful to you for not charging me to use the washroom attached to my room or not asking me to register prior its usage....Worst experience ever!!!!!

Room was ok, but don't care for the small double beds. Usually offered a King at other hotels I have stayed at. Breakfast no included and NOT cheap either. Plan on 20-40 USD for either breakfast or lunch. Dinner is much more.The hotel itself is several miles from Ginza, and just about anything else fun to do for that matter. No restaurants close either. It will cost you about 2500 yen, which is about $25 each way in a cab to run down to Ginza district. If comfortable with the trains, then it you could save some money, but will take longer.If you like walking and seeing the beautiful sites in Tokyo, this may not be the ideal choice for you. There are plenty of others closer to the action.Good -- it was slightly cheaper, decent room. Not so good -- location, cost of food, no king bed.Also.. had to wait for taxi as they don't have many staged like the other hotels.

Probably my last year of being a Platinum member, I wanted to go to Osaka and stay at Marriott there because its room was great and its executive lounge was super. However, since we live in Chiba, just east of Tokyo, I decided to give the Tokyo conterpart a try. While its room was great the bathroom has a tub and take shower inside the tub. While Osaka Marriott has a shower only room and its shower fell from top of the ceiling like Niagara Falls, which is what I like. Now the executive lounge. Tokyo's lounge was about a quarter size of that of Osaka's. A clar win for Osaka. Its wine was not as good as Osaka's. Whiskey was fine. Foods. Clar winner was Osaka. Best food in Tokyo was Takoyaki follwed by Yakisoba. In the afternoon Tokyo offered a tiny Japanese confectionary which was super good but they were so small. One clear advantage for Tokyo was that you could have breakfast buffet at its regular restaurant. I wonder why some of the contributors did not like the idea. Overall, Tokyo Marriott was no match to Osaka. I have been to many Marriott lounges and the Osaka has been clearly the best. But Tokyo Marriott was good too.
