So we probably go stay again later in the year before my platinum status expires.

Visited Tokyo for the first time as part of a Round the World trip and wanted a quality hotel. Tokyo Marriott delivered and more. This is a stylish property in a stylish city. Not very central, perhaps but near enough to airport and city centre. The hotel is spotless (pretty much like Tokyo) and the service is exemplary. It is not low cost but then hardly anything is in Tokyo!. Above all the staff are wonderful.......well trained, polite and communicative. I would not hesitate to return or to recommend this hotel to others.

The hotel room we were given had a weird musty and smokey smell. I told the manager at the executive lounge and he moved us rooms right away. The next room had the same smell, but I do appreciate the service and efficency at the hotel. Also the hotel provides a great buffet breakfast.
user_name:
SRK123451
New York City, New York

review_body: My family and I had a decent stay at the Tokyo Marriott in June. We were in town to explore and enjoy the city. The staff was friendly and the room itself was large for Japanese standards. We are gold members so we were able to dine in the lounge after our days touring the city. During check out we mistakenly left our laptop at the front desk. We didn't realize it until we arrived at the airport. We called the hotel and asked them to place the laptop on the airport bus (the method which we traveled to the airport), but they recommended a taxi instead which would cost ~ $200. After much debate, we decided to have the laptop shipped to America. Via email exchange the hotel stated it would cost ~ $80 to ship the laptop. When the package arrived the postage was ~$60, ($20 short of the quoted price) They took advantage of my mistake and profited, poor customer service in my opinion.This entire experience ruined an otherwise good trip. It had me rethink my Marriott loyalty, but I'm not one to let one incident change my view on an otherwise good hotel chain. Moral of the story .... don't leave your laptop at the hotel. But if you do be aware that this property will certainly profit off it! James

Stayed one night at this hotel for a business trip. Stayed on 5th floor and the room was fairly decent. Breakfast was not included and had to pay about $30 USD for a typical breakfast buffet but remember this is Tokyo. Bed was comfortable. Be mindful you have to flush toilet using the panel/buttons on the wall. Will definitely stay for business again.

It's a nice hotel. However, the hotel room is very small but that is standard for Tokyo. The service is a bit sterile but still very helpful. The real attraction to staying here is the location. Recommend!

Starting with the good - clean room, friendly staff, really good breakfast. Ideal location only a 15 minute walk from Shinagawa station connecting us to the rest of Tokyo. Breakfast was really good - and the cook to order menu was very generous. Loved the smoothies.The reason for the 4 star rating was because the administration really made our check in experience uncomfortable. This stay was part of a much larger three week stay across the globe, so as you can imagine a lot of money exchanged hands between multiple properties. To reduce the amount of charges on my credit card while I was away, I prepaid for all of the hotel expenses in advance. This was processed without an issue, but as I'm sure everyone is aware most hotels take an additional amount at checkin to cover additional room charges/expenses such as laundry, room service, restaurant charges etc. I emailed all the hotels I was going to be staying at well in advance to figure out what that amount was going to be. All hotels, including the other ones in Japan, came back very quickly and explained what they would require at checkin for a deposit. I emailed this hotel multiple times and each time I was told that they would not require any amount for incidentals because we had prepaid for the room. When we arrived very late at night after a 10 hr flight, we were told very clearly that we needed to provide a credit card so that they could pre-authorize 50,000 JPY. We were totally unprepared for this requirement and luckily we had a credit card that we could swipe for that kind of an amount, but it certainly was not planned. I realize that this is a country where English is not the first language, but If they can clearly explain it at check in, they can clearly explain in an email prior to arrival to prepare the guest - especially one that is taking as long of a trip as I did.

Perfect hotel to start off our Japan trip. Great, clean room with an amazing buffet breakfast. Very friendly staff. About a five minute walk to the Shinagawa station. This hotel is some-what in a business district, but because it is a short what to the train station it is very easy to travel to the airport and all areas in Tokyo for fun attractions and food.

We had very pleasant stay in Tokyo Marriott hotel with my friends. Actually It's not too close from the subway station but there's free shuttle bus to go by the schedule. Generally hotel is very clean and luxury. It's not 4'star hotel staff service, Its exactly 5 star hotel service!!The staff(Christine?) at the front desk who checked us in, she did warm welcome for us :) When we are hesitating at the lobby, the concierge staff expecially 'Madoka' she helped entire of our stay. She's so lovely!Then, we had a breakfast at the restaurant, the staff, her name was 'Chang', and 'Korean Chef( I am sorry I don't remember his name)'also were fantastic with beautiful manner and service!!On our last day, when we did check out, 'Hashino' at the front desk helped us. Even we forgot to get our receipt but he urgently ran in front to us (on the way to go to take a airport bus) and gave us the receipt! It was made me special and he was so detail!All of your staff are very friendly, helpful and try to help us once they find out someone is looking around in hotel. Two Tumbs up!!!!!!We stayed there for 3night. The service was fantatic than I expected! I will stay when I travel again in Tokyo

There are some terrific things about this hotel:1. Very helpful staff2. Great exec lounge (if you have access)3. Fully provisioned breakfast buffet4. Large rooms5. Comfortable bedsThere are also some not so terrific 1. Expensive. Only with corporate discounts does it compare with other hotels in the area. If you can take advantage of the lounge then the high price is easier to understand.2. Inconvenient location. It's just a bit too far from the station. The bus helps if you don't want to walk.3. Trains run next to hotel. Get a room on an upper floor to help reduce the noise impact.4. Baths are poorly designed and showing age. The strange half shower door leaves the floor wet and shower drafty.

I'm giving this hotel 4 stars, only because it is a little isolated. The hotel itself is great and has modern western rooms that were actually larger than what I had imagined. The closest restaurants are a 10 minute walk away, but there is a family mart in the lower lobby ( great for snacks and drinks). The large Shinagawa train station is a 10 minute walk away, which is fine, but sometimes us lazy Aussies wished it was right outside!

This is the fourth stay at this hotel and it is still very good. The rooms are large and spotless and the service from the staff is excellent.The restaurant is good and the Executive Lounge have stepped up their food quality. The location in Shinagawa is OK but there is not much else around although there is a complimentary bus to Shinagawa Station and easy access to downtown Tokyo on the Yamanote line.

Was meant to stay for three nights but reduced to two as was so disappointing.As a platinum member I expect so much more from a Marriott hotel. The facilities at the hotel are basically non existamt with one restaurant that you have to use for breakfast and a very small executive lounge on the ground floor in a windowless environment that gets very crowded.Rooms are very small and if you look at the fire escape maps obviously being a platinum member does not mean a upgrade or larger rooms.On checkout I asked for a car to the airport so that I could pay on my bill but was told bluntly that as I had not booked I would have to get a taxi...great service.Disappointing that there are no other restaurants in the hotel so I walked around and found some good places to eat about a 10 minute walk away.Overall very disappointed with the hotel and surprised Marriott class it as a Marriott and not another lower brand in their portfolio, I will avoid if I return to Tokyo

We had a pleasant stay in this hotel (stayed at 8th floor). Though it is not close to the train station, they have service shuttles to ferry guests to and from the hotel. (Its quite a walk if you miss it) The hotel is very clean and posh and the service staff are excellent and friendly. Christmas decors were nice too. But Hopefully, the ambience at the lobby should reflect the mood and colour of the holiday season instead of the very hush and office-like mood we observed during our 7 days stay. Will visit again.

Rooms here are generous compared to what is typical in Tokyo, probably because the location is away from city center. Hotel is 7-minute walk (or faster shuttle) from Shinagawa train station so access to all parts of Tokyo is easy. Train station, typical for Japan, is a hub of activity, including food courts, bakeries, and restaurants. So plenty of options. Breakfast (unfortunately not included) was pricey but truly excellent. Huge range of Japanese and European options and of the highest quality. Like all Japanese hotels we visited, there is a chronic shortage of drawer space. But in every other way the Marriott excelled in terms of room comfort. Excellent staff and service. Nexpresso machines in the room (but ask the desk for more pods, there are only two caffeine/two decaf supplied).

My family just came back from Japan yesterday after spending 2 nights in Tokyo and 5 nights in Osaka. The Tokyo Marriott is conveniently located in Shinagawa. (Shinagawa Railway Station is about 10 min by train from Tokyo Railway Station). A 10 min stroll from the Shinagawa station will bring you to the hotel. However there is a free regular shuttle service to and fro the hotel from Shinagawa station. The shuttle bus stand is located just outside the Railway station and next to the regular bus stand.Checking in was a breeze. The level of service was good. Our room was located on the 4th floor overlooking a small garden which was fairly pleasant.The room size was good....I have no complaint. The bed is firm and they have a range of pillows on request, subject to availability, including Tempur pillows. I stand corrected but I think the room safe was not available.The toilet / bathroom size was also fairly generous. My only lamentation was the bathtub. I would have preferred a shower tray / cubicle since I am not so young and have to struggle in and out of the bathtub. However there is a small drainage along the edge of the bathtub. This is well thought out to ensure the rest of tbe bathroom is not too wet (even though half the bathtub has a glass panel) to prevent water from splashing out and wetting the toilet which can be annoying.The range of Thann brand of toileteries offered is comprehensive and there is a list of additional toiletries which are not placed in the bathroom eg after-shave lotion, hair clip, etc available on request.Intetestingly the Executive Lounge of this hotel is located at the Lobby level (as opposed to many Exexutive Lounges which are normally at the top or almost top floor). The Executive Lounge is located after the Dining / Lounge area separated by the kitchen just before the Receptionist Counter. The drinks / finger food for afternoon tea and evening cocktails / canapes are reasonable, adequate and tasty. This Executive Lounge does not serve breakfast which is served only in the Dining / Lounge. Breakfast has a respectable variety of offerings, both western and japanese cuisine. It is definitely more than sufficient for anyone even for those with a very hearty appetite.....yum yum!To sum up, it was indeed a very positive experience, certainly a wonderful and memorable experience.

We stayed here at the end of May and in June on our 25th wedding anniversary tour. Our first encounter with a Duty Manager was a bit shaky BUT after that everything was excellent! The staff, the food, the service and the location was excellent. The hotel is a very short bus ride away from Shinagawa station. The bus is complimentary and takes 5 minutes from hotel door to station. Easy access to and from Haneda Airport, metro lines and the Shinkansen. Excellent value for money!

The size of the room was big (40-50sq meter) which I did not expected in Japan. Hotel is not far away from Shinagawa Station just 10mins walking distance. The staffs are friendly, likes Ms. 立澤 at reception and a girl at Concierge (speak fluent English). Definitely will recommend to others.

Stayed for 4 nights. Rooms are big. Considered mostly a business hotel. Concierge was helpful but sometimes it was difficult to communicate. Located in Shinagawa, a few stops from most main stations in Tokyo. There is a free shuttle from hotel to Shinagawa station which was great. Very clean. Breakfast buffet was delicious with a lot of options! Would recommend to others but not to travelers with children.

We stayed at the Tokyo Marriott Hotel in May 2017. It truly became our home away from home and thought it was a nice blend of East and West. We utilized the executive lounge and thought it was fantastic. The location was close to Shinagawa and that was really easy to get anywhere in Tokyo. Everything you could want was right there. We aren't in for too much nightlife so can't comment about that.

We stayed 3 nights at this Marriott in a family room which was adequate for us. The hotel has a very courteous staff, everyone is smiling and very helpful. The breakfast was excellent spread of local and international cuisine. There is a small Japanese garden right next to the hotel for peaceful morning walks. It is located 1 km from the Shingawa train station - very helpful for local travel and for taking the bullet train to other cities. There is a frequent free shuttle between the station and the hotel. The housekeeping was excellent. No matter how late we left the room they magically got it cleaned when we came back and also did the turn down service everyday. Overall - a very nice experience.

Very nice hotel with exceptional level of service and fantastic breakfast setup (probably the best I've seen for a hotel with superb quality) made this a 5 star rating. Turn down service included. Though not a Park Hyatt in terms of luxury level, this is a great place to base your trip to Tokyo since the Shinagawa station is nearby.Also, their concierge got me into Jiro's for lunch, so BIG bonus for that! Wifi could've been faster.

Very nice hotel with very good service. Our bus got us there well before it was time to check in. We were told that as soon as the room was ready they will let us know. In the meantime we could have breakfast and stay at the lounge (this is included in your member status). Just as we had finished breakfast, we were told that the room was ready and our bags have been taken to the room. The room is spacious with a nice size bathroom. Comfortable bed. The only draw back is that it gets very hot at night. I complained to them and our A/C was changed to 18C. However, we felt that they must reduce the A/C through out the hotel at night. Hence, the heat! Breakfast was good and had enough of a spread to please everyone. I have to give a shout out to the staff at the Executive Lounge. They were awesome!!! Thank you for always making sure there was enough evening food to please everyone, including drinks. Since the space is rather small, it can get very crowded at times with no place to sit. The staff still managed to do their best.

It seems as though the Marriott Reward Platinum member comments made by a number of other contributors are consistent !! It is so frustrating to check-in late at night and to receive absolutely no Platinum recognition whatsoever. As with others, you are then given what can only be described as a clean, but quite out-dated basic room with a shower over the bath with a curtain. For some bizarre and unknown reason, despite having a spacious Executive Lounge, you can't have breakfast in it. Instead you are told to go to the extremely busy main restaurant where you wait to get a table and are then seated a few centimetres away from other guests. I can't think of another hotel that has an Executive Lounge but does not serve breakfast in it. The choice of food is decent but the environment is far from satisfactory, especially when you know the Executive Lounge around the corner is empty !! It is a very functional hotel in a good location but if you are a frequent Marriott guest, lower your expectations prior to arrival.

This is a better than average Marriott, the rooms are well maintained, comfortable and clean. The TV choices are limited and the audio keeps dropping the english and going to Japanese. The internet is extremely slow. But the breakfast is very good.

Hotel was perfect! Less then a mile from the JR Line(10 minute walk) that will take you anywhere in the city. Staff is friendly and helpful. The breakfast lounge was the best part of the hotel. Pretty extensive buffet from different regions including an American style breakfast. Overall this is just a classic Marriott, you know what you're going to get, professional service and clean efficient rooms.

We booked a twin deluxe room for our 7 days stay at Tokyo Marriott. We were tired from our early flight and we were greeted by very polite and accommodating staff. They allowed us to check in early and to our surprise, they upgraded us to a family room. My two kids were so happy to see our clean and spacious room. What's more you can see the sakura from our window. There is a small park right outside the hotel where you can stroll & relax. It was very helpful too that there's free shuttle bus to & from shinagawa station arriving & departing on time. Thank you Tokyo Marriott for your excellent service!

This hotel is in need of updating... We stayed here after Taipei and the experience at this hotel was so different than at the Taipei Marriott (which was fantastic). The hotel is near Shinagawa Station which is big transit hub. There's a shuttle bus that takes you between the hotel and the station; it runs on a fixed schedule and is super convenient during the day and evening. During the times it doesn't run, the station is only an easy 10-15 minute walk away. Shinagawa is actually a pretty convenient place to be - you can get to most major tourist sites from there.As a Platinum, your check-in is handled in the Executive Lounge which is on the lobby floor. The lady gave us the absolute smallest room in the building. All you have to do is take a look at the fire escape map and you can see how small the room is compared to all other ones. As a Marriott Platinum, I expected a much better room. I asked for some fruit and nuts as my Platinum Arrival Gift, and you know what they brought? A bowl of chopped almonds and dried cranberries which was plastic-wrapped. It did not look appetizing at all. Turns out it was the same stuff they serve in the Lounge.After having a terrible night of sleep, we asked to be moved the next morning. They said they'd check but would not promise anything. When we got back later that day, they moved us to a regular room on a non-Club floor but it was at least twice as big. We were staying about 6 days so I asked why we didn't get an upgrade and the excuse was that there were many Golds and Platinums at the hotel... I wonder what those other Platinums are getting.The Executive Lounge has no windows and is a pretty depressing place to hang out in. The good thing is they offer a broad selection of liquors in the evening and they have a lot of bottled water to take away when touring the city.Breakfast is served in the main lobby restaurant. Decent selection of western and eastern food, and they'll make you eggs, omelettes, pancakes, and waffles to order. Service is so-so though - on two days, we had to ask 5 different times for coffee when we were seated (despite the fact that the hostess asked us what we wanted for coffee when she placed us).Overall, this was a pretty standard hotel experience, but I rated them as "poor" since we were really not taken care of even though we gave them them several chances to do right by us. I was expecting so much more as a Platinum, but I guess I got spoiled in London and Taipei.

Stayed there 2 nights, room is decent, a bit noisy with the trains passing by.Good room amenities ( Thann)Location wise, this Marriott is a bit remote despite offering a shuttle to Shinagawa Station.Service is where the hotel is faulty I suppose:- Wireless Internet Connection is at best erratic ( could barely keep up signal constantly)- Room service very slow ( called me back to mention it would take more than 35 mn as per original time..)- Went for breakfast at first in the Executive Lounge ( which was empty and had really nothing then walked out to the public area...) breakfast is simple, nothing special ...Ordered some tea, never got it.- Requested some information and help to buy a Narita Express ticket...not much helped received.

We booked 2 rooms and stayed on 2 separate occasions at Marriott Tokyo in Shinagawa. Both stays were outstanding and my family were very impressed with the level of service, courtesy and attention they received. I was very fortunate and grateful to have Mr. Hiroshi-san at the Front Desk to take extra time and special attention to accommodate both our reservations. In my opinion, and being a lifetime Platinum member of Marriott I would rate Mr. Hiroshima-san up there as one of the best customer service representatives I have ever encountered staying at a Marriott properties anywhere. He truly cared and appreciated my loyalty to Marriott. Breakfast, concierge lounges and guest services like transportation, in-room service, etc were all outstanding. The ladies working in the concierge lounge were most helpful and attentive. Location being near Shinagawa station is a big plus if your are connecting and using JR, Tokyo metro, Shinkansen etc. Free shuttle is a nice plus as well. It is also a nice and pleasant walk to the station. Although there are minimal shopping and restaurants in the immediate area the hotel does offer a bit more peaceful and quieter break from the bright lights of Shibuya, Shinjuku, etc.We would definitely return to this property on our next visit to Tokyo.

As expected, the service and ambiance are wonderful. The room was thoughtfully, and classically appointed. Lovely Japanese china for in-room coffee and tea service, beautifully appointed living and seating areas, extended amenities in the bathroom. I greatly enjoyed in-room and in-hotel experience. The executive lounge was conveniently located on the lobby level, with a door connecting to the main restaurant, for easy access to breakfast buffet. The location meant that there was no view, so the lounge was rather dark and uninviting. The breakfast buffet was truly amazing--with a complete range of breakfast options across cultures. The lounge offers complimentary snacks during the day, an evening food / dessert service, and drinks. The alcohol disappears promptly at 9:30, which is rather disappointing on the weekends.The hotel location is convenient to train station, but you are in a neighborhood that is pretty far removed from tourist / sightseeing activities.

Smooth check in and check out (thanks to Miku at the executive lounge). Comfortable room. Thanks for a high floor for Marriott platinum member. Capsule coffee machine. breakfast was very good. order items - eggs, waffles were great. Juice section was good as well. thanks for making watermelon juice (Mr. Kind staff ). Will return to this great hotel in Tokyo. Swimming pool and gym were the other building, so need to walk a bit (normal in Japan, but not convenient).Swimming pool is good.

I am Marriott Platinum and was highly satisfied, with service, rooms and treatment. Great staff! Really professional and courteous, effective!I was concerned about its location, but actually it is very well connected to multiple means of transportation, including complimentary hotel bus, so not an issue whatsoever.On map, location seems very south of city, but not so. Convenient if using Haneda because it is closer. If using NRT, limo bus makes stop at hotel. NRT Express stops at Shinagawa. Easy.Overall treated very, very well. Check in at Executive Level on ground floor; Very formal, received letters, etc. Offered water and Espresso.Welcome Gift of macaroon and welcome card at RoomWelcome Gift, Choice of Non Alcoholic Drink and Snack or 500 points. Took points since Executive Level has drinks and snacks at all times.Daily turn down service with a different small gift each night, Chocolates, etc1 drink voucher for 2 drinks in lobby bar, anything on menu, had some fine Japanese sake and whisky ~$75Upgrade to high floor, bay view, deluxe room, spacious and well appointed, ie, safe, minibar, robes and slippers, pijamas, small fridge, desk, etc and robot toiletAccess to Lounge for evening self serve happy hour, 4-7 choices of desserts, plus at least 15 choices of hot dishes, fried foods, cold cuts, cheese, etc. Small and no windows, but in my stay never overcrowded.Full breakfast at restaurant, including egg station and Asian noodle dishes.Free Spa access for gold and platinum . Large gym including outdoor tennis courts, dry sauna, hot tub. Dated, but very well maintained.Free Schedule Shuttle access to Shinagawa Station, JR line, NRT Express,etc; If you choose to walk, 10 minutes, not too steep hillLimousine Bus Stop, drop off and pick up at hotel lobby2 bottles of water, replenished dailyFree wifi, very reliable and fastLate 4pm Check OutBuilding Complex has Bank ATM and Convenience Store on lower floor.20% off coupon for food and drinks at restaurant Location, south of city, but easy access to all transportation.Cash stays incur a 10% service charge.

The Tokyo Marriott Hotel excels in many ways, particularly when it comes to service. We are Platinum Elite Marriott Rewards members and often feel “valued” by Marriott. But this hotel goes well beyond that of many other hotels (this is often the case when comparing Asian hotels to that of Europe, Australia, and the U.S.). The hotel is located in an office complex, surrounded by a park. It is about a 10-minute walk from a major railroad station – Shinagwawa. There is a shuttle bus to and from the hotel, which runs about every 15 minutes. However, we were very confused the first time and ended up taking a taxi (about $5), because the bus had the name of the building on it, and not the Marriott. That, however, was the only problem we had during our stay. The train station is surrounded by small restaurants, including in the Wing Department store. We were greeted as we walked in the door and taken to register at the executive lounge. The lounge is small and unimpressive, but you have breakfast at the excellent restaurant in the lobby. The breakfast buffet is outstanding. The lounge also has tea service and substantial snacks in the early evening.The rooms (we stayed twice, with a trip to Kyoto between them) were very nice: extremely comfortable, with views over the river. The beds were large and comfortable and the bathroom well appointed, including a heated toilet with a multitude of functions. The rooms have plenty of storage, a safe, bathrobes, slippers, iron (abet, a strange one), and an ironing board. There is an okay fitness club in an attached building, which is free to silver and up elite members. Internet is free to Marriott Rewards members (join there if you're not a member). The quality of the Internet was not great, but overall adequate. As I said, the most impressive feature is the service. For example, many of the staff called us by name shortly after our first arrival. Upon our return, we were greeted by a young woman who called my husband by name and took us in hand.

The hotel is quite pricey but it's located next to the very well connected Shinagawa station, staff and customer service have been outstanding, and breakfast, especially fresh fruits, were to die for. Great stay

Yes it is convenient as an American staying in Tokyo to pick an American chain but the Tokyo (Shinagawa) property has attention to detail down to a science in making sure every aspect of your stay is comfortable and satisfying. The facilities are quite nice as is the myriad of food and beverage options found throughout the hotel from top to bottom - bar and dining on lobby level topped off with Sky on top floor (great views of the city). The rooms are quite comfortable and well appointed for leisure or business stay and the location is ideal less than a kilometer from the major Shinagawa train station which get you anywhere in the city, Narita airport or bullet (Shinkansen) train connections for travel elsewhere in Japan. A convenient shuttle bus makes it easy to get to and from. Staff os wonderful and highly attentive to your needs - takes the stress out of overseas travel and acts as a nice oasis in Tokyo.

My husband and I stayed here two years ago. Based on that great stay we decided to stay here again this trip. Everyone of the staff members are committed to making our stay here the best and most memorable visit possible. The room was spacious and the view of Tokyo tower spectacular. I highly recommend this hotel and encourage you to give it consideration if you are coming to Tokyo

plus point of this hotel are convenient store in basement, jogging track attached with this hotel, and free internet for marriott memberminus point are quite far from JR train station even there are free shuttles from the station into the hotel. there is no electricity plug with international holes. Also very limited free seat in the public area.

As a business traveler I finally got to take a family vacation using Marriott Reward points.The concierge staff was very helpful to me in planning for my trip to Tokyo. I emailed them a lot asking questions as I researched my stay. They were always quick to respond with helpful answers and making arrangements for me.The room was a bit on the small side. My king size bed was more like a queen size but that was ok for me since I'm average size. The room itself was nicely decorated.I loved loved loved the warm toilet seat!The breakfast in the restaurant was outstanding with a very wide variety of choices. My family loved all of the food.The hotel is in a residential area but within walking distance to the train which will take you everywhere you want to go in Tokyo.

I stayed here for 2 nights after arriving into Tokyo Haneda with my daughter. The hotel is a short 5 minute taxi ride from Shinagawa station. Our room was spacious (for Tokyo) with modern decor and amenities. The beds were really comfortable and we slept well. The best part about our stay was the delicious breakfast! They had a little bit of everything whatever your taste and it was all delicious. We will definitely stay here again.

Great hotel overall.Platinum lounge is relaxed with great alcohol and food options.Breakfast spread is 5 star, with everything that you could ever need.Shuttle bus to nearest station, every 15 minutes from next door business centerAmazing toilet with seat warmer every time you sit down!First class all round!

I stayed in Tokyo Marriott in April 3-5th. I was extremely disappointed starting from check-in through check out. Although it was clearly stated in my profile (I am a platinum member in Marriott) as well as my verbal reminding during check out, they still put me at smoking room in 16th floor. After complaining to their reception manager and staying at a smoking room first day, then next day they change room.In the next day, when I went to the breakfast at 10:20 am (which is closing at 10:30) in the morning, the staff was checking their watches and acting like I was late :) I would probably never stay in this hotel again! The difference between Marriott and Sakura Prince hotel is monumental. I would Prince Sakura Prince in any given day. p.s. the only reason I gave 2 stars, because when i check out, their concierge manager personally apologized from me and genuinely listen my feedback. He is the only diamond among rough.

I was recently in the Shinagawa area for business and found that the Marriott had a much better value for price than the other options. I am Marriott Gold due to a frequent flyer perk and it's truly the first time I felt special as a Gold, with access to the Executive lounge and free breakfast. I was in a room on the high-teens and did not hear the trains very much, although I could hear it early in the morning a bit. Amenities in the room were excellent, although the bathtub was merely adequate by Japanese luxury standards. The location is probably the biggest minus, although we found that the bus from Shinagawa was pretty frequent at the times we needed to go to and from the hotel. On the other hand, it's in a pretty quiet residential area (the high-rent district!). Breakfast was also merely adequate. Compared to Grand Hyatts I've stayed at in East Asia, it was lacking. The staff at the breakfast were nice and friendly but not too competent. I observed several communication failures with other western guests. The staff on checkin and checkout was first-rate. Very efficient as you'd expect, and proactively offered me late checkout due to Gold.

We really enjoyed staying at the Tokyo Marriott, the executive lounge was as you would expect at an international Marriott - free breakfast in cafe & snacks/drinks in the evening. What put this lounge over the top was the beautiful woman who assisted us Yuki, greeted us at checkin and assisted us with directions, airport shuttles, and kept us from being lost a couple of times :-). She was a model for others. However, there were a couple of things that caused us to rate this hotel a 4. The hotel in next to a major train line and therefore has ongoing train traffic nearly all night. We stayed in room 1215 and it was a very nice room, but looked down on the tracks. It wasn't high enough to keep from hearing all traffic. You need to be aware to ask for rooms either very high or away from the train tracks (or both). The hotel has a shuttle to the train station from 7:30 to 21:30 - great location, but you'll need to take a cab back from the station to hotel if you are out later. Only other gripe is that there is no place I could find where they provide the Japanese address for the hotel to show to cab drivers until you get to the hotel. Definitely will stay again, but will definitely request a different room location

Be prepared for small rooms specially if you have big luggages. Hotel has a nice and clean room but the space is very limited.Also, you don't find ice machines as you usually do on all Marriotts around the US

Stayed here many times for my business trip to Tokyo, and here is my perspective on this hotel in comparison with Prince Sakura Tower as a Marriott Rewards elite member. Pros: - Executive lounge (not a good one; at least there is one)- Compliment pressing especially with the overnight service - Slightly more choices and western menu items for breakfast - Slightly cheaper than Sakura TowerCons: - Not a convenient location; need to take public transportation to get to Shinagawa station- No restaurants nearby- Rooms at Sakura Tower has better views of Tokyo or beautiful garden- Gym not a part of the hotel; privately owned and operated- Smoking and non-smoking rooms are on the same floor (smell is unbearable)- Feels dated and industrial compared with traditional Japanese charm with modern amenities at Prince Sakura Tower Once Sakura Tower completes their lounge, I think I am taking my business to My latest stay has been absolutely awful with the cigarette smell in the room and the hallways. To be fair, they offered to change the room, but it was too late after I was all unpacked and settled in. I was certain that they marketed this property as 100% smoke-free; not sure when it changed.

Stayed 2 nights, was planning on 3 nights, but didn't offer corporate rate for Saturday night, price more than doubled to over 500 usd. Lounge was ok, on first floor, room was very nice and as expected. Staff was very good, had a few issues with the bill, the booked rates, and canceling the 3rd night, but it all worked out in end. About 10 min walk from Shinagawa Station, or they have a shuttle 3-4 times an hour to and from station, slightly less on weekend and holidays. Breakfast was standard Mariott buffet.
user_name:
NukeExpatinTheDesert
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Stayed at this hotel for 8 nights on a mother daughter birthday trip!A 10-15 minute walk (depending on how much luggage you have) from the JR SHINAGAWA TAKANAGA EXITAs soon as we entered the hotel staff quickly handled our luggage & waited for the check in process.Hotel was very nice wonderful rooms ours was on the 12th floor no train noise could be heardStaff was very helpful with any questions you had even gave us a map of the train lines and told us which lines to take to get to our destinationThe free shuttle bus runs about every 15 minutes from outside the gotenyama building during the weekdays from 7:15 am - 10:00 dropping you off right across from the JR station.The weekend bus runs about every 20 minutes from 9:00-7:00If you,want to take the shuttle from the station back to the hotel take the closest but stop just up from the station exitIf you don't want to wait for the bus you can take a taxi 410 yen during the day 570 in the evening hours.Gave the hotel 5 stars HUGE THANK YOU to the staffbecause my mother left a bag in the room & they will ship it to us back here in the USwonderful beautiful gardens behind the hotel must check it outWilling to stay here again on a future Japan trip

First- the location may not be in the heart of Tokyo but the service is above par and the amenities are fantastic! After a long flight - we had a very warm welcome by the reception desk at the executive lounge.Located near Shinagawa Station ( walk about 15 minutes) or you can take the free shuttle from the train station. This beautiful hotel is in a small park oasis with waterfalls and beautiful gardens.Amenities: We had two rooms on a high floor ( you could hear the train if you are a light sleeper)The rooms were modern and equipped with really good nespresso coffee makers.The Executive lounge laid out daily food service that was top of the line.Hot appetizers and cold apps with wine and sparkling wine. Dessert was also a delight for the eyes and palate! Breakfast was an extravaganza of hot & cold entrees - where you could order your own style eggs. With American, European and Asian choices. I tried the local omelete with small fish that was really good. You have american style breakfast from pastries to smoothies and fruit. One day I had the japanese breakfast of miso soup, rice, salmon & mackerel, tamago, pickled cabbage and pickles. Oiishi!Service was outstanding! From the reception, porter,servers and concierge- who recommended several excellent restaurants for us to try. And they were all on point!

My Daughter and I visited Japan and stayed at this hotel. My daughter speaks a little of the language and I know all of 3 words. The staff was very friendly and answered ALL of our questions. This hotel is very close to the train station with a free shuttle to Shinagawa Station. The room was also PERFECT. Very spacious, had everything that we needed. All hair products, brush, toothbrush, soap, etc. Breakfast is a little pricey, but there is a little market in the basement if you are hungry.

Checked in on April 4, at 1600. Check in process was extraordinarily slow. By the time I checked in I was told my room (king bed reserved) was not available. The room I was given is okay, clean, but nothing special. I expect to get the room type I reserved, especially as a platinum elite member.

I chose this hotel because it was one of the drop-off points on the Airport Bus Limousine routes and I’m proud to say that I made the right choice. The hotel was in Shinagawa and was close to the JR station. During my short stay, I didn’t manage to work out how to get to the station on foot as there was no need to. There was a frequent free shuttle bus that transport the guests to and from the Shinagawa JR station daily. On a couple of occasions, I missed the last shuttle bus back to the hotel and resorted to taking a taxi, the maximum damage was 500 JPY so it wouldn’t break the bank if you were out having a good time and were worried about the cost to get back to the hotel from the JR station.I stayed in a hotel room with executive lounge access and it was just wonderful. The lounge was location on the ground floor and there were daily provisions of drinks, snacks and evening canapes. A buffet breakfast was also provided, the food was not in the lounge area but in the main restaurant area. The clever design with the lounge was that there was an inter-connecting door through into the main restaurant to access the breakfast buffet and to bring the food back into the lounge to consume in the quieter environment. Although, if I wanted to sit with the rest of the hotel guests in the main restaurant, I was free to do so too.The room I was provided with was ample sized. In fact, it was bigger than your average Tokyo hotel room. I read reviews that due to the proximity of the JR station, the noise level from the incoming/departing trains were a nuisance and impeded the guests’ hotel experience. Personally, I didn’t notice any such noise level at all. I’m not sure if it were because I was allocated a room on a higher floor.The Concierge were very helpful with my queries on how to reach certain tourist attraction areas. The team were detailed in providing me with the platform number to take the Yamanoto line, the number of stops to my connecting Metro Line, the exit number at my destination etc. Their service was superb.I shall be returning back to this hotel for many reasons such as the ease of connection from the airport, close proximity to the JR Station, well-informed Concierge team and the small but perfectly formed executive lounge area. I have previously stayed in plush hotels near Tokyo Station which offers the same transport connection to Shinagawa. However, I preferred the latter because the station was a lot smaller and not as daunting as Tokyo Station where I spent a great deal of time wandering/milling around the station attempting to find my way out.

Overall the hotel is wonderful. The location, although a bit of a walk from Shinagawa station, is still convenient due to the shuttle that runs between the hotel and the station every 20 minutes. However, note that shuttle stops running around 10:00pm, so if you're getting back after a late night, you'll still be making the 10 minute walk back to the hotel (or take a taxi).Upon arrival, the hotel is very nicely decorated, and everything looks very modern, from the lobby, the bar, and the reception area. The spacious rooms are the same, as it appears that much thought and detail were put into designing the rooms.For some reason, the hotel did not have mobile check-in enabled, even though the reservation shows up on my phone. However, the check-in process was easy when I arrived at night, and I was given my room on the 19th floor.Now, I just have to get into why I was only able to give 4 stars instead of 5, as everything else about the hotel would have been 5 stars. Most Marriott locations can normally see that I am a Platinum Premier member (beyond just Platinum), and most Marriott hotels will give special recognition for it. I was surprised that for being an overseas Marriott, they had no distinction of Platinum Premier, and did not even know what this status was. There was no upgrade in terms of the room (even though it was on a higher floor instead of a lower floor), and I was given the same things that Gold and Platinum members would receive (lounge access, breakfast, one free drink coupon). When I asked which floors were "Executive Floors" (to see if I at least was put on an Executive Floor), the front desk staff first checked my room number to protect themselves, and seeing that I was on the 19th floor, replied that the Executive Floors were "19 and up". This was entirely not true, as looking from the Marriott website, one can see that Executive Floors are 21 to 23. It is fine if they just told me that no rooms were available for an upgrade, but there was no need to lie about saying that I was on an Executive Floor.I stayed here for 5 nights, and will be taking the 7 day JR pass around Japan. When I return, I will be staying another 3 nights. I'll see if the front desk service is the same when I return.But, aside from that, as I mentioned before, everything in the hotel is great, especially for status members (Gold and up). The breakfast buffet has a wonderful selection of food. The Executive lounge is excellent in the evenings, with a variety of food options and an open self-serve bar.As for the gym, I was actually pretty impressed. They had a great selection of free weights, which one cannot find in every hotel gym. It included a full olympic rack with safety pins, as well as a variety of weight benches. It provided equipment regardless of people's goals, whether it be weight training or just cardio.I'll be looking forward to staying here again.

The facility is a new one, easily reached by Airport Limo and is near the JR metro station. The staff is very international and is very professional and welcoming. A fantastic choice for those looking for familiarity with just the right local touch. As is with everything on Japan, it is very tidy and lots of attention for details.

I stayed at the Tokyo Marriott as a Marriott platinum member so of course it was very nice. The breakfast each morning was wonderful as was the rest of the restaurant food. I unfortunately do not speak Japanese but found the staff at the hotel to be incredibly helpful. Additionally, when I became seriously ill the hotel manager found this out and personally went on a hunt for over the counter medication for me. Their service was exceptional. The location to the train station was perfect-10 minute walk. I have three more trips to Tokyo this year and will be spending them all at the Tokyo Marriott.

I have stayed many times at this hotel (and at this location before it was a Marriott). Location wise it is a 10 minute walk from Shinagawa station. There is also a free shuttle bus from Shingawa to the hotel /office building next door which runs during normal business hours during the week. Rooms are large in comparison to most Tokyo hotels with full bathroom amenities. Staff is helpful but sometimes their English is not as strong as you might require. Breakfast/Dinner is available in the lobby area. Food is expensive, unless you have a breakfast coupon , I would try some of the restaurants near Shinagawa. Be sure to walk through the gardens next door and enjoy the scenery and the Koi pond. Very peaceful. Plenty of restaurants between the hotel and Gotanda station (opposite direction than Shinagawa)Agree on the comment about hotel gym. However, there is a nice running loop if you go out the back of the hotel, down the hill and run along the small river. Remember the hill when you come back.

Other than bigger than average hotel rooms, everything is deplorable the moment you step into this hotel. This may be harsh and to be clear, this is comparing to Japanese level of hospitality. A business trip and despite pre-arrangement via my director's personal assistant, a room was not ready by 4pm when we wanted to manage a quick check-in before a meeting with Japanese clients at 5pm. And we thought Punctuality is a virtue. Acceptable of company VISA credit card depends on who is managing the POS system. Credit card rejected at check-in by a new staff member despite a complaint from us that the same credit card is accepted at the main check-in counter when used by another colleague. We also called the credit card hotline to make sure the card was okay and they verified not trace of a transaction was not submitted. Eventually found someone else on check-out day to sort it out.Nobody was outside the lobby area to help with taxis. When the person on duty came, he just stood comfortably inside. We had passerby from the park next to the hotel cutting in to steal our taxis while we waited in the hotel, so we had to stand outside in the cold to get our taxi. Not an example of omotenashi at all.A big commotion about losing 3 limousine bus tickets that were issued. As the tickets was lost during breakfast somewhere in the lobby about 45 minutes they were issued, went back to the counter and had to pay the fare for 3 pax again. As there was evidence of payment and number records, not sure why hotel cannot speak to the limousine bus company and ask for waiver to show ticket, especially when we had the hotel printed confirmation (we just did not had the tickets as being small, they got misplaced after breakfast)Ordering a coffee ala carte during a morning business meeting at the lobby area took 2 tries. And after it took so long, I walked up to the window where the brewed coffee was and spoke to the guy inside myself.Location was not as good as the other hotels nearer to ginza or those beside shinagawa station. So the higher price it commanded does not seem sensible.As this is our managing director's first visit to Japan, I feel embarrassed about the standards of hospitality shown.P.S. For the price, Coffee was only as good as McDonalds 24h brewed coffee.. Standards are higher outside the hotel where people put heart into making the brew in Japan

My second visit to Ṭokyo Marriott hotel, Shinagawa and once again, it was a delightful experience. Very warm welcome as a platinum member, get very early check-in and a great room. Executive lounge was great too, nice snacks and drinks. Quite convinent to take free shuttle to shinagawa train station as it runs in every 20 minutes. Very comfortable stay overall.... thank you...: )

The hotel was wonderful; the restaurant delicious; the lounge excellent - but the Gym was old and incredibly dated - it was not operated by Marriott. I have never seen anything like it for such a nice hotel - but otherwise the hotel was great.

This Marriott is gorgeous and the service team is well above par! About a 10 minute walk from Shinagawa station you are in the heart of the city but still cozy and quiet. The rooms are spacious as is the bathroom. The beds are a bit firmer than US Marriott hotels but still great.The breakfast is incredible! Highly recommend getting a package that includes that or if you have status; it's included.The lounge is lovely, with service all day and a nice respite. Net-net, if you are a Marriott person this is a fabulous property.

I loved the service and the hospitality at this hotel. Located at a 10 mins walk from the Shinagawa station, this hotel is beautifully built. They also have free shuttle to and fro the station at a 15 minute gap. The in house lounge is also nice but with less vegetarian options. Their gym is amazing with all the facilities but I could not use it :(Definitely visiting this hotel again since I am a marriott member as well.

I spent 4 nights at this hotel in early February and the service was absolutely outstanding. From arrival, check-in, platinum lounge, restaurant, bell man's desk and maid service - everyone was helpful and went out of there way to answer every request I had. Overall, you would have thought this was a top of the line JW Marriott. I would highly recommend this hotel. It's a 15 minute walk to the nearest train/subway station and the surrounding neighborhood was perfect for an evening run.

Excellent breakfast, lunch & dinner (gluten free bread available! ) The rooms are comfortable with great view. What a beautiful location in downtown Tokyo. Convenient location close to train station and many sites. They have a wonderful executive lounge and concierge!

My husband and I stayed at Tokyo Marriott for a week stretch. We are Marriott Vacation club Platinum Elite members. My main disappointment with this hotel was the lack of variety in the good offered for the executive lounge and the buffet breakfast. The executive lounge food basically had two different menus, which they repeated every alternate day. The food offered was not very tasty and there was a limited range each day. The breakfast spread was the same every day we were there. It was a far cry from what was offered in the HK JW Marriott. Service is as excellent as you would expect from any Marriott hotel. One of our luggage was damaged while it was in the care of the hotel and they reimbursed us for a new suitcase with minimal hassle. We had a beautiful view from our room on the 23rd floor. There is an indoor heated pool and a jacuzzi but I was disappointed that the jacuzzi water was only warm, not hot. There is a free shuttle bus (pls note it looks like a public bus, or you may miss it) to the nearby Shinagawa train station at regular intervals so it is no hassle to go out for your daily jaunts

If you are staying in the Shinagawa area than I would strongly suggest you try to book into the Marriott hotel. It is important to book a few weeks in advance or the price will be high compared to other much smaller hotel rooms.

I often stay at Hyatt Regency Tokyo as I am a Diamond member. Recently, I stayed at Tokyo Marriott in Shingawa to try. I am a platinum member here as well. Here is my honest comparison.RoomsMarriott is more updated than the Hyatt. For the money, you are probably better off with Marriott.Location:Hyatt is in Shinjuku which is very central and you can access Tokyo much easier than Shinagawa where the Marriott is. Shinagawa is a bit out (15 min) from the real cenral Tokyo but not far. Both hotel has shuttle bus from the station. Nothing around the Marriott but many restaurants, shops etc, very close to the Hyatt. So for location Hyatt is the winner unless you are doing business close to Shinagawa area.Regency Club - Executie loungeThe Marriott lounge is hands down better than the Hyatt. Hyatt has a nice acceptable breakfast at the lounge but the Marriott breakfast is at the restaurant which has significantly more variety. Marriott has high tea in the afternoon with numerous cakes, sandwiches, scones, danish and Japanese sweets. Hyatt has cookies and pound cake. In this area, Marriott wins hands down. For the evening spread, both hotel has free drinks. Wine, beer, champaign, etc. So drinks are comparible. However, for the food, Marriott makes Hyatt look pretty bad. Marriott has numerous dishes (6-7) and it is constantly being refilled. The quality is also excellent in my opinion. Compared to Marriott, Hyatt Regency Tokyo's evening spread is cheese, crackers, nuts and one plate of food with 3-4 small peices of things. Only one plate per person. The quality is also a problem. It is not very good. So if you are looking for a lounge with ample offering, I would avoid the Hyatt and go for Marriott. The only draw back of Marriott lounge is the size. It is not a very big lounge where the Hyatt lounge is large.Staff and service.Both hotel has good service and staff are very nice. PricePrice is comparable at both properties.Elite membersIf you are top tier member, you will be allowed lounge access. For the room upgrade, you will probably get an upgrade if you are Diamond or Platinum but don't expect a significant upgrade from either hotel.All in allIf location is important, then Hyatt may be better unless you need to be in the Shingawa area. However, if perks such as lounge quality is an important factor, Marriott wins hands down.

It is a nice place to stay, if you are in the higher levels it should a quiet and well taken care of. The breakfast is ok and the dinner can be really good if you like beef. Overall it is I'm my top two places to stay in shinagawa.

Overall the hotel is pretty nice. The breakfast is rather expensive - $29 if you are a marriott reward member of $36 otherwise. The drinks in the lobby bar are also pretty expensive (beer - $20, glass of cognac - $60). Other from that - the concierge is helpful and nice, she helped me to organize my weekends and plan my trips. The rooms are clean, the internet is fast and there is also a free shuttle to the closest JR / subway station - Shinagawa (品川). The lobby bar has a standard menu, no sushi or other traditional japanese meals, but you can easily catch a taxi and have a ride wherever you wish, there are plenty of sushi bars around. Another negative point is there is a railway road very close to the hotel, so if you have a sleep disorder and low floor you may experience problems in the night. For me it was OK, but my colleague suffered from the railway noise. I will definitely return to this hotel, my experience there was very positive.

Stayed for four nights and was very satisfied. Staff was very friendly and the breakfast buffet was one of the best I ever had. The room was nice and clean. And not to forget the gym was a proper gym and just a treadmill. I will stay here the next time I will visit Tokyo again. Sure it's 10 minutes walk from the station, but that is ok for me but worth to know.

Really good location, it's not right next to a train station but close enough, about a 10-15 min walk downhill to the JR Shinagawa station. If you prefer not to walk, a taxi costs 730 yen (the flagfall rate), or you can take the free shuttle bus that picks you up across the road from the JR station.

Having stayed at the Marriott Courtyard at Ginza using our Asia Pacific points, we were initially anxious why that hotel was dropped from the list and this one at Shinagawa was the one available. So we took the chance and booked it. To say we were pleasantly surprised is an understatement. The hotel is located in a quiet neighborhood but accessible by free shuttlle bus from the Shinagawa train station. Weather permitting, one can walk to and from the station and try the small eateries and shops along the way. The room, though compact, was immaculate and complete with all amenities. The hotel staff was attentive, friendly and made sure all our needs were met. Nice park outsde hotel where one could sit and meditate. And for fitness buffs, there is a complete gym and spa. We would definitely go back to this hotel.

Comfortable hotel with great service. We stayed for 9 nights over New Year and had a great time, the location is great with the train station in walking distance but they also have a bus shuttle which is very handy especially when it's very cold! The members area is well stocked with a great variety of food and beverage, but it was a shame that it didn't have any windows.

Nice, quiet location easily accessible to the Shinagawa Train Station. There is a free shuttle bus to the hotel from the train station. Rooms are compact but complete with everything you need. Service is exceptional especially at the Lounge & Dining G. Breakfast buffet selection is great and the staff give 5 Star Service!

I begin by noting that I had two previous stays at this hotel that were quite nice. This stay however was not. Despite being winter and off-season with the hotel nearly empty, the only room for my stay was one very small room right over the most frequented rail lines. When I requested a room change I was provided a quieter room with lights and electricity that didn't work when I arrived and a broken shower. Dining in the hotel restaurant was not much better. Despite a fairly empty Monday night, the only table was by the host stand and kitchen access. I probably could've gotten over that except the Chef's treat that night was small glasses of shrimp covered in red sauce. One of the waiters of course dropped a tray full of the glasses and the result was red sauce all over the legs of my trousers. 2 breakfast occasions where I was asked if I wanted coffee or tea and both occasions that order was promptly forgotten. All in all I found the hotel quite disappointing given the rather high off- season rate for the stay.

Good quality hotel, about 20 mins from Haneda airport and 5 mins from Shinagawa station. Shuttle bus runs 3 X per hour to / from the station or its JPY 500 for a cab.Rooms aren't huge but are biggest than most in JP. Nice lobby bar and good breakfast buffet. Attentive service as you would expect...

this is the first time I stay in this hotel. Locational wise, this is not close to train station, you need to walk about fifteen mins to the station or five mins by taxi to shinagawa train station. This is a business hotel with simple interior design. Room size is ok, around 350 sq feet. same as other marriott hotel brand standard, the mattress, pillow, duvet are comfortable and other amenities are also sufficient. But one night, I wanted to make some hot tea, when I open the cabinet, I saw two (drawers), the top one is deeper while the lower one is shallower, when I try to pull out the lower drawer, the whole (drawer) falls down, then I realise it is not a drawer but a tray only.... when the house keeper comes to clean the broken glass on the floor, he told me this has already been the third time on the same day that guests dropped the tray on the floor...I think it is not a good idea to put the tray in such a way because we don't even know this is the tray during night time. So suggest to change it to a real drawer or put a anti slippy mat under the tray to avoid it fall down when guests pull it out from the cabinet. The loung and dining G breakfast is good except the hot dish need to improve cos' lack of choice. Will come here again....

It's great place - room is bigger than usual Japanese hotel, it's clean and services was good, food was amazing!! It's little tuck away from hustle and bustle but it's really not far from it - they run free shuttle to station but it's really short walk away if you decide to walk. It will be our choice again if we go back there.

I'm torn. First, we weren't able to check in at 12. That has never happened to me at a Marriott property, especially after emailing them the arrival time. Mobile check in was also. It available. But they're busy, and I understand. Luggage was misplaced. Ok, I guess I can that was also excusable. But after a red eye flight, having to go to an afternoon meeting and not being able to even freshen up made me a very unhappy customer so I'm taking off a star. And I'm also taking off a star for the location. It's hard to get to. There are only 2 buses from Haneda/day. The shuttle from the train station runs fairly frequently but stops around 9pm. There are no restaurants within easy walking distance either. I think I'll stay elsewhere next time.

We choose Marriott because of the location. It's very near everywhere downtown Tokyo, The bus takes you to & from. It's a super classy hotel, the staff are friendly let alone with the very friendly Guest Relation Manager. My family & I were looked after very well, WOW factor! Amazing stay! Thanks so much Marriott Hotel & staff

Stayed there for 5 nights, and was pleasantly surprised that the room was as large as a US Marriott. The breakfast buffet was well positioned near the main entrance, which makes it convenient to catch the free shuttle buses to the Shinagawa station. The hotel is about a 10 mins walk to the station, which makes for good exercise. The executive lounge is also located on the ground floor and it is well stocked with beverages till late in the evening.

We stayed 2 nights at the Marriott Tokyo, Shinagawa and had a luxurious stay. Excellent prompt and helpful service, excellent shuttle transportation to and from Shinagawa Station. 2 kids were in a two room Quad set up, with separate rooms for boys and girls. We had a spacious superior king a few floors up, but very easy to access kids with lifts close by. Husband and I enjoyed the separation actually from the teenagers!!Would definitely stay again!

This hotel was very good. Rooms were of good size, in all standards. Well appointed and house keeping did a great job in keeping our room, and all parts of the hotel extra clean. Staff were, as most Japanese people, polite, courteous, professional, helpful and always smiling. The executive lounge was very well stocked with all types of hot and cold foods and drinks including premium beer, wine, liquors, soft drinks and even Sake! The main restaurant offered an excellent breakfast buffet including Japanese food. Great location jy by a major train station.

The service was top notch from the very first step into the hotel. There is a free shuttle that runs from the hotel to the nearest subway which was very convenient, considering the hotel is out of the way from everything. Breakfast had a large selection and the food was pretty good for a breakfast buffet.The lounge had a very large selection of beverages and snack items throughout the day. Although as a platinum member I am guaranteed a suite upgrade if available. It was available and was like pulling teeth to get the upgrade! Overall it was a pretty good stay and I felt the value was fair for the rate of the room.

A short cab ride or walk from Shinagawa station which is right on the south end loop side of the Yamanote line, you will find this hotel that has exceptionally clean rooms, all the amenities you could want and on top of it, the most excellent customer service that one can EXPECT to receive in Japan. Though the room may be small to what some big westerners may be accustomed to, they have everything you want - from a king bed to complimentary toiletries to even a view of Tokyo Tower in the distance. Looking out of my window, given how quiet everything was, one would never know that you were in the middle of the world's largest city.The hotel partners with an exercise facility right next door and their equipment for workouts was adequate. But to offset that, they have a nice 25M pool underneath and along with that, a Jacuzzi and in the locker room an onsen style bath (yes!).Would have been nice to have a complimentary shuttle to / from Narita or Haneda.

Stayed at the Tokyo Marriott in Nov 2016 and although it is slightly outside of "city proper" I found it to be very convenient. You have to take the JR line train to Shinegawa station and walk about .5 mile to the hotel. Great Marriott, rooms were clean, spacious and good amenities. There is a small convenience store at the foot of the escalator into the hotel (which makes it easy to grab sundries if needed). There is also a post office next to the convenience store if necessary to mail post cards. I want to point out that this Marriott has fabulous customer service! I have a life threatening food allergy (shellfish, yeah I know Asia is difficult for me) and they bent over backwards to accommodate me in the restaurant. All other places I traveled in Japan I found it difficult to find food that wouldn't kill me. This hotel? Not a problem at all. Can't say enough good things about it!

The stay started brilliantly with special check-in using the concierge lounge. The check-in experience was made better with immediate access to the lounge whilst the hotel staff ensured the best possible room upgrade was made available. I was then escorted to a lovely, large room with an excellent bathroom.The location of the hotel--about a ten-minute walk to a large train station and easily an hour's drive to Narita aiport--is good to visit the city. The concierge was able to highlight on the map all of the essentials for visiting and made some personal recommendations as well. His suggestion to visit the quirky Shimokitazawa neighborhood proved to be most excellent.The property is nice and modern, with all the amenities you'd expect in a Marriott hotel. I was impressed with the breakfast buffet but the dining outside of breakfast was lacking. I would've appreciated more food and drink options than were presented.The service was the highest of quality and excellence. I did not find myself wanting in this regard.

We stayed overnight at the Marriott Tokyo purely due it's proximity to Haneda airport for a flight to Chintose the following Recommend booking an executive room if you do not belong to Marriott rewards, a great way to start Mew Years celebrations prior to hitting the town.Good central location, last year we spent 4 nights at the Westin, which was possibly a higher standard but located a little further out.?The Marriott is always a safe bet with great accommodation and services.

I have been in this last week of the year 2016 and was great experience to me. First if the hotel is very clean, new where the staff here are very helpful. The hotel is about seven minutes walk from Shinsgawa JR station but there is free shuttle that can drop you to and from the hotel till nearly 10 PM but still you can take the taxi for 730 yen. The breakfast is very nice and have so many choices. The room size is good around 30 m2 and bathroom is great as usual in Marriott hotels. The internet is excellent and it is for free if you member in the Mariott. We were family with young kids and they loved the stay so much. This hotel is highly recommended in Tokyo.

This hotel is very close (walking distance) to Shinagawa station. The room we got was amazing, as well as the overall service of the hotel. Would definitely return. It is slightly far away from other parts of Tokyo.
user_name:
jafm87
New York City, New York

review_body: My wife and I (late 50's) vacationed in Tokyo for 6 days. Used Marriott as base. Great hotel. Location perfect. 10 quick minutes to JR train/subway station or free shuttle. Staff superlative. Helpful when we had issues with our tours. Pleasant and knowledgeable. Rooms comfortable. Gym fine. Japanese hot tub fun. Morning breakfasts really good. Made the vacation!

I love Marriott properties, specially this hotel. It offers a complimentary shuttle service from the Shinagawa train station to the hotel. As a Marriott platinum member, I appreciate all the perks such as complimentary breakfast and access to the lounge. Their rooms are clean, offers a city view and comfortable beds. I highly recommend this hotel for business or leisure. We will definitely be back.

The Tokyo Marriott is a fantastic hotel! Room is big (compared to other hotel rooms in Japan), bathroom is spacious, the hotel restaurant has great food and even better service, the concierge is extremely helpful and speak good English. I'd definitely stay here again. The only drawback is it's location. It's in the "rich" part of Tokyo and the hotel is somewhat isolated. Don't expect to be near restaurants, shops and the Shinagawa train station when you get out of the hotel (although there is a free shuttle bus to the station every 10 to 15 mins). It's a quiet hotel that needs some effort to get to outside restaurants and shops. Overall, this is a hotel that is best for people who want peace and quiet.

Perfect hotel choice for our first trip to Japan. The location makes it easy to get around other parts of Japan. Easy to get to the local train station. We will be back!All staff are pleasant and accommodating. The Lounge & Dining G Restaurant is exceptional. Thank you for telling me about the area Kohei. We loved the breakfast buffet and bar menu. The best buffet breakfast I have come across. There is something for everyone from fussy eaters to connoisseurs.It would be good if the pool was open to children under 16, with adult supervision. My boys are 10 and 8 and would have enjoyed the pool. This would not stop us from visiting again.Thank you Marriott Hotel Tokyo

The fitness center on the main floor is small but has all the basics. You can also walk or jog in the park connected the hotel. There's also a play area for young children adjacent to the check in area. Dining is limited to the Lounge and Dinning G in the lobby and room service. I did a separate review check it out. Our room was very clean with a nice view of the city and Tokyo tower. The room was decent size for Tokyo. King bed, couch, desk and mini bar fridge you can place your cold items in. Bathroom was spotless with lots of amenities. The shower I found odd with only half a door??? Only two bath towels in the room so they were still damp the next morning. The atrium is a great place to relax, check email and people watch. It was a little chilly to sit at the outside patio. The wifi I found to be quick. The music is very peaceful and tranquil. If you are going to be utilizing the Shinkansen bullet trains this is a great place to headquarter.

Only there for one night but loved it. The executive club was great and served Mumm champagne which was a bonus. Really close to Haneda airport. Staff were very friendly and really helpful. Great location in Tokyo. Would stay again,

This hotel is 1km away from the Shinagawa station. They provide free shuttle and the lady driver we met today was very pleasant.The hotel looks beautiful and impressive but the staff lack a personal touch, very cold and distant. We received a robot like check in experience. This is very different from the previous 4 hotels that we have stayed in Tokyo.So to begin, it was my mistake to hv booked a double bed. I travelled w a 14 maths old baby and we co sleep so she sleeps btw me and my husband. When we get to the room and notice our mistake i went to the reception to explain my problem and asked for a room with one bigger bed.. The lady at the reception surprised me with a sour face. I have never received such response in any hotels in Japan so far. So after she scrolled through her computer she told me she can give me a smaller room with a bigger bed. I told her that is fine. She asked if i have touch anything in the room and i said no. And i mean really no. i only opended the door and then i went down. She told me to wait at the room and someone will come and escort me and i gave her back the previous room keys.And the bigger surprise came. Her colleague came quite promptly and helped us w our luggage. Before we leave the room she went in and inspected all the mini bar and bathroom to make sure we really did not 'touch anything'. I don't know about other ppl but i felt insulted. Extremely insulted. We were standing outside the room waiting for her to inspect the room. I feel they can do this after we left.And when we got to the second room she asked me for the previous room key cards. I told her i have passed it to her colleague at receptions and her response was, is it?? And then she called her colleague in front of me to make sure i am telling the truth. I seriously was and i still am very very upset with the whole scenario. Is this how a 5 star hotel treats their customer?? The room is very nice and well equipped but i really cannot enjoy any of these. After many years, i may not remember any names or faces but i believe the impression this hotel left on me will not be forgotten.Will i be back? Definitely NO

Friendly staff. Clean rooms. Within 15-20 minutes walking distance to 2 train stations. Hotel has a shuttle to Shinagawa station every 15 minutes or so. The whole shuttle process takes about 10 minutes so you are not really saving on time. Breakfast was quite good especially the fresh juice and the pancake/waffle station. Only small complaint is the lounge food. The kind of food alternates every other day so if you are there for more than two days, it gets rather old. Dessert was great though. Make sure you check out a great tempuraRestaurant at the other train station (not Shinagawa). Inexpensive and delicious.

Hands down the best Marriott experience we've had (and we've been gold rewards members for several years). The location is central, walkable to Shinagawa Station which connects you quickly to all points in Tokyo. Hotel offer free shuttle back and forth to Shinagawa Station if you're not up for the 15 min walk. The rooms are comfortable and spacious, some with a nice view of the city. Garden area around hotel beautiful and connected to a running trail - a great mid city oasis. The best part of our stay was the breakfast. Made to order eggs Benedict, fresh smoothies, attentive service - everything you could want. And then when one of the hostesses found out we were going sightseeing she helped us pack snacks for the day! So so kind. We felt spoiled by the entire experience. Oh, and I didn't mention the arrival drinks for rewards members!!!

Fourth visit to this hotel over 18 months. Hotel is not what it has been over past 3 years. Impossible to get a cup of coffee at 530AM: lounge entry closed, even though people are setting up the breakfast restaurant will not allow using the coffee machine, room machine capsules not refilled.Breakfast quality (eggs) not the same. Very few breads, and not of the same quality. Appears to be tending to Chinese tourist selections.Play lounge selections limited, such as deserts. Lounge services not as good since Mr Kim left. Tough market to keep ahead in. Losing the battle now.

My family of 3 stayed in a room with a king size bed. No complains about the room and amenities provided. We are gold marriott reward members and check in was efficiently done. Breakfast spread was reasonable. Only disappointment was when I approached the staff at the members' executive lounge to ask if they could help me arrange for just a slice of cake with a candle sent to my room for a little surprise for my husband's birthday that day. The staff directed me to the restaurant to purchase the cake instead. There was not even a birthday card from the hotel. Not sure if it was something uncommon in the country, but I know of hotels which will do this without hesistation for their guests on wedding anniversaries or birthdays for free. It would be a nice gesture for the hotel to take note of members' birthdays and acknowledge that.

Short 15 minute walk to Shingawa train station making easy for easy access. Check in was prompt and quick with friendly staff. Room was well equipped, quiet and comfortable. After a long day was happy with the options available and enjoyed nice dinners.

I was just here for 5 nights, and was thoroughly impressed and how beautiful the hotel was, and how spacious and nice the room was. The staff was extremely helpful, and the executive lounge was very nice. In addition to an open bar from 5:30-9:30pm, they have daily drink specials that the staff will make for you if you ask.The minor issues I had were with the wifi, which was so bad in my corner room that we had to literally walk towards the room entrance to make it work. Small nitpick, but slightly frustrating considering how magnificent of a hotel it was.The only other minor inconvenience was the location. It is about a 10 minute walk to Shinagawa station, which can get you anywhere. But it is still not as convenient of a location as some of the other hotels I have stayed at in Tokyo.All in all, great hotel. Maybe ask them for a different room if you get one in the corner!

Strange set up when you enter this hotel as it feels like an office building, the reception is tucked away past the restaurant, but the rooms are good and very large for Tokyo.
