The executive lounge is a bit bland and on the ground floor with no windows but is well stocked.The stand out for me were the staff, one in particular Mary Grace who serves during breakfast, she certainly made my day each morning with a very positive attitude and warm smile. Total asset to the company and made my stay, the breakfast is also very good.As a SPG platinum I'm used to the shearton but will be using the Marriott from now on, the benefits and service are excellent

I've never been treated so well! The staff was exceptionally friendly, welcoming, and accommodating. If you have Marriott status, you'll be treated like royalty (way more than in the states) The restaurant downstairs is impressive! Delicious menu options, and top notch servers. We splurged on steak... which literally melted in our mouths. We stayed on a weekend evening and there was even entertainment (singing) which was lovely. We opted for the breakfast buffet which included a vast assortment of American and authentic Japanese cuisine. I've never had so many buffet options at a hotel before. This hotel was the highlight of our trip to Tokyo!

actually i went to Japan last year on 2015 , this hotel was my first hotel in Japan . The room is great , breakfast awesome , and they have not-so-fast checking in (which made us wait and took a time) but it's fine for me . And they prepared us the non-smoking room . But unfortunately when i step into the room , i can still smell the little smoke inside the room . (the smell which sometimes give me an uncomfortable feeling after someone just smoke in an Air conditioned room) but if you were just fine with it then its fine. But for me it's somekind of uncomfortable. But all is well , all the staff are very helpful , i don't understand Japan Language , and we have to book a non online hotel for Fuji Rock which is located in some place far away from Tokyo and they barely dont speak english. So the staff in tokyo marriot help us with it. But their breakfast is awesome! So i would say , this is a nice place to stay :)

Modern hotel located in the area of Shinagawa station on JR line. Nicely decorated rooms with well-equipped bathrooms. Excellent breakfast with fresh fruit juices and smoothies, great selection of eggs/omelets, Japanese items, salads and pastries. Friendly staff. The only troublesome issue is the noise from the railway if your room is located on this side of the hotel. Trains do pass every 5 minutes including early morning. Despite double glass window, it was difficult to sleep. Ask a room located in the other side. In addition you will have a nice city view including the Tokyo tower illuminated at night.

This hotel has a convenient location with a frequent shuttle service to and from Shinagawa Sta, which is the second largest railway station in Tokyo. Shinagawa is a easy Narita Express stop (next stop after Tokyo Sta). The staff is very attentive, pleasant, and fluent in English. There is an excellent breakfast offering. The executive lounge is convenient and you can use it to check-in and out. The rooms are comfortable with nice bathrooms. All in all, this is an excellent option and not overly expensive when doing business with the many companies headquartered in Minato-ku.

Lovely staff, took care of me when I got stuck due to a missed connection. Room is everything you expect from Marriott - comfort squared! Restaurant staff an amazing team who work smoothly together to take care of small details for guests.

When we first arrived at the hotel, the customer service was absolutely beautiful, they treated us with such care and always had our interests in mind. The family room that they had prepared for us was also amazing, it had a fresh and welcoming aroma that really made it appealing.

Great place to stay in my visits to Tokyo and also out of Tokyo since it is near the main train station, Shinagawa Station and the hotel has free shuttle bus to it too. If you want to walk it is about 10 minutes only so really a convenient place. Plus it has a nice garden beside the hotel where you enjoy the cherry blossoms during spring and autumn foliage during autumn.

The last time I visited Tokyo, this hotel is not yet open. I am glad that in this visit there Tokyo Marriott Shinigawa. It is near the Shinigawa station and offers free shuttle service. Even before I arrived they ensured that the hypo allergenic pillows are provided in my room. They also asked if I have any food allergies. The staff of the "Lounge & Dining G" are very courteous and accomodating specially Grace and Benny.The room is very clean and very Zen. As a constant traveller, I am very particular about room cleanliness. For Japanese standards, the room is quite spacious including the bathroom.On my next Tokyo vacation (and for others vacationing here) Tokyo Marriott Shinigawa is the best place to stay.

The Marriott in Shinagawa is about a 7-10min walk (free shuttle bus also available) to Shinagawa Station which is a major rail hub in Tokyo from where you can get to just about any part of Tokyo very easily as well as taking the Bullet train to other parts of Japan. Shinagawa is a pretty quiet part of Tokyo with not much tourist friendly nightlife but there are some hidden gems for restaurants and drinking spots if you are feeling adventurist enough to explore the small neighbor hood spots that cater mostly to local business people. The hotel itself is quite nice and modern with plenty of room. Clean and modern bathrooms that are large enough for taller people (wont be bumping your head on the ceiling while in the shower or having to duck down to to get water on you). Hotel breakfast is quite nice with standard Japanese style and western style foods to choose from. Hotel bar is nicely arranged, lively and has a great selection of spirits as well as good local Japanese beers. Over all very nice hotel in a quieter part of Tokyo.

Hotel is only 3 years old and the rooms are a clear reflection of it. The rooms have a modern decor and are much larger than most hotel rooms you would get in Japan. Has a shuttle that runs ever 20 minutes to shinigawa station. Not convenient to try and walk here from the train station. If you are trying to take the train to the hotel, the shuttle bus looks like a local city husband picks up on the back side of Shinigawa station. Great service! The hotel staff were eager to help with any concerns or guidance requested for our trip. This was also the most English friendly speaking hotel.

Had a excellent stay at the Tokyo Marriott! Spacious and modern rooms! Staff was very accommodating and genuinely cared about their guests. Close to a cool aqua park/aquarium which has an indoor dolphin stadium and other exhibits.It is a quick walk down the hill to the Shinagawa train station which made it easy for transportation, if you miss the last train however be prepared for your expensive taxi ride.

Stayed 3 nights in this hotel. Overall, it is a good hotel. The front desk is very helpful. the room is neat, clean and spacious. The bathroom also spacious. The G lounge where we took the breakfast is quite nice. There are various food from italian (such as pizza), japanese (udon), western (breads), egg station, various flavor of juice. There is family mart in the basement. The only minus point from this hotel is the location. They provide free shuttle bus, but the last bus is 10 pm from shinawaga station, so if you miss the bus, you need to walk approx. 15 minutes or you can take taxi which is more expensive.

Rooms and bar area were decent. The check in area is below par for sure along with the executive lounge. It is close to nearby attractions and not that to rippongi. The week I was there it was pretty packed and i had to pay an exorbitant price. Not sure i would go back.

We stayed here after traveling around Japan for 10 days. It was very clean, with beautiful modern decor and comfortable rooms. The location is close to the Shinagawa train station and has a number of activities close by. This is not in the major tourist area and has many more business travelers/conference attendees. The fitness center was large and with outdoor space! The hotel is right next to an urban garden which is a nice escape from the chaos of central Tokyo. Also, the grab and go food in the lobby was amazing for a quick breakfast and lunch!

Dont get fooled by the pictures on the website. It is one of the lousiest Marriott hotels I have stayed at! I checked out after one night and went to the Grand Hyatt (which interestingly was less expensive on that tday and a true 5 star). The "lobby bar/lounge" is the best feature and that's where it stops. The checkin counter won't even pass for a bellboy station in most hotels and is tucked in the back. The "executive lounge" is on the first floor...no windows--small and depressing! My room was good--on one of the top floors with a nice view--standard Marriott amenities.Stay here only if you are forced by your corporate policy to stay at this hotel. If you still want to be at a Marriot, in Shinagawa, go for the Prince Sakura Hotel--it is a Marriott property, a few mins walk from the Shingagawa stattion (closer that this Marriott) and a much much better quality hotel.

- Easy shuttle to Shinagawa station which is a great hub for train travel- Impeccable service - they go out of their way to help you- Breakfast buffet is great - American and Japanese style- Exec Lounge has something going on at mostly all times of the day, including drinks

This is my first time in Tokyo so I don't have anything to compare this to but I love a Marriott. We were here for a week for work and last year my co-workers stayed in a hotel closer to the office which they said was nice but had much smaller rooms. I had a King sized bedroom and it was larger than I was expecting for a city. Bed was nice and comfortable and the bathroom was large. All of the staff was accommodating and I loved their breakfast. We had dinner here a few nights which was convenient but not the best food. One of my favorite things about this hotel is that they have a trail about 1/2 mile long around the hotel so in the mornings I could run. They also have a gym which was big enough for my needs and I used the fitness room while classes weren't taking place. I'm glad we switched our hotel to the Marriott and would stay here again.

We stayed at the Marriott for 7 days and then at the Prince for a few more. We wanted to compare the two. I personally much preferred the Marriott, the room was very small but very functional. The decor was modern and recently updated. The staff was friendly and helpful, most of the front desk staff didnt speak English so that made it more difficult when trying to request certain things. I honestly would have given those hotel a 5 if it werent for the lounge. They shouldnt advertise having a lounge for their gold and platinum members. It was a windowless space off the lobby. It doesnt compete at all with the lounges at many of their competitors in Tokyo. The food was the bare minimum, the staff couldnt help us make dinner reservations or advice on activities in Tokyo. If you came at peak times this tiny little room was hot, stuffy and had no where to sit. I am hoping this is only a temporary lounge location while another is under renovation. The breakfast buffet was quite extensive and all tasted great. It is nice that it is included for Marriott Elite members.

Great hotel located just outside of the city. Spacious rooms. If you arrive into Shinagawa via the subway/train, there's a (free) bus that operates just outside the station and will take you directly to the hotel. It's call the Hybrid Non Stop and runs about every 20 min or so (730a-930p)...very convenient. Step out of the station and goes to your left and follow the side walk to the street. The bus stop is located to the left of the traffic light/crosswalk. I think the schedule is also posted there.

I recently stayed at Tokyo Marriott and want to make a comparison review to Prince Sakura Hotel(Marriott Autograph family) since I have stayed at both places. Hopefully this can help others to make a good choice between these two hotels since they are close to Shinagawa station and price is about the same. Location: Prince Hotel is betterPrince hotel is closer and can walk in 5min( a bit of hill). For Tokyo Marriott , you should take a free shuttle from/to shinagawa station. Shuttle bus just runs between hotel and station and runs every 10-15min on weekdays and every 20min on weekends. If you don't mind the wait, it's fine but I missed it once and had to stand around for 20 min. Room size/choice:Both hotels have pretty big size rooms. Prince have slight bigger room and has jacuzzi bathrooms on some rooms which is awesome on those tired nights after long flight or drinking nights. But Tokyo Marriott is slightly more modern and recently updated. I heard getting suite upgrade on Tokyo Marriott is better. Being a Platinum member, I have not gotten any suite upgrade yet from both places. Breakfast: Tokyo Marriott winsBoth hotels have awesome breakfast featuring Japanese and western buffet but Tokyo Marriott does have huge place to eat. Also having Udon and variety of freshly squeezed juice is plus at Tokyo Marriott. They also have more English speaking staff. Both hotels offer free breakfast for gold/platinum members. Executive lounge: Tokyo Marriott wins herePrince hotel does not have lounge. Tokyo Marriott does have one but oddly it is located on 1st floor. They do serve lots of different food/drink/snacks but don't expect any great views. Also it's pretty crowded at dinner time. Other things to note: prince winsPrince hotel does have nice Japanese garden that you can walk through in the morning.Both hotels have fitness center but Tokyo Marriott has it outside hotel which run by different company. I never used it so I am not sure how good it is. I hope this helps and let me know if you have any questions

The facility is nice, rooms are modern and very well maintained. The lounge is PATHETIC, no windows, poor food choices, no service. Think US Marriott lounge, not a typical Asian lounge by any stretch. The pool was closed when we were there and I would like to see English speaking channels beyond the news.

This hotel used to be called LaForet and I had stayed here before under this previous name.The hotel is a good 10 minute walk up the hill from Shinagawa station (one of the larger Tokyo stations)The hotel does offer a complimentary bus service to and from Shinagawa station.The rooms are in size comparable to what you expect in Europe. So very big by Tokyo standards. The room I had consisted of a double bed, a table and chair, a large side board, a double wardrobe and a small settee. There was still ample space to store two large suitcases and you were not falling over anything.Bathroom was a good size with the usual Japanese short deep bath. The shower was nice and powerful with ample hot water.Breakfast in the restaurant downstairs was a good spread. Omelettes, fried eggs, waffles, french toast were cooked to order but at peak times could take 10 minutes. Simple system (once you know) take the little skewer from the pot on your table and hand to person taking orders at the omelette station.In addition the had - A good range of hot (Japanese version) English breakfast items - mushrooms, bacon, sausage, chips, macaroni cheese. - They then had a Japanese section. - A bread/pastry section (the blueberry danish and raspberry danish were delicious) with various breads including gluten free and muffins.- Cold meats and fish- fruit bar with cereals, smoothies and juices. The hotel has a pool but this was closed during my stay for maintenance so I cannot comment on it.There is a pod like coffee machine in the room and a kettle with a wide selection of teas refreshed every day.

It was such a great experience stayed at this hotel during my holiday trip around Japan. The room itself offered a great day and night view of shinagawa area and I also can see odaiba rainbow bridge during night.+ Clean and very spacious room+ Airport limousine bus transport either from narita or haneda airport available+ Good english speaking staffs+ Convenience store located just at the side of the hotel+ Direct complementary shuttle bus from/to shinagawa station but without luggage storage+ Great night and day view of shinagawa area- Have to use shuttle bus to nearby station (shinagawa) otherwise you may have to walk for 20 minutes. The bus itself come in 20 minutes interval- JR lines is the most convenient way to travel to shinagawa station while other metro/toei lines needs to do multiple transfer- Sound of travelling train from/to kita-shinagawa station may be disturbing during its operation hourOverall it was such a great experience staying at this jotel and very recommended to take higher floor to see amazing view of shinagawa area

Recently stayed at this hotel. Although a small room compared to some I have stayed in the room was immaculate, spotlessly clean and comfortable with everything in it you could wish for. The softest towels I have ever had in a hotel, everything little thing was provided and the heated toilet in the bathroom was the best!! There was a shuttle to take you to the nearest rail station and getting into the centre of Tokyo was very easy. Lovely staff who could not do enough for you. Would recommend without hesitation and stay there again if we ever venture to Japan again.

The staff at the hotel went above and beyond to ensure our stay was exceptional. They treated us like celebrities, I would compare the level of service to the Ritz or any 5- star hotel in US. Everyone we met was extremely friendly, accommodating gracious and spoke very English. They made sure we had directions and knew where to go in Tokyo. The shuttle was very convenient. Breakfast buffet is a must, had a great selection from "Western" food such as pancakes to traditional Japanese dumplings.Make sure to check out, I usually don't in the US. In Japan it is a must, we almost missed the shuttle leaving because I forgot. Kenji Sato, director of food and beverage, was kind enough to make sure we were able to catch the bus to get to the airport in time. He went above and beyond to make sure we were happy with our stay and left a great impression with us to remember Tokyo by. I would highly recommend Marriott in Tokyo.

I wish I would have researched hotels in Tokyo prior to spending four days there. We selected the Tokyo Marriott because usually they are a good choice. That was our mistake. The room size was ok but the lighting was poor and there were NO drawers. How would you like to live out of suitcases?? In addition, there wasn't an English speaking concierge. We were going on a cruise and no one could help us locate the port. We finally figured it out on our own. We were not told that the Marriott provided shuttle service to the train station and shopping. That was unacceptable. The restaurant was very good for breakfast and dinner. Don't take the tours. Don't expect English on the television. It was quite limited and variable.  If we were to return to Tokyo , we would select a hotel in the Ginza district . It cost $40 plus from the Marriott. Also, be prepared to spend more for clothing than in the good old USA.  Lastly, take a shuttle from the Narita airport. We paid $195 for two. Taxis and private cars were much more because it takes 1&1/2 to 2 hours .  Good Luck!!!

This hotel was just fantastic, considering it was a Marriott (we have stayed in Marriott hotels all over the world and it's a very good product) but this was beyond any other. The room had everything one could possibly need in the bathroom plus a few bits and pieces you never even thought of, for example a fold up hairbrush, hair grips, a razor and shaving gel, basically everything. Big comfy bed with huge pillows. Clean comfortable and warm loo seats that cleaned themselves and you should you so desire. There was a shuttle bus to the nearest Japanese Rail station which gave easy access to all attractions. Fabulous introduction to Japan
user_name:
Robbie Z
Greater London, United Kingdom

review_body: I stayed at the Tokyo Marriott, Shinigawa for a week recently (23rd - 30th October 2016) and found it to be excellent.The rooms were large and scrupulously clean. The Executive Lounge was capacious and served excellent food, and the Eggs Benedict for breakfast were superb! Truly the best I have ever eaten.But the best thing was the staff. Nothing was too much trouble and they were happy and smiling all the time.I would definitely stay here again if I was to revisit Tokyo.

We stayed in September and October. The service is excellent even before I decided to stay there. I sent enquiry through the Marriott website and a few days later I received a detailed email from the concierge with information including JR timetable to get to my destination. And a map and instruction to access free shuttle bus and hotel from airport.We arrived early and check in was very efficient and hassle free. We used to stay at Shinjuku but the stay at Marriott is much relaxing with less people around the JR station and still have the convenience of finding supermarket near the station and restaurants. We walked with our nine years old daughter from the JR station to the hotel and it took maybe just over 10 minutes. The house keeping is also very clean and attention to details. We were provided with air purifier as my daughter has eczema and asthma. It was a nice stay for her, she didn't have any eczema skin problems during the stay.We will stay there again.

We stayed here for vacation for 7 days. The hotel seemed kind of out of the way at first, but it's actually kind of nice to retreat to a more quiet area at the end of the day, but still only be minutes away from all the action. The hotel is modern, clean and updated. The staff is all very kind and professional. They are very efficient and quickly answered our questions and needs without hesitation. The breakfast buffet was included in our stay and It. Was. Awesome. So good! Eggs to order, ramen station, cereals, breads, deli meats, fresh smoothies and fruit. You name it, they had it! What a great way to start our day each day! Loved this!One miss was room service. This was in the evening and the guy who took our order had no idea what we were asking for and wasn't able to answer our questions about the burger. The hamburger meat wasn't the texture we're used to and was a little off. We were too exhausted to even call back to deal with it. There is a free shuttle to Shinagawa Station which will connect you to wherever you want to go. It's only a few minutes ride and a less than 10 minute walk downhill. Very easy. Check out was just as easy as check in. I would definitely stay here again and highly recommend it to all my friends. Thanks for a great trip, Tokyo Marriott!

I had to request for a morning early check in as my flight arrived very early. The hotel staff gave me a very warm welcome and the entire process to check in was seamless. Excellent service and I look forward to staying in Tokyo Marriott again!

Very comfortable hotel, good bedding and spacious western rooms. Breakfast spread is good too and very good amenities. Service is prompt and up to requirements. Service staff is multinational and English is not a problem in terms of communications.

Just got back from a 5 night stay at the Marriott Shinagawa hotel. Very nice hotel. Room a bit small but very quiet. Breakfast buffet is very good. Special thanks to Grace for the great smoothies and to Kevin for his help. Good location, close to shopping and train stations. Great service and food at the Excecutive Lounge. Thanks to all the staff that made our stay so pleasant.

Very nice newer Marriott with great staff and service. Short cab ride to shinagawa train station makes it easy to get around townEnjoyed stay and service while enjoying TokyoStormchaser on vacation says good choice

Stayed for three nights.The first Marriott hotel to forget my birthday. Not being very sensitive, but was disappointed. I have been celebrating my birthday in a different country at a different Marriott or Marriott affiliate hotels and brands for the past 15 years.Location is good, close to Shinagawa station. The hotel is good and Marriott style. A bit off from the action, but transportation was convenient enough.The room was of good size and the bathroom, too. Breakfast very good and cozy.The staff was friendly but the language barrier was a major issue. I was surprised that a Marriott hotel didn't have proper English speaking staff. It was rather challenging to get answers to our questions and queries. TV selection was very poor, only one English speaking channel. Had to stay in for most of the first day due to rain and it got a bit boring.All in all, a good stay.

Decent location, but not too much very close by. It's a bit of a walk to the restaurants but convenient to the metro. Its a new and modern property with all the usual Marriott amenities. It's a little tough to find if you're walking from the train, but most taxis should know it by now.

Stayed at Marriott shinagawa. Amazing service at bar, breakfast lounge and check in! A big thank you to Naoki and wada Yasuna for making it an amazing customer service experience and a memorable stay for our daughter! Awesome start to a holiday!! Highly recommend :)

Room sizes OK and staff very helpful. Wi-fi can be a bit spasmodic. Prices for meals and the breakfast very high. Shuttle bus to the station (free) very helpful and works well.Good location near to the JR train line and the airport.

Centrally located in Shingawa area. Very comfortable rooms with nicely appointed features. Executive lounge has light snacks but meals need to be taken in restaurant. Elite members get breakfast coupons which was much appreciated. Be prepared for very limited English TV. CNN international and one other channel.

This is a nice, pleasant hotel with good staff, reasonably convenient location (and a shuttle to take you to Shinagawa station), nice sized rooms (for Tokyo), etc. All around its a pretty good hotel, except for the executive lounge. This is easily the smallest executive lounge I have come across in a long time, and it got packed up so not only could I not get a seat during happy hour, there was nowhere to even stand and wait for a table to open up.

Hotel was very nice and rooms are very adequate and nice, but bathrooms were slightly dated. Lobby area is nice, check-in is a bit confusing. Breakfast is fantastic is lobby - definitely have this before you leave for the day. Executive lounge is near check-in which is odd but nice to have as a meeting location. Very expensive for what you receive.

For work I stayed here again. This time for two nights. Check in was friendly and the room is actually quite spacious. Bed are very comfortable as is the aircon. Good variety of pillows and extensive supply of barroom amenities. Staff is friendly and the breakfast was perfect. I honestly don't have many improvement points. Maybe the concierge could worry a bit more about his guests finding a taxi in the morning. Overall conclusion is that I will happily return anytime to this oasis in the Tokyo buzz.

It was a pleasant stay, overall experience was good. very quick action with the check in & out. very Helpful staff .The Breakfast was very good with wide variety to choose , the daily fresh fruit juice was excellent ! And will take the opportunity to send my special thanks to the best ever two girls in the Marriott restaurant ( Mary Grace & Mackie ) !

Following an enjoyable week staying at the Courtyard Marriott Tokyo Station (CYMTS) we took the JR Yamanote line to Shinagawa (5 stops away) where the Tokyo Marriott is located. We exited the West Exit on the left to catch the free shuttle bus at #6 bus stop to the hotel and avoid an arduous 20 minute trek up an incline with heavy luggable. Accessibility oto activity centers is not as convenient as CYMTS due to shuttle scheduling constraint although hotel - station taxi ride is 730 yen. We checked in at the executive lounge where the hotel served generous and high qualify food and drinks. The breakfast buffet was also excellent. Room and bath were spacious. View of city was similar (not spectacular) on both side from our 23 fl. rooms. Airport shuttle to Narita costs $31. Possible language issue almost caused overpayment (charged to room and paid in) at shuttle desk far away from the front desk. Poor communication between staff there and confused front desk clerks (Maika & Nao) even after we had to run back to clarify left a bad impression that marred an otherwise great experience.

While traveling to Japan on business, I decided to layover in Tokyo and stay for a night. I chose the Tokyo Marriott as I'm a Marriott Rewards member and I can say this is probably one of the nicest Marriott hotels I've stayed at. Absolutely gorgeous. Locating the check in desk was a little difficult as it is behind the restaurant that you see when you first enter. There is an area for Marriott Platinum members only but I passed it and they directed me back there. They staff was very pleasant, most speaking some English so it wasn't difficult to communicate (I always worry about this traveling internationally) I was upgraded to a larger room (thanks! :) and it was very nice, with some cool technology incorporated (window shades controlled via remote, heated bidet, heated mirrors, etc.). I did try breakfast at the restaurant the following morning and they had a great spread with many different kinds of items (Japanese and American/Western). There is a nice walking trail outside of the hotel as well. I wish I could've stayed longer but I do plan to travel back to this property in the near future.

Pretty late on the review but must say i had the best experience in Tokyo thanks to the marriot! Dinner on the 63 floor was amazing but prices was a bit up there. Not bad for a first time experience Japanese cuisine.

My one single gripe is that our room smelled vaguely of smoke. It wasn't a strong smell, but enough to notice right when you walked in. I'm honestly not sure if there was an option to book a non-smoking room, when there is we always choose it, but like I said, not a smell bad enough to worry too much about. We got there early and they held our bags til we came back to check in. Service was wonderful, the room was clean other than the smell and well-appointed, comfortable bed. Location a little further from Shinagawa station than we would've liked, but not terribly far, and there is a shuttle bus from the hotel to the station that we took advantage of the next morning to get us and our bags to the station so we could make our way to the airport.We did have drinks and breakfast in the restaurant, both were a nice experience, and the service there was great as well. Also had quite nice entertainment, a singer and guitarist, on Friday evening. Very happy with our stay here.

The hotel is like new, the latest technology in room design and layout. We stayed at the concierge level which included a great breakfast buffet, a free drink at the hotel bar and a nightly snack time with free drinks. The appetizers were ok not great the best place for these are the Marriott in Hong Kong Beijing and shanghai. The rooms are clean and well assigned, the problem we had is that there is no place to put your close, as good as no storage. We stayed 5 nights and lived out of our suit cases. The night stands had no draws, the closet no upper shelf to put items.Those are my only complains. There is a shuttle service to the nearby station which only take two minutes or a 15-minute walk.The staff is very polite and professional, when I gave a tip when they picked up my bags from the room they returned to me later because they said it was too much. I insisted they accept a smaller tipThe made me a box lunch when I could not be there for breakfast.The windows should be more sound proof so that you will not hear the trains

It's close to the train station, so ideal if you're the walking type. The room was well appointed with a sofa, coffee table and a king bed. The Nespresso coffee machine was a nice touch as well. Staff was friendly. Having stayed the previous week in the Ginza area of Tokyo, I can say that I did not love the area of Shinagawa as much (but the hotel really can't control that part).

My wife and I spent 5 nights at the Tokyo Marriott earlier this month. We had a great time. Everyone at the hotel was most helpful. The Concierge answered many questions before our trip to help us get prepared for our stay. A special thank you goes to Rita who provided guidance how to get to the hotel from the airport, the free shuttle bus from the train station, etc. We felt the location was a good one - not in the heart of the city but within minutes to all attractions by the subway. If the budget allows it upgrade to the lounge access. You get breakfast, afternoon tea service, and dinner with drinks. The staff throughout is friendly and courteous.

Getting to the checkin desk is around behind the restaurant, so a little odd, and if you're a Marriott Platinum member, there's a glass door on the left before the main check in area - could be better marked. The concierge lounge had nice variety and plenty of food for extended hours (not the typical 2 hour window). As long as people were in the lounge, they continued to restock the food. Rooms were clean and roomy. Concierge staff was excellent and patient in terms of giving recommendations and more than willing to spend as much time as necessary to help me plan my days. Hotel was in a nice location in terms of getting to the train station. They have a complimentary bus that regularly goes to the station. Would definitely stay again.

This is an above average Marriott location with a good but not excellent staff. It is kind of a weird layout as the check in is in a cubby hole about 500 yards it seems from the door. The rooms are nicely appointed and comparable in size to US Marriotts which is a big deal in Japan where the rooms are closet sized. Pay attention to your room location if you need quiet. One side of the hotel abuts the train line.

This place is great. I'm a platinum elite member and only stated one night. While I did not receive an upgrade I was impressed with my king size room. All the amenities of a western style hotel. Roomy with a nice desk for work. My bed was very firm but I like hem that way. Bathroom was very spacious with loads of toiletries. The staff brought me water and chocolates. The tv was rather large approx 45 inch and had English channels. There is a nice jogging path through a small forest on the property. The gym was very adequate with free weights. I am not a fan of hotels that do not have free weights. The staff spoke English well and took care of all my needs. And OMG the Buffett breakfast was amazing. The breakfast is what made me write this review. Good job Marriott.

Service excellent and understated, rooms as expected of hotel class, dinner in the bar/restaurant was first class, breakfast was as expected. Only downside was reception/lobby, a little difficult to negotiate and nowhere to sit if waiting for pick-up or transfer. English spoken by staff and found them to be most helpful. Hotel is a little isolated but a free shuttle operates to Shinagawa railway station. The hotel is in Tokyo consequently cost is at the high end for us.

The lobby doesn't inspire a lot of confidence as you have to walk past the breakfast area/coffee shop to get to the reception. However the rooms have been renovated, larger than the standard Japanese hotel room and were very comfortable. The location is convenient, as it is very close to the Shinagawa train station.The breakfast spread is decent, wifi is free, the staff speaks English and the gym is functional. Overall it met all my needs as a business hotel. Will be back.

The rooms are nice, the bed is comfortable, the service is excellent and the breakfast is very good, however it lacks a restaurant, except for the bar area which serves food. Even though there is a free shuttle that takes you to the closest train station (Shinagawa), there are no restaurants within a reasonable walking distance. The executive lounge is small and crowded and the hors d’oeuvres being served don’t have much variety.

A typhoon cancelled our flight. ANA staff told us to get a bullet train from Shinagawa. But there were no trains. Called 5 hotels but they were full. Tokyo Marriott had 2 rooms for us. Beautiful hotel. Great rooms with nice amenities. Friendly, English speaking staff. Expensive. If the airline wasn't footing the bill we would have stayed some place cheaper. Even the airport bus was expensive.

Don't have the Marriott feel or other affiliated chains... Nothing much to offer, staff are scarce. Personal feel is far from entertainment or eatery, nearest shopping area is at shinagawa station I think... Room is good sized compared to tokyo station

Rooms are nice with a very well stocked bathroom! Train tracks nearby the hotel makes some noise unavoidable but I think it's not as bad as some reviews stated cos I managed to have adequate sleep despite being a light sleeper. There's a shuttle service to the nearest subway/train station Shinagawa but watch out for weekends as the frequencies is cut and ends earlier.Arrange with hotel on the airport limousine bus which is just JPY729, just be mindful there're only 3 timing for transfers to Haneda airport whereas Narita's transfer is more regular.

We stayed at Tokyo Marriott Hotel from 8/5-7 and 8/9-810 for 3 nights this Aug. Honestly we felt some disappointed compare to Osaka Marriott.This hotel felt old even though they just open 1 or 2 years ago. I can see their updates but the bathroom looks old. The room was ok but you can hear your next-door talking in the early morning or the hall way.The location is about 10-15 walking from Shinagawa station. They have a city bus at number 6 bus station for free. In our 4 days stay, we maybe only took one time bus because it runs half hour. In the hot weather, we ended up using Taxi for 730 yen each way or by walking. They do have a orange bus runs to narita airport for about 3000 yen per adult.Their service was just ok. If Osaka Marriott service is 10, here probably 7.

I have stayed in many hotels of varying brands and I'm shocked at how bad this hotel really is. The location isn't great, however, there is a bus that takes you to Ropponge in about 20 minutes. I arrived with two heavy suitcases and a laptop bag, so I was hoping that there would be helpful staff waiting at the entrance to the hotel - I was wrong. I then had to drag everything myself to the reception, through the restaurant as the layout is very strange. The staff in general were nonchalant and not service focused. An example was when I went for dinner at the restaurant and was told that I couldn't sit at one of the numerous empty tables on my own and that I had to sit in an uncomfortable high chair at the bar and under strong lights. I was amazed at how rude they were. Being hungover and desperate for food I had no other option, but to sit at the bar, across from the blender that used pretty regularly. If the hotel was in a better location I would have just ate out. Before staying here, I spent over a month in the Marriott in Nagoya and it's like night and day in comparison, to the extent that it's embarrassing how polite and helpful the staff were. I genuinely can't believe this is a Marriott. The rooms are reasonably new, but pretty small, with a really strange lowered ceiling over the shower leaving not much space between my head and the ceiling - I'm only 6ft1. The bed was actually pretty comfortable: big king size. There's a Nesspresso machine in the room, which is nice. On the whole the rooms are ok, but I was facing the train tracks and it's constant traffic. I won't be staying in this hotel ever again and I'd recommend people to stay well clear. The food was average, the service was nonexistent and unfriendly. The quality of the room is the only thing that brings it up to a 2* rating and even at that, I've had better rooms in lesser quality hotels for a fraction of the price.

This was a beautiful and top notch hotel. Sylvanus Masiro at the concierge desk took care of many arrangements before we arrived and was so helpful while there.Close to main train station and in a quieter part of Tokyo it was a wonderful home base for our week in Tokyo. Rooms and views beautiful.Food at breakfast outstanding.

Has the best gym, nicest foyer, breakfast and gym of the Marriott/Courtyard hotels in Tojyo I've stayed at - gym because of size and proper free weights and other equipment and I guess thus reflects the fact that it's 10 mins walk from Shinagawa railway station and do 20 mins from Tokyo Central Station. But also only 20-25 mins from Haneda airport on metro.As always in Japan, clean, tidy, very helpful staff, good Exec Lounge (though windowless and on ground floor), nice rooms - if I was the manager I'd vary the breakfast and Exec Lounge offering as it does get awfully repetitive!

I stayed in this hotel on a business trip for 6 days, and was very convenient, comfortable and very foreigner friendly The one major issue was the vegetarian options - very limited (actually one dish) in the restaurant or room service menu - and was surprised they were not flexible to make or provide other optionsBut overall the hotel rooms were clean, comfortable, spacious and the nes coffee was greatThey have a shuttle to Shinagawa station, which then connects you to entire tokyoBut the place is aloof, so you don't have much in a walking distanceThey do have a nice gym, if you are looking for work outsThe front desk folks speak good english and can guide you wellOverall a very good hotel to stay....

4 night stay with 4 children and 3 adultsAlthough a business hotel still very accommodating for children. Convenient shuttle to the train station and good variety for breakfast buffet. Easily recommended for foreign guests. The only flaw that I could see for tourists is the location is limited for local sightseeing.

Check in timing ( 3 PM) is extremely unreasonable for the guests. My request for early check in was rejected and once I agreed to pay almost a day tariff was charged. Feel cheated. I was travelling with family two children from Singapore with an overnight flight.

On arrival, good English speaking and helpful staff escorted me to the concierge and managed to radio ahead for my reservation to be ready when I am at the desk! Check in becomes a breeze and I got to my room in less then 5 mins. Hotel room is well maintained and modern design. Bathroom is nicely stock up with generous toiletries and equipped with latest automatic self washing WC.A wide breakfast spread covering both international and local dishes. Though good quality and value but still quite pricy for an al carte meal. Overall this hotel has up hold the Marriott brand reputation very well.

This hotel has a free shuttle going between the hotel and the nearby Shinagawa station, making travel around Tokyo very easy. Otherwise, there is not a lot nearby. The rooms are indeed small, but not bad by Japanese standards. I had a very clean, fresh room. The one restaurant was well served, with a moderate sized menu. Overall, recommended.

Just finishing up our week stay at the Tokyo Marriott, this is the only place I stay when traveling to Tokyo. The location is convenient to Major train station, the hotel itself is exceptional and the staff make it world class. The concierge Sylvanus Masiro is always on top of things and has an answer to questions asked of him and ensures that your needs are met. The concierge lounge staff is tremendous and always a pleasure to be around handling everything from check in to check out and all your needs in between. The breakfast arrangement is beyond words, Galova Marketa always turns your breakfast request into a culinary masterpiece. As a lifetime Platinum Marriott member I can say without hesitation that staying at the Tokyo Marriott is satisfaction guaranteed!

The rooms are nothing special, just look tired and the one thing I was not expecting is that they have only one place to eat, and that is the Cafe-like establishment on the 1st floor. Although the breakfast is acceptable, the lunch and dinner menu - better to walk 15 minutes to the Shinagawa Station and eat at the local restaurants, even though it is a challenge in English. I had one dinner at this Cafe-like establishment at Marriott. The menu is very limited and minimal Japanese dishes for being in Japan. I ordered a Reubin Sandwich and the sandwich had a maximum 2 thin slices of meat in the middle of 2 slices of toast. What a rip off!!!!! never ate there again on my 2 stays on this last trip which ended on 19 July 2016. Just to be fair, the Executive Lounge is very nice even though there are no windows and is on the ground floor.

We spent 8 nights at the Tokyo Marriott and were delighted with our stay. The staff are absolutely outstanding!We were on the 23rd floor and enjoyed a city view and a peekaboo view of Shinagawa Station which is fascinating to watch and we were pleased that noise was not an issue at all.Our spacious room had everything we could ask for- cozy terry bathrobes, comfortable light cotton night shirts, a/c that works perfectly, a fabulous box of toiletries- (the in house shampoo and conditioner are lovely- no need to pack your own.) The hairdryer has plenty of power. As the voltage in Japan is lower than in North America, my flat iron for your hair wouldn't work but the hotel provided a loaner. Mirror positioning is a bit awkward to hairstyling- with strategic placement of the makeup mirror it can be done!If you turn on the TV and English speaking channels like CNN and BBC are voiced over in Japanese you can check your TV Remote info card- there is a button to turn ff the translation.Breakfasts are fantastic with a perfect mix of local and Western- I made a beeline to the soup area- delicious ! I really enjoyed the location- the Shinagawa Temple and Hara Contemporary Art Gallery are both less than a 10 minute walk away and are not to be missed. The Shinagawa Station has a great selection of shops. The East side has some souvenir shops. Downtown Tokyo is a short bus or train ride away.This was our first trip to Tokyo and the Tokyo Marriott Hotel added to the pleasure of our experience!

I spent 5 nights. The hotel is well located, close to Shinagawa station. All the services are very good but I would stress the great job done by the evening staff of the hotel's restaurant, in particular Romain (special thanks) who was very professional, extremely efficient and always smiling ! Definitely a place I will come back to

Had to switch rooms due to the noise of the train lines that run right below the hotel - not all the the rooms have the same level of sound proofing. The best solution, though, is to get on the other side of the hotel and as high as possible.Also, discovered (I did not see this on internet) that there is a pool (good for laps) and a gym. Seems if not Elite member you are charged for this.

I like the hotel. It is in a quite location but still in city center. There is free shuttle bus that goes to Shinagawa Stn every 10-15 mins. There is also airport shuttle that goes direct to the hotel. Very convenient. Even walking from the hotel to Shinagawa Stn only takes 10-15 mins.Free wi fi is available. Spacious room with complete facilities. Staffs are able to converse well in English and are very helpful.The price is rather expensive but I think it is in par to the services and facilities that you receive and enjoy.

We stayed at the hotel for 6 or 7 nights in June. It is a very nice hotel. I think it would be especially nice for business travelers. We were a family of three. We had a roll away bed added to the room for the 12yo. The bathroom was huge! The closet was small (but plenty big for a single business traveler or couple). We only had one drawer that we could use to put clothes in. Again, not a problem for a business traveler, not great for a family of three. Nice tea and coffee service in the room. We had a fridge which was essential since we were traveling with meds that needed to remain refrigerated. The food in the restaurant was very good and the breakfast buffet was nice too. The best part of the hotel was the location. A short walk (less than 10 minutes)to Shinagawa station. This was how we got around the entire trip. Again, the hotel was wonderful and so was Japan! I am hoping to return again someday.

Nice hotel, a bit outside of the center but ok for access to airport. Fitness centre a BIG disappointment. US$20+ for a very meagre offering, limited opening hours and outdated equipment. Hard to recover from the trip if fitness is important.

We liked the hotel and the service. Breakfast was good, although Executive Lounge was very deficient.Worst thing about this hotel is the location, there is not a single Metro station in sight, so if you take the shuttle to Shinagawa station, you can only go in the JR Yamanote line, which is not convenient to most attractions.Hotel should have a shuttle to a Metro station and improve the Executive Lounge offerings.

One of the better Marriotts I have stayed in. The staff's attention to detail was superb. Large spacious rooms. Breakfast had Japanese and Western choices. Some of the best tomatoes I ever had. I would recommend this place to anyone. Shuttle to and from Shinagawa train station.

One night stay in 2 connecting room with my family on our way to Singapore .Great rooms tastefully decorated and very spacious for Tokyo standards.Bathroom is super with fantastic ammenities.Garden on the back side of the hotel is great for a morning walk or tai chi if you are jet lagged at 6.30am. we took the express train from Narita and arrived with no transfers needed into Shinagawa station at rush hour in the afternoon...We survived! One comment on the shuttle bus to the hotel from Shinagawa station: It's a shuttle that also serves the offices building next door to the hotel so it can get pretty crowded , if you are travelling with big suitcases it can be difficult to board the shuttle at peak hours.Another piece of adviise, ticket machines at the station don't take credit cards but there is a Travelex currency exchange service at the station where you can get Yens.Less than 20 minutes to Ginza by a direct line.

We were in Room 2015 which overlooked the railway lines. The view could have been better but the room location was ideal. Its near the lift and a corner room with a roomy layout.It took us a day or 2 to appreciate the hotel location as we were previously accustomed to staying in Ginza and Ropponggi which were more central and hence cheaper taxi fares. There is shuttle service from the hotel to Shinagawa station which convenients connects to Tokyo, Shinjuku and Shibuya stations but this shuttle service is also available to the tenants, residents or anyone who wants to utilize it from the office and apartment blocks next door. so seats are limited. Furthermore the shuttle service stops quite early in the evening.However the grounds are very well landscaped with paths, waterfall and loads of foliage. it is very relaxing considering the hotel is in the city itself.The breakfast spread was extensive as well. The after lodging service is commendable. I had left some blocks of butter which i had bought fr Hokkaido in the mini fridge. I immediately emailed them upon reaching Narita to send it to another friend's hotel in Shinjuku. When I landed back in Malaysia 8 hours later, the arrangements to send the butter by refrigerated courier had already been made. This quick and efficient service pleasantly surprised me and commend the hotel for this.I highly recommend the Tokyo Marriott especially if you are able to spare a few days in Tokyo.

Great hotel. I stay at this hotel as often as I can for business. They offer access to a health club and spa. Great healthy breakfast buffet. The only thing that disappoints me about the hotel is that it doesn't have a Japanese restaurant. Nadaman on the lobby level vacated the hotel. I really miss the Sushi bar and Tempura counter. I hope Nadaman is replace by another quality Japanese restaurant.

All the staff we friendly, knowledgeable and helpful! The tiny things they do for you make the stay memorable - welcome card, housekeeping, and concierge services. We are going to miss everyone! Peace and love. Yang family, Kansas City, Kansas, USA

Tokyo Marriott was the perfect hotel for a visit to Japan with my kids. After a day of touring around the city, it was a perfect air-conditioned oasis. Breakfast was excellent and the Executive Lounge was a nice benefit as well. Our room was clean and the beds were very comfortable. We were upgraded to a suite called the "Executive Premier Suite". Perfect, as we had a small living area plus a bedroom with two full-size beds. I think the "Family Guest Room" may also have two full-size beds. (And the Presidential Suite has 2 queen size beds.) Great stay - 7 days in total. Also, we were able to leave some of our luggage with Marriott when we traveled to other parts of Japan. VERY convenient. Finally, hotel provides a free shuttle-bus every 10 -20 min from Shinagawa station. Great experience overall!

Visited this hotel during a business trip. Everything you would expect of a Marriott hotel. Nice room, well equipped, good beds, good service. Restaurant offers Japanese and western food. Staff very polite and service oriented. Close to the station.

Last December 2015, me and my family stayed at Tokyo Marriott Hotel. From the very first time we entered the hotel, we knew that we will love this place. It was perfect. Close to the train station, post office, convenience store, and restaurants. We will definitely stay here again, if we happen to go back to Tokyo.

Great hotel. Good breakfast. Hope in future they keep Gym open for 24/7 as 6 am to 10 pm is not convenient to beat jet lag. Coffee machine in room great. Bathroom with half glass makes be near shower otherwise wet floor safety care one has to take. I will come again.

I enjoyed my stay at the Tokyo Marriott. Rooms are very nice, comfortable bed, bedding, reasonably quiet but it is across from the train tracks. Used the lounge on the 1st floor with a friend that was Platinum Marriott member - that was good quick stop. Bar / restaurant was good but pricey for breakfast if you don't eat the entire buffet. Hotel was the walking distance to some nice restaurants within walking distance, as is the Shingawa train station. We took the bus directly from Narita to the hotel. This is the only hotel I would stay in in the area.

Pros-I stayed here for two nights in early June 2016. Our room was modern, had comfortable beds, large oversized bathroom and a great selections of coffee and tea. My room was on a high floor but I could still hear the train at times. As a gold member, I was able to use the executive lounge. The lounge offered a variety of food/drinks and was the best part of the hotel. The concierge desk helped me map out different sights. CONS- I was disappointed to have to pay to use the pool. I feel as a rewards member, that the pool should be free. The pool has quite a bit of rules that were annoying. At check in, the desk did not want to give me access to the lounge because I was not traveling with my husband. They did finally agree because my name is on the reservation. There is an attitude in Japan that it is not acceptable for a woman to travel without her husband. I encountered this several times in Japan. Please note that you can get a shuttle bus for free rom the Shinagawa station- stop #6.Easy to get to/from Narita using the Narita Express. If visiting as a tourist, buy a Japan rail pass prior to leaving the US. The Narita Express is covered on the pass.

Great stuff:Rooms and bathrooms are modern, spacious, clean and comfortable.The bed was firm, just the way I like it!We enjoyed the complimentary coffee and selection of tea.Convenience of having the "Family Minimart" nearby.Shuttle bus to and from Shinagawa station made it more convenient versus walking.For improvement:Room rates are expensive especially when rates do not include use of swimming pool and the gym.Waste bin in bathroom is too small.Room tip:Our children stayed in Deluxe Twin which has much bigger space compared to our Deluxe King.Rooms with odd numbers - we could hear the train passing by. Even number rooms - you can hear the passing train but it's less noisy.

I was really pleased with my weekend stay at the Marriott in Shinagawa. I wanted to try a different location after staying at the Hilton in Shinjuku during the week (which was really nice) and was happy with this choice. My room had a gorgeous view of the Shinagawa train station, which was really spectacular at night. The bed was comfy, room was quiet and service was attentive. It was only a 10 minute walk from the train station and the shuttle bus was very easy. It was also a quick walk to Gotanda. I liked being in a more quiet part of town, but with easy access to the rest of the city. The front desk was extremely attentive and I really liked the executive lounge, which had some very special treats.

Stayed here twice in June and picked the hotel mainly because of my Gold Elite status, which meant that I can book the cheapest room and still get the benefits (28,000 yen rate including taxes in June). Compared to a number of decent options in Shinagawa the rate was kind of overpriced given that there are decent and cheaper options right next to Shinagawa station (e.g. Excel, Prince, Strings).Many reviews have noted the hotels location and it is definitely not that convenient. While there is a shuttle bus to and from the station the last bus from the station departs at 9:55pm so if you have a late night out then you have to walk 10 minutes uphill or get a taxi for 700+ yen. Also, the shuttle is not exclusively for guests but is shared with the office workers next door to the hotel, So the shuttle can be packed, especially on the down trip after 6pm. So while the hotel would be a good base to explore Tokyo in theory because you can practically get to anywhere from Shinagawa station, it is not really that practical.About the hotel itself, it is part of a bigger building complex so the layout is unconventional. Rather than entering through a lobby one has to walk a while before getting to the front desk. In any case, the rooms are well-sized and typical Marriott quality and standard that are comparable to Marriotts in the US. A major plus is having access to the Executive lounge which is open till midnight and offers a range of food options throughout the day, such as afternoon tea and evening snacks. Breakfast is taken at the hotel's one solitary restaurant, which finishes at 11 am, a plus for late sleepers. Added to this are host of other benefits such as welcome drink and complementary pressing, as well as a 'guaranteed' late checkout of 4pm. This sounded good but the two airport shuttles to Haneda Airport leave at around 9am and 11am, so while we did take advantage of the late checkout we took a taxi to Haneda, which came to 4000 yen. But of course, I only received the benefits on the cheap rate because of my Gold Elite. I could not imagine how much an Executive level room will cost.Service levels at the hotel were mixed. Staff at the restaurant and lounge were exemplary. Bell section was another matter. On both occasions my taxi arrived and there was no staff at the entrance. The first time, the taxi driver helped get a trolley for our 3 suitcases. The second time I had to personally get the trolley and unload and load myself. Only later did some staff belatedly came out. As I told the staff in the lounge: "Once can be an accident, but two times is something more systematic", and I asked for the name card of the General Manager. I do not normally mind these kinds of things but I did not pay Marriott price to get Courtyard level service.All in all, this is a good hotel for business execs with Marriott Gold/Plat Elites. Otherwise, there are many more options available for the price.

Stayed for two nights, but wish we could have stayed longer. The staff were exceptional and the rooms were immaculate. No language barrier for us and everyone went out of their way to help us and make us feel at home. Maybe this is was just because I'm a Platinum Elite member, but they even allowed my whole family of 5 to use the Executive Lounge, when it's usually only allowed for the member and one guest. We were met at the entrance and tended to until we got to our rooms and had our bags dropped off. Complimentary drink coupons and breakfast buffets were also provided, although these were only for two people. Can't complain after all the service I received. The location worked very well for us. It was an easy train using the Narita Express to get to the Shinagawa station. I followed the directions using a previous post to find the shuttle bus (exit the Tanakawa side and head left when you get outside) and was at the hotel just a few minutes later. The Marriott provided easy access to the city via Shinagawa station. It helps to know the shuttle bus schedule, which the hotel will provide if you ask, but even the walk is only about 10-15 minutes. I would stay here again the next time I return. The rooms were more spacious than I expected and had JBL bluetooth speakers, the elevators were fairly quick (we were on the 22nd floor) and did I mention the service?

We stayed at the Marriott during a business trip and had mixed impressions. The hotel and rooms are very nice and clean. Breakfast was great, but not cheap. The gym was a little disappointing. It costs $20 to get in and has all these Japanese rules if you want to use the pool etc. The equipment looked OK, but nothing special, and I would not spend it again. Another issue is that I yet have to find a taxi driver that knows how to get there. Most have not heard of the Marriott, and communication is difficult, even when you try to write it down. Hopefully that will change over time.

Located near major transit hub, Tokyo and Japan are easily accessible. Modern, upscale rooms tastefully decorated. Service levels congruent with Marriott service levels at similar properties. Breakfast buffet is a must. Fitness center located next door is complimentary for elite members. Ok facility. If you're craving sushi and want you eat nearby bring cash. Cards not accepted at nearly sushi spot. English spoken by much of staff. Overall this property is GOOD.

Two tips on public transportation(1) Limousine bus from/to the Airport Both Narita (NRT) and Haneda (HND) airport have a limousine bus to Marriott hotel. As of May 2016, both airports had a promotion on limousine bus tickets which includes subway pass as well. Please check the photo for details.(2) Free shuttle bus from/to Shinagawa station There is a shuttle from/to Shinagawa station, which runs between the Marriott hotel and the station. As of May, 2016, you can take it at bus stop #6 in Shinagawa station. Please check the photo for the schedule.

We stayed at this hotel for 8 days in Jun 16. As with most Marriot Hotels, the rooms and amenities were of decent standard. What really bothered me was at this hotel, the service attitude of the front desk seemed biased. As a non-caucasuan guest of Chinese descent, I perceive a difference in service standard and attituyde. An encounter on my last evening here confirmed this; I was rudely addressed by the front desk staff who did not even bother to give me eye contact. This was in contrast to the fawning treatment given to the caucasian guest just before me. Maybe it was just me but I do not think so.

4 nights at Tokyo Marriott during a busy week worked out very well. Huge rooms compared to other Tokyo hotels, with great bathroom. Great international breakfast and very service minded staff. Highly recommended to all biz travelers. .

Just returned from staying there for 4 nights on a Business Trip. First ever visit to Japan -Cannot fault anything! Service was second to none, all staff so helpful and so friendly, great rooms and amenities, relaxing bar area, great food.

My employer has a corporate rate at this hotel, so I was more than happy to accept the offer from AMEX Travel agents. Overall I was really pleased with my stay, its a well appointed hotel with a big business in Weddings in their array of banquet rooms in the lower ground floor. If its not too humid, the hotel is an easy 10 minute walk from Shinagawa train station, its also part of the Friendly Bus service from Narita Airport so you can get right to the door and skip the NEX train if you prefer. They had a nice breakfast buffet, with omelette maker!! Recommend a higher room to avoid any train track noise, also the rooms with 2 beds are fine!! Each bed is plenty big enough!

Stayed here for three nights for business. My first time in Tokyo so was not sure what to expect. Delighted with the hotel. It seems new and modern and everything is in excellent condition. The lobby is large and comfortable. The staff are all very polite and helpful and spoke good English. My room was a surprise, I was expecting something small but it was a good size as was the bathroom. Spotlessly clean with all modern fittings. My first experience with a computer type toilet was fun and all hotels could take a lesson the shower - perfect temperature control and pressure. The wifi was fast and reliable. For those with an interest I flew into Haneda Airport which is much closer than I had realised to the hotel - about a 20 minute drive. I wasn't sure about transport - the hotel bus seems to be only one per day and didn't fit my schedule so I used TokyoAirporter.com. Was met at the airport and driven to hotel in a car. Very impressed with their staff, quick email communication.

My standard room manage to host 2 adults and 2 kids with a 3 bed configurations, and still ample of space for our luggage and room to walk about in the room. Room is clean and bathroom is huge and stock with a wide variety of toiletries. Breakfast at the restaurant was great. There are Japanese local breakfast, western egg, bacon and waffles, as well as, a pastry, deli and a fruit and juice station. Staff are friendly and helpful. Executive lounge seem to be very popular and at times, an empty table of seat may be hard to come by. Still, this is a nice hotel that I would recommend.

Stayed here recently for four nights on a business trip. Hotel itself was lovely with the room large by Japanese standards and bathroom well laid out with a great shower. What set it apart from others is the extremely high quality of staff. When I arrived I had a lovely warm welcome by the staff at the front desk and was escorted to the club lounge for a very smooth and efficient check in. This standard of service was repeated throughout my stay in both the lounge and at the front desk. As I had several meetings to attend in Tokyo and Yokohama with no idea of how to get to my destinations, my travel schedule was arranged each evening by Mikuko Nagashima at the desk in the club lounge who not only told me what train lines and subways to get but also timings around when I wanted to go, the platform to use and the ticket price. Thanks to Mikuko for this and also to her and her colleagues (Kanako & Linda) in the lounge for looking after us all so well each evening. I also tried the restaurant on a couple of occasions and again the service was good as was the quality of the food. I never tied the gym or the pool so I cannot comment on these however the garden adjacent to the hotel is a great place to switch off and a seat beside the pond watching and listening to the waterfall is very soothing. I will definitely stay here during my next visit to Tokyo.

This hotel is quit nicely renovated and very comfortable. The staff are very good. But the information you get is usually missing a key bit. For example, there is an airport limo service (shuttle bus) and it's only 720 Yen, they don't tell you it only runs certain times of the day and if you have an early flight then you'll need a taxi that is closer to 5000 Yen. We were given complimentary drinks vouchers, ordered a drink from the drinks list (nothing special just a beer, the same beer on offer in the lounge) to be told we couldn't order off that menu and were handed a scrappy piece of A4 with a much reduced list to choose from. I still got my beer just not the one I wanted.Others have already mentioned the joke that is the gym, How can a 4 star hotel even think it's reasonable to charge for access to a gym and pool. I've stayed at other Marriott hotels with a sepertely run gym and hotel guests are allowed to use them for no charge. The dated and chargeable gym facilities (Not to mention the creepy female staff member that followed me around the gym) means I'll choose a different hotel next time. The staff work hard to meet the needs of the guests but the product they hve been given to work with is just not good enough.

Is this the perfect hotel? No... Is it close to all the action? No... But I really liked it.It was clean and comfortable. The only thing that was weird was the rooms had small beds. Like not twin size but not Full size. I'm referring to the rooms with two beds. I'm not sure if that's just how the rooms are, or if they didn't upgrade me to a room with 2 queens... We only slept here so it wasn't a big deal.I was able to speak to everyone in english and they totally understood me. I had no issues getting my points across.As an elite member I got access to their lounge which I only used a couple of times because we were usually out in the city. Breakfast wasn't served in the lounge it is served in their restaurant and let me tell you... i was impressed.Not only did they have delicious western options, they had delicious local eats with fresh local breads. They had miso soup, and noodles and this stuff that was wrapped in a leaf. It looked like a "tamale" (that's the only thing i could reference). But it was made from rice and had chunks of pork... SOOOO good! There was also an omelet bar that made excellent egg dishes AND pancakes and waffles. The pancakes were like these tiny balls... amazing. with whip cream and strawberries... super delicious.I was impressed.Now as far as location this place is in Shinigawa at gotenyama trust tower. And the Shinigawa metro/train station is like a 15 minute walk... but there's a free shuttle that runs till like 11pm and it's like 5 mins...The Shinigawa station is massive so get familiar with the metro and rail system (they are separate) because it is overwhelming. You can be anywhere withing 10-15 minutes... don't take a taxi. trust me. it's expensive and it will take 40 mins... There is also a nice garden. We didn't go into it but we saw the outlying cherry blossoms from our room... it was pretty.The concierge here was top notch. He was very helpful and gave me this tokyo guidebook that is essential for anyone coming to visit.. it really helped me get everywhere.This place is what you need. A super comfortable sanctuary to come home to after a long day of site seeing. I loved it.

Even after paying more than 35000 yen per night for a very average room they expect you to pay over 2000 yen to use the shared gym facilities... Unbelievable. Definitely not competitive with SPG, Hilton or intercontinental brands and below expectations.

Location:The hotel is about 1 hour driving distance from Narita airport and 30-40 minutes by taxi to city center. Although Tokyo is a large city and it will be hard to find the perfect place, hotel's location is not ideal for discovering the city. You spend a lot of time travelling if you want to visit the main sights. Hotel & Rooms:Upon arrival, my first impression of the hotel was not very positive. The layout of the main lobby is very unusual for a hotel. Bell desk is right at the main entrance, but the main reception is on the opposite side of the ground floor, away from the main entrance and you have to walk pass the restaurant for check-in. Firstly, we stood slightly confused at the entrance, as we did not know where to go and it took a couple of minutes for the staff to realise and direct us to the right location. The reception area is hidden in the corner and does not make the justice for the hotel. Dark and without nice vibe. My negative comments will end at this point, as once you checked into your room, the positive experience starts. The rooms are bright and spacious with large and comfortable beds. If you receive a room on a higher floor you will also appreciate beautiful city view. The bathroom is also spacious and well designed, with amenity box, which exceeds any expectations and which definitely provides everything you might need in case you forgot your cosmetic bag. Service and cleanliness:Overall the staff is very friendly and efficient. The concierge patiently explained us the best way to reach our desired destinations and also provided some personal suggestions. Upon departure we needed large taxi, for which we would needed to wait 1 hour. One of the bellboys did not hesitate and went out and tried to bring a taxi from the street, which thankfully worked and we got the taxi we needed after 15 minutes. During the breakfast the staff kept the tables clean and the buffet was refilled regularly. The cleanliness in the rooms, as well as public areas is spotless. Restaurants:We have dined only in the main lobby restaurant, which also serves the main breakfast. Breakfast buffet offers nice variety of Japanese and international dishes. It is nicely laid out and the quality is one of the best I experienced in a hotel. Many hotels offer larger selection, but the quality suffers, which is definitely not the case her. Overall:A part from the badly designed lobby, the hotel ticks all the boxes. Nice and spacious rooms, good service, friendly and efficient staff, attention to detail and cleanliness make this hotel really good choice for traveler. The re-designing of the lobby might not the top priority for the hotel management, but it should be something to consider for future to make this nice hotel even better.

Staff was extremely nice -- especially Sylvanus Masiro, the concierge. First time in Tokyo and found the hotel's restaurant prices extremely high, e.g. $80 per person (U.S dollars) for a buffet lunch. Glass of iced tea was $9! Other than the cost of food being a shock, the hotel is very close to a major transportation hub: Shinagawa station. We had a very spacious suite -- probably the biggest of any hotel we've ever stayed at. The room prices, in contrast, are very reasonable for a hotel of this quality. El Chompo bites again!

This was my first visit to Tokyo, Japan. I have traveled to 6 continents, therefore, I like to compare services. My spouse is a Platinum Member of the Marriott Corporation, Marriott hotels and resorts are our first choice when we travel Domestically and Internationally. I was traveling solo, there was some concern regarding my spouse not traveling with me, and my receiving benefits as a Platinum spouse's member. My thanks to Mr. Shigehisa Hirasawa, who interceded on my behalf, went above and beyond my expectations, for the upgrade to a junior suite, corner room, located on the 24th floor. There were many amenities (including an entertaining toilet with so many options!!) The concierge Mr. Sylvanus Masiro was very helpful in making me feel comfortable as a tourist. He provided me with information and made sure that I was comfortable with going out on my own to explore Tokyo, showed me where the free shuttle to Shinagawa train station, how to read the train schedule (I have traveled to Paris, France, Washington D.C., etc., and the layout of the trains were similar). Although I did get lost, I kept asking, eventually, I found my way to the free shuttle back to the Marriott. The Executive Lounge was on the first floor and that is where Marriott rewards members can have drinks and food during the day. As a rewards member, the full buffet style breakfast was excellent, with several food and drink choices. In the afternoon, there were tea, Scone & Sandwiches, in the evening, there were light meal & sweets, and full bar. The staff in the dining area was very professional and attentive to the type of service that guests were looking to receive. There is also a fitness saloon.

We had a rail pass that got us a Shinkansen trip back to Tokyo. We thought we would have to, with our luggage, go into the main station and change trains, during rush hour no less. Imagine what a pleasant surprise to hear Shinagawa called, the station before arriving in Tokyo.The staff were fantastic, the room extremely comfortable, and a lovely night view, although in the daylight it was a *cough* view of the train tracks. The best part of it however and well worth becoming a Marriott Gold Rewards Member for, was the executive lounge which was extremely well stocked with drinks and goodies galore.

Great hotel! And the breakfast bar is amazing!! If you are in town for a few days. This is a great hotel near train station. The service impeccable!! When you here ask for the peach juice its delicious ! And for those like bread. The breakfast offer an Excellent selection.

Coming from the Osaka Marriott, we initially was disappointed with the Tokyo Marriott. But this hotel grows on you, the longer we stayed here, the more we came to love it. The customer service is top notch here, especially Yuri Ebisuno at the lounge. Yuri was so patient and sweet with us, she helped us almost everyday, any question, any problem. We had an incident in the hotel where I got a cut on the leg, Yuri and Mr. Shigehisa Hirasawa stepped in, and resolved the problem right away. Thank you Ms. Yuri & Mr. Shigehisa!! Breakfast at the hotel is really good, the lounge could be nicer if it has a view. Overall a wonderful hotel. We will be back!!

As a Platinum Member, I was deciding between this hotel and the Prince Sakura Tower for my 6-night stay in Japan. While the Prince Sakura is a closer walk to Shinagawa Station, the Marriott has an executive lounge, so I picked the Marriott. (I went with my parents, and they always look forward to going to the lounge when they travel with me.) Before I talk about the hotel, I’m going to cover getting around to and from the hotel. Normally I don’t go into this much detail in my reviews, but for someone new to the area, this information would’ve been immensely helpful to me had I known ahead of time. If you want to go straight to the review of the hotel itself, skip the next two paragraphs.The hotel is pretty easy to get to from the airport. We arrived in Haneda (HND), bought PASMO cards, and took a direct train to Shinagawa Station on the Keikyu Line. When you exit the station, make a left and then another left on the sidewalk along the side of the station. At this point, you can either walk to the hotel (about 1/2 a mile, and you’ll see it to the right before you get to the next intersection) or catch the shuttle. The frequency of the shuttle varies depending on time of day and day of the week, and it doesn’t run very late, so you may want to ask the hotel for the schedule if you plan on taking it to the hotel prior to check-in.
