Note that the shuttle is actually a bus which runs between Shinagawa Station and Gotenyama Trust City (where the Marriott is located) and you don’t have to pay even though it is equipped to accept payments. (See below for a picture of the stop.) We didn’t realize the shuttle was actually a bus, so the first time we tried to take it, we waited as few came and went thinking the shuttle to the hotel would look different.It took a day or so to get the hang of going to and from the hotel, since I wasn’t familiar with Tokyo. What threw me off was that the rail system is operated by multiple public and private companies, and the Tokyo Metro app that I downloaded didn’t cover Shinagawa Station in its routing. (I have no affiliation with Tokyo Metro, but I recommend the app as it works offline and tells you which stations are nearby. You can find a download link on their site.) While you may come up with a better strategy, here’s what I used to get around: When heading out for the day go to the Central Entrance of Shinagawa Station and get on the Yamanote Line. This line is a ring around Tokyo and you can either get to where you want to go or transfer to the line to get you where you want to go from here. (FYI, the Yamanote Line isn’t in the Tokyo Metro app either.) Coming back, I would either take the Yamonote Line back to Shinagawa, or I’d use the Tokyo Metro app to get to the Asakusa Line (Sengakuji Station - A07 if you have to pick a stop). From there you can transfer to a “Haneda Airport Limited Express” train which will stop at Shinagawa Station. If you get on a train that stays on the Asakusa Line, the next stop (Takanawadai Station - A06) is about a mile walk back to the hotel, and there’s no shuttle from there.Now on to the hotel. The room was very clean and quiet and visited by housekeeping twice a day. The light controls for the whole room (except for the bathroom) were only on the headboard, so while you could control all the lights from bed (including a floor light which functioned as a nightlight), you couldn’t turn off the lights on your way out—something I always make a habit of doing in hotels. What stood out though was the TOTO Washlet toilet seat in the bathroom. This was my first experience with one of these and I won’t go into details, but the photo below of the control panel speaks for itself. Suffice it to say that a European bidet can’t hold a candle to this thing. (No pun intended.)The Executive Lounge is located on the first floor of this hotel and is open from 6:00 AM to midnight daily. They offer soda, coffee, tea, and snacks all day long as well as breakfast, afternoon tea, and a light evening meal. They also have a full open bar in the evening with wine and liquor (see pic below). It’s worth noting that they do stick to the rule of limiting admission to the Elite Member and one guest. Of all the Marriott hotels that I've visited, this was the first one that was strict about admission into the lounge. While disappointing to hear, I can understand. The lounge isn’t very large and did fill up during peak times, but I was always able to find a seat. Unfortunately this meant I had to bring my parents in one at a time. (They were staying in a different room, so their key wouldn’t get them in.)Instead of eating breakfast in the lounge, I preferred to join my parents, so I opted for breakfast coupons in the hotel restaurant, Lounge & Dining G. I highly recommend going this route whether you have lounge access or not because the breakfast options are much better in the restaurant. There’s a bar for ordering eggs, waffles, and pancakes, an area where you can select a Japanese breakfast (including noodle soup customized to your liking), a bread bar, a fruit bar, a cereal bar, a selection of juices, a selection of cheeses, and probably more that I'm missing. You can easily stay here for a week and have something different every day.All in all, we had a wonderful stay at this hotel. If you’re looking for a place that’s not in the busiest part of Tokyo with easy access to both local trains and the Shinkansen, you can’t go wrong here.

I stayed here with a friend for one week after coming to Japan for a holiday. The hotel is really easy to find- about 15/ 20 minutes drive from Haneda airport and a 5 minute walk from Shinagawa station. The hotel itself is very nicely decorated and spacious. We stayed in a twin room on one of the higher floors and the room was huge with a tv, seating area and really big marble bathroom. The bar downstairs is really ambient and cool looking. The food is gorgeous and the drinks were fabulous. There's a great breakfast buffet with different stations for things like pancakes, omelettes and waffles etc. The staff were very friendly and kind and spoke very good English. They greeted us with a big smile and a hello every day. I would definitely recommend staying here if you are visiting Tokyo on business. For a holiday and if you are looking to go out partying, somewhere closer to Shinjuku/Shibuya etc might be better (as the trains don't run throughout the night and taxis are very expensive!)All in all a wonderful stay though and I would definitely go back :)

Our second trip to Japan and our first stay with the Marriott and we couldn't fault it. Our room was very comfortable and extremely quiet as per our request. The staff went out of there way to help in any way possible despite our language barriers. We ate in house a few times for breakfast, lunch and dinner and each time were very impressed. Breakfast is available buffet and Alacarte which not all hotels offer and they have a small section to buy bakery goods and takeaway coffee. The lunch menu is extensive and served most of the day with typical fare of burgers and pasta, again excellent. There are three restaurants but our favourite was the grill where we shared a latter of wonderful grilled meat, ribs and prawns all cooked perfectly. The staff were fantastic and we'll trained, if we couldn't make ourselves understood there was someone else to try. Remember we are the visitors so have patience.There is a bus every few minutes to shuttle you free of charge to Shinagawa station or if you feel adventurous walk to Kita shinagawa station nearby and ride to Shinagawa in one stop. Alternatively it's a 10 minutes walk.Highly Recommended

The Marriott Tokyo property was the last hotel on our 6-leg trip on which we departed from Miami to Washington DC traveled to Dubai, then Bangkok, Ao Nang, Koh Phi Phi Don and finally ended in Tokyo. The property is clearly geared towards the business crowd and was perfectly appointed for that crowd.Unfortunately for us, we were traveling on pleasure and arrived to the property after 24 hours of constant travel from a 45 minute wooden boat ride to a 75 minute ferry to the mainland, followed by another 75 minute plane ride to an hour airport transfer and then additional 10 hour flight to Tokyo. Clearly we were exhausted and upon arrival at 9am to the hotel our rooms were not available. I had already emailed the reservations department the week prior to request an early check in (in addition to my comments when booking the reservations 5 months in advance) however it was not until the day before my arrival (travel day) that I received the answer that our request could not be accommodated. We even tried using our Marriott Platinum Rewards member status to see if that would at least get one of our rooms available earlier than the standard check in so we could shower and change, but no luck!We were however, offered use of the gym facilities and showers downstairs for a charge ($25 USD per person) at that point we just needed a shower to regain some energy and continue on our day so we caved in and paid the fee. I must say that the shower facilities themselves were a cultural experience. There are no private enclosed shower stalls - it was an open shower with the hot tub in the middle and sauna at one end of the pavilion along with some stool and hand held shower hoses. I will spare the details and leave it at the fact that it was an interesting experience. My fiance and the boyfriend of our friend that we were traveling with even shared a shave with a group of Japanese men in their locker room - again great cultural experience. After our showers and quick cat-nap in the lobby our tour guide met us around 11 am and we got out to explore the city. When we returned to the hotel that evening around 11pm our bags had been delivered to our rooms and we were able to settle in for the night. The rooms were perfectly appointment for our purpose, bed and clean shower facilities. Safe was large enough to accommodate our necessities. It may have been the exhaustion but that night I slept perfectly and we awoke the following day continue our exploration of Tokyo and attend the car show which first spurred our trip to the East. On the last night of our trip we were over all the fried rice, noodles and sushi we had consumed in the previous 10 days of travel and decided to have a burger at the bar - by far one the best burgers we have had! The tomato bisque was equally delicious and warmed you from the inside out! Unfortunately I cannot recall anyone by name from the hotel at this point but we enjoyed our stay in Tokyo. Tips - there is a market and post office on the main floor at the hotel where you can stock up on refreshments and snacks, as well as ship out any souvenirs and extra purchases you may have made on the trip in order to avoid the extra baggage fees.

I stayed here for one night and it was very good. I walked from Shinagawa station which is a little bit of a trek as there are a number of main roads and rail tracks to cross. It's definitely better to take a taxi. Also coming in from the park area there's no quick way in to the hotel and the signposting could be improved.Reception is tucked away behind the cafe/bar area which isn't great when you first walk in to try and find it.Check in was fast and efficient. Staff friendly and helpful.Room reasonably sized, clean and all usual facilities expected from a hotel of this class.Breakfast was straight forward and catered for most appetites and tastes but I didn't see much in the way of fruit yogurts and my omelette was slightly under cooked and lacked a little flavour.I'd definitely consider staying again.

This is a typical Asian Marriott hotel. It would have received 5 STARS but for few key areas that is fell short of (a) the executive lounge is ordinary, not large enough, on the lobby level and seems to be somewhat crowded (b) they charge money for using Jacuzzi and Sauna - this really ticked me off - which 5 STAR hotel charges money for using Jacuzzi and Sauna after paying > $300/night (c) the entrance lobby is not impressive and befitting what one would expect from Marriott.On the positive side. This hotel has great service - from Concierge to Front desk to Bell men, all are very good. The breakfast lounge is also very good and they make fresh smoothies which is worth trying. The hotel also has a complimentary shuttle to Shinagawa station which runs every few minutes in the morning hours and then slows down to every 20 minutes during the day hours.Shinagawa station is a walking distance but you can take Hotel shuttle both ways if you are tired or if the weather is inclement. The Concierge is quite knowledgeable but the bell desk is somewhat slow and not sharp.Again, would have received 5 STARS but it fell short of key areas listed above, and I certainly would not be generous to overlook these especially I paid > $300/night for this hotel.

The hotel is situated within a short walk to the shinigawa rail station, so, the location is convenient. The staff is very friendly and helpful. The hotel has a very good breakfast selection with cereal, fruit, and hot items including American and Asian food.

On my way to Singapore I stayed overnight at the Tokyo Marriott near the city airport. A quick taxi run and a very quick check-in found me in a perfect location to sleep off my 12 hour flight. After an restful sleep, I enjoyed a wonderful breakfast before checkout. I know you can't say much about staying a single night, but this is a Marriott! Adding to this was the world class Japanese hospitality which still remains at the top of my list. For those of us that travel the world for a living, you can't go wrong with this fine state of the art hotel when in Tokyo.RegardsMike

This hotel is one of Marriott's best. The service is above and beyond anywhere else I've ever been. The rooms are super comfortable and quiet. The shower is awesome and we were on the 22nd floor. The hotel is conveniently located to Shinagawa Station. And. There are shops in walking distance.

I stayed at the Marriott for a short 3 night stay while in Tokyo for work. I picked this hotel due to its location which is close to my companies office and the fact that this seems to be a business hotel instead of a tour group hotel like some hotels I have stayed at nearby. The room was very comfortable and was just what I was wanting for a stay away from home. The breakfast restaurant in the morning was busy with business travelers so you need to ensure you give yourself time. The buffet was just ok, there was a lot of cold food like the bacon (every morning I was there) and having to order eggs even just scrambled caused a very long wait. I think the breakfasts can be improved by keeping the food under lights or something. The gym is very large but full of equipment that must be 20 years old, this needs an urgent upgrade. You have to pay separate to use the gym which only happens in Japan, I find it an inconvenience and strange. All up a nice hotel at an acceptable rate and I would stay here again.

This hotel is truly beautiful and the rooms couldn't be more comfortable, the bathroom nicer than words can describe, but it's location isn't great. Getting around to see other areas of Tokyo is going to take some considerable leg work.

The hotel is situated on the south side of Tokyo, about 15 minutes walk from Shinagawa station. From there it is easy to get anywhere.our room was big enough though not large and very quiet. WiFi was great. We did not have the breakfast included but got our modest breakfast from the FamilyMart downstairs.The service was friendly and efficient. Downstairs there is a big and very lobby with too loud music for a pleasant stay. Of course a hotel like this in Tokyo is not cheap but it offered good value for money.

The hotel itself is very nice. Our room was large compared to most hotels that we have experienced in Japan. The breakfast buffet was fine -- not the largest we have seen but adequate with good service. I can't comment on the cost as breakfast was included in our room charge. We also had access to the executive lounge. We arrived relatively late in the day and there was very little food, just a few snacks. That caused me to give a Very Good rather than an Excellent rating. If you don't plan to use the lounge, I think it is excellent. There is not a lot to do in the Shinagawa neighborhood but the railroad station has excellent connections. We did not use the free shuttle to the station as it is an easy 10-15 minute walk.

Beautiful hotel. Shuttle bus runs very regularly to Shinagawa station which takes about 5 minutes of 15-20 minutes to walk. Great location to explore Tokyo. Great exec lounge for Marriott Reward Members

To me it is kinda disappointed. Nothing really special about this hotel. The facility is just like any other hotel, the service as well is not amazing. The location is a bit hard to get. Need to take shuttle or need to walk to the nearest station. Would I come and pay $250 a night for this hotel. Probably not. I think there are many better hotel with less price than this one

The hotel has a nice ambience and walking distance to Shinagawa station and also provides shuttle services. The rooms are big and comfortable with nice bathrooms. The service was good. The breakfast buffet has a wide spread of options.

First, the negatives: our room was small (but maybe typical by Tokyo standards) and the Club Lounge was rather uninviting (first floor of the hotel, just near the lobby lounge, and internal to the building so no windows).The rest is all positive!Excellent location near the Sinagawa station, convenient for taking the JR Line, Shinkansen bullet trains, and many other train lines. Super clean and with all the amenities you'd need. Nice grounds behind the hotel with waterfall and "forest". Convenient shuttle bus service between hotel and Shinagawa (but reduced service hours on the weekends and any public holidays).We woke late most days so decided to get breakfast in nearby restaurants and coffee shops, but we did enjoy a late breakfast at the hotel lobby lounge area on our last day. Service is impeccable and consistent with many other establishments we visited in Japan.If you're looking for a full-service Marriott, highly recommend this one.

This is a beautiful property and located minutes from the train. The experience starts as you drive up to the Tokyo Marriott. I was met as I entered the hotel by one of the hotel staff. The front desk is located in the back. To get there you walk around a beatific restaurant which is the center piece of the building, once to the front desk it was realized that I am a Gold Elite member and was ushered off the the Membership Desk. The attention at the membership desk was wonderful, you sat and relaxed as the hotel rewards policies and special services. The room was love,y with a beautiful views. The room was comfortable and the bed to die for. The members lounge was delightful with delicious treats. Membership breakfast was served in the hotel. I had a 6:00 pm to Korea and took advantage of their 2:00 pm check out time. I hope I return soon!

My husband and I arrived at 1am Tokyo local time after a tiresome West Coast non-stop flight. Finding the reception was a little tricky from the train station as there is a massive garden wrapping the building. Make sure you print a map from the train to the hotel reception/front desk.We were checked in quickly enough by English speaking staff. However to our dismay, despite requesting a non-smoking room, the room assigned to us smelled of cigarette smoke. We immediately requested a change and the hotel front desk complied which we were grateful for.After that, no hiccups at all. The first class breakfast served in the lobby each morning is not one to miss. Everything from coffee to the English breakfast tea, salads, seafood, continental goodies are a royal spread. The servers, as expected in Asia, are trained very well and look after you so well, compared with Marriott in any other region.The hotel is walking distance to residential neighborhoods so you can either use the fantastic zen garden around the hotel or the jog in the neighborhoods. The train station is a 20 minute walk away or make use of the hotel shuttle that runs every 30 minutes too. Make sure to ask for a timetable at the front desk as when you're returning late night, you'd like to know if a shuttle is available to take you back from the train station.As is standard in Japan, vending machines are at the corner of every street for hot and cold beverages. Restaurants and food centers are within 15 minute walking distance. Coffee shops are available within 10 minute distance too.We stayed for 5 nights in this first class hotel which is fairly central to all Tokyo destinations. I highly recommend it for couples, families and friends.

After trying many business hotels in Tokyo, I have to say this one is my favourite. Close to Shinagawa station that leads the way to hundreds of offices but also many trains to touristic places. The quality of Marriot hotels is even more impressive since the staff has that Japanese style of being polite and helpful. If you have the budget, stay here, specially if you fly from/to haneda airport.

New, nice, modern hotel that meets and exceeds Marriott standards. Great breakfasts, with a nice park outside property.Expensive, but expected for Tokyo. Very nice facilities and rooms are great. Only negative, compared to others in Shinagawa, is the location. It's a good 10-15 minute walk to/from the train station. All uphill to the hotel, which is problematic with suitcases. All restaurants are equally as far away, but you don't really stay in Shinagawa for the food/nightlife, although it is getting better.Even with this, still choose this hotel over others. Shinagawa is very centrally located and this hotel is very nice.

Was given a 'room with a view' but jet lagged like usual I couldn't enjoy it (it's of the docks.....) and on top of that the train runs in front there and it's not noisy but when you're trying to sleep in the day it's annoying. It doesn't run at night (when I was awake anyway)...the breakie is really fantastic. Excellent staff all over from bell hops to waiters. Nice lounge with cool snacks like m and m's and mini cookies ..not such a great dinner selection but afternoon tea was nice! Downside for a perpetually jetlagged biz traveller...gym isn't open at night - it's a good gym, not world class or anything but well equipped apart from the free weights stand as you need a girls hand to put the weights back without pinching your skin and they oooonly just fit in the rack...! Also the floor is sprung wood so running on the machine sounds terrible and you have to geeeently put the weights down before you squeeze them back in the rack. The pool is suuuuper - about 15usd extra but worth it if you like lap swimming. Lounge closes at midnight till 6am....Not far to the train station, overland to shinjuku in 20 mins. A great, spotlessly clean hotel with great staff. 24 hour gym and lounge would make it a 5+ star hotel in my view.

After reading the hotel reviews for Tokyo, I decided to stay in Shinagawa at the Tokyo Marriott. I took the train from the NRT airport and walked a short 3 blocks to the hotel where I was immediately greeted and walked to the front desk by a smiling gentleman in a nice suit (very professional).I was checked in within 5-7 minutes and given a full explanation of the hotel and its amenities. My room was extremely clean and spacious. I was greeted 10 minutes later with a note from the hotel manager thanking me for choosing his Marriott and a plate of chocolates. (I am a Marriott rewards member). The concierge suite was on the first floor and had outstanding complimentary snacks, appetizers, and a full hot breakfast. Mr. Yukio Saijo was extremely helpful and kind during my stay. He went above and beyond to make his guests feel welcome and pampered. He was professional and always smiled. He made my trip exceptional. Thank you Tokyo Marriott.

A good place to stay at the end of a trip with excellent accommodation and facilities, which you would expect from an international chain. And, with all things Japanese, great service and helpful staff. I wouldn't want to spend my entire holiday here but it was an ideal last night, close to the airport for an early flight.

Usually stay at the Shinagawa Strings which is right by the train station. The Marriott Tokyo is on the other side of the train station. It’s a hike up the hill or a quick taxi ride. The hotel is much more Western – or what you should be used to in a Marriott in the U.S. Has a breakfast buffet that meets most Western palates. The hotel is nice and would recommend from being able to stay. The hotel shares a gym with the building next door. Relatively light on the equipment. Got up early enough before the streets got crowded to go running. Meetings that I needed to attend were on the other side of the train station, but a hotel I would stay at again.

This is my first stay, the hotel is very nice especially the Japanese garden. It is very nice and clam. Meeting facility is great, free wifi and free shuttle bus. The only downside is bus stop opposites Shinagawa station and you must walk across the road to the train station.Hotel 5/5Service/Staff 5/5Restaurant 4/5

It is a fine hotel and I would have gone to five stars but it just was lacking a bit. Good sized guest rooms, fine food and great location in Shinagawa. (I walked to train but they have a frequent bus too.)The Exec Lounge was a bit lower quality than other Marriotts in the region. Variety of food was also limited as were room service hours. Many international flights arrive late in Tokyo and one has to raid the mini bar if hungry after midnight.

the hotel has a very nice rooms, very helpful stuff, and very good breakfast.the hotel is located approx. 1 km far from one of Tokyo main stations (Shimagwa) where several tours start from it.you can also find some shopping centers close to the train station and restaurants.

Hotel was correct in every way. It is difficult to find the check in desk when you go through the front door - you go the right around the restaurant. The temple is a short 10 minute walk and worth the visit. Behind the hotel there are nice peaceful gardens.

Stayed for a delightful 4 day Tokyo experience. The hotel is easy to get to on foot from the station if you don't want to wait for the shuttle. If there is traffic you are likely faster to walk. As platinum members we were checked in at the exec lounge which was very efficient. The lounge is small and unfortunately has no windows so is not a place you would want to spend time out with bar hours in, or within bar hours. Rooms were immaculate and silent, I did not hear noise from others in the building during my stay. The bathrooms are large and the showers excellent, with really hot water which is a winner for us. Service throughout was superb. It was my fathers birthday and he was wished a happy birthday by multiple staff at different points through the stay without a reason to know who he is. Breakfast was superb. Great selection from the buffet and made to order pancakes, waffles, eggs and omelettes. The only down side was that it was not adjacent to a train station or more central. If you are visiting for a short time, you should consider a more central hotel to save time on the travelling, however for our stay it was manageable. Thank you for a great stay!

This Hotel is a little off the main path, which means it much more quiet place. The good news is that they have this wonderful shuttle service which runs between 15 - 20 minutes which takes you to the Shinagawa train station. From the station you can get anywhere in town. The rooms were very nice and extremely clean. Loved the bathroom. They offer a wonderful breakfast . If you are a Elite Gold and above you are able to use the Club Lounge which has fantastic appetizers and snacks almost all day long. I have nothing bad to say about this hotel. Another extremely good note, all the windows are very sound proof and you barely hear any noise from the trains.

It located about 10-15 mins walk from Shinagawa station and the hotel provide free shuttle bus service. Accommodation wise it was just as good as most of Marriott hotels, spacious bedroom and bathroom, nice bed and bed sheets, great selection of breakfast buffet. Though the free shuttle bus was an important service of the hotel (to overcome its location disadvantage) but they did not promote it enough, like we have to ask the staff for it so they let us know such service and gave us the time schedule. Also when we were out on a Thursday which happens to be a holiday in Japan and the shuttle bus provided limited service but no one ever told or warned us about this.

Having flown here from Santa Clara where I stayed at the Santa Clara Marriott I found this one to be better in every respect. Starting with good value, convenient to Shinagawa train station, very good spacious room with a lovely couch in the window, good view, large bathroom, meticulously clean and fresh. The staff have been helpful. There is a lovely garden at the rear. I am not on the railway side of the building so cannot comment on the noise I have seen mentioned in other reviews. Overall a very good experience.

I spent several nights at the hotel for business. Beautiful room, nice bath amenities. The breakfast in the restaurant was awesome. Snacks and drinks in the executive lounge are great as well. The hotel is a 10 minute walk from Shinagawa station (or a 5 min free bust trip), which is on the main line in Tokyo. About 20-30 minutes via train to central city or other hot spots such as Shibuya. Good restaurants within walking distance, too.

Took advantage of a layover in Tokyo on our way back to the states. From the airport we hoped the subway and in 20 minutes we were at the Shinagawa station. The hotel runs a shuttle or a 10 minute walk. Hotel is large with 20+ floors. Staff was very helpful and took good care of is. Breakfast buffet had everything you need to get you started. Airport shuttle runs frequently so no issues getting to the airport.

The hotel is in a quiet place - far from main center, but near train station.even being at the 10th floor you can still hear the sound of the train, not really bothering though. (wonder if we were in the lower level).the room is quite spacious, just dissapointed that when we arrived the toilet was not cleaned which we have reported. However, the clean service the day after was ok. they did re-check. We enjoyed the garden, beautiful. and we were lucky there were still some of autumn colors despite winter season.

We stayed in two rooms - one overlooking the railway - so noise from trains all the time, and the other on the other side which was much quieter. The service was great, the breakfast fantastic, staff friendly, free shuttle to the station convenient, would choose this as a Tokyo base again.

We enjoyed our stay at this Marriott hotel -- good quality and spacious rooms. Like the design and furnishing of the room (nice sofa and table), and toilet/bathroom and the toiletries. Because of its location, you will need to take no-charge (I.e. free) bus to the Shinagawa Station. Both pick-up and drop-off points are conveniently located.

I did struggle a bit whether to stay in another hotel in Shinjuku or Marriott in Shinagawa. Afterall I picked the Marriott as I have read some pretty good feedback from Tripadvisor - and it didn't disappoint me! The rooms were well-equipped and out of my expectations they were very spacious; new and comfortable! Although it's a bit far from the Metro Station - roughly 10 - 15 mins walk, but it was a pretty pleasant walk; and the hotel does offer shuttle buses (every 20 mins) to and from the Metro Station.Generally, I was very pleased and would love to stay in this hotel again!

Spent 6 nights at this excellent property....21-27 Dec. The hotel is located in Shinagawa...we arrived via Narita airport limo bus....direct to front door. This is the easiest option, however, it is also possible to take the Narita Express train to Shinagawa station, but, it's a 10-15 minute walk, slightly uphill, and if you don't know where you're going, could be confusing...The hotel itself is lovely, with a large atrium, large rooms, and a couple of eating options in the hotel...breakfast was excellent, with lots of fresh fruit, and wide array of Japanese and western options. I will note that I am a Marriott Platinum member, so, free breakfast, and access to the Executive Lounge, and WI-FI, and access to Fitness, was complimentary....I had requested a quiet room, not facing the train lines, and enjoyed no noise...the hotel has been completely refurbished, and rebranded a Marriott...decor is modern, everything is clean and comfortable, and staff are outstanding ....Shinagawa station is a main train hub, and you can get anywhere in Tokyo, and fast trains to several places, eg., Nikko, Kyoto, Kamakura....with no problem...JR line and JR Shinkansen are available...I would definitely stay here again...without hesitation...

This hotel is located ~ 15 min by walking or 5 min by Taxi from the train station. Another hotel that located in a quiet place. However, from the hotel if you turn left( opposite direction to the train station) you can find many restaurants and supermarkets. The price of the foods is reasonable to cheap when you compared with other places in Tokyo. As it is located near to train station, you may travel to places like Ginza, Meiji Shrine (明治神宮, Meiji Jingū) easily.

I have stayed in this hotel for more than 10 years (prior to Marriott taking over the property it was a very tired Hotel Laforet), including five times in 2015. Marriott has completely revitalized the facility, with a solid lobby restaurant to complement the existing two Japanese restaurants. All the rooms were redone and are very well appointed. Most importantly, the staff is top-notch, starting with Masiro-san, the conceirge. It is in an quiet and interesting neighborhood near Shinagawa Station, a major train station in Tokyo.

This review is for a stay that we did at Tokyo Marriott in early July, 2015. We flew into Narita and took the NEX train to Shinagawa station. There is a free shuttle bus which we missed since we were looking for a hotel shuttle (bus looks like a regular city bus). Anyhow, we just made the 10-15 min. walk to the hotel. Once inside, we were treated like royalty. Being Marriott Gold, we were taken into a separate check in area (inside Concierge Lounge) and received a nice upgraded room. Room was spacious and bed was very comfortable. Of course, there was the entertaining toilet with so many different options!!! We loved hanging out in the Concierge Lounge with all the delicious food, desserts and alcohol offerings. The morning breakfast spread at the hotel restaurant was also quite good with plenty of selections.The hotel also has a small Japanese garden on the property which was a nice touch. Although the hotel is in a quiet area with not much happening around it, the train station is very convenient and you could go anywhere in the city from there. The hotel staff truly made me feel appreciated as a Marriott Elite member. We absolutely enjoyed our stay at this Marriott and would surely return.

I opted for the Tokyo Marriott for a few nights as my usual hotel was booked solid. It's a bit out of the way in Shinagawa, hidden near the smaller Kita-Shinagawa station. There are shuttles that take you to Shinagawa station which makes it convenient.I was able to take the Airport Limousine Bus direct to the hotel, which made things easy. Rooms are quite nice and the service, as usual in Japan, is very good. I have platinum status to I was offered breakfast downstairs, which included a very nice spread. For the most part, I enjoyed my stay here. Whether it was the room, service, even transportation, it was a pleasure staying here.

A very nice and very quiet hotel but toooo far from the Subway station. They have done a nice job remodeling the former La Foret hotel. There is no passion or emotion (even more than the average Japanese) in the location, staff, or service. Its all good but not very exciting. The front desk is hidden waaaayyy in the back and often is unmanned. The executive lounge is a small window-less room next to the check-in counter. The rooms are spacious and comfortable. They are clean as would be expected in Japan. There is a beautiful and quite expansive Japonesque garden/forest in the back which is wonderful to take a stroll through. You can lose yourself in the city. The hotel does not promote and does a very POOR job letting guests know that it exists. The hotel seems to attract primarily those American business men locked into the Marriott rewards program. In summary it is a very nice quiet boring hotel, 10-15 minute walk to the Shinagawa station which makes it not useful for a business traveler unless you are one that just cabs it everywhere. I should be fair and note that there is a shuttle bus. Oh yes and it is probably one of the best bargains most likely due to the location.

Flew into Narita Airport, bought a round trip ticket for the N'EX train at the JR Travel Center and got off at Shinagawa Station. Train took about an hour. Once at the station: Take the Central Gate West Exit - Takanawa and go left once out to the street. The hotel is a 10-15min walk up the hill or a short taxi ride. The hotel has a shuttle, however I did not know where to get it or the schedule. (Never did use it as the walk was easy.)I received assistance at the front door w/ my luggage and was walked to the Concierge Lounge for a friendly check-in. I stayed in room 2009. Very well appointed large room. The internet was fast (tested 20M up & down). The Concierge Lounge provided evening snacks and beverages. Breakfast was in the lobby area restaurant/lounge. Excellent buffet.There is a convenience store one level down off the lobby heading towards the street which has an ATM.Everyone was very helpful and courteous. Housekeeping, Food & Beverage, Concierge Lounge and the Front Door Staffs were excellent.The Shinagawa Train Station is a very convenient hub of numerous train and subway lines with access to anywhere in the Tokyo area. I will stay here again.

Tokyo Marriott Hotel is located in Shingawa prefecture. It is close to the JR Shinagawa Station, and other form of transportation! The staff are very courteous! Most have knowledge of the English language! They were very helpful in informing us the best route to take for our "family expeditions/adventures!" I highly recommend the place, and would definitely stay with them again, if given the chance!

I like this Hotel - unlike many other Hotels in Tokyo, the interiors are really contemporary, nicely designed. Rooms size is good, you will heave enough space, in particular bathrooms are spacious. Breakfast buffet offers everything you need, also coffee for take-away.

I was able to get this hotel for only 180,000 YEN per night (~$150), and I still cannot believe such a nice room was available at some a reasonable rate in a city like Tokyo. The room's furnishings and bathroom were all updated.Sleep quality was very good. i could hear no noise outside my news, and the bedding was excellent. The room's temperature controls worked perfectly too.The hotel employees were very service-oriented even considering the high standards that exist throughout Japan. The free breakfast I got with my Platinum status was very nice.Finally, it was a short $40 cab ride from Haneda Airport and a short 15 minute walk to my office. This is my hotel of choice when staying in Tokyo.

This is a nice hotel with rooms that are bigger than a standard business hotel in Japan. The service is what you would expect from a Marriott in Japan. Friendly and efficient. The executive lounge is nice but; in a bit of a strange location. It is situated next to the reception area so there are no views and in fact, no windows. The only thing I found a bit odd was the lack of any light switches near to the main door of the room. When arriving into a dark room, you have to fumble about a bit to turn on a light. At least this was the case in my room.I would recommend this hotel.

This hotel is nice. The rooms are spacious and clean. The work space in the room is a bit limited but doable for a short stay. Staff are very pleasant. The executive lunge is small and this is a problem in the evening because there isn't enough space to accommodate all guests.

Honestly i am kind of disaappointed with the service and facilities of tokyo mariot hotelI booked this place in celebration for my husband's 50th BdayFirst i was dissapointed that no proper instructions were given to me about check in and shuttle bus to the hotel that i have to take a taxi thereAlso not happy that you have to charge for swimming pool and gym???? This is the most ridiculous things i have heard for Marriot property. When i checked in, i mentioned it is my husband's bday, what will the staff do for a special occassion and his response is "Happy birthday". Thats all?!!!We went into the room and saw a mini display of macaroons and candies. That was 15th Nov when we checked in, hubby's bday is recorded on 17th Nov. Sadly nothing was done for 17 Nov. No extra mile. This is disappointing. Is it becoz its not in the japanese culture to do something for guests?? This was in fact the perfect opportunity to do so but failed. Bed was also kind of hardStaffs were cold, not warm and very robotic. Again, not expected of a marriot service level received from marriot staff. The only thing we are thank full for is that the hotel was willing to keep our luggage for a few days while we are away to other cities and we came back to recieve the luggage again. Thank you for that. I think this is the saviour bit. I am usually very loyal to your brand, am also a marriot vacation club member for few years already but after this stay, am really questioning if this would be the standard we would receive for future marriot?

After reading some less than positive reviews of this hotel I was beginning to have doubts.Having stayed here now for the third day I'm delighted. Clean and fresh, good food and drink, respectful and helpful staff.Arrived late after the Exec Lounge had closed. No problem. Mixed nuts and beers in the Lobby Lounge at no charge up to 11.30pm,An easy 10 minute walk to Shinagawa Station with lots of eating options around that location. I'll be back.

Well, this hotel has beds and an executive lounge. It is close to Shinagawa station, but I would not recommend walking (we did). Just grab a taxi for 600 yen. Finding the entrance as a pedestrian is a little confusing, and the hotel tower itself is in the middle of a large complex. No upgrade was offered or available on request for Platinum member (there were many larger rooms available for reservation). The room was quiet, and small. There is an executive lounge on the ground floor that is more like a cafeteria. It gets the job done.The breakfast buffet was nice, with a good eggs station. On a two week trip we stayed at some really neat properties in Japan, including a number of western chain branded hotels, and this was the worst. Not bad, just uninteresting and zero soul.

I stayed in three hotels in my two weeks trip. Marriott is the best, compare to the other two hotels in similar price range. Room is newly refreshed. Free shuttle bus to Shinagawa station, which is a major transit hub in Tokyo.

Spent a few days here while on business in Tokyo. As far as Marriotts in Asia go, this hotel was just okay. The rooms were a little small as are most rooms in Japan, but they were extremely clean. I was in a room near the elevator so it was a little noisy. There was also not much of a view as there is little to see outside. The breakfast buffet was really good having many helpful options. As a platinum member it was included in my rate, but it would otherwise of have been pretty expensive. The Executive Lounge was pretty good and quiet, which I alway like when doing business travel.

Rooms recently refreshed, entrance and hallways clean, lacks character. The hotel is a business hotel somewhat stuck away from the action excepting perhaps the .5Km stroll down to the area around Shinagawa station. Lots of restaurants and beer, don't expect Shinjuku or Roppongi like surroundings in any case. Restaurants ok with the requisite sushi bar (although selection was very narrow.) Lobby bar in evening (dead) turned into the breakfast area in the morning; for the life of me I can't see what the raves are about the breakfast. Standard American omelets, fruit and breads with Japanese savory options; very stander fare. Stay here again, I'm a high level Marriotts point person but would prefer the aforementioned Shinjuku, Ginza, or Roppongi just for someplace to walk, something to see.

We like to take this review opportunity to express our appreciation towards the care we received during our week long stay.From the start of our checking in my wife and I were lucky to be taken care of by Mr. Jongsung Park of executive lounge concierge. He is very professional, efficient and very helpful to every of our requests. Over the years I have found out that the best asset of Marriott is their employees. They make all the differences when you are tired and away from home. For our trip Mr. Park has demonstrated the impeccable service to us are genuine and make our entire trip a very very enjoyable one. In addition, the hotel room is of good size, functional, very clean, and modern. The bed is very comfortable and the air conditioner is quite and effective. In summary, Marriott should be very proud of their employees and we'll be happy to be their loyal customer for years to come.

Great hotel. Clean and the rooms are decent size and well equipped. The hotel is about a 10 minute walk from the Shinigawa Train Station and is easy to navigate - that is, there are sidewalks/etc. The hotel is a bit difficult to find once you reach the top of the hill, so just be patient and look around for the signs. The hotel has bars and restaurants (as any Westerner would expect). I would stay here again.

Great location with free shuttle service to the Shinagawa train station. Wonderful breakfasts are included and have everything one comes to expect of a Marriott. Rooms are large and loaded with amenities. Service is excellent. It is just what you expect of a Marriott. Plenty of the familiar and plenty of opportunities to experience the unfamiliar. It is a home away from home.

We stayed at this hotel for a business meeting that was being held in the hotel. The rooms were quite spacious by Japanese standards, and had all the usual Marriott amenities in the room. As is common in Japan, the bathroom had a fancy toilet with heated seat and bidet. Robes and slippers are included in the room as well, but you get one bath towel per person and you must ask if you need another one. The mattress on the king bed we had was very firm, a little too hard for my comfort.The breakfast buffet which is included was wonderful, with a huge variety of fresh fruits and vegetables, breads, sweet rolls, juices, and traditional Japanese fare including fresh fish. In addition, one could order eggs, waffles, pancakes, breakfast meats all cooked to order and brought to your table. The staff was friendly and helpful. If one couldn't answer a question, he would find someone who could.The fitness center was practically empty whenever I went there in the morning. The one elliptical trainer they had (my usual machine of choice), was rusty and made a loud noise when I tried to use it, so I switched to a stationary bike which was very new looking. They also had Nautilus style machines but not sure what the brand was. There were signs all over about not wearing outdoor shoes in the gym, but I wore mine from my room and no one questioned me. I'm not sure what that was about. The attendants working in the gym had very little ability with English to explain how anything worked.The free bus to the subway station was a great convenience, although it was not very far to walk if you were just going sight-seeing.I do not think that the staff expected tips as we tried to tip and it was refused.

Lovely hotel, provides free shuttle to the Shinagawa station, room was comfortable and there are extra blankets that can also be used as cushions near the elevators. We had a hard time finding it on foot from the station, I recommend a taxi for your first time. However, unlike Japan traditions, they do expect tips for their services and the breakfast buffet was way overpriced!!! The staff was extremely friendly and courteous. There is a Family Mart downstairs for a quick snack and refreshments to take with you or to the room. Although I didn't stay there, the Prince Hotel lobby area was nice and it was right by the station. Checking that option for the next trip.

The hotel is a high quality business hotel, typical of Marriott's in Asia. The rooms are spacious for Japan and the breakfast is outstanding -- one of the best in a hotel ever. The gym is also first class, as it is really a facility for members, not just for the hotel. The major problem is the location. You can walk to the subway station, but it is not a short walk, say about 15 minutes uphill on the way back. There is a shuttle bus, but it is hard to find for the trip back. Shinagawa itself is not in the center of things, and the subway is the main means for getting to the major Tokyo sights.

I travel WW mostly Asia non stop and stay in the Shinagawa area avg 2 nights every 4 weeks. I wanted to stay at the Intercontinential Strings which is clean, modern, efficient and has a nice gym. Marriott is dirty, the general area is old fashioned and charmless, the rooms have a very poor air quality and are not clean, with the exception of the bathroom, the rooms are strange in design and utilize the space very poorly, breakfast is not included, and slightly more expensive than the excellent strings. The gym is not a gym for the hotel, and charge a horrible entry fee. The hotel is walking distance from the shinagawa station, but not that close. There are at least 2 MUCH better alternatives around - and a number of equal places I am sure for half the price. Firstly on the same or with a corp discount probably cheaper - the Shinagawa Strings is super nice and modern, clean air, nice gym. It is right on top of the station. The annex tower of the prince shinagawa is much better in terms of view, and is almost half the price, and is nice and clean. This Marriott is a dump, which should go the extra mile in terms of freebees and service to compensate for it's poor location, design, air quality etc, but does not try to compensate on the service side, and deserves the poor ratings myself and others are dishing out and then some. I don't stay often in Marriott but when I have it has been very significantly better than this one.

The Tokyo Shinagawa Marriott is near (but not attached to) Shinagawa station, and some of the reviews have alluded to this. Overall, this is a nice Marriott, about what one would expect in terms of a Marriott located in Asia. If you are looking for a hotel that is attached to Shinagawa station, I would recommend the Intercontinental Strings.Getting here: I find that the best way to get to Shinagawa station is to take the Narita Express from the Narita Airport which is a single stop before arriving at Shinagawa Station. The cost is about ¥3,190 but you can buy a round trip if you have a foreign passport and expect to return within 30 days for ¥4,000 – a bargain! The train has a single stop prior to arrival in Shinagawa station and takes approximately 1 hour for the journey. Compared to a taxi (I have done this and would NEVER recommend it unless you are made of money) or the Bus (also highly recommended, but it can be caught in traffic) I prefer the Narita Express. Exit the station at the Takanawa Exit (going AWAY from the Konan entrance) and take a left on the main street when you see the McDonalds and Wings department store. Walk about 5 minutes up the street, crossing to the right at the hill, and keeping the Marriott sign in your line of sight for an additional 5 minutes. It takes less than 10 minutes if you walk fairly quickly, and is a nice walk. As a side note, the grocery store in the basement of Wings is a great place to pick up food, drinks, supplies and I use it for sushi on the run. There is a food court in the basement as well that is reasonably priced. Of course, Shinagawa station has a large number of food courts and places to buy drinks. The Marriott is a “standard” Marriott in terms of rooms. It is more modern than the U.S. centric Marriott’s – what I liked about it was the air conditioning was cold if you set it lower, and the drapes kept the light out for those of us with jet lag. The Gold/Platinum executive lounge is on the first floor next to check in (not common) and you will receive coupons to eat breakfast in the main restaurant if you have the Gold/Platinum status. Overall, this is a nice hotel, but is a bit more out of the way with respect to Shinagawa Station. I have also stayed at the Prince hotel (I like the Marriott better) and the Intercontinental Strings located at the station (similar quality, and better location for transportation). If you don’t care about points, and the price is the same, I think the Intercontinental Strings is a better choice. Regarding the distance from the Marriott to the Station, I found it to be a pleasant walk, uphill to the hotel, downhill to the Station – a good brisk 10 minutes in the morning or evening was a pleasant walk and very straightforward.

Stayed here for two days. I arrived on a Thursday evening and requested the transportation service from Narita to the hotel. Expensive (¥45,000) but flawless. So on my departure day I called, in the early morning, to book the return to Narita for 1:00PM. I was assured, no problem, go to hell desk after 12:50. Well, it is a problem. The car wasn't available and they tried to put me in a taxi (at ¥30,000). It's now 1:21PM and in spite of assurances and promises over the last 20 minutes... No sign of the taxi.Incompetent.

Located a it outside the main hotel zone (i.e. not right in front of Shinagawa station) this hotel is very well designed, as usual service is impeccable. ithin walking distance of Shinagawa and Gotenda stations. I had problems with the Wifi (too slow) they immediately sent someone and gave me a router and a cable. Breakfast is fantastic but way too expensive (about 30 euros) though you can get it chepaer by asking vouchers at the front desk (a strange system).

Large rooms with very large bathroom. Clean and quiet. High standard, but we were disappointed that breakfast was not included, except for one person in our group who had stayed there several times before. Good location 10 minutes walking distance from Shinagawa station.

I LOVE this hotel. I stayed at this hotel for a week at the end of Sep 2015 and early Oct 2015. The hotel was beautiful - excellent rooms, excellent service, great location, amazing Japanese garden attached to hotel, very close to the train station, easy to access from NRT airport ... I can't wait to go back to this hotel.

From the moment we stepped in the front door it was obvious the employees here are truly committted to making our (your) stay memorable. The staff is very professional, concerned for your well being and willing do whatever they can to make it happen. We travel alot, every hotel is brick and morter. What makes the best stand out is the people. When travel brings us back to Japan this Marriott will be our 1st choice to stay.

This is our first time staying in the Shinagawa area. There is nothing around the hotel. You need to take the shuttle bus to JR Shinagawa station to see some departments stores and food choices. There is a nice garden across the hotel though. We like to walk and explore so Ginza, Shibuya and Shinjuku areas will better suit usHaving said that, the service here is excellent. Upon arriving, someone greeted us and asked for our names and escorted us to the front desk, about 3 mins away. She radioed ahead and our documents were waiting for us when we got there, as well as some packages sent to us in advance by postThe rooms are spacious, bathroom is spacious but of course typical of Marriotts, have no character. Everything worked and internet was fast. The lobby restaurant was fast and efficient and food was decent

Unless you have business within the vicinity, this hotel is not convenient. Although there is shuttle bus that takes you to the nearest station, in this case, Shinagawa Station on the JR Yamanote Line, it is still inconvenient especially when you miss the bus and have to wait a while for the next one that it is best to just take a cab. However, the room was very comfortable. If you can ignore the office building nearby, the view from the room is interesting because you can see the small residential homes surrounded by office buildings. Having the end room we also had views of the rail and highway but no audible noise emanating from them. The room provided nice Thann toiletries and the usual hot pot and tea and coffee packets. We had access to the executive lounge where drinks and snacks were provided. Service was okay not the usual Japanese omotenashi I am accustomed to from other 5 star hotels. When we came to check in at the lounge, I thought the individual there, Yena Ji, was rude by Japanese standards. The first thing she asked was for our passports. Not even a "how are you" or "welcome" in Japanese. However, the lounge offered delicious snacks and an adequate variety of drinks.

They will look at your passport and your face and treat you accordlingly. As a platinum premier member who spends 200 nights a year with Marriott I felt undervalued by this hotel. Asked for a room upgrade at the checkin and the respnse was a dry "we have given you a king size bed"... yes this is how they define upgrade for non western looking people at this hotel.. at the lounge I asked for a printer and the response was "we do not have".. I looked after and there was one right in the lounge.. but juste for wester guests I guess.. breakfast is average also.. overall they made me feel like I did not deserve to be platinum and that they had to deal with it..

This a very good Marriott hotel and this is the third stay and it continues to set a high standard. It has a good Executive Lounge and an excellent breakfast. The staff are friendly and courteous. It has an excellent garden area and is a short walk from Shinagawa Station which provides access to down town Tokyo via the Yamanote line.

As the Exodus Tours allocated Hotel, this turned out better than anticipated. Location seemed an issue...with a 20 minute walk from the station...however, the free bus either way was door to door Hotel to Shinigawa Station. Brilliant.Felt more a Business Hotel, however the staff were very helpful and personable. Room 306 wasn't huge, bathroom was more roomy, but had all we needed. Bed was comfy, room and corridors were very quiet. Fittings were to normal Marriott standard.Drinks, coffees etc in the Lobby were on the pricey side....but the setting was lovely, nice chairs and ambience. Being the start of Cherry Blossom season, the outdoor trees were lit beautifully...it was spectacular.Being aware of the transport...yes, would stay here again if the need arose.

The property is modern and luxurious. There are so many Americans staying here -- it's like being in Detroit. The breakfast buffet is excellent. Service at the front desk and valet is very slow (could be cultural). The major disappointment: THE ROOMS ARE TINY!! There is a Marriott Autograph in Tokyo (see my review). Stay there instead. It's better.

There is just something about Marriotts. I stay at a lot of business (and boutique) hotels, and I have to give to Marriotts - they are consistent - but like McDonald's that is not only a good thing, at least for me. You know you can find a clean bathroom and a Big Mac at McDonanld's, and similarly at Marriott you will find a clean room, decent food and little-to-no soul. To give an example - this place has a perfectly good grill downstairs - but the ambience is some strange Hawaiian theme. It would have been one thing had they done this with a bit of irony, or perhaps an 'Endless Summer' motif - but no, in true Marriott spirit they are trying to pull off a Hawaiian theme with all seriousness.... I can't complain that much, the staff are friendly, things are clean (as said) - it was just very boring and tomorrow I move to the Conrad... Oh, and the WiFi is a disaster...hotel really needs to fix this..

Stayed here during summer trip in Japan. Rooms are nice and up to date. It's not the latest Marriott design but very clean and quiet. Service good and executive lounge is good as well. Breakfast buffet offers a lot but only lasts until 10am but after that it's à la carte (which is also free for gold and up members) until noon. Only point: wifi signal in the rooms at edge of the building can be weak so that part of the room is not covered. Told them and they are working on it.

The Tokyo Marriott rooms were modern and reflect the newly renovated style and design of Marriott. However, the Marriott Tokyo does not share the opulence of the Marriott Osaka, nor the convenience of the Marriott Nagoya. They do offer a bus which shuttles passengers to and from Shingawa, which is also a JR Rail hub and a station on the Narita N’EX line, which is very convenient. For Elite members, the breakfast service is offered by coupon to the main breakfast buffet – which is nice, but only two coupons were allotted per night. The executive lounge has service throughout the day, but is smaller and has no view to speak-of, unlike the Marriott Osaka and Nagoya. I found the service at the Tokyo Marriott to be a little “cool” compared to the other properties on our Japan visit, but generally they stay was comfortable and pleasant.The Tokyo Marriott is located within a 10 minute walk of Shingawa station. For those travelling with JR Rail passes, this is extremely convenient as it is served by the JR Yamanote line which allows travel with the JR Rail pass. There is a free bus that goes between Shingawa and the Marriott that runs every 20 minutes, and is located street-side (the shelter does contain a sign for the Marriot, and this is a city-bus not a typical hotel shuttle).

Located near Shinagawa Station - you can see the Shinkansen train go by regularly from your room window. Not very far from the business district. Good breakfast, slow internet and the fitness centre does not open before 7am.Try it..and enjoy the sun downers at the lobby with Hawaiian Hula dance.

From our point of view very good location as we flew in through Haneda and the transfer by taxis took us 20 minutes with a cost of around 45€. In addition our office are in the same complex of buildings so that we were able to have the whole day air condition which was really necessary as Tokyo was boiling hot with a lot humidity.The staff is very friendly. The rooms are very clean and wide. Breakfast was good.If you would like to get around in Tokyo, Shinagawa Station is only 10 minutes away. From there you could get trains to almost anywhere in Tokyo.

Very good location though you would need the shuttle to the main train station.As being a very centeral station, one will fine fast connections all over the country.This should be no issue as it is running every 20 min.Warm and informative staff.Wide rooms, well equipped and clean.Quality breakfast and dinner.Good buisness solution.Look for the Air port shuttle and leave out the expensive taxi rates.

We stayed at the Tokyo Marriott Hotel for 2 nights in late July. Our experience was excellent. The staff was very friendly and almost everyone spoke good English. No need to worry about that if you're concerned about the language barrier. They were also good about allowing us to speak Japanese as much as we could and didn't just assume we only spoke English. Our room was huge and on the 20th floor with views of Tokyo Bay, the shinkansen train station and (if you looked carefully) the Rainbow Bridge. The breakfast was excellent with lots of western and Japanese choices on the buffet along with made-to-order eggs, waffles and "pancakes". We couldn't even keep up with the offers of refills on our coffee. We also enjoyed using the late night drink coupon in the lobby bar. As the room was booked by our Japanese friends, I'm not sure if that is included for everyone or not. It was a great way to end our hot days of sightseeing. I also enjoyed getting a copy of the Japan Times at my door each morning.There is a complimentary city bus-type shuttle from Shinagawa station that will take you to the hotel/office complex several times an hour. Honestly I was expecting something a little more luxurious at this price point than a city bus but it got us where we needed to go. It does stop running fairly early (around 9pm?). If you don't want to bother with the shuttle, the charge for a taxi to the hotel from Shinagawa station is within the basic fare of 730 yen and takes about 5 minutes. It may have even fallen within the "short fare" category at 560 yen. The Airport Limousine Bus stops at this hotel making it a seemless connection to/from Narita and Haneda airports. It was nice not to lug bags on and off the subway or train! There were just a couple minor annoyances to keep in mind:1. Wi-Fi is not included in the room charge. I know this is a Marriott "thing" and kind of standard at big dollar, corporate hotels but it is annoying to not automatically have wi-fi when the room costs so much! As our friends were treating us to the hotel stay, I did not want to run up their bill by tacking on wi-fi charges. It became difficult to keep up on communication and checking schedules without it. We stayed at hotels a third of this price during our trip where wi-fi was complimentary. 2. There is no public place to print an airline boarding pass. When I asked at the desk, I was told to email my boarding pass to the front desk and they would print it. As I did not have wi-fi (see above), this was impossible. Finally after much discussion and phone calls, I was led into the executive center where I was allowed to use the computer to check in and print my passes myself. Many thanks to the staff of the Tokyo Marriott for a very pleasant stay!

Check in Marriott for 4 days my wife being a gold club member has so many advantages. Arrived late in the afternoon was immediately assisted and invited as in the club lounge while waiting for our room to be ready as we requested an extra bed for my daughter. Only Marriott that offered night cap for elite members, been to other Marriott in Europe, South America and North America and other parts of Asia. Staff very helpful. Food was good except for the omelette that we have requested in the morning during breakfast. The European guy who made the omelette did not do a good job as the omelette was soggy, and on top of that my wife has to stand up to follow up on the Omellette as they misplace the order the firt time. The hotel was very clean. Very accesible to Shinigawa train station

OK, Tokyo is not a cheap city to do business in, so if you are going to spend top dollar for accommodations, this is a solid choice. Spacious hotel, huge flowing lobby and the rooms are surprisingly quite large. The service is top notch and very English friendly. The room decor is almost minimalist but does not go as far as taking away those comforts we know and love about Marriott. Only downside is the gym for the hotel does not open until 7AM, pretty tough to sneak in a workout before that 9 AM meeting.

They have great and very helpful staff. Nice rooms and great small forest park in a luxurious residential area. I have lost my shopping bags in the train and the staff has helped me call JR 3 times trying to locate my lost stuff. Although they were never found, the staff, Mr. Mori, has been so helpful and patient to help me throughout the process. I truly appreciate their effort and dedication to guests. Although not located next to train station, it offers frequent free shuttle bus and still a walking distance to Shinagawa station.

Our family is a Marriott hotel fan. This one in Shinagawa is not a walking distance to shopping centers but they have a free shuttle every 30 mins going to the train stations. The Family Mart just below the hotel premises is an extra treat for my children. They have a park with cherry blossom trees where you can do your morning walk and savor the good spring weather.

I had to stay here for 4 days, and I can confirm the top level in service and quality.Only one point was bad - you pay more for a tea then a beer - prices are too high.The Breakfast was perfect. There is a little supermarket in the front downstairs you will find reliable food and drinks.

We picked the Marriott for our last night in Tokyo, near the Shinagawa train station where we would catch our train the next day for the airport. The large room and bath were quite comfortable. As a Marriott rewards member, the Wifi was free. The buffet breakfast was good and offered a wide selection. The free shuttle bus to the train/metro station stopped after 9 pm or so, and we did get a bit lost walking back, but figured our way eventually. The map given to guests could be a bit clearer. The good part of getting lost was that we found some great local restaurants under the tracks on the way for noodle soup.

We really enjoyed staying at the Tokyo Marriott. It was very close to the train station so we were able to walk to it. Very close to lots of shopping and restaurants. The service was really good. We only ate breakfast but that was fantastic as well. Would highly recommend for a family stay.
user_name:
Jessica D
Chicago's North Shore, Illinois

review_body: We can't say enough about the Tokyo Marriott. The staff were very friendly and helpful with suggestions about how to get to the airport (via bus shuttle costing approximately $20 each instead of $150 plus via cab). Tokyo is huge and it takes about 1 1/2 hours to get to Narita Airport. There is a public bus that picks you up complimentary of Marriott to take you to the nearby Shinagawa train/subway station so that you can navigate your way around variousTokyo neighborhoods. It is not difficult to figure out the subway since they have a map in English to the left of the Japanese map in the subway stations, which are very clean. Tokyo is a lovely city with many interesting areas to explore. Also, the hotel can give you a map of the separate neighborhoods and what to explore in each one. The people are friendly and helpful and very respectful of tourists. We would love to go back one day and would definitely stay at the Tokyo Marriott again.

A great experience.Stayed for business for 3 nights. I can’t comment much on location, because it was right near my office and I only traveled back and forth between those two points. So what may be a perfect location for my purposes, may not be great for anyone else.Unlike some other Tokyo hotels, the rooms at the Marriott are really generously sized. I didn’t feel cramped at all.

This was our second stay at the hotel, this time, for 5 nights.Check-in was rather slow, and despite not having a queue, it still took over 20 minutes.As Marriott Gold members, we got 5 breakfast vouchers and 5 night cap vouchers.We were allocated a Club suite on the 25th floor (room 2501).The room was rather large, but looked more of a junior suite than a suite, with a single bedroom and sitting area in the same space with no actual separation.The living room area had a weird orientation and a counter was located in the middle of the room for no apparent reason.There were way too many doors in the room, and it sort of felt like going through a maze.There was a big balcony outside the room, but due to the fact that it was a single balcony for the entire floor, it was not accessible.The view from the 25th floor was nice, though.The bathroom was large and included a bath tub, a shower, a toilet and 2 sinks.There was an extra toilet for guests just by the entrance to the room.The Club lounge (located next to the reception) was as good as the first time we tried it, but was actually a bit upgraded – the removed the huge cakes and instead brought in plenty of more food in the evening spread.The night cap option was a nice addition – it enabled you to order numerous drinks at the lobby bar after 22:00 and until midnight – free of charge.Breakfast was as brilliant as the first time.Bottom line – a solid 4-star Marriott near Shinagawa. Recommended.

This is the quietest and most elegant hotel I have ever stayed at. I could not hear the air conditioning. The only barely heard outside sounds were the train rails, and someone shutting a door in the early a.m. Bed was wonderfully comfortable.There was a T-Fal hot water pot for tea/coffee with an excellent arrangement of coffees, teas, sugars, and creams to choose from. In room refridge filled($$$$) but with room for your own things.LOVELY arrangement of bathroom shampoos, bath gel, etc. Bed was SO comfy. Towels extremely soft. Staff was beyond courteous.Many spoke good English.Ones who had marginal English were still very courteous and able to assist easily.Hotel restaurant is VERY pricey - 6 ounce glass of wine is $14. BUT, there are many restaurants within a 15 minute walk that are very reasonable. Walking from hotel to Shinigawa Train Station, there is a great noodle restuarant...like "Cheers" ----all employees great everyone who enters!! Great ramen soup bowls at super prices.Walk through train station and look for 82 Ale - it's a great bar with super food. You order at the bar - super service and great prices. We got chicken yakotori, fried chicken, grilled green peppers. Great staff, friendly atmosphere no matter your nationality.

Hotel is in Shinagawa, not in the heart of Tokyo and in a neighborhood that isn't exactly conducive to walking around -- it appears safe, just not particularly interesting or scenic. When I entered the hotel and indicated I was checking in, the bellman asked my name and then sent me down a long hallway to reception. Not sure why he asked my name . . . it's not as if he communicated it to reception.Check-in was quick and my room was ready. The 3 elevators are small and in the back of the hotel -- not exactly what you'd expect -- but were reasonably prompt. The room was decent in size with a bed, settee and round table that doubles as a desk. Furnishings are very modern and look exactly like the website, though the actual room seems smaller than the picture would indicate. Bed was very comfortable. Bathroom has been modernized other than (as others have said), the tub, which really does look 1970s. Bath amenities include almost anything you could want/expect and were replenished twice daily. Shower pressure was excellent. Stayed on a high floor and had no noise issues.Executive Lounge was nice. Not huge so could become crowded but it wasn't when I was there. Plentiful food and beverages with a combination of self-serve and folks who will serve you; this works quite well. Breakfast was quite a spread -- almost anything you could ask for including cooked-to-order eggs and other Western fare as well as Asian items. Service was impeccable. Ate dinner at the Japanese restaurant. Food was excellent and the service very prompt. The menu is a bit limited compared to a US Japanese restaurant in that there are several multi-course meals and then a few a la carte items. It's thus not easy to pick and choose what you want to eat, although you might be able to make special requests (though servers don't speak much English). Prices aren't cheap but there also aren't many options in the local area.There is no pool or fitness center on site, although they provide information on a nearby fitness facility that was free of charge, although it may not be free to every traveler.Overall, this was a perfectly fine hotel and I had no complaints. However, it lacked the special extras to make me give it 5 stars. If returning, I might select a hotel closer to the city center/shopping, etc., but that's a personal preference.

I was living there for 7 days and I only have two words: high quality! Nice staff, clean and big rooms (following the standard of Marriot Hotels) and services extras (concierge, gym...). The location is OK, close to the train station and with a direct Shuttle service from/to Norita AirportGreat option in Tokyo!

We stayed at the Tokyo Marriott for 4 nights in April and were overall very pleased with our stay. Many elements of our stay were 5* and and if it wasn't for the less than perfect sleep I would not hesitate to give 5* overall. Arrival was great (it is a shortish walk from Shinagawa station; there is also a shuttle bus); they called ahead from the entrance and someone was already waiting for us at the executive lounge (which surprisingly is on the ground floor) to check us in. The executive lounge in that sense is a bit awkward and there appears to be limited access checks through the day with folks just walking in. Service in the lounge and offerings through the day were nice; food in the evening seemed decent and plentiful, but we only ate there once. If you have access to the EL you also get free breakfast in their main restaurant which features a nice buffet with Japanese and Western fare.The hotel room was nicely refurbished but very small (no upgrade given :( ) which was o.k. since we weren't planning to stay in the room much at all. What I just can't understand is the window situation; they completely refurbed everything and they are not putting in better windows? The hotel is right above the Tokyo-Osaka Shinkansen line and there is a train pretty much every minute. If you are a light sleeper, this can be a problem. I slept o.k.ish with ear plugs, but it was still disturbing during the night. The other part where they ?? ran out of money ?? was the bathroom where half looked nice/modern and refurbished and the other half with the bathtub looked like the 70s. They must have spent quite a bit of money on redoing all the rooms and it is such a pity that the bathrooms did not get fully upgraded and the windows are not better.At the right price, and we got a pretty good deal, this hotel is great for Tokyo stays especially when you plan on using public transportation and day trips using Japan rail pass. If you are a good sleeper and don't mind some mild to moderate train noise it might actually be perfect. For us it was unfortunately enough to knock one star off the review, but overall still excellent.

We had the most wonderful four nights in Tokyo at this Marriott Hotel. The service and attention to detail was tops. The food, room and location were outstanding and yes the toilets are a kick. It is located in a lovely neighborhood and has it's own Japanese Gardens. When I go back to Tokyo I would love to go back to the same lovely Hotel. By the way the hotel is very new and the concierge is outstanding.

Spent a few days in this nice hotel with a luxurious accommodation during the cherry blossoms season in the month of April. It is ideally located in Shinagawa, just a 5 minute walk from Kita- Shinagawa Train Station and offering a free shuttle ride to Shinagawa Station. The hotel is also very near to the bustling areas of Shibuya and Shinjuku, about 20 minutes away by a train ride.The room has a nice look, a beautiful nighttime view of the city, with a flat screen TV, fridge, tea and coffee bags and nice toiletries.There is also an available high-speed internet access throughout the hotel. Other commendable amenities include express check-in and check-out, free luggage storage and concierge services. After this pleasant and relaxing stay, Im hopeful to be back soon!

Hi allcheck in professionell and fast, room quiet + big + clean, brkfst is super, but only 95% my style - a creamy cheese would be great in the future.To Shinagawa station its a 10 min walk or take the free shuttle bus.around the station there are plenty restos + and Pubs !Unfortunately you have to pay for the gym ;-(Tips: Buy a SUICA Card ("debit card") which helps a lot - you can always pay with your deposit JR line has a direct link to Shinjuku (take platform 2, its 200 YEN)in Shinjku visit the north (in the night) and south (during day) tower of the goverment building (10 min walk from main west exit in Shinjuku) => free view over Tokyo!!Tokyo is great !!wifi is free if you become a member during check in !!CheersSchlampi

Nice variety of buffet spread would make your stay comfortable.
