A good variety of fresh fruit and salad, juices, and both traditional and international touch of choices make other business stay pale in comparison. Good hospitality, comfortable good location, just 10 mins walk from Shinagawa station make it a good choice of hotel for both leisure and business. It is value for money too.

The hotel is located on a hillside close to Shinagawa station. Th station provides fast links to both Haneda and Narita and also to the rest of Tokyo. The hotel provides a free and frequent bus connection between the hotel and the station. The hotel is modern and has recently been renovated to a high standard. The rooms are as big as most European and US hotels and are well furnished and are really excellent. What makes this hotel stand out is the staff - nothing is too much trouble for them and they assist with a smile and make you really welcome. Add to this the truly fantastic breakfast that is available in the hotel restaurant. I have stayed in MANY Marriott hotels over the years in Europe and the US and nothing compares to the welcome and level of service provided here. This is truly hospitality at its best ! Why can't all Marriotts be like this ? I would like to thank all the staff for making my stay so pleasurable.

I stayed at the Tokyo Marriott about 1 year ago and at the time, there needed to be improvements especially in the Executive Reward Members Lounge. I can say that there has been a big improvement in the Staff training, their very professional and friendly. Ms Yena Ji, Ms Maika Aoyama, and Ms Hue Nguyen kept everything well stocked with food and drink and constantly kept the lounge in great order. It makes a big difference when you have stayed over 800 nights in Marriott Hotels like I have and come back to the hotel and see friendly faces and and be able to relax with a good drink and snack. As many people have reviewed the rooms at the Tokyo Marriott are larger than your normal Japan hotel. Their breakfast is outstanding and you won't go away hungry. I really enjoy the free bus that runs between the hotel and Shinagawa Train Station. Taxi's are not cheap in Japan and saves me on average $15.00 dollars a day by just using the free bus. I can tell that the staff is now very well trained and do an excellent job and willing to help you with anything you might need. It's a pleasure to stay here and I will make sure it won't be another year before visiting again.

A large room with a large bathroom and very modern and super spaciousfor Japan standards. Con of the hotel is that it is a far walk from anything! It's a very gorgeous hotel but it definetly would be the most desirable place to stay if you are looking for convinence. Also they say there is a gym and pool facilites but it there isn't. You have to pay to enter which makes no sense at all but it's fine if you dont mind paying. Mainly if you are going there for business this would be the hotel for you. If you are going for vacations and sight seeing, the hotel wouldn't be the most desirable place to stay. For a family with children this is definetely a great place for you. The train station is very close by and has a lot to offer but still you must make it up the hill first. There is a fun sushi place where you can "play" with your food near by.
user_name:
Jessica C
New York City, New York

review_body: Nicely freshened up Marriott where the service is exceptional. Staff very good and always happy to help. Make sure you get to breakfast as it is one of the best with lots of western breakfast choices on offer. Be prepared to walk to trains but not to far.

What more can can you want? this is a very nice example of the Marriott brand (not in the USA though) with the extra Japanese politeness and etiquette.The rooms are very nice, clean modern and beds comfy> The breakfast again as Marriott policy is excellent with great waiting staff too. The location is perfect, not too close to downtown with a 10 minute walk to Shinagawa Station which is well located for all trains> It is in a green part of Tokyo as another reviewer has stated.There is a fitness facility which is complimentary for Marriott members Downside is the food is not available after 11pm apparently, i came back late and all was done,

I had stayed in quite a few international 5 stars city hotels in Japan, this is the first one that gave me that breath of fresh air and energy that you find in a modern hotel. It could be that it is newly refurbished or it could be that the team was new and was endeavor to prove themselves. The concierge was fantastic, despite our late request, their persistence managed to got us into 2 very good restaurants on the weekend. The rooms were new, modern and well equipped. Breakfast was extensive and exquisite. One of the best I had ever experienced. There are very few eateries within walking distance but the hotel provide free regular shuttle to the Shinagawa station which offers plenty of food options. Areas that can be improved: 1. The club lounge was small and windowless. It felt like a temporary setup which I hope it was. 2. It does not have a pool and gym. Despite the short comings, it was still a pleasant stay.

Comfortable modern hotel and set in a much more tranquil and green part of Tokyo. A little bit further away from downtown, but a much more pleasant area if you want to get out and go for a run or walk in the nearby garden... very pretty & peaceful! Rooms were nice and the bathroom amenities were great! Breakfast buffet was also great and hotel service was very friendly and hospitable. Although it's a little further away from my office than where I would usually stay in Ginza/Shiodome, I would definitely stay here again more for the serenity and peaceful surroundings... not as much hustle & bustle!

The room was huge for Tokyo standards, of course it was a bit out of the way, but they provide a free shuttle to the Shinagawa station which will take you to pretty much anywhere in Tokyo. If you like walking, the Shinagawa station will take you about 10 min walk from the hotel. The staff speak great English and we love that there is a convenience store at the hotel, makes it easier for us to get water and other snacks. They also gave us free wifi. Recommended for people with a bigger group so you don't feel cramped in the hotel room and for those who don't mind a quiet surrounding at night.

Comfortable place to stay with modern amenities. Food options very limited for vegetarians but otherwise decent menu. Breakfast spread was okayish, not too great. Has a mini forest behind it if you want to explore.

Good:(1) provide "Thann" brand shampoo shower gel set. Bath Tub, not shower room.(2) water pressure is strong enough for shower even i stay in 18/F(3) Breakfast is good, but variety is not enough compared to the previous hotel I stayed. Still good though(4) Breakfast time last til 12:00 noon. Good for those who wake up late(5) Close to Haneda airportBad:(1) No restaurant nearby, given not a noodles shop (but you can walk to shinagawa station, take 15 mins or actually there is a hotel shuttle bus between the hotel and the station, so the problem is not really that serious) Shinagawa prince has a better location, but my friend said the room is smaller compared to Marriott ( I havent been to Prince hotel )(2) Swimming pool is not free(3) Don't change money in this hotel, the rate is not good, better change in HK(4) Noise isolation is not good enough, you can hear people talk in the corridor(5) 21000 yen per night, I think we can book a better hotel with this priceTips:Free Wifi only available for memeber, so, join the membership when you check-in, it is free to join

Stayed one night, nice large clean room. Big bathroom with everything you need.Park kursieren, gym etc available.Huge modern Lobby. Staff helped with chargers.Location not central and trains are audible. Was OK for me though.

I stayed here for one night. It was clean and well designed. Ordering taxis was easy. The staff were friendly and helpful. The restaurant was good, but the hotel seemed to lack atmosphere. I had a nice stay and would consider stopping here again.

I really enjoyed my stay here - the hotel is modern and comfortable. Rooms are spacious.The staff are very friendly and helpful. The executive lounge is great with a good choice of drinks and food. Breakfast is excellent with a large choice of western and Asian foods. My only criticism is the dinner in the hotel restaurant is extremely over priced and not that great. Luckily it's only a short distance to plenty of cheap, good quality food near Shinagawa station.

Last time here was my first time and I wasn't impressed. This stay the service level was much improved and my room was large, quiet and super comfortable. The wifi is fast. The food quality is high. The staff is responsive and flexible. The hotel is spotless and the breakfast selection is really great. The executive lounge people couldn't be nicer. Once you get over the slightly dark and not all that welcoming lobby the rest of the place sparkles. And yes it's a 10 min easy walk to Shinagawa train station. I think I'll move from the Ginza courtyard to this property permanently.

Hotel is great. Loved the room and power outlets everywhere, which is really important for a couple that is addicted to social networks and traveling internationally.The morning breakfast buffet was great -- combination of both western and eastern menu items.

Excellent hotel! Highly recommended. I stay in hotels 75-100 nights a year. The Tokyo Marriott is amongst the best in which I have stayed.Top marks go to the quality of the service - from the time I arrived (11am - and they found me a room) to the time I left (5:45am - and a lady came in early to make sure I had a 'take-away' breakfast bag). The quality if the breakfast was outstanding - even for Marriott standards! The service was outstanding and it did not take long for staff to predict my breakfast requirements!The room has a modern design - not totally my choice, but the bed is up to the usual Marriott standard. I would have preferred a 'desk' to a round table - but perhaps I am getting fussy. The 'extras' in the bathroom are beyond the norm and would do justice to a JW Marriott. The Executive Lounge is well stocked with both food and drink.The location is great for the train station - there is a shuttle bus or a 10 minute walk. Direct trains from the station will get you to central Tokyo or out the airport.Note - there is no pool.The service sets this hotel apart - for that reason alone, I would return to the Tokyo Marriott. The rest is a bonus.

I absolutely love the Tokyo Marriott. It's modern and clearly well taken care of. The bathroom is stocked with everything you could possibly need - from bandaids to toothbrushes - and it is clear the hotel takes pride in its appearance. The rooms and bathrooms are large and the modern conveniences (ample plugs, heated toilet/bidet combo) made this an incredible stay. Our package included a buffet breakfast with options for even the pickiest eater and free wifi. The location is prime as well, with Shinagawa station servicing the JR lines, subway, Shinkansen, and other train lines. Just ask the front desk for the shuttle schedule and you're on your way! I hope to have the chance to stay here again.

Never matching Marriot standards. Very few people in night shift . Dark lobby. They charge 100yen for giving multipin adaptor. Just average in all aspects. Really surprised at their attitudes. Need to go a long way

The hotel's location is about a 10 minute walk from Shinagawa station. There is a free local bus service that runs at least every 20 minutes to and from the office building that is right next to the hotel and shares the same entrance. The staff were impeccable and every request was fulfilled quickly and with a smile. The rooms are modern and nicely equipped. At least our room's size did not look as big as the images on the website. Whereas this hotel's rooms are larger than average in tokyo they are still smaller than what you might expect from a marriott in North America or Europe. The website does mention the roughly 300 square feet but that includes the bathroom (good size tub) and the entrance corridor. There is also very little space for clothes and suitcases but it is manageable. There is also a Family Mart (24h convenience store) on the premises for stocking up on water and snacks. The location around the hotel does not feature any restaurants. But a short hop on the bus to shinagawa (5 min) solves that problem.I would stay here again if in tokyo as shinagawa train station gets you a direct train to almost anywhere in tokyo.

A quiet, modern, super clean hotel in a park-like setting. Exceptionally accommodating staff. We left bags and went touring for the day. Returning for check-in at 5p we found bags already delivered to our room. Spacious, bathroom and very comfortable bed. The bellman also helped with the airport shuttle, which saved us a ton getting to Narita. This is an exemplary Marriott property and staff.

Taxi drivers relying on local GPS still know it by it's former name - Hotel Laforet. It enjoys proximity to areas in southern Tokyo - less than 30 min taxi ride (about ¥4,700) from Haneda Airport and about 30 min train ride from Shinagawa station to Yokohama. On the flip side, destinations in central Tokyo require 20 to 40 minutes commute on JR line/subway lines. Front office staff and concierge are proactive and comfortable in English. My deluxe room was contemporary in design, very clean and spacious. It had a good-sized bathroom - complete with auto WC and heated seats! I thoroughly enjoyed Marriott hospitality for 5 nights!!

Stylish hotel with western style rooms, good view on the surroundings, very good service. The breakfast buffet has a wide choice of food and comes at a reasonable price (if you pay in advance when you check-in). Good quality internal Japanese restaurant, but orders need to be placed before 9pm. Shuttle bus from Shinagawa is every 20 min.

We spent 3 reward nights at this hotel, in late July.The hotel is conveniently located within a 10-minute walk from Shinagawa station (or a 5-minute shuttle buss ride).While this is not the most pretty or interesting area of Tokyo, the hotel's location is not an issue.The hotel's reception is oddly located in the back side of the building and you literally have to go through the hotel's main dining area to get there.We were granted an early check-in as early as 12:15, which was nice.The check-in process, however, was a real pain.Although specifying this in our reservation and double-checking it via email the night before, we were assigned a smoking room (2203), despite the fact we were guaranteed a non-smoking room.It took the hotel almost an hour to change our room to the nearby room (2205), which was a smoking room as well.Only 30 minutes later we were assigned a non-smoking room on the 23rd floor (2305). Finally.As Marriott Platinum members, and despite booking a regular room with points, we were upgraded to a Club room, which was very nice.We chose 500 points as a Platinum gift, but also received a lovely plate with gorgeous looking cookies in our room.The room itself was pretty spacey, with a rather simplistic design and a view towards the port.The beds and couch were very comfy.There was a huge safe in one of the drawers, where even a big laptop fitted with ease.The bathroom was very nice, although it only had a bath (no shower).Water pressure was very good.The amenities were outstanding (Thann and Aromatherapy).Naturally, the toilet included a hi-tech automated bidet, which is regular in Japan.The hotel had no gym nor pool on site. Instead, you can buy access to a nearby old-looking gym (apx. 20 USD). This is pretty sad, actually, as you'd think the hotel would've reached some agreement with the gym to allow access to its guests.There's a a convenient 7/11 just next to the hotel with decent prices.The hotel offers a free shuttle bus service to Shinagawa station (ask the reception/concierge for the timetable).The shuttle from Shinagawa station to the hotel leaves from bus stop number 6 – just exit Shinagawa station from the Takanawa exit, turn left and walk apx. 50 meters.The one place the hotel demonstrates a 5-star level is the Club lounge.The lounge is rather oddly located next to the reception, in a window-less room (which is not an issue at all).The club features an extensive full buffet breakfast, which is served in the hotel's restaurant (superb selection!), all day nibbles, including cakes and pastries and an amazing dinner presentation, which includes over half a dozen hot dishes, sweets, soft drinks, good quality alcohol and huge cakes and pastries.Being a Marriot Platinum (or Gold) is certainly worthwhile for hotel guests, as you receive both Club access and a full buffet breakfast.All in all, despite the somehow painful check-in process, we had an enjoyable stay.

Hotel is beautiful, grey, lavender and white color pallet. Western style beds. Excellent service. A perfect breakfast buffet, western and Asian foods. Delicious fancy sushi restaurant in the hotel, Nadaman. Free shuttle to Shinagawa train station leaves / comes every 20 min so hotel is convenient to everywhere in Tokyo. We will return. Highly recommended.

Modern hotel, clean, far from the major attractions of tokyo, nearest to shinagawa station, the hotel provided shuttle bus to shinagawa station, far from narita airport, but near from haneda airport. Choose The limo bus from haneda or narita airport more cheeper than taxi to this hotel.

I guess I have expected a lot since I have stayed to other Marriot hotels in other countries. I wouldn't say that the experience was not good but it was not at par with the other Marriot chains of hotel. The fascade was classy and very business-like. There's the Lounge & Dining G at the lobby where the buffet breakfast is served. Tasty food but minimal choices. I was expecting Japanese dishes but none, probably it's because they are not served during breakfast. The bedroom was just okay. I have a city-view for my room at the 18th floor. I got a king-sized bed and soft pillows so it was very comfortable to me. I am a Marriot rewards member so I have a complimentary internet access ( so I suggest you get one for its perks ). There's no complimentary water though. The bathroom is nice as well. The cable TV shows mostly Japanese shows. I dont't think the hotel is child-friendly coz the cartoon channel is also in Japanese but for a business trip, Marriot hotel in Tokyo is just fine.

Hotel located walking distance from Shinagawa station, but can be a bit challenging to walk if you have many luggage. There is a free shuttle bus from Shinagawa station (Takanawa exit, bus stop no.6). I attached the photo of the bus, schedule and pickup/drop off location for reference.Hotel room is very clean, modern and updated. Room is small and standard in Tokyo. Marriott Gold member gets free wifi and free breakfast. Service is really great and most staff do speak good English. Overall, this is a nice Marriott hotel. But if you are looking for something closer to Shinagawa station with a larger room, do try looking into Prince Sakura Tower Autograph Collection.

This is a nice hotel but a bit out of the way. Restaurants in the hotel are limited so you really need to head down to Shinigawa station to grab something to eat. This is less than a mile but don't make the mistake of trying to walk.

Have previously stayed at the nearby Sakura Prince/Autograph Collection property, but glad that I came here instead. Public areas all recently renovated, hotel is an easy 12 minute walk or a shuttle is periodically available (cab 720 yen). Walk in the front door and a bellman greets me, learns my name, and escorts me into the Concierge lounge for check-in. As others note, the first floor lounge is oddly-sited and has no windows, a bit of a downer in an otherwise bright and air-y lobby. However its proximity next to the restaurant made it easy to take the great coffee from their machine while enjoying complimentary breakfast in the lobby restaurant. Upgraded to a nice suite on top floor with sweeping views. Entry way has a wonderful art-niche, but there's nothing there - silk flower arrangement or a painting/litho should be placed there. I'm also staring at two nicely finished doors, but its not clear where the room is...one door to a bathroom, another to the suite. The suite has a large desk, sitting area and a flat-screen that can be positioned towards the bed or sitting areas. There are two balcony's outside the room, but they are only accessible from the fire escape; no doors to the balconies. Windows aren't just double-paned; there's two sets of windows to ensure that no exterior noise gets in the room, though the neighborhood location means most of the noise might come from the trains running in/out of shinagawa station. Removeable remote control for the blinds. Bed is insanely comfy for a Marriott - my best nights' sleep of the week. No artwork at all in the room - lots of wall space but nothing on them. Makes the room seem more industrial (maybe primarily for meetings?) and less home-y. Open another door to part of the bathroom - a large and well-lit sink, and a make-up area..but there isn't a chair at the make-up mirror, and no chairs in the room would fit there. Yet another door takes you into the spacious room housing the walk-in shower, washlet/toilet, and tub. The shower only had a wall-mounted wand shower, and as the moisture built-up in the shower, the wand would slide down the pole and I'd have to push or hold it over my head. Would expect a room of this stature would have a fixed wall or ceiling mounted fixture in addition to the wand.Staff was very friendly throughout the hotel. Bought some fish at Tsukiji and they offered to keep it in their industrial freezers until check-out. Enrollee to the train station I realized that i left my phone in my room...when I walked back into the hotel and said that I forget my phone, the bell-lady was waiting for me, knew my name and quickly returned with my phone and charger in a shrink-wrapped bag. Great hospitality.All in all a wonderful stay where everyone made me feel welcomed. A few simple decorating tips in my room would be a nice touch for future guests.

Located in a very quiet area - probably mostly a business hotel.Good rooms, all in perfect order and the usual very good 'Marriott'-bed. The staff were all professional and attentive, and we got all the help we needed and then a little more.Good experience

The Shinagawa neighborhood was recommended by a Japanese friend. The Tokyo Marriott turned out to be a wise choice close to the train station, a ten minute walk or 5 minutes by the free shuttle provided every 20 minutes. Room was extremely comfortable, American sized with a very comfortable king size bed. All the amenities were provided in the splendid bathroom. Service was impeccable and the Kenyan(!) concierge particularly friendly and knowledgeable. Dining was pricey even by Japanese standards but tasty. Lots of restaurants nearby, especially near the huge train station from which you can go anywhere. All in all, the experience was excellent.dio, Boston

I am a Platinum member in Marriott, however they did not offer the same service like other Marriott in other countries. They did not help with my luggage when I got there. USA, China, UAE and Mexico have a better service on Marriott hotels.

This property is the definition of a big bland conference hotel. If you're visiting Tokyo for work, this property will do as it is close to a conference center and some major corporations. However, if you're in Tokyo for leisure, look elsewhere. The location is not really convenient for a tourist. Further, while Marriott has made an effort to update the property, it lacks wow factor and the rooms and common areas are generally nondescript. My spouse is a Marriott gold level member and we were given a room about 175 square feet. The bed took up almost the entire room. The staff is relatively friendly. However, I'll note that when I asked for a dinner recommendation, the only suggestion I was given was the restaurant in the hotel. Really? Tokyo is the largest city in the world and I was in a lounge that is supposed to cater to the frequent traveler and the best/only restaurant that I can be steered to is the one in the hotel. One upside is that the hotel is relatively close to a train stop for Narita Airport.
user_name:
JonathanN378
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Marriott is a good place - nice lobby, good rooms and comfortable beds. Location fairly convenient...not much immediately walkable but within 15min cab ride of most parts of Tokyo and has a free shuttle to the Shinagawa station and commercial area.Downside is not great facilities - gym and pool onsite but is pay per use.Like most Japan hotels, beware if you want to checkin early. At 9am the room was ready but was told it was a full extra night to checkin early. After a bit of negotiation they agreed to waive it.

I stayed at the hotel 10 days. The hotel is great. Big and clean rooms and bathroom, very nice sttaf, very good brakfast and very good laungue. There is bus servis from and to the airport.I very rcommend this hotel.

I stayed twice in 3 weeks at this Marriott. The rooms that I had seemed standard Marriott size. Updated rooms with blt in HDTV on wall, large King bed. Nice views of city. We had lounge access where staff again was very friendly and helpful. The lounge provides hot Hors d'oeuvre wine, champagne, beer, hard liquor and great deserts. My only complaint with the lounge is that they don't seem to vary the hot hors d'oeuvres. Usually teriyaki chicken and pork skewers, fois gras. The buffet breakfast in the dining room is quite sufficient. You can have made to order omelets, waffles with real maple syrup from Canada, not the imitation stuff that restaurants substitute, miso soup with additions, fresh juices, hot lemonade, cappuccino, latte, coffee, all with coffee syrups like peppermint, plus cold cuts and various breads and rolls. When I first got to the hotel I walked from Shinagawa station, about 10 min. Later I learned there is a free city bus shuttle which is very easy to find outside Shinigawa station and stops directly in front of Marriott. We took JR train around Tokyo which is at Shinagawa. Also Norita Express stops there as does the Haneda train. Haneda airport would be my choice as it is the city airport,. much closer than Narita. The major attractions of Tokyo are not walking distance from the Hotel, such as Ginza, Disneyland, Akiabara, but with JR train, it doesn't matter as you can get there quickly. Kentara Kubota, Front Office Manager was especially helpful. I would highly recommend staying here.

Those who are looking for a spacious, American-size rooms will be happy with this hotel. My double room was very nicely appointed, spotless clean, and had a nice view of the cityscape. The whole building design is minimalist in style, with granite and gray tones. It's calming, but does not exude excitement, if that's what you are looking for. The staff is very nice and helpful, without being intrusive. The hotel is in a quiet residential neighborhood, a bit far from centers of activities, but there is a nice garden around the hotel, and a quaint, little private museum next door, which is a nice place to spend a quiet afternoon. It's a bit of a hike from the nearest train station (Shinagawa), but there is a shuttle bus that runs very punctually every 20 minutes or so. You need to ask where the bus stop is to catch it at the station, because it's not obvious.The restaurant in the atrium is okay, but not great--except for the service, which is very good. It seems to try to be like an American restaurant, but doesn't rise up to the level of excellency. I'd prefer if they serve regular Yoshoku (western food) that the Japanese do so well. The breakfast at the restaurant is very expensive, unless you are a Marriott club member. Since I don't like to have a big breakfast, I bought some sweet rolls at the convenient store in the basement, and had them with the coffee in the room, which was excellent. I didn't try the other restaurant on the premise, Nadaman, which is rather expensive. I'm sure the food is excellent there, because it's a well-known chain.
user_name:
Barcrofter
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Impressive lobby design - sleek and modern, though a little drafty, chilly in lobby. Breakfast buffet is extensive - includes traditional Japanese selections as well as Western selections, savory and sweet. Guest rooms are well-appointed and great design. Very comfortable beds. Great sofa. Great views. Quiet rooms. Marriott Rewards members Executive lounge has great amenities throughout the day - it's unfortunate that lounge is located on first floor with no windows. Unfortunately fitness center carries additional charge (2100 yen) in adjacent building. Great staff - from front desk to bell desk to concierge to breakfast staff to lounge staff -- all very helpful and welcoming. Shinagawa area hotel - 3.5 miles from Tsukiji Fish Market; reasonable cab ride to Asakusa. Convenient shuttle service to Shinawaga train station for access across Tokyo and beyond. Reservations available for shuttle from Marriott to Narita Airport for 3100 yen.

The Tokyo Marriott is an older hotel that has been recently renovated. The rooms are beautifully finished, modern and very clean - as you would expect from a Marriott hotel. The bathroom is nice, with a combined shower/bath and the bathroom amenities box was well fitted out with brushes, combs, shavers, tooters/paste, etc, etc. The toilet seat is heated and there is a bidet fitted. Quite common in Japan, but a very "interesting" experience for me as these are not common in Australia.The breakfast is quite expensive (Yen3400) which is about AU$34. If you were in the mood to go for a walk, you could definitely find breakfast nearby, in a cafe, for half that price. The quality of the breakfast was good, with omelettes, egg, cereal, fruits, and japanese style fare.The hotel has a free shuttle bus that regularly goes back and forth from nearby Shinagawa railway station. This is really convenient.Overall, a very nice, clean, well furnished hotel.

Very modern high end full service hotel at a very reasonable rate As mentioned in other reviews, a 10-15 minute walk from Shinagawa Train Station or you can take the complimentary shuttle to and from that runs about every 8 minutes. Plenty of taxis in front of the hotel if you're on the go. There is also a shuttle bus to Haneda Airport, but only has 3 departure times. Not sure about Narita, but you can always take the Narita Express Train from Shinagawa Station. Show them a foreign passport and the fare is half price, its also part of the JR Rail Pass. The windows in my king room did not open but were doubled up to soundproof the noise from the trains. The amenity kit had a lot of amenities, such as a shaver, shaving cream, scissors, tooth brush, etc. Room had a mini fridge with room to put your own drinks. One of the few hotels that I have stayed in Japan which did not require you to insert your room key inside your room in order to turn on your power. Don't forget to bring you three prong adapters! TV had a couple of English speaking channels but no ESPN. Free Wi-Fi with no issues. Only negatives about the hotel is that there is not much to do around the hotel. It's not the Ginza District.

I had a business meeting at the Tokyo Marriott Hotel the first week of December 2014. I am normally one not to select chain hotels and prefer boutique hotels, although as the customs in Japan are different than ours in the states, I had to rely on a local meeting planner and this was their recommendation as far as space and location for my meeting. The hotel was said to be purchased by Marriott last December and has since been renovated so inside it looks quite new. I was a little taken back that I had two twin beds in my room as I have never seen that in the states although as I was traveling alone without my family this was not and issue for me. The food selection for the breakfast buffet was excellent as well as the other meals served at the hotel. The two meeting rooms we used were the perfect size for our group (one day we had a meeting for about 20 people and the next day 60 people) and the food selection between breaks and lunch was very pleasant. The hotel is located about a 10 minute walk to Shinagawa train station although if you choose not to walk the hotel provides a free bus shuttle to the train station. From this station you have easy access to other areas in Tokyo including a lot of sight seeing in the event you have time.My overall experience at this hotel was very good and would recommend to people who are looking to have a a meeting at or simply on holiday.

Just had a one night stay here over the weekend. Suprisingly it is next to my company's Japan HQ. This used to be the La Floret hotel. Location: About 10 mins walk by foot from Shinagawa station (Takanawa exit). There is a shuttle bus provided - go to Bus stop number 6. It is complimentary and runs rather frequently during the week and less in the weekend. It is not a Marriott exclusive bus, so it can get crowded especially during peak hours.Becareful that around Shinagawa itself, there is basically not much to do especially in the weekends when offices are close. Lobby:The lobby is rather hidden, when you enter the hotel, you are greeted first by the Lounge and Dining G (restaurant). There is a concierge at the entrance. I reported to him and he looked up my room and told me to proceed directly to the Exec Lounge to check in. There was someone waiting at the entrance already to greet me.Check-in:Was fast and efficient as expected by Japanese standard. Given all the different vouchers for breakfast at the Lounge and Dining G, Nightcap coupon (because the lounge closes at 10pm), 10% off voucher for dining and internet access.RoomVery well appointed. A modern contemporary style room. If I remember correctly I was upgraded to a Deluxe room, which in Japanese standard was a rather huge room. I had a view out to the Shinagawa station and the port area. Could also see planes landing and taking off in the afar HND airport. (becareful for light sleepers - you can still hear the train running on the 20th floor)Bathroom/Toilet: Very well equipped. However the bathtub was most probably from the old establishment. Other than that, I did not see any other things which looks to be from the old hotel. Water pressure was strong for a nice powerful shower. Executive lounge:Located at the ground floor (same as the lobby). Not the most exciting one as there are no windows/view. Evening offerings are ok. Sufficient to make a meal out of it (though in Japan - why make lounge food your main meal). Overall, a good hotel with good connections to the different parts of Tokyo for tourist or business. I will certainly return to this property if I am in the area as it is connected to both HND and NRT conveniently.

Location: About 10 minutes walk from Shinagawa train station in affluent business complex.History: Built and opened as La Foret in 1990. Acquired, renovated and rebranded by Marriott in 2013.Interior decor: Marriott standard. Wide open space lobby and lounge. Elegant room furniture. Adequately lit. Stylish restaurant appearance.Exterior appearance: One of the skyscrapers in Gotenyama business complex near Shinagawa/Osaki.Outside view from the room I stayed at (906): Clusters of business/residential buildings, JR East railroads.Room Size: Approximately, 28 square meters. Reasonable for the price I paid, amenities and the convenient location factors. Room Cleanness: Very well maintained.Noise Insulation: Occasional noises from trains that run nearby.Price and Value: Adequate considering complimentary breakfast rate, room/building conditions, stylish interiors, and professional services.Breakfast buffet: Excellent selections of wide varieties of food with modern 21st century looking decor.Bathroom: Full of amenities and polished floors, walls.Bed: King size. Medium softness - slept well.Parking: 2000 yen per night. A bit steep.

I stayed at the Tokyo Marriot in Shinagawa rather than the Courtyard in Ginza to try a location outside the central district. The rooms and amenities are as to be expected from one of the Marriott properties. Please give the concierge a ring if you need any help with reservations or transportation. He was very helpful during my stay.The rooms are clean, spacious, and have good wifi signals. There is also a good restaurant in the hotel where you can eat Kaiseki. I did not have the opportunity to try but taxi drivers commented on the quality and reputation of the Nadaman Ryotei.The closest station is the kitashinagawa station where you can quickly buy tickets to go anywhere in Tokyo and its surroundings on Japan's famous public transportation. If you do not want to do the short 5-10 minute walk to the station, there is also a shuttle that can take you to the Shinagawa station. Taxis are also readily available.Lastly, the breakfast spread was of a high quality and has western and Japanese style options. If you are traveling through Tokyo for business and want a good quality place to relax outside the hustle and bustle of a big city, consider the Tokyo Marriott in Shinagawa.

We had the choice of two hotels for this trip, the Prince Sakura Tower and the Tokyo Marriott, since we want to accrue our Marriott points, After much deliberation and discussion, we decided on the Tokyo Marriott based on, of all things, photos. The ones for Tokyo Marriott were consistently nicer than the other. We arrived late (lost luggage...don't ask) and were ushered, by name, into the Executive Lounge for check in. To have adult beverages offered after nearly 24 hours of travel and a lost bag was heaven itself, but the staff were so pleasant they made it even better. The rooms are large by Tokyo standards, and the staff went above-and-beyond to accommodate our every request (adjoining rooms with our daughters, higher floors, etc). Everything is pristinely clean and run efficiently well. We have had a wonderful buffet breakfast (complimentary for Marriott gold status) every morning, with cooked-to-order eggs and pancakes, with a myriad of fruit and savory dishes, as well. There are snacks/tea/desserts available all day, and you can take anything there to your room with their approval. The bus/shuttle to the Shinagawa station and back to the hotel is consistently on time and located right outside one of the train station. When in doubt, ask anyone and they will most likely help you. Overall, this property gets high marks in my book and we have stayed more than 40 nights in hotels this past year alone.

Tokyo Marriott is a great place to stay, typical of Marriott. The rooms are very good, neat and comfortable. The bathroom/shower was great too. The breakfast buffet is excellent with food that can satisfy all tastes, and included local fare as well. The staff is very friendly and service is excellent, and you can pretty much ask them for help on anything and they will happily do it for you. It is located quite close to the Shinagawa station (10 mins by walk), one of the largest railway hubs in Tokyo from where you can take multiple train lines, including the Shinkasen (Bullet trains). As you can imagine, being in close proximity to a railway hub can have its disadvantages too, as you can see/hear trains all through day/night. I was not bothered about it, but some may as a colleague of mine. Make sure you have the address/map in Japanese as many cab drivers did not know the place and the Japanese address helped me.Overall an excellent place to stay for business, but for a casual traveler it might not as good as it is not very close to the Tokyo landmarks, but again you can get a train to pretty much any place in Tokyo from here.

I am a current Platinum Marriott Rewards Member. From last year, the hotel services and amenities have changed significantly. Last year, the room was horrible, service was terrible. This year when we returned back to the property, everything has changed. Excellent service, Room upgraded with better amenities and the Executive Lounge with better food selection. The breakfast at the restaurant was phenomenal. Upper management at the hotels are watching all parts of the hotel to insure everything goes well. I would like to say that one of the manager, Makoto Nakajima, the Executive Housekeeper on the property, took care of us very well. As one of the family member has a shrimp allergy, he informed all the staff and let us know which restaurants to go to and all. This hotel has change significantly from last year and I highly recommend this hotel to everyone if you are in the Tokyo area.

I stayed her during a short business trip. Getting to the hotel from Narita was really easy on the Airport Limosine service. The room was quite smal but very well furnished and very clean. The food in the hotel was excellent. The only issue that I had was that the hotel was only recently made a Marriott and one of the taxi drivers that I had did not know where to go. The reception team at the hotel talked him through it on the phone and so all was then OK
user_name:
AndyJWa
New York City, New York

review_body: Still staying in Marriot - the hotel is very comfortable and quiet. Room size is big in Japanese standard. The hotel is not located in busy shopping district, but it is a ten minutes walk to Shinagawa station, that makes you easy to go to any place. It is a place if you want to relax abd stay away from tourists. The service is very good. I like their buffet breakfast. I am very happy with my stay.

First time in Japan so I can't compare this with other hotels in Japan esp inTokyo. Yes. Like some said, it is too close to train station (but I believe most of hotels are) so if you are going to stay here, pls do ask for a room which is facing the front of the hotel. All staffs were very nice and always tried to help so I was very happy with that. Whatever I was saying or asking, they always tried to understand me and help me. Executive lounge- not high level. if you enjoy wine and beer, it will be all right but if you are looking for something good quality or something can fill your hunger, no way! Room quality - train noise which I really didnt enjoy but my friend's room was very quiet. Pls do ask for a quite room! Clean and neat! Bed was amazing. Have backpain so bit sensitive abt beds yet it was great. Esp I like their shower gel, it was also good enough for fantastic bubble bath. Breakfast - had three breakfast meals and as far as I can remember, they were all same. No different menu. On my third day, I got very tired of what I was eating. Service- was great. Location - you have to take a shuttle bus and it was bit of hassle since I stayed there during the winter. Overall - pretty ok experience. staffs were nice. Didnt use any other facilities beside executive lounge so cant say anything about other facilities.

I have never been to a Marriott this horrible. The service is terrible. The executive lounge is not even a lounge, no food. The rooms smell and reek of dissection juice (not exaggerating) and finally the railroad is right outside. Try sleeping! The concierge is outrageously rude, believing he owns the place. ***This place was originally a different hotel and Marriott bought it, the lack of quality and service is because they didn't train them, they have the old staff (a 2 star hotel). I highly recommend the prince shinagawa hotel which is conveniently next to the metro, an easy way to get around.Marriott has a shuttle bus that DOESNT RUN every day!!!!!!!, paying $15 just to get a ride to the metro. Furthermore: Paying to use the pool?! It's filthy too.I recommend the Keio Plaza hotel in shinkuku, a better location. However if you want shinagawa, then Prince is the place to go.My experience was horrible, and the manager has yet contacted me in regards to his apology. I have emailed him and the supervisor, and he responded that he was going to speak to me tomorrow. But he "was out", when I checked in the morning. I expect him to email me, as he has my contact information, and show some respect. I am highly disappointed.

Good hotel, like the Marriotts. clean and good service in the hotel. as being Japan hotels you will not find water for dinking separately ad not very big rooms. If there is one then there is charge. You get room view from where you can see tokyo tower as well. The bath accessories are also very good. I hadome earlier than the check in time and as per rule would have to wait for almost 2 hrs, but eventually i could get the room within an hour which was good especially after such a long travel. The room services are also very good and the food is also good.very convinient hotel as it is just about a maximum of 30 min away from Haneda airport. also shinagawa station is only about a 5 minute walk. overall good hotel.

The Tokyo Marriott places itself amongst the top hotels and does so pretty successfully. At check-in, I was taken directly to the Executive check-in without saying a word. The bellman, whom I saw checking my luggage tag, must have used the earpiece radio to tell the person escorting me who I was and what my booking was. Very impressive. I was asked to take a seat in the lounge and offered a hot towel and snacks, drinks, whatever. Check-in was smooth and quick and I ended up lingering a bit to finish the Espresso I had made for myself during check-in.My room was 1710, a corner room with a king bed. It was not large, but it was well- appointed and it had great views. The linens and beddings were top- quality and I slept very comfortably. A nice touch is an outlet next to each side of the bed, so my phone could charge overnight but was still to hand. The room was very quiet, and it was hard to hear the Yamanote, Keihin Tohoku and Shinkansen lines constantly going by on the tracks down below.The bathroom was modern, everything functioned perfectly, and it had a great selection of amenities. Had I forgotten my overnight kit, I would have been well- covered.Breakfast was very good, with a large selection, an eggs cooked to order station, fresh squeezed juices, smoothies, and most of the usual goodies.The view from my room ranged from Gotanda / Meguro off in the distance, across Shinagawa Station and all the large buildings there, finally reaching to the canals of Kita Shinagawa and the TY Harbor Brewery. There is a large office building next to the hotel, blocking the view towards Roppongi. On the other side, the view would range mostly south and east, including Haneda airport off in the distance.The location is good but, for most people, at 850 meters distant, probably not walking distance from Shinagawa Station if you have luggage. It is 730 Yen for a cab from the station. It is an easy (but not interesting) walk without luggage, and you could not lose your way. The location features a beautiful wooded garden on the hotel's property – called La Forêt, which was the name of the hotel before it became a Marriott. It is a reasonable walk to SONY and many other businesses on the Konan side of Shinagawa Station. The gem nearby is the rejuvenated Old Tokaido Road, which wended its way, mostly along the coast, from Edo (now Tokyo) to Kyoto. It’s 500 meters from the hotel’s front door and has many small shops and restaurants, very few foreign tourists and is a very pleasant change from the neon-lit, brash areas nearer Shinagawa station. You could almost think you were in a village.The final touch, when I checked out, was the front desk asking if I would need a cab, and having it pull up at the moment I walked out the door. It seems that this attentive and anticipatory service runs throughout the hotel. It does not come cheaply, but it is very well-done and you feel like your money was well- spent.

This hotel was absolutely immaculate and staff was some of the most service oriented staff at a Marriott hotel I've ever seen. The food at the main restaurant was also excellent. However, be careful as the iPhone map does not have this hotel as of November 2014. You can walk from Shinagawa train station, it is about 15-20 minutes.Only downside is the hotel does not own its own gym and there is a charge to use the gym attached in the office center. This would have been a sigifnificant frustration if my stay had been longer than two days. However, there is a very nice park next to the hotel with good running trails if you don't mind doing laps.

Good all round business hotel, avoid corner rooms though as they are very small. Clean, great service and wonderful breakfast. Just a note, taxi drivers are not familiar with the hotel so make sure yo have the full address.Don't assume the water in the fridge is free, it's not! And there is a charge to use the gym.

This is a good place to stay that is slightly outside the city center. Was able to hit the major sightseeing areas for a $30 taxi ride. You could take the subway if you can figure out the complex routes which are daunting for Americans. If you are adventurous, however, that would be the cheaper way to go. This Marriott is older and has had some renovations done but still is a notch below what I expect but can't complain. The staff is always attentive and the rooms are clean and well maintained. You can walk to the subway station or there is a shuttle - would take the 10 minute walk if you are so inclined as it is an easy trek.

This is a very modern hotel in the Shinagawa area, which is one of the major train stations in Tokyo. This is a convenient location in terms of getting to/from both airports and to many of the major tourist areas of Tokyo.The hotel is a 7-10 minute walk (uphill) from station; not so far that it’s a deal-breaker, but just far enough to add a layer of hassle to any commute. Like many big hotels in Tokyo, it’s located within an office building complex. A free city bus goes between the station and the hotel and is well-used by hotel guests and office workers. Frequency is not as much as you’d like, though. I never did find the one that goes from the station to the hotel, but did ride the one from the hotel to the station a few times. Stayed over a weekend so I assume the bus is much more crowded during the work week.As a Marriott gold member I was able to check in at a special area. Food and drink offerings there were beautiful and reasonably varied. I also had free wifi; not sure what the charge is if you're not a gold member.Buffet breakfast in the main area was spectacular, including an egg bar and a wide variety of other choices including freshly pressed juices. Service was impeccable. Restaurant area was very large and could accommodate many guests. Large multistory open space meant that it didn’t every feel cramped or crowded. Service at the hotel is top-notch (it’s Japan, after all). Rooms were clean and up to date; bathroom was large and well-appointed with Thann products and other amenities. This was one of the few hotels I’ve been to in Japan in which the room was “American-sized” instead of small and compact. The room was also very quiet. I felt very pampered in the room.Overall this was a great hotel; the one thing that gives me pause is the location. Over time the walk up/down the hill to the hotel adds up. With so many other choices (including the Prince Sakura (Autograph Collection) much closer to Shinagawa station as well as other hotels in different areas of Tokyo, given the choice, I’d probably lean in that direction.

A fairly typical Marriott hotel I'd say. I've been to enough to know! This hotel is actually very nice. The rooms are spacious and exceptionally clean, but if you've been to Japan you'll know that cleanliness is standard protocol here. The rooms are standard layout and the beds are comfortable.Free WiFi if you're a Marriott rewards member, so sign up if you're not a member, it's free!As is standard they ask for a copy of your passport at check-in. By government regulation the hotel staff has to take a copy. The Shinagawa train station is about 4 minutes by taxi, about 730 yen. You can walk it in about 15 min.

I had a lengthy stay at the Marriott Tokyo near Shinagawa station in October, 2014. Like other Marriotts in Asia, this property is excellent, particularly for elite Marriott Rewards members. The property only recently came under Marriott's management so it is not listed on sites such as Google maps. The rooms are large by Tokyo standards and have recently been completely renovated. The executive lounge has an excellent selection of wines, beers and liquors (e.g. Johnny Walker Black) and snacks during the evening and they even gave me a coupon good for a free drink every night in the bar after the lounge closed. Although the lounge is not open for breakfast, elite members get complimentary breakfast in the restaurant, which has a wonderful buffet with eggs cooked to order. The location is a little out of the way , about a 10 minute walk to Shinigawa metro station which is a major station for both the Tokyo metro and the bullet train. However there is a free bus between the hotel and the station which runs frequently and takes only a few minutes. Also, I never had a problem getting a cab at the hotel (however since most Tokyo cab drivers do not speak English pick up a card at the hotel desk that has the hotel's name and address in Japanese to show to cabbies for return trips to the hotel). The concierge (a Jamaican gentleman) and staff in the executive lounge were also excellent. The wifi (again free for elite Marriott members ) was excellent--fast and available throughout the hotel. Also I only had to log in once for my weeklong stay which was nice, particularly as compared with many hotels that require log in each time a guest wants to use the wifi.There are a couple of items that can be improved: first, the hotel does not have its own fitness center, but there is a health club located in the same complex which is a quick, indoor walk from the hotel. It has an olympic size pool, tennis courts, etc. However it is VERY expensive( over $20 per visit unless you get there before 9 am, when the fee is about $10. ) The hotel should have its own fitness center with at least basic equipment available for free for hotel guests. Second the hotel does not have a business center. This was not an issue for me since there were a couple of computers ion the lounge but could obviously b a problem for non-elite guests.

I usually stay close to downtown Tokyo, but no rooms were available. Not a problem. I was at the Marriot for almost 3 weeks; the staff are wonderful, the food excellent, and the area around (Gotenyama Gardens and Forest) were nice and peaceful, even as I could hear the trains close by.Cons - As I mentioned to the restaurant manager, I would love to see more menu choices on the room service menu. The Executive Lounge didn't seem to be open during the times listed.Pros - the staff. FABULOUS staff and wonderful people. Tips: Get a room away from the rail tracks; it should be a bit quieter, although it didn't bother me. The walk to Shinigawa Station was quick - about 10 minutes and there is a shuttle. Bear in mind that the shuttle is a regular bus (not a hotel shuttle) that goes back and forth to Gotenyama Trust City and Shinigawa Station.

The Tokyo Marriott hotel has a very convenient location- about 20 minutes from the airport and very close to Shinagawa station- which you can walk to or take the free shuttle bus which does 3 trips per hour. The bedrooms are small but comfortable and contain all the amenities one would expect from a hotel like this. The executive lounge, oddly located on the ground floor, is very small but the food and selection of drinks served there is good. More impressive is the dining lounge close to the hotel foyer; the wide variety of breakfast options available is excellent. The gym and pool is not actually part of the hotel but is in a serviced tower block close by. Guests of the hotel are required to pay a small fee in order to gain access. The staff at the hotel are extremely pleasant and welcoming and very helpful when it comes to answering general queries about the area. Nothing about the hotel made me think that I would have to return to it if I visited Tokyo again but, overall, I was very satisfied with my stay.

Hi, A few point to note about this hotel: The room: The bed is comfortable. Pillows are very good But the only problem is with the room is the position of the bed which was facing the window and not the TV, so we have to see theTV side ways, I don't understand the logic why the bed is positioned that way since there was ample of space for the bed to realign to face the TV. Working table is too small, perhaps remove the cabinet below the tv and place a bigger working table would be nice. The safe box is way below on a drawer almost to the floor, it will be convenient if the safe box is located waist level height. It will be difficult for someone with backache to bend down all the time to put something in the box.Ample choices of coffee and tea in the room, although house keeping staffs was excellent, they tend to forget to refill them when they come for housekeeping on and off at times. The bathroom is good, with good shower pressure, a bath tub, good selection of toiletries. Wifi is excellent in the room and throughout the hotel. TV channel, was really nothing interesting to watch, 2 news channels, 1 fox channel, 1 sports channel and the rest were all in foreign language, i stayed here for 2 weeks, you could imagine how boring it would have been being in room and having nothing much to watch, perhaps management should look into upgrading the channel packages if there is any.The Breakfast: Have been staying here for 2 weeks, the same menu everyday, the menu can have a better rotation rather then the same thing everyday. I only see salmon or the other fish everyday, suggestion, you could make fried rice, noodle fry, change of vegetable rather then French beans everyday. Overall need to look in the menu and make some changes. The Lounge: Lounge have variations of drinks and food, snacks, and alcohol drinks, varies depend on time on what they serve. The happy hours is from 5pm till late night. Smoking room: The room is below one level from the ground floor. Its kind of far walking from the room and making a turn at the Dining G area and then take an escalator to the base floor. Perhaps could have a smoking area nears to the ground floor. Bell Desk: Bell desk staffs are extremely helpful in providing information, maps, calling taxis, especially Praveeen and Yuri. Hotel Ground: Has a Family mart mini market next building, lower floor. A flower shop A Post office A garden just to relax the morning or evening. The hotel can arrange for airport Limousine bus service to Narita or Haneda, on time and efficient. Very convenient.Overall a good hotel, but can improve in certain areas.Thanks

A disappointing downtown hotel so typical of many Japanese hotels seemingly caught in amber since they were built in the city's heyday in the mid 80's. The rooms are super small, the bar and restaurant are over priced and lack ambiance, the gym is small with old equipment and inconvenient hours (7am to 9:30pm). The hotel is basically a Marriott in name only. Positives? The bed was reasonably comfortable, the door men were helpful with good English, the location was close to Shinagawa station (about a ten minute walk) and there is a nice (small) park around the hotel. I'd avoid (The Strings at Shinagawa is much nicer and more convenient for similar price) and if you do have to stay there ask for a high level room or be prepared to be serenaded by the multiple trains coming and going from Shinagawa station.

It is a comfortable and cosy room away from home. Very nice buffet spread though not too elaborate but very practical and pleasant. Location is 10 mins walk from Shinagawa station. Staff with good hospitality and pleasant in mannerism. Excellent place for home away from home.

Away from the throngs of people in downtown, this Marriott property was quite comfortable. The room is well appointed though stark on first glance. After settling in I realized that everything I could possibly need was there; ironing board, electric teapot with coffee and teas, a fantastically comfortable bed and a comfortable work space. The only thing that I found lacking was more than a few English language TV channels. As a business traveler crossing time zones I find that being able to turn on mindless entertainment helps me to relax while trying to acclimate. The restaurants were good and the breakfast buffet was quite impressive. We dined in the ground floor traditional Japanese restaurant and the sushi was outstanding. All services and personnel were exceptional and very happy to oblige any request. As a side note, I had left a fax behind on my departure, the staff copied the fax to a pdf file and emailed it to me. Now that's service!!

This hotel has good access to Shinagawa station which accesses the JR Yamamote line into central Tokyo but ia also a hub for the Shinkansen and a stopping place for the Narita express.The hotel is a short distance from the station but there is a regular free bus from there to the hotel.The hotel is quietly situated. although the railway is near, there is little noise. The corner room on the third floor had views of the hotel garden,a pleasant 'oasis' amongst the concrete of the city. The hotel is fairly new and that makes for a great stay;comfortable bed and pillows, crisp,quality bed linen and large fluffy towels. Housekeeping is immaculate throughout the hotel.It was a pleasure to stay here.

Stay nowhere else! The Tokyo Marriott is my second home-away-from-home. Their General Manager, Hiroshi Komoto, has created a perfect experience from the front door to check out, a brilliant Concierge in Sylvanus Masiro, and a great experience with all the staff. Close to the train station, free shuttle, excellent food...I would stay nowhere else.

Good:-spacious room -excellent quality beds (far superior than regular Marriott)-Great bathroom and in room facilities-excellent staff with great English-Lawson market on property-the restaurant gets 10/10 for breakfast, dinner selection and the bar-direct/cheap limo bus from airport Bad:-location is kind of dull with no easy access to early morning jog or stroll-Shinagawa station is a good 10 minute fast pace walk-The restaurants near Shinagawa station (takanawa side) are not worth noting, better to hop on a cab and go elsewhere.

So surprise to find that hotel doesn't have gym and swim pool. Guest need to USD20+ to get in a private gym. Location: just so so. Hotel room is clean but small. If your room is facing retail way, lots of noise.

I've stayed in a lot of hotels and this one was not the most spectacular but it was still perfect.Room - very clean. The Bed - firm but comfortable for me. If you like a soft bed, this could be rough for you. Temp control seemed to have an instant change in temperature but I could hardly tell the fan was on it was that quiet. I never heard a sound from other rooms and could only hear the trains if I paid attention and listened for them.So the rooms had no "frills" to them. Beds, TV, computer table and lights. If you need shiny cherry wood cabinets and gold plated fixtures, this is not for you. It was absolutely perfect in that it met every one of my needs and exceeded my expectations in most areas.Bathroom - clean and exactly what I needed. The shower was the best shower in my life, at home or away. Adjustable height, pressure and temperature. The towels were the best I've ever used at home or away. Thick, plush and absorbent. Heated mirror.Oh, the TV hardly had anything for English speaking customers. I would stay at this hotel over any other I've ever stayed at including the ones with the fancy cherry cabinets and gold plated fixtures. Why? because this was actually clean and not the pretend clean that some hotels provide. There was not a hair or stain in the place and nothing makes me feel more comfortable than cleanliness.

location is a little bit far but perfect for a business traveler whose local office is just in the same building. Hotel is newly renovated and Marriott branded. Room is good, clean and not too small. Room price is quite affordable, although the dinning is a bit expensive in the hotel. Overall, very good hotel and will certainly stay here again on my business travel.

I never like Marriott. Maybe because I had bad experience when I was in SF Marriott. But my husband has to book this one in Tokyo as it is close to his work office and he thought was the nicest at Shinagawa. We meant to stay 7 nights. Upon checking in, I asked reception if we can pay extra to be upgraded to club floor. She said yes so long we pay USD 120 per night for 2 pax. I said ok. Then I told her to put us at club floor level pls. She said yes. We ended up on 22nd floor but realised the club lounge is on the 1st floor!? Once we entered in the room, we got a shock as the room is small and very dull looking like the typical airport hotel! To stay here for 7 nights? I think I'll get a depression. Husband who is very easy-going was also shocked. He went down to check with the reception what's going on + peeking at the club lounge. Club lounge has no windows and it was locked at 11pm! The reception has to unlock club lounge to let my husband takes a peek! They've a gym but you've to pay Yen 1,270+ per visit. I thought at least they can extend this for us for free since we're willing to pay extra for the club service and long stay. When reception heard we didn't like our small room and disappointed by the paying gym, she only apologize and didn't try any harder to retain us (not even to view other rooms since we're staying for the next 7 nights). Wifi is good and strong. Breakfast is very good. Love the noodle soup station and their service crew who are very prompt. Marriott has a shuttle that goes every 20min. to Shinagawa station. Butwe didn't get the chance to use it as we checked out the very next day and move to The Strings - Intercontinental which is just 3min. walk to Shinagawa station.

The hotel is very nice and has a great outdoor patio where you can enjoy a drink next to a small park. The rooms are smaller than normal but very functional with excellent amenities. Tip for the TV: For English speakers, there is a small square button on the TV remote that will turn OFF the voice over translation on international stations like CNN. The train station is a 10 min walk from the hotel. There is not much nightlife around this hotel, you will need head towards the train station to get to the restaurants and catch a train for the bar scene.

We arrived at the hotel via airport and was immediately taken care of. Luggage was quickly picked up by staff and we were taken to check-in. Escorted to our room and our luggage was already there. Staff there was always courteous and helpful. Service in all areas, from the lounge, restaurants, house-keeping, check in, all the staff, was exceptional. Our 2 bedded room was large for Japan and very comfortable. Equipped with a mini fridge(bar) and a hotpot to make coffee or tea. Not a lot of spaces to store you clothes in the room. Bathroom was well equipped with toiletries, toilet seat was heated, flushed automatically and also was a bidet. Shower was really good. Breakfast buffet was good with a nice selection of items including cooked to order omelet, waffle, pancakes and noodle soup. Only thing not good there was the regular coffee but you could order a latté or other types of coffee which were considerably better. Breakfast is pricy if not included with your room. Executive lounge was very good with very good selection of drinks and appetizers. You must be a Marriott gold or higher to use it. Not much to see around the hotel except for a very beautiful garden next to it. 10 minutes walk to main train station or take the shuttle bus. I had a medical issue upon leaving and the staff quickly found me a clinic with a English speaking doctor and driving directions to the taxi driver which was waiting for me. All in all, we enjoyed our stay there for 3 nights and will be returning there in a few days. Only big problem at this hotel was I was not offered an upgraded room even though I am a Marriott gold member, and upgraded rooms were available. Secondly, I had 2 rooms and they were not going to honor my gold perks for the second room, even though this was for a immediate family member and we didn't all want to be crammed in 1 room. Would recommend this hotels because of the great staff and service..

The bedroom was pleasantly large, but overlooked the railway line so there was constant noise from the trains during the day, fortunately the trains don't appear to run late at night. The bathroom was nice, the toilet seat was fantastic, heated and with a built in bidet, and the toiletries provided were comprehensive All the staff I met with courteous helpful and spoke more English than I speak Japanese. The breakfast buffet was mediocre at best, the coffee was tepid and the food in the "hot" food buffet section was barely warm, except for omelettes, poached and scrambled eggs that were freshly prepared. The service and the offerings in the executive lounge was excellent and the lounge, though small, seemed about right for the small number of people using it. If you have time, go down the the B level and walk around the gardens. A haven of tranquility in the city, the sound of grasshoppers and birds and two waterfalls calm the soul and revive the spirit.

Here is the biggest issue with this hotel: it's not next door to tourist areas. That's about the only drawback. This hotel is close enough to the train to get you where you need to go. The rooms are larger than I was expecting from here in Tokyo and the price was not too bad. The amenities in the room were outstanding. The hotel is laid out a bit unusually in the sense that the lobby is a bit removed from the entrance, but that's nothing to be concerned about. We flew into Haneda, so that was closer than Narita which might be a consideration. I would highly recommend this hotel.

Stayed here for a single night 20AUG14. The hotel was immaculate and the staff and service were exceptional. The rooms are large, something not always seen in Tokyo, and at a good rate. The close location to Shinagawa station was convenient, and I would highly recommend the breakfast.

Good mix between Japanese and Western Standard. Big room and bathroomoutstanding breakfast buffet and vera friendly service.Too bad the breakfast starts pretty late at 6:30 and the hotel is to far a way to walk to the Shinagawa train station

actually i booked at this hotel because most of hotels was booked in the city center.the hotel is big but its old and the room is normal but its comfortable.the nearest station is Shinagawa and its about 10 minutes walking from the hotel.the hotel price is average.the executive lounge small.

This hotel gets the job done, but there isn't much activity there. Staff was nice, but the lobby seemed a little dead (all the time) with not much excitement. Rooms were great. Food at the hotel on the first floor was fantastic. The gym was disappointing. First of all, it was an extra charge. Secondly, the equipment was pretty dated. Not impressed, but there is plenty there to get you what you need. There is even a tennis court, but that too, is likely extra - not sure. Wifi was a hassle - could never stay connected for any period of time. Phone and laptop kept getting kicked off, despite strong signal. Train station down the street, will get you anywhere you need to go. Cabs out front. Fare from the hotel is about $215.00, so be ready for that, or take the train.

I decided on the Marriott for my first visit to Tokyo, using both points and cash. I could not have been happier. I had read all about the small rooms in Tokyo, but the rooms in the Marriott are large and comfortable. I loved everything about the room, especially the teas. The breakfast buffet is delicious, and the lounge for Platinum members is quite nice. The concierge helped me book a tour to Kamakura and Yokohama, which was very nice. I took the limo bus from Narita to the hotel, which was $31.00. For sightseeing, I took the free shuttle to the Shinagawa station to get around by train and subway. It is very difficult at the beginning to figure out the train and subway stations. But, it is worth it. I visited the Tsukiji Fish Market, the Imperial Palace, Asakura, Senso-ji, and Tokyo Sky Tree. This was a great first visit, and I look forward to returning to Tokyo!

Was put in this hotel which is quite far away from our office and I don't like it at all. The hotel is located in a office area so there is nothing much around the area, like a dead town. You have to first walk very far from the entrance to the front desk area and the room is not really big but what I cannot understand is the lack of drinking water. Even local chain hotel offers drinking water. Anyway my room faces the train tracksks *horrors*, you can hear them but as the night progresses, you can't hear them so I guess the trains either stopped or slowed. The breakfast is simple, not as much options as other 5 stars hotel and the japanese options are very limited. Bathroom amenities are good iron in the room is pretty interesting. Airconditioning is weird, it gets very cold or very warm even though the temperature wasn't set to the extreme. During check-out there was only 1 person so it can get slow as more guests proceed to the check-out.

First, the review by Koyangie in mid July is quite good and sums things up. So this is more of a personal reflection and a couple extra details. We got here by train, first to shinagawa then by the local train one stop away to kitashinagawa. The walking bridge crosses the street, head right & up a block or so and you're there. No long waits for shuttles if you're willing to take a brief walk. The hotel is much bigger than the local standard bed in a closet room. More to a western standard. We're platinum for now so check-in was in the executive lounge. Excellent English all around. The lounge has plenty of alcohol if that's your thing in the evening. The finger foods were pretty good. The rest are snacks in small glass jars. I do think the lounge is an after-thought. It would be nicer if it was on a high floor with a view instead of a windowless room and a single tv. Service was excellent and attentive, though. The rooms are fine and summed up elsewhere. Breakfast has a bit of the standard western and local Japanese + Vietnamese fare. It was average. They bring omlets to you which delays things a little. And they do guard the coffee a bit much, considering how bitter it is. One nice surprise is the large walkable garden adjacent to the building. There was a local food / beer fair going on which was fun. And if you don't want a fancy dinner there's the family mart at the bottom of the stairs with snacks and some quick noodles. Big picture: Good hotel, reasonable price, excellent service, and an easy train ride from downtown. Improvements can come from the executive lounge, breakfast service, and maybe a chocolate with turndown service :)

We stayed here for five nights on a business trip. The staff and facility is a fine example of why we enjoy our overnights at Marriott Hotels. We were always greeted with smiles and eager helpfulness. There was a short walk to a large train station for us to explore Tokyo in our free time.

I stayed here for a meeting and the meeting space is large (unusual for Tokyo) and very clean. The hotel rooms are large and appear to have been recently updated so they do reflect a Marriott theme which is good if you are a frequent traveler as myself. They offer an executive lounge on the first floor with evening cocktail hour and snacks and drinks available most of the day. The buffet breakfast in the lobby lounge restaurant is excellent with large selection of made to order eggs, oatmeal, fruits, etc... I found the staff very friendly and helpful. This hotel is set in a quiet setting near the Shinagawa train station, this train station is very large and can be quite confusing for first time visitors. If there is a drawback it would be the location from easy subway access to Roppongi and Ginza areas frequently visited, I suggest taxi which is about 20 minute ride. Overall I would say great for business stay.

I tried most of the Shinagawa hotels. Apart Sakura Tower, this one is the best and even less expensive. Shuttle to station is free (5 minutes). The lobby is far to be impressive but the rooms are modern and very comfortable. Special congrats on the bathroom amenities. Decoration could be still a bit joyful.The breakfast is excellent although not much choice. Really enjoyed it, especially for a foreigner in Japan. I would go back.

Hotel is overall OK, relatively new and within quiet location. It is near Shinagawa subway and rail station. Plus: There is an airport shuttle to / from the hotel costs around US$30, takes one hour. This is convenient, specially if you have suitcases. All facilities in good working condition, clean, and well-maintained. Regular shuttle bus, about 3 every hour to and back from Shinagawa station. Japanese restaurant on the ground floor has excellent service from graceful ladies dressed in traditional kimono. Although relatively new to Japanese cuisine, we thoroughly enjoyed the set meals. Convenience store in same building complex. Buffet breakfast has good selection of fruit, usual continental breakfast fare, egg station is fine. Wifi throughout hotel. Our package included wifi, seemed it may be an extra option. What you will not find / may not like: rooms are small. Gym is not within hotel but available within complex and costs around $21. I did not try and was disappointed that there was an additional fee. No restaurants or stores within vicinity of hotel, you will need to take shuttle to Shinagawa.

It's a nice hotel. Rooms are small and it's clean. It's not very English speaking friendly- no English tv. Not really anything in walking distance. The staff is very friendly and went above and beyond. The Japanese restaurant is great. We had tempura and the lunch restaurant very good too.

The rooms are expensive and very small. The restarting attached for breakfast is poor quality. The rooms and hotel is reasonably new but much like many other hotels in Japan the rooms are tiny. The library bar is open late but limited selections and I atmosphere. Not much point having a bar in the lobby located where everyone sits with no atmosphere. Overall ordinary hotel and I personally expect so much more from Marriott Hotels

It's a good hotel. Rooms were clean and had spectacular view. Service was not as good. Executive lounge is ok. They are not open for breakfast. I'm a premier platinum and was given only 2 coupons for complementary breakfast, although we were 4, 2 adults and 2 kids. When I asked for bottled water at the executive lounge, I was reluctantly given. I was told I need to ask from the person who does turndown service.

In preparation of our trip to Tokyo I reviewed Internet hotel comments to gleam others opinion of the hotel.
