Although there is a Ritz-Carlton and Courtyard in Tokyo this is the first “Marriott” in one of the worlds largest and most populated cities. The property was recently rebranded “Marriott” from the previous brand Hotel La’ Forte. Further, as a loyal Marriott member I make it a point to stay with the brand I know best and have expectations to the level of service offered by Marriott properties.The Narita Airport Limo deliveries you to the front door and is the first stop in Tokyo. The trip takes approximately 70 minutes depending on traffic. If you are returning to Narita for your outbound flight it is advisable to purchase the round-trip ticket to realize a small savings in cost. The bus was comfortable and the pick-up was a convenient location just outside the arrivals hall Terminal 1. We were met on arrival by staff and escorted to the Executive Lounge. The hotel is located adjacent to a lovely park and although major rail lines are directly across the street is quite. The hotel evidently went through a major redecoration phase prior to opening as Marriott so everything is new.A number of reviewers complained of the distance from the Marriott front door to check-in, although it seems like a long walk it is only about 75 meters and is close to the elevators. After setting in an airplane for 12+ hours and the bus ride from the airport the walk offers an opportunity to stretch your legs. The Executive Lounge (Marriott Platinum/Gold members or Executive Floor paid guest) is located on the first floor next to the general check-in desk. There was a problem with my Marriott credit card at check-in. It was repeatedly rejected but finally accepted. After getting settled into my room I had a “Fraud” alert email awaiting my review that showed the number of attempts (5) the hotel had made to authorize the purchase, interestingly no two were for the same amount. The card had previously been used in Japan so it was not the location that raised a flag. I expect the issue resulted from the multi attempts and various amounts entered to clear the authorization. Smooth Marriott Executive Lounge operations support customer loyalty to the Marriott brand and are an important aspect of the loyalty program and Marriott Shinagawa was no exception, the staff was excellent and very attentive, although somewhat shy. The availability of an Executive Lounge influenced my decision to stay here, as I’m sure it has/will others. The lounge is a closed room with a somewhat unfriendly environment and is rather uncomfortable, not a place to relax and unwind after a busy day of business or tourism. However, the staff was friendly and helpful in everyway possible. The night manager was on hand to assist with our check-in. After getting into our room I immediately noticed there was no “walk-in shower” available only a high-sided tub/shower. My wife recently had surgery and I have a replacement knee and we both would be challenged and face a potentially dangerous venture each day getting into/out of the tub. I went back to the Executive Lounge and explained my concerns. At first they said there were no rooms with walk-in showers but after checking the system further came up with a solution at an additional nominal daily charge. Mr. Yuta Terakado personally escorted me to the new room to insure it was satisfactory and had our luggage relocated. Exceptional service and attention to the customer! That said, in hindsight I should have verified the availability of a walk-in shower before arrival, my bad! The staff (Mr. Yuta Terakado & Ms. Yuri Ebisuno) were understanding of my need and responded accordingly. After we got settled in our room we went down to the Executive Lounge for a snack and a cold drink. Although the Welcome Information Sheet indicated snacks were available between 7:30 PM and 10:00 PM when we arrived around 8 PM all snacks had been cleared for the night. In hindsight, it was probably a misunderstanding on our part as to the definition of snacks, i.e. finger food on our part and candies and other treats on the hotels side. The set-up appears to be a quick fix solution to address the need for a lounge, hopefully this is a temporary arrangement resulting from the rebranding and a more relaxing environment will be forthcoming in the not too distant future. Mr. Rai Shu kept the lounge food and drink bar well stocked and responded to our every need. Great job Mr. Shu. Ms. Kanako Yorioka was especially helpful in my search for an old Japanese friend from the 1960’s. Another common complaint of other reviewers was lack of available in room storage and overall room size; that was true of the first room we were booked in, but not the second. The bed was comfortable but the furniture is rather uncomfortable. I think we must appreciate Japanese Hotels are not overly spacious, and I have stayed in other Marriott’s whose rooms were even smaller. When booking online the actual size of the room is given so you should have an idea of the size before arriving. The rooms are “Art Décor” in appearance but new. There is a “business” electrical outlet configuration on a worktable (no desk) with Japanese fixtures; you’ll need an adapter to use American three pronged cords; available through the hotel if you forget to bring your own, which I did. Wi-Fi worked fine but the signal was degraded in the bedroom.TV’s with beautiful displays were available in both the setting and sleeping area. The controls however are in Japanese and some programs such as BBC and CNN have Japanese voice over; could not figure out how to turn this feature off or if it could be turned off? There were no channel information sheet/instruction normally available in most hotels to help navigate program offerings/settings. The Executive Lounge does not serve breakfast but offers a complementary breakfast (Marriott Platinum/Gold members) at the Dining G Restaurant. A wide selection of food & fruits, and made to order eggs are available. The restaurant offers a nice relaxing atmospheres and an attentive staff. However, the bill of fare remains pretty much the same day after day (we were here 9 days). The only variety I saw was the substitution of bacon for ham every other day. I also discovered on my third day that a bread and pastry room is located in the rear of the dining area. I had thought this was a private room and had not ventured in before. Management might want to think about letting the customer know about the availability of bread and pastries in this special location! I don’t recall the staff saying anything about where the bread was located, perhaps it is a given we are suppose to know about this? Coffee refills can be a hassle, as you have to catch the attention of a waiter and then will only get half a cup unless you ask otherwise. It was as if they were rationing coffee! Exceptional staff throughout though and many speak very good English. Management should train their personnel not to assume all Asians speak Japanese as the staff launch into Japanese when they see an Asian. My wife for example is Korean and does not speak Japanese but the staff assumed she did and directed all conversation to her in Japanese. There is a “market” in the lower level of the office complex next door from which you can purchase beverages, water and various Japanese items i.e. noodles of various flavor, etc.A free shuttle bus is available to/from Shinagawa Train Station and offers a frequent schedule. This is a real plus. From Shinagawa Station it is an easy metro ride to all points within Tokyo or rail connections for travel outside Tokyo. Regardless of where you stay in Tokyo you will be faced with the need to commute via the metro and Marriott Shinagawa is an ideal base location for your Tokyo stay. Older stations are demanding for those physically challenged as not all offer elevators or escalators for entry/exit to platforms. This should also be considered for those traveling with infants or small children. For those involved in developing travel applications the development of an app that indicates availability and location within a station offering handicap access to station platforms would be genuinely helpful.An exceptional treat is the terrace lounge outside the Dining G. Very pleasant atmosphere surrounded by trees. This was a great place to unwind or just enjoy the outdoors while reading the paper.The bottom line, would I stay here again if I were in Tokyo or recommend it – YES! The costs of rooms are comparable with other properties, a major transportation hub is readily available, and an excellent, attentive staff, and the deciding factor for my decision to stay was the availability of an Executive Lounge. Although the lounge is not on par with other Asian Marriott’s it offers an opportunity get out of the general traffic of the hotel, and this hotel is busy. Previous experiences at Marriott Asian properties (Beijing, Shanghai, Bangkok & Seoul) set the level of expectation and perhaps it would be of benefit to have a “mentor” program with those properties to learn the Marriott way. Mr. Jong Sung Park, executive Lounge was a very good “go-to” person for assistance throughout our stay. One last comment, the housing keeping staff was excellent and the room was kept fresh and tidy each day.

This is a great hotel in a great location. Part of a business complex the hotel sits somewhat by its self so you don't feel like you are in the a sense urban setting there are beautiful gardens off the lobby and restaurant. Easy cab ride to the train station. The rooms are very spacious and very nicely appointed. The bathrooms are awesome with large glass enclosed tub/showers. Robes, slippers and many complementary toiletries. Not a good walking location but excellent location. Recommended.

We moved to this hotel from Hilton Tokyo Bay after a few days in Disney as part of our Asia vacation. We had previously stayed at Marriott Osaka Miyako and again this hotel was of great standard and room 2002 was furnished to high quality and had a great view of the bay area. Breakfast was really excellent and staff members were all very accomodating and helpful - we chatted daily to Rai Shu in the Executive Lounge and he was very knowledgeable and we laughed with him many times, he is a good asset to the hotel. Concierge also helped us to get to see Mount Fuji from Enoshima and Kamukara which helped us a lot and made a great day out sightseeing. Reading other reviews of this hotel I don`t think they fully represent the quality of the hotel and its location. I would return again when in the Tokyo area.

Stayed at this Gotenyama hotel for 4 nights. Spacious lobby, courteous staff, very clean room and comfortable beds. My room was on 9th floor, overlooking the train tracks, but it was very quiet. There are 3 shuttle bus services every hour to Shinagawa station where Shinkansen, other JR and Keikyu trains stop. Also this is a good hotel if you fly in and out of Haneda airport. Only downside is that they charge for Gym.

We were at our hotel within an hour of landing at Haneda airport. A beautiful hotel - amazing view of Tokyo Bay and the city skyline from the 22nd floor. Great location - near many restaurants and urban areas and very close to Shinagawa station. Comfortable beds, great service and affordable compared to similar hotels in the area. One of the nicest hotels I've visited in Tokyo. There is a free shuttle from Shinagawa station and we were able to book the Limo Bus to Narita airport with the concierge and bill it to our room. If you are flying into either Haneda or Narita, it is easy to get to by either the Narita Express (NEX) from Narita or the express local train from Haneda. Hotel staff was very friendly and helpful. I would highly recommend this hotel!

Stayed two nights early May. Great service and very friendly staff. 5 to 10 min walk to major train station. There is also a free shuttle bus from the station to the hotel and back. There is an attached garden (forest) to walk around which is pleasant to stroll in. Would stay again.

This hotel has some criticism on trip advisor but we found it very good. Its just 10 minutes from Shinagawa station with connections from there to all parts of Japan. It has a nice garden and very good restaurant. Service was excellent particularly from the " bell boy" who spoke great English and sorted Taxi's no problem. Will stay there again if in Tokyo,

I've stayed at this hotel 6-7 times in the past five years. It was previously the LaForet Tokyo before changing to the Tokyo Marriot in the past year. The rooms have been upgraded and refreshed as has the lobby and downstairs area which resulted in a greatly expanded restaurant on the first floor. My experience here has always been very nice. The updated rooms are a good change. There is an executive lounge on the first floor that has a quiet area to work, snacks and drinks (including all liquor and wine free 5:30-7:30pm each evening). Although the property is very nice, the rate is high for a property such as this even for Tokyo. On the other hand, the staff and facilities are both quite nice. My room was very comfortable. The bed was good and the bathroom was large and well equipped. The staff is great as they always have been. The location is within five minutes walking from Shinagawa Station and there is a free shuttle bus that runs regularly (multiple times per hour) during most of the day and evening. I'm sure I will be back.

Its a pretty new Marriott hotel (6months), but the standard is very low. The executive lounge is very marginal....almost no service. The reception staff is not well trained and informed...wrong infos and no infos. No amenities at the check in as Platinum Reward member.The breakfast buffet is ok, but not outstanding.All in all, well below standard and no more choice for the future on my business trips.

We stayed for one night on 6th April 2014 and again on 20th of May 2014.The hotel is located 5 minutes distance from Shinagawa Station where the hotel offers complimentary shuttle bus service every 20 minutes. If you take taxi it would be minimum rate of USD 7-8. The limousine bus to Narita International Airport is available but you can choose direct train service to Narita International as well as Haneda International airport as well.When I travel abroad I send my suitcases from my home to Narita Airport directly vice versa on return trip. The American Express card has a free service to send your suitcase to the airport when you have ticket to go abroad. I use this service and hands free then to use train which is faster and aculate and even cheaper than bus for Narita airport.Executive lounge service is very sophiscated in Japanese OmoTeNaShi and the Breakfast is very good. I saw a gentleman taking more than 5 minutes how his eggs should be cooked in details at the counter. He looked so happy. So I visit Tokyo several times and I do repeat my stay here.

For a business hotel, the service is quite underwhelming. I arrived at ~1130pm from Seoul, and there was only 1 individual working the check-in desk, and unfortunately for me, he was quite junior. Despite having all my reservation materials in hand, it took him a good 30 min to get me checked in. As a Gold member, I was given a tasteful room although it only had one bath towel which was surprising. The breakfast selection is adequate and the food itself is okay, but the service is atrocious. I was there for 3 mornings, and each morning it took them 20+ minutes to provide a cup of coffee. Don't even bother asking for a refill. Further, on the first day, despite being the first individual to place an omelette order, I had to wait 30+ minutes for my order. As for other amenities, the executive lounge is ok. The adjoining fitness center is decent although it has a putrid smell.

First class service, very comfortable and spacious rooms.Easy access to the main line train and subway with a shuttle bus to and from the hotel.Would definitely return to the Marriott on our next visit to Japan.

I had just spent a week in Bangkok at the JW and was looking forward to a few days in the flagship Marriott name in Tokyo, but did not find an outstanding experience.I was upgraded to a large room, which was nice, and had a nice view from a high floor of the Toyko Harbor. The bathroom was much smaller than some of the other hotels I have stayed, with only a bath/shower. I have become used to larger bathrooms, even in other hotels in Tokyo. Also, the turn down service failed to come on the second day I was there, leaving me short towels and a fresh bed to go to sleep. While I can obviously make due with calling for additional towels and re-making my bed, it is not up to the service standards I expect from Marriott.The service was a bit lacking. In the lounge, I did not find nearly the level of service I expect from a Marriott - very much a self-service lounge. The quality of the food and drink was adequate, but not spectacular.The breakfast was decent, though my omelette order was completely messed up (ham and cheese came out as mushroom and onion). I think, perhaps, I would rate this hotel higher if I had not had so many good experiences in Marriott hotels around the world. I am not sure that I will return to this hotel, instead might look to try the other Marriott properties in search of one with superior service.

I am ashamed to say that when I walked into this Marriott, for the reasons of it's location and suburb feel, I was immediately turned off. When we realized that all other hotels in a more central location were taken, we decided to stay. It was the best thing that we ever did as the hotel, staff, and location turned out to be one of the best stays on our trip around Asia. As for the location, you have to take a train to everywhere anyway in Tokyo, and it's about 15 min ride which is actually nothing. The shuttle bus from the hotel is so on time, too that it's never a inconvenience to use it. Loved that service! Also, there are some great restaurants in the Shinagawa area (Inose Sushi!) and it's actually really nice to get out of the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. The breakfast was above average for a hotel breakfast(i mean it's a hotel breakfast buffet) but lots of fresh berries so i was able to find a healthy option which never happens! Also, the beds and rooms were so comfortable! Staff was so helpful, too. Honestly, was such a lovely stay and am a bit embarrassed that I wanted to leave before giving it a try. I would def come back.

What a fabulous property!  As we exited the taxi a young lady with a headset asked our last name and radioed ahead as she escorted us to the Front Desk. We had a gorgeous room on the 23rd floor overlooking Tokyo!In the Executive Lounge, the associates could not be any more helpful and friendly. Particularly Mr Parks and I believe the lady was Kanaka. They took extra care to make sure all of our needs were met!I was able to meet two of their managers, also excellent representatives of Marriott: Kazuyuki Shimoshigi and Hiroyuki Hatori. Their politeness and willingness to take all steps to make our visit enjoyable were greatly appreciated!!The bed is the best we’ve ever slept in and it made our Honeymoon around the world extra special night.Fabulous location only about 150 meters from a major JR subway station Shinagawa. It was disappointing that there was no fitness center and it would cost us $21 USD to use a nearby facility.
user_name:
Byron C
Nassau, New Providence Island

review_body: What I liked:Big rooms, very quiet, superb location (15 mins walking to Shinagawa station, 5 mins to the station by free bus), staff tries hard to pleaseWhat I dislikedHorrible breakfast experience (just don't go there, around Sinagawa station there are so many good cafes/restaurants), limited knowledge of English of the staff (but hey, that's pretty standard everywhere), a bit priceyOK, quite honestly I wouldn't have stayed in this business hotel if I was paying for the hotel myself but from business traveler point of view the hotel is really good - except breakfasts, which does spoil a lot of experience.

Having read some of the reviews I was concerned but the Tokyo Marriott is a very good hotel and far better than most domestic US Marriott hotels. It is clear that there is some inexperience with the staff but they try very hard, are very pleasant and attentive. The hotel has been refurbished and is located well and close by Shinagawa Station. The Executive Lounge is more than adequate and those who complained about the walk to the front desk probably need the exercise.

We stayed at this hotel for 4 nights. This hotel became a Marriott property December of 2013. It is located in Shinagawa. If you want to visit all the major sightseeings in Tokyo, you will have to take a train from the Shinagawa station. It's only a few stops. The hotel is no more than 10 minute walk from the station, but they have a free shuttle if you don't want to walk. The room we stayed at was very small, but otherwise convenient.We had a misunderstanding with the reservations and the manager, Kazuyuki Shimoshige handled it in a very professions and accommodating way. We thank him for making our stay comfortable.

my regular hotel in Tokyo was booked solid and as gold elite member, I wanted to try the newest Marriott in Tokyo. Being in Shinagawa area, my travel time to meetings seems to be shorter than Shibuya area. Although, Shibuya offers much more of shopping and restaurants, trade off was equal.The executive lounge staff was excellent and i do not mind if it's on the first floor, they had all the necessary items.The cafe was excellent, i think dinner special package was excellent, The breakfast buffet was very good, recommend go early to avoid large crowd.

I've stayed recently in this hotel and the main reason I decided to write this review was mainly becaus I understood that some of the bad reviews I read before going were a bit unfair to the hotel and to the hotel staff.I'm a marriott platinum elite for life, so I think I have enough habilities to review this hotel.... The hotel room was very nice, because it wasn't facing the station was very quiet. Also the executive lounge was nice, the staff was extra friendly and very competent. The hotel location was great! We could not only move very easily to any part of tokyo or any other cities (kyoto and Nikko in our case). Also the free shuttle from and to shinagawa station was just great!I recommend this hotel!

Just spent five nights in this hotel and it was decidedly better than some of the earlier reviews indicate. Met at the curb by porter who unloaded our luggage and delivered to room expeditiously. Greeted warmly upon entering and directed to reception, which is indeed a distance, but no farther than at the Waldorf Astoria in NYC, when entering from Park Avenue... Rooms are large and recently redecorated, well-appointed, and well-stocked. Two shelves and a drawer were plenty of space to unpack our things for a three-week stay in Japan. A few extra hangers would have been nice. Lovely lighting, with options, in the room and bathroom. Bathroom is very nice with heated mirror, Toto Washlet toilet, and tub/shower combo that many travelers appreciate. Again, very well-stocked. Food in restaurant is very good. Menu options between bar/lounge and dining room are confusing. One menu would be better. Breakfast buffet, with many options (which is why it is spread in location), is very good. Staff includes veteran servers and some improving their English skills and understanding. Give them a break! Restaurant manager on-site and attentive to diners' needs. Location is very good,with lovely small park right next door. Old Tokaido Road is a short walk away, with shop and restaurant options. Shinagawa Station an easy 10 minute walk. An excellent hotel choice...

Previously the Hotel Laforet Tokyo and most cab drivers will only know this name so be sure to take a business card with you. This is definitely a new Marriott brand for the hotel. The rooms are a little on the small size even for Tokyo. Room size is not much different than the Courtyard Ginza. Internet service is excellent. Definitely goes for an upscale group of Americans and Japanese. The only weakness is the distance from a subway. They have a free shuttle to Shinagawa station running every 20 minutes, but the freedom to just walk to the subway and then onward lends convenience to the Courtyard Ginza. Staff is quite friendly and everyone speaks English well. The nice thing is that the Narita Express goes through Shinagawa station. The Orange Limousine Bus does stop at the Marriott Tokyo. While wonderful accommodations worthy of 5 stars, the inconvenience of not being within walking distance to a subway stop is a weakness. It costs an additional 730-1000 Yen for cab fare each way. So sightseeing trips can get expensive quickly.

-This place is going through some growing pains. Booked for 3 nights and were told on night 2 we needed to check out and check back in to change rooms for the last 2 nights. Even as Marriot platinum members, they just shrugged their shoulders and said, oh well. -Check-in is like a 100-yd walk from the front doors, which I thought strange.-The gym cost $11 before 9AM and $27 after 9AM. A few rusted out treadmills and some machines. Pool is downstairs and I didn't use it for fear af being charged another $30.-Breakfast buffet is average to below-average and costs $34. They have a juicer surprisingly!-Location is great. 5 minute cab ride to Shinagawa station where you can connect to anywhere, and a quick drive from Haneda airport.-Wifi was free but speed was so-so. Could only Skype/Facetime late at night when the servers were less busy.-Bed was very Japanese. Firm, but comfortable.-Toilet controller is very complex, and if you can figure it out I have a few atoms for you to split.-All in all, I'd try someplace different next time.

Stayed here for 5 days in March 2014 and much fell way under expectations for a Marriott. #1 - We booked two rooms -- king and twins connected -- and were given two rooms with two twins not connected. They apologized and claimed the rate didn't cover what we requested. We would have preferred notice when we booked.#2 - We ordered Dominoes on the third night and it was held hostage by the bellman until we went down to be scolded. "No outside food allowed" but they made an exception after a thorough bashing. By the bellman. We spent easily $250 in the restaurant in the hotel prior to ordering pizza. Seems a silly rule regardless.#3 -- The room service menu is very Japanese. If you are Western and have kids, be aware their room service is very expensive and the pizza has seafood it (which is why we ordered Dominoes). You can always bring in from the Family Mart, of course.#4 -- They made a point of asking for our Marriott rewards card, which we supplied, but they never entered it. So, no points.#5 -- Taxis are surprisingly difficult to get from a hotel so close to a major Tokyo train station. Plan ahead and even call down to order one ahead of time if you are on a schedule. Walking out to the street to get a taxi is unpleasant.#6 -- Beds and pillows are uncomfortable for a Marriott.#7 -- We were not tourists on this trip but if we were, the location was horrible. Try Shinjuku or Ebisu.PositivesWe have a cat and our company goofed when booking us here as the Marriott has a no pet policy. Understandable. They were very helpful in providing recommendation for a nearby pet hotel over the phone. Luckily, we know Tokyo as once we checked in, the bellman tried to send us to Ebisu instead of down the street.The restaurant/bar food is very nice. I was never sure of the menu difference between restaurant and bar so always chose bar as that felt more pleasant.Free, quality wifi throughout the lobby.View was nice from our mid-rise room.Overall, stay was fine but for a hotel that wants to accommodate (or does accommodate) Western guests, they need some pointers from corporate.

This hotel recently became part of the Marriott chain. when you arrive you can tell that the Marriott people didn't build it. There's a big open atrium space in the entry area and its kind of dark and not very inviting when you first enter. The location is great as its a short taxi ride to the main train station. The resterant is right in the entry foyer and is open to the lobby area. Guess I just didn't like the layout of the lobby plus the resterant staff were not the friendliest. The room was nice and in good shape. The AC system worked well which is key and the wifi was ok. The concierge lounge is on the first floor by the registration desk which a number of reviewers didnt like but it didn't bother me. I actually prefer the Ginza Courtyard property to this one.

Nice hotel and good location. Rooms are really clean. Breakfast can improve with more options. The breakfast place can improve with a centralize table and the options. You need to walk around and find out where the food, fruits, etc... Not systematic way to serve. Decoration is good and the location around a park is nice. There is an area to stay outside and have a drink. Really nice. There is a balcony but without access. I did not like that. It is convenient based on the location. Closest to the train station and Haneda airport.

It's a10 minute walk to the train station. There isn't much of interest in the neighborhood; but you can be in Tokyo Station or Shinjuku relatively easily. The room was standard, clean, hot water in the shower, etc. It's really fine; there is nothing outstanding.

Coming to the end of a five country, nine city business trip of East Asia, I have stayed at one Courtyard, two JW's and three Marriotts. This is by far the worst. In fact probably the worst Marriott I have ever stayed at worldwide.What can I say that is positive? It is a short taxi ride (700¥) from Shinagawa and there is a shuttle bus (shared with office workers so get in the queue early!).On being dropped off with a large suitcase, laptop and handbag, there were no porters of bellboys to greet me. I made my way into the lobby, and felt as if I was walking in through the back door. To check in it is a good walk through the bar/ lounge area to a body reception area. Apparently though I had come to the right door, it is just laid out very strangely, with no welcoming reception lobby on arrival.Despite being a Marriott Rewards card holder, and having spent over thirty nights in Marriott hotels so far this year, I didn't receive any particular welcome (every single other hotel has offered me refreshments on arrival after a long journey and/or arranged fruit in my room). My room was very small, fortunately it's just me - certainly not adequate for two, and the bathroom is something you might find in a Blackpool B&B (suggest that the manager reads Notes From A Small Island by Bill Bryson if he doesn't know what I am talking about), with a very pokey bathtub/shower. I find it odd that with such a large building with a labyrinth of wide corridors downstairs, the rooms themselves are so mean.Sleep quality? Hahaha! On the 11th floor, overlooking the railway line. In Tokyo the train drivers must exist on five hours sleep as the noise from the trains (if there was a 60second reprieve this was peaceful!) started from 6am and continued until 1am. Earplugs are a must!So arriving fairly late, I got myself settled and browsed the room service menu ringing to order something light at just after 11pm. If you are hungry between 11pm and 6am then that's tough. No room service- I ask you!?! In a Marriott?!!?As in most Tokyo hotels, the gym area is payable, although the price for a very shabby and tired looking gym, shared with the office next door is extortionate ($20), and payable daily.Wifi is complimentary for Marriott Rewards card holders, but is otherwise incredibly expensive.I can safely say that my next visit to Tokyo I will be staying elsewhere. For $200 per night this just doesn't meet my needs. I would suggest that being a fairly new Marriott, the staff are encouraged to visit other hotels within the brand and see what expectations of customers are having stayed elsewhere. This falls well below my requirements.

We arrived very late, which they knew we were coming and still they greeted us by our name. The room was wonderful but more importantly the service was impeccable. What a wonderful property, very close the train station. Every encounter with the staff was a great experience. The breakfast was good too. While I had access to the lounge, I didn't have time to experience so I cannot comment but if traveling again to this area, it is where I would stay.

Let me start by saying that, like a few others who reviewed the hotel recently, I am also a lifetime Platinum member of Marriott hotels. However, I am bemused by the negative comments of others who thought you shouldn't have to pay for the gym, or that the Executive Club is in a strange location, or the hotel location is bad. Yes, you have to pay for the gym, but westerners need to understand that gyms are not a high priority in Japanese hotels. Comfortable rooms, excellent service and good food are priorities, and on all counts, the Marriott delivers. I've stayed at the Sakura Tower nearby many times, and it's very nice, but more expensive than the Marriott.The hotel lobby is a high ceiling, glass atrium, so its light and airy. when I arrived on the limousine bus from Narita, I was greeted by the bell boy, who asked my name. By the time we were inside the hotel, he'd been instructed to lead me to the executive lounge to check in, which was quick and efficient. The Executive lounge is on the first floor near the restaurant, main reception desk and restaurants (i.e. in a good location). It has complimentary hors d'oeuvres, free beer, wine and spirits. The rooms are a good size, with plenty of drawer space, a wardrobe with lots of hangers and the usual slippers and yukata to wear. It has good internet speed, a safe, and a bathroom with all of the overnight toilets you could possibly need. There's A/C which is very quiet.Breakfast was excellent and I was able to enjoy a Japanese breakfast of steamed fish, rice, pickles etc. to start my day. If needed ,there is a good short order bar where you can get eggs, omelettes, etc. There's also a good selection of fruit, juices, breads, pastries. etc. In terms of value, the price I paid last week is about the same that I'll pay to stay in a Courtyard in Boise this week and there is no comparison between the two. Location wise, its about about 600 yards walk from Shinagawa station so its not near the other hotels which made it a bit quieter which is always nice in Tokyo. I can have a brisk walk to the station. Otherwise, there is a free shuttle bus to the station and taxis.Overall I really liked the hotel, especially the service, and I would definitely return.

Formerrly known as the LaForet Hotel it opened as a Marriott only last December (2013). It is close to the (big) Shinagawa railway station(s) which is very convenient when you arrive from one of the two International airports, Narita (by Narita Airport Express) or Haneda (by Keikyu Express). If you don't want to walk, there is a free shuttle bus service every 20 minutes from the first bus stop(#6) to the left of the main exit from the station. The bus looks like a regular city bus and serves not only the hotel but also the adjacent office tower. Hence, if you want to leave the hotel during rush hour you better line up early as you will be competing with the office workers. Our quiet room (2307) was on an executive floor which means access to the windowless lounge on the ground floor. While during the five nights we staid there the lounge never was crowded we noted that repeatedly staff was slow to refill both food and beverages.The room was bright and nice and the furniture"trés chic" however, the designers have put form over function and we seriously lacked storage space. There were almost no shelves to put our stuff. While we know that the Japanese usually travel lightly with surprisingly small suitcases tourists from overseas whose number the Prime Minister wants to double) spending several weeks in the country need some more space. There was not even a drawer in the single bed stand (for two beds) Having stylish furniture is certainly nice but these designers clearly went overboard and put form over function. On a positive note, our room quickly took on the picturesque appearance of Attila's camp....The bathroom could benefit from some additional hooks. For the shortsighted (who take off their glasses under the shower) making the shampoo and body gel containers of different shape/color would be a real help. The stylish waste basket is ridiculously Breakfast was gen tiny.erous and eggs or omelets will be prepared extra for you. While the hotel does not have a gym of its own guests can use the sparingly equipped Laforet Gym in the adjacent office building (covered access) for a daily fee of approx. $ 20 (half if you go before 9 AM) plus tax. In that same building there also is a convenience store (FamilyMart) for necessities, beverages etc.

Let me start by telling you I gave the Marriott Nagoya 5 stars and an outstanding review. From the moment I entered this hotel I could tell something wasn't right. No bellman to great at the door. By the time he arrived I had my suitcases out of the trunk and ready to go. Then at check in at 4 pm only one of our rooms was ready. REALLY at 4 pm. The restaurant serving western cuisine was inadquate. Limited selection and poor service and we were the only ones in the restaurant. Thinking something wasn't right we asked how long Marriott owned this hotel and were told only since December. ah ha that explains the lack of training. Very poor service here. Marriott send this staff to Nagoya so they can teach them how to be successful. I do not recommend this hotel, although the rooms are very nice, the location, service, and amenities are mediocre at best. There is a fee for the gym which is adequate and has a very nice pool. Overall I am unimpressed with this hotel and cannot give it more than three stars. My colleague is even less impressed. Stay in center Tokyo because it is easier to get around and better hotels are there.

I'm a loyal lifetime platinum member; couple of disappointments here which others have recorded, too:1. The gym is within the building but separate; you will pay 20 dollars plus another 5 to rent their shoes PER DAY. Pretty outrageous, and also a very poor gym itsaelf.2. The exec lounge food in the evenings is extremely poor. Barely could be called appetizers, and exactly the same night after night after night. Managment needs to visit other Marriotts in Asia to compare.Rooms excellent; restaurant very good; staff excellent.Would not return here until these 2 things are improved//resolved.

I am in executive room (platinum member) which is lovely, but a bit of train noise if you are a light sleeper ( does not bother me). The staff have been superb !! The guy on concierge is excellent giving all sorts of useful advice for tourist and business travellers alike. The exec lounge is very depressing as previous stated, no windows etc. on 1st floor. Hence no character or atmosphere = shame marriott ! They need to sort this out ! Breakfast in main lobby was superb ! The staff extra attentive and first class selection of dishes (omelette station which will cook your eggs any style and quickly). The hotel is located 10 min walk from shinagawa station (slightly uphill) and no restaurants or nightlife close by. Just a convenience shop (family mart) in b1 selling selection of goods you made need. Did not use any other restaurants in hotel so can't comment on them. I will use the hotel again, but to be honest if you are a tourist you need to be closer to the trains (JR or metro) and restaurants etc. but for business stay it's OK. But the staff are A1 !

First time at the Marriott near Shinagawa station. The hotel itself is about a 10 minute walk from Shinagawa station and really not close to anything. Most of the restaurants are either near the station or a quick cab ride away to Meguro.The hotel is clean and the staff efficient. I had an executive level room booked which included access to the lounge. The room itself was nice, the bathroom was a little old stylish with the sower in the bathtub itself ( very Japanese). The checkin for marriott rewards members is in the executive club on the ground level. Managed to have a drink and biscuit while waiting a a the cocktails had already been put away for the night. Value for money I'd say it's not that great, I would have preferred a better area for restaurants and nightlife.

Upon arrival I was taken to check-in. There were several persons taking care of checking and using walk talkies. The show seemed a bit unorganized. At the check-in I was given no info about hotel and it's facilities. Normally you get some kind of briefing since hotels wants to promote their services to customers.The breakfast was served in cold hall. It was snowing outside and I suppose it is expensive to heat that kind of hall. I had a quick dinner at the same restaurant and that was quite ok.When checking out the process took about 30 minutes due to incompetence of personnel. I wanted to give feedback to duty manager but it wasn't possible since manager didn't speak English well enough to understand.I've traveled all over the world could always trust that I get good service from Marriott. From Tokyo Marriott I returned disappointed.

A little bit a walk uphill from Shinagawa station, but they have a shuttle if you have bags or weather bad. Not meant restaurants outside hotel to choose from but if you head 10 minutes towards Gotanda, or back to station area, there are plenty.The hotel layout is a little strange, they have the exec lounge on ground floor near the check in desks. No windows so feels a little claustrophobic. The fitness centre is outside the main building, run by third party and you have to pay USD 10 or 20 depending on time of day. I object to paying at any hotel to use a fitness room especially when it only opens at 7 and the machines are all a little old and mismatched... But service was great, very helpful people. Rooms are a good size by Japanese standards and light and airy. All been recently upgraded/renovated so spotlessly clean and very quiet. Internet was free and excellent speed.Good business hotel.

I am a Marriott Platinum member that has stayed in Marriotts all over the world. I usually stay at Prince Sakura Tower also near the Shinagawa station (affiliated with Marriott). My last stay my colleagues and I decided to try the new Marriott. Yes the lobby area is very nice and the service was excellent but that is where the highlights stop. The Executive Lounge is POOR in terms of location (first floor) and size. The lounge was very small, poorly furnished and not typical of what I have come to expect in an Executive Lounge. Being that the hotle was new I thought the lounge was in a "temporary" location but I was told it was the permanent location. Rooms were small for Platium member and all rooms sit atop train lines coming out of the Shinagawa station so be prepared for train noise in your room! Electrical hookups and outlets poorly laid out. Amenities in bathroom and design also poor for a Marriott name brand full service hotel. Toilets very small and shallow! Worst toilets I ever sat on in all of Japan. Shower? Be prepared to jump in the bathtub and pull the curtain as shower is not a separate entity. I know I sound spoiled and perhaps even a bit snobbish in my expectations as a Platinum member but this comes from staying in Marriotts all over the world that are my measuring stick for Marriott Awards Members. For the first hotel to place the MARRIOTT name on in such a major city such as Tokyo I think Marriott layed an egg big time. Prince Sakura Tower (Marriott Affiliate) down the road is much closer to Shinagawa Station, Has a much better breakfast servise and atmosphere and is overall a much better choice for the Marriott Awards member in terms of expectations from the Marriott brand.

The location of the hotel is not very convenient for walking but taking a taxi will take you to Shinagawa quite easily. Overall the hotel does offer a nice lounge for Gold and Diamond members with free drinks as well as good breakfast. As with everything in Japan they are sticklers to rules and mentioned that guests are not allowed in the lounge. The hotel says it has a pool and a gym, but that is not true. It is in a separate building with paid access to the gym. The gym is quite basic and dated but the pool is nice. Overall, the stay was good. Staff is always very pleasant in Japan.

I was staying with my family. My husband travels a lot for work so the room was paid for with points. Because of the executive status we were allowed to eat in the exec. lounge which was AWESOME! During dinner hours there was about 12 bottles of top shelf spirits to choose from. A bottle of red wine, white wine and a bottle of Champagne. I enjoyed having wine and champagne with my dinner. The staff was very helpful and eager to make our stay comfortable. The bathroom had a blow dryer and a stocked box of toiletries. We had a delievered paper every morning and a electric kettle with coffee and teas to choose from. The bedding was new and very nice. The bed was firm but soft. I slept very well. The walk to the train was about 10 minutes. There was a near by convenience store called Family Mart that we frequented as well. It was located in the same building. There were great views from the rooms of Tokyo but I couldnt open the windows to take a picture without glass. You could see that there were balconies but I guess during the remodel they closed them up. There is a pool and fitness center but its $20 a day to use. I didnt go to the spa. They have a restaruant and bar but we didnt eat at it. The prices were pretty expensive. for example, hot tea was $9,

Although the hotel is impeccable and the staff extremely eager to help, it does not compensate for the over pricing when compared to other Tokyo hotels.We spent New Year's Eve there after a full week at another recently opened hotel in Shinjuku, the granbell, and the difference in the atmosphere and feeling was very big. True the rooms in the Marriott are bigger but the don't even have a stereo where to connect your phone or music player. Disappointing for a recently refurbished hotel as well the 80s feeling of the rooms,All in all the hotel is ok, nothing obvious to complain about and the staff is attentive but I will not repeat.

This venue just opened DEC 2013, and new addition to Marriott group and also Shinagawa area hotels...Marriott members should be really excited, two Marriott group hotels in Shinagawa area...and this place doesn't disappoint, in fact I think this is as good / better than Prince Shinagawa or Intercontinental. Marriott is priced right and better value. So this hotel used to be a Japanese business hotel, Marriott bought it and renovated. Majority of hotel workers slide from the old business hotel, but they have good skillsets (like most of Japanese hotel workers are).Building itself is within office complex, like many Japanese modern hotels are. Hotel prepared a welcome gift in my room, which was very nice and never seen in other places like Intercontinental or Hilton...thanks Mr. Marriott!I used the concierge desk to check in / out. Had three guys helping me to check in. Room is good size, has plenty of electrical outlets, fast free wifi, and comfortable bed. Fridge is roomy enough to keep take out left over. I had free breakfast at concierge floor...keep in mind, the concierge floor is on the first floor and not very big, if you are familiar with the one in the US, you might be surprised. Regardless, the waiters working there are awesome and make you a fresh meal in kitchen. There are a few restaurants located within the hotel, very elegant Japanese venue on top floor with ladies in kimono. First floor venue is more casual western style. Both very nice but tad pricy. There's also a very nice fitness center with personal fitness instructors. they also have tennis court, yoga studio, and massage room. It's walking distance to Shinagawa station or take a shuttle bus. This place is by far better value than Intercontinental Shingawa, and competitive to Prince hotel in the area.

Formerly the la Foret hotel, the Marriott incarnation is excellent. The staff is extremely courteous and the location perfect. Everything has been redone from the rooms to the lobby. My only complaint is not enough Japanese food for breakfast.

I usually stay on the club floor of the Shinagawa Prince New Takanawa but wanted to stay at the Marriott since I have been an elite member for many years. It is about a 10 -15 minute walk from the train station and is located in the same building as offices and what appears to be apartments/condos. The staff is well trained and fluent in English. The rooms are nice but on the small size compared to US hotels and the Prince New Takanawa. What I appreciated the most is the ability to control the air conditioning during the winter months. Other hotels in Japan usually turn off the AC so the rooms get very hot. The club is located on the first floor and elite members can check in/out there. The atrium area near the front of the hotel is very impressive and the bar/restaurant is located there. If walking from the train station, the rear entrance is more convenient but the lobby is difficult to find. This is sure to be a popular hotel due to its location and US branding and will most likely be booked most of the time since only about half of the rooms are currently open.

Great start for this hotel in it's second week of opening. Staff is fantastic working through some minor hick ups. Loved our three night stay, Very comfortable room. Could see the Tokyo tower from our room. Great location to take in all of Tokyo. Short walk to shopping
user_name:
JimDykeman
Mercer Island, Washington, United States

review_body: Hotel opened this week and the wife and I had an event in Tokyo and decided to try the new spot out. Very well done redesign of an older building. The staff was tremendous, gracious Japanese hospitality and manners, high tech sleek room design, nice amenities, great executive lounge snacks and cocktail hour, and a free shuttle to Shinagawa station. Good job Marriott. Only complaint is having to pay to use the health club.
